name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: I suspect this product is keeping Mr. Coffee in business. You cannot expect a product at this price to perform well, yet this machine has not let me down. I have made a latte daily in my own house since 1998; usually two or three. A day. I have no shame. I have owned a variety of expensive machines, including pump machines. The volume at which they operate is ridiculous. Next door neighbors should not be able to HEAR you simply making coffee! The Mr.Coffee model shocked me when I gave it a try about five years ago. I could not believe how well it worked and at such a quiet volume. It makes a lovely latte and perfect foam. I am certain the machine was never designed for the use ...er ...abuse I put it through. After my two to three a day habit, the machine gives out in about 6 months. That's okay by me! For the price, it does not bother me to replace it. Also, be mindful that the first five or so drinks in the new machine may have a slight metallic/plastic taste. This is normal with this (and other) machines. It will go away.

This machine is pretty compact so it does not take up too much counter space which is great. I have to admit I didn't have high expectations for an espresso machine at this price point, but my boyfriend and I are totally amazed by the espresso this machine produces. There is a slight learning curve but you figure it out really quick. I use Cafe Bustelo ground espresso and have been using the plastic tamper that comes with this machine. The majority of my shots have tasted pretty good but I always mix my shots with milk. It does produce a crema but the shots are not super syrupy or thick. There were only two times that the espresso turned out bitter but I was playing with different amounts of ground in the filter and tamping the espresso using different pressures. I noticed a lot of reviews complain about the frothing arm for milk. My frothing arm did not look the same as the one in the picture (it was actually located towards the rear of the machine - not the best location) but I figured out the best way to get hot, steaming, foaming milk. When I use this machine I have to move it toward me because of the location of the frothing arm. I removed the plastic sleeve from the wand because the plastic sleeve was causing milk to splatter everywhere which seems to be a common complaint in reviews. By removing the plastic sleeve I no longer have the milk splattering issue and I also have more control over the amount of foam I want. I can heat the milk with minimal foam, or heat the milk longer to get more sweetness and more volume. Another word of advice is to make sure you use enough water in order to get enough steam for your milk. The espresso craft holds 8 oz and numbered for 2 ounce shots. If you want four shots you need to fill water up to the top of the metal band on the craft. If you want two shots (4 oz), you need to fill the water up to the imaginary 3 shot line or higher to get enough steam to heat and froth the milk. General rule of thumb is to add 1.5 to 2 additional ounces of water for frothing the milk. Keep in mind you have to manually change the brew feature to the steam feature once the brewed espresso hits the desired number of espresso shots in the craft. Have your cup of milk ready and submerged in the frothing arm when you change the brew feature over to the steam feature. By adding the additional 1.5 - 2 ounces of water you will have more than enough steam to heat and froth your milk. I usually have enough steam to clean the frothing arm with a clean cup of water after my milk has been heated. I also noticed that milk also tends to cake the wand so have a kitchen towel or bar mop towel handy to wipe it down after each use. If you are unsure or on the fence about purchasing this machine, you should buy it! I have been using this machine every morning and multiple times on weekends to make shots of espresso, one morning I drank 8 shots.....not sure if that is healthy. But that should tell you the quality of espresso this machine produces, no one drinks 8 shots in a day if the espresso tastes bad right??? Yes, you may need to tweak your espresso brewing skills a bit to get the taste you want, but making espresso is considered an art form you perfect to get the taste you want. You cannot expect to press start, walk away, and have the perfect cup. You have to create it the you way you want it and you can with this machine.
reviews.review_header: Good for the Price, Makes Yummy Lattes

reviews.review_text: 49 mm tamper is what I am using, although it is slightly smaller, as I press down in the basket, it fits. I have used this for about a week. I got my money worth and more. I am new to the game. But I wil save up slowly for a top notch one. I have a keureg, and my wife said its more watery. But when the espresso steams, man, its so much richer, 4 shots, and we are wired. Not sure if I need to upgrade, but as I put 5 bucks aside for ever 4 shots, I will eventually upgrade, and then take this to my office. Also...I watch a few videos. And as of right now, I don't know what espresso should taste like, but for me, this model is sooo good. And I will save and be mesmerized when I upgrade. But so much better than my keureg. One thing to mention. I spent 6.75 on a bag of espresso. Still have a lot left. And loving it. Saved so much money.
reviews.review_header: Worth the money. Seriously, for 30 bucks, it extracts!

reviews.review_text: Summary: This espresso maker is simply for the budget minded. I say that because it doesn't make high quality espresso, BUT it makes it good enough to satisfy most. The package comes with everything minus the cup, coffee, and water, though I will say the scoop-tamper design is nice for scooping, but doesn't do well as a tamper. I went out and bought a third party tamper and called it a day. The positives of this unit are the price first and foremost. It's not too high and the device is pretty reliable. In addition it's easy to use and steps are easy to understand. And ultimately, it's a pretty quick machine at what it does. From a cold state, it'll brew 4 shots of espresso in about 5 minutes. The negatives are quite a few... For starters the unit lacks an auto-off feature. So you're best to sit close when using it. The cool-down time is a bit longer than most espresso makers I've used (but for a single user it's not a big deal). In order to froth milk, you're best to brew first (Even if it's only brewing water) or you'll sit there for quite some time waiting on the water in the reservoir to get hot enough. The frother is a bit low, to the point where I had to position my machine on the corner of the counter to be able froth with a normal coffee cup. Other notes: If you buy an after market tamper, don't use too much pressure, the compressed grounds will create a block and pressure will build up and you'll have hot wet grounds spread across your counter-top AND in the water reservoir. The power cord can be a bit short for some, it's just over 12" long. Noted regarding other reviews: I've been using this machine at least 5 days a week for the past 4 months and it's been working just fine for me. I've had zero issues, aside from the day I compressed the grounds a bit too much with the tamper. The machine is not at all great, but for most it will suffice your desires for espresso. If you're an espresso enthusiast or you're particular about your espresso, you should avoid this and purchase a real deal espresso maker.
reviews.review_header: Inexpensive and easy to use budget espresso maker with frother.

reviews.review_text: This machine gets 4 stars, given that it's also only $40. In other words, I didn't have high expectations, so it's a pleasant surprise that it works at all! The short review is that it makes a perfectly acceptable shot for a latte; but the quality isn't high enough to sip it as an espresso. And it does a fine job of steaming milk. The good: • the machine itself is small, lightweight and easy to clean. Plus it was quite inexpensive, as espresso machines go! • It's a pretty simple process to make a latte. I've never owned any other machine like this, so maybe others are just as simple. • the steamer makes nice hot milk with decent foam (I actually use almond milk, so I can't say what it would do with regular milk) • after 10 days of practicing, I've figured out how to get a shot that produces a darn tasty morning latte. The bad: • it takes a LONG time to pull a shot (3 minutes?); and even when I'm only making a single 2-ounce shot, the machine slows down twice, tempting me to believe it's finished even though I have less than 2 oz of espresso in the carafe. But no, if I just wait patiently it does eventually produce a full 2 oz of espresso. • the steamer arm is poorly designed. It only sticks out about an inch from the machine, so you can't move it around much in your cup of milk. Another reviewer had recommended tossing the black casing right from the outset, so I did that too. Never even tried using it. • the shot produced by this machine doesn't have any crema at all • the cleaning instructions were insufficient: the first 3 shots I pulled, after having cleaned the machine, left a bit of white powder on top of the coffee grounds. A few usage tips: • The directions say to start by brewing your shot but then switch to steam in the middle, and then go back to finish pulling your shot after your milk is hot. That seems crazy to me so instead this is what I do: When I first turn the machine on, I start with it in the steam position. I do this after having poured my milk into a mug. While the machine is heating up, I measure out my coffee and attach the little basket to the machine. As soon as steam starts coming out, I began heating and frothing my milk. This takes about 60 seconds, for 6-8 ounces of cold milk. Once my milk is nice and hot I switch the knob to brew. • As I mentioned above, the machine acts like it's finished before the full shot has been produced. Not only does any espresso stop dripping out into the carafe, but the machine belches out a fair amount of steam, which I always thought was a sign it was done. But no, if you just wait patiently the machine starts up again (it takes about 20 seconds, so it's REALLY tempting to give up) and eventually produces a full shot.
reviews.review_header: An acceptable espresso maker, given that it's only 40 bucks

reviews.review_text: This is my second time purchasing this unit as our old one recently died (started taking forever to brew likely due to pressure/steam escaping). Still, before its death it lasted over a year of daily use (sometimes multiple times a day), so our $30 got us roughly 400-500 cups of espresso without a problem. Is it going to brew gourmet "Starbucks" quality espresso? No. The machines that do that are $1,000+ and we don't care to spend that much. When deciding whether to buy this unit again or get one in the $100-200 range, I found those ones have the same issues this one does and don't seem to last nearly as long, so why bother spending more? Bottom line: if you want a decent and quick espresso fix and are ok buying a new unit every year or so, this is an economical choice.

At $30, there is little to lose. I gave it a try and it has been phenomenal. I have a $700 Italian espresso maker and this Mr. Coffee machine - at about 5% of the price - is actually better. And after avoiding spending $4 for each Starbucks latte, the machine paid for itself. I recommend buying this tamper RSVP Terry's Dual Sided Espresso Tamper and this metal frothing pitcher Update International (EP-12) 12 Oz Stainless Steel Frothing Pitcher . You'll get very skilled at making just the right combination of espresso to milk. One note of caution! DO NOT tamp the espresso grounds too tightly! I did that and the machine nearly broke due to the inability for the water to get through the too tightly compressed grounds.
reviews.review_header: Coffee machine - at about 5% of the price - is actually better. And after avoiding spending $4 for each Starbucks ...

reviews.review_text: This is a great machine for the price. I use it every day. I have one piece of advice and one complaint. Advice first: READ THE INSTRUCTIONS BEFORE USE. I didn't read them all the way through and ended up with very hot water all over my hands. Read the entire instruction manual before you brew. You'll thank me later. Now, complaint: The plastic taste is overwhelming. I think it's because it's new but nothing tastes worse than burnt plastic in a cup of good espresso. I've been washing it through with water cycles and even trying to leave the pressure cap off to let it air out, but the taste/smell has only gone away slightly and I've had it for almost a week and a half. I'm going to try to rinse it out with vinegar, I read that can help. It's helped with my Keurig before. Anyway, great product for the price, but I hope they come up with a way to eliminate that taste!
reviews.review_header: Great for the price but tastes like plastic.

reviews.review_text: This small compact machine makes great espresso & cappuccino for $30.00. It reminds me of the Krups machine I had years ago. It's similarities made it easy to use. I was enjoying my 1st cappuccino within minutes. The only negative was the plastic sleeve to froth the cream which can be easily removed to make it work properly. My first attempt was with the plastic sleeve on and the cream splattered every where. I removed the plastic sleeve on my 2nd cup and I had no issues frothing the cream, no splatter at all. For those of you needing help making great cappuccino here are my recommendations. You do not need to use espresso grounds. I actually find that the espresso grinds are too fine and when lightly tamped down using a small spice container the steam has a hard time making it's way through the grinds and steam escapes through very small gaps thus reducing the steam for frothing. I use Militta classic blend coffee lightly tamped down with a small spice container. As far as frothing the cream or milk I highly recommend adding an extra ounce and a half of water so there is enough water to steam your cream or milk. I have lived in Italy for 3 years when I was young and the cappuccino I make using this machine and Militta coffee taste just like I remember.

I'm not really a "coffee person", I usually drink tea (British-style, with milk and sugar) every morning and have coffee every once and a while, but that might change with this product. It's great! The espresso it brews is of course not as good as what you'd find in coffee shop with a $$$$ espresso machine, but for $40 I'll take it. The steaming wand is fabulous although I do recommend removing the black steaming "helper" part of the wand and using it as is. When used in that way, it's very effective. I've been making cappuccinos mainly, and have been quite impressed with both the quality of the espresso and the amount of milk foam I can create. Highly recommended.
reviews.review_header: It's great! The espresso it brews is of course not ...

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: Ignore all the naysayers! This was my first espresso machine I purchased. And I learned a lot! This machine make great coffee! You just need to learn how to make it correctly and use good quality coffee beans. It does not break easy, you just need to take good care of it! Overall, I loved this espresso machine! It also made me want to spend more money and get a better one. I recommend this espresso machine!

This is my third home espresso machine, and I'm totally LOVING this one! Each of my previous machines lasted about 10 years each, so I'm a veteran home latte brewer! My last machine was a Mr. Coffee as well, and I was really fond of the sleek design of it, so I was initially not very thrilled about this boxy look. I considered this model for several months, only seeing it online and thinking it looked like it would take up more space than I wanted. I finally saw one in a store then immediately came home and ordered one from Amazon. It has taken some getting used to, mostly because of differences between it and my last machine, but after several weeks of daily use I now love it! What I love most is that it is REALLY FAST!!! I guess that's the drawback of a machine that lasts 10 years... you miss out on the latest technological improvements! This machine heats up incredibly fast, so 4 shots of coffee is done in less than 5 minutes, and steaming the milk takes about 30 seconds for two batches! ... I'll time it soon and update with exact times. :) The steaming wand is very short and far back, and I thought this might be an issue for me as just a personal preference thing, but it's not, at all. In fact, my previous machine had a very long wand that swept forward toward the front, and I would sometimes burn myself a little bumping into it. There is very little chance of that happening with this model. The boxy shape of the top part of the machine is made that way to be functional so you can put the carafe or portafilter parts there to dry or store while not in use, which I actually finally started doing, so now I appreciate the boxy design. The handles on the portafilter and carafe are longer than I'd like, and it makes me more nervous about knocking the glass carafe on the floor and breaking it. But I'm getting used to them after using it daily for several weeks now, and I suppose it's better for someone with very large hands. My only lingering complaint is that the lid of the glass carafe barely snaps in, so at the slightest tap against the Portafilters spout, it dislodges. This can make pouring the coffee a little messy if you don't realize it and re-seat the lid first. All around this is an amazing home espresso machine, especially for the price, and I would highly recommend it to anyone wishing to make espresso, cappuccino's or lattes at home. It would also make a wonderful gift!
reviews.review_header: Fastest home espresso machine I've ever used! Love it!

reviews.review_text: Awesome espresso machine. It does the job for the price.. Coffee comes out really good but You have to make sure that you use filtered water and fresh ground coffee. Also, don't forget to clean the steamer every time you use it, and make sure that some steam comes out at the end, if not the steamer will get clogged. The part that I didn't like was that you are able to make only 2 cups of espresso at a time (if you are looking for a late or capuccino) main reason is because you need half the water to brew the coffee and half the water to steam the milk. If you are not a pro like me and you are looking for a good espresso machine, this is the one. I''ve had this coffee maker for about a year and it is great. A lot of comments said that it would explode and things like that but, after I've been using it I think theirs exploded because it wasn't closed properly or coffee deposit was not installed correctly. Make sure to read the users manual before using it. Good luck

Fantastic product for the price, if you aren't unlucky. So far, I have used three of these machines, and the quality of espresso they put out is actually very good. However, it seems that quality control might be an issue for these machines (as the price would suggest), and sometimes that might lead to failure; I have had one completely break (broken seal or something), that ended in a cloud of steam and grounds all over a counter. Bad quality control also means that most of the time the machine will be fine for years; I've been using the same one in my house for around three years now I think. Overall, I would definitely recommend this machine if you're on a budget.

I received the espresso machine on time but it did not turn on (it was defective). I was sent a replacement and I received it within 3 days. The replacement works like a champ. I use this machine at least 2 x each day without any problems. The espresso comes out luke-warm but I froth the milk until it's hot so the overall drink (latte) is as hot as one that you would get at Starbucks. Definitely worth the $$$ and it's easy to use.

To start, I don't drink hot drinks...like ever. So this is solely used to make iced drinks. Specifically, I make a protein shake with the espresso in it. I used to have a similar machine by another manufacturer but it quit working and they don't make it anymore. I tried a more expensive one but wasn't happy with it. I bought this one and love it. First, it's super easy to use. I like the fact that it stops automatically after making the amount of water you put in there. Second, it brews a consistent cup, which I like as well. I never use the steam feature so I can't comment on that. I enjoy this everyday!

It's been a year since I purchased this little machine. It was for sale at a cheaper price then, but I still think it's worth the price for which it's being offered now. I've had several espresso/cappuccino machines, most 4xs the price, and this has held up better than most. I write this review because one thing is really important....regular cleaning and maintenance are very important. I have discovered that if I put 1/3 vinegar with 2/3 water in the machine and run it like that weekly, I can keep using this without any issues. I also run that water through the steamer to make sure things run smoothly with that as well. The other thing that I have found works better is to simply remove the plastic cap on the steam wand. It produced bubbles and no froth. Without it I've been able to get a really nice froth.

I am so impressed by our Mr. Coffee espresso machine. The size is great for us. We have limited counter space in our house, and the espresso machine is so compact that it has a permanent spot on the countertop. I was intimidated because I did not know how to use an espresso machine. It is the easiest thing in the world!!!! Easier than brewing coffee--seriously! it is super self-explanatory. The ONLY "negative" thing I found out about it is the milk frother. I don't even hardly use it because it doesn't come very far out from the machine itself, so to actually swirl the milk to get it frothy and heated through consistently is a pain. Believe it or not, I have scraped my knuckles trying to swirl a glass measuring cup underneath it. I just heat my milk in the microwave while the espresso is brewing. It doesn't give it that frothy texture, but who cares....when you have 10-15 minutes in the morning before going to work, you are not going to mess with the milk frother anyway! Overall, I give it a 10/10!
reviews.review_header: GREAT espresso machine, so well worth the money!

reviews.review_text: This is a great machine if you are just starting to experiment with espresso. The instructions were very clear on how to use it and how to clean it. The hardest part of using the machine was figuring out what kind of coffee to buy. After using the machine for a couple of weeks I was having issues with the frother not working properly. After reading the manual I found that I had not been cleaning the steaming arm well enough. This would be my only complaint, it is very difficult to get the steaming arm completely clean each time. You would need to essentially do a deep cleaning of the arm immediately after each use to keep it perfectly clean. This would mean risking a burn (as the steaming arm is incredibly hot at this point) and by the time you would be done cleaning your drink would be cold. Overall, this machine does do the trick. It make good espresso shots for the price of the machine. I would recommend purchasing a tamper for the espresso grounds and a pitcher of you plan on steaming milk.

This is perhaps the fifth Mr. Coffee espresso maker I have bought in my life. They are not expensive and need to be replaced about once every couple of years if you use it every day - but they are way cheaper than buying cappuccino everyday, even if you buy the machine once a year! That is how I look at it. They produce great foam (I automatically remove the plastic cover that comes on the foaming apparatus and do not use it; I just don't need it and I feel like it foams it before it heats it - probably because I steam the milk right in my coffee cup, which is small compared to a foaming carafe). And they produce a decent espresso. It is not thick espresso, but it is adequate. I know espresso is supposed to pour at a certain thickness per second - but I am not that technical or picky. I have bought a model every couple of years since I was a freshman in college in 2001 - I recommend it to someone who likes cappuccino, doesn't want to pay three dollars a day for coffee, and who is not an aficionado. How do I know when it is time to replace my machine? Either the foamer or the espresso making part just quits working, it sputters and takes forever to produce coffee, even after I give it a vinegar rinse. Then it is cheaper to replace than to fix. Tip: using distilled water from the grocery store prolongs the life of this product significantly. Another tip: if your water is hard, like well water from Michigan or Florida, DO NOT PUT IT IN THIS MACHINE. Hard water clogs this thing fast. I think this would be true of any espresso maker, however.
reviews.review_header: Still worth the money, even though you have to replace every couple of years.

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: I have had this over a year ++ now and it is still running strong. I use it mainly to make coffee, using a fine medium roast. Like a breakfast blend. I have also made espresso in it and it is decent enough. Would be good enough for lattes, which I love, except for the foaming wand isn't quite good enough. I add extra water to have longer steam time but I just can't seem to get it right. So I still buy lattes from my local donut shop. But all in all, I am very happy with this machine. I am writing this review now, because I am thinking of getting the next one up for the lattes, you know.
reviews.review_header: Makes great coffee if you use a finer grind. Makes OK acceptable espresso.

reviews.review_text: My wife loves her lattes. (I prefer a good strong cup of dark roast coffee.) Over the years we have gone through numerous espresso machines. We finally tried Mr. Coffee and were stunned to find that it outperformed all other brands. It was also less expensive. After several years her Mr. Coffee machine began to malfunction. The cost had dropped and the design had become more streamlined. Its shorter height suited my height-challenged wife. She loves her lattes and her new latte machine. BTW: She doesn't use the milk steamer. She microwaves her milk and used a battery-powered frothing wand to produce her foam. Cheers!
reviews.review_header: Mr. Coffee makes a great espresso machine. This new model replaces one we have used for years.

reviews.review_text: I love my coffee, especially through the cold, dark, winter days. I've been buying from our work cafe for years now, since they serve white coffee, but I resolved this year to save money and brew my own. After reviewing a few of the lower priced units on here (lets admit, I'm only using this for personal use, so I'm not too picky), I decided on the Mr Coffee ECM160 model, and was pleasantly rewarded. The machine itself appears relatively sturdy and compact, and fits quite nicely on my counter. As other reviewers mentioned, it is necessary in some cases to unwind the cord at the base for additional length. I did not have to, where I have it located. The stainless steel finish is nice, and I like the ridged top - it makes it easy to clean. The carafe and lid are dishwasher safe, as is the basket, although I prefer to hand-wash. But, for convenience sake, this could be noted. I find that the scoop included works well for standard espresso, but when making white coffee (my preferred method), it's best to err on the side of under-filling, as the white coffee seems to expand more when the steam is pressed through. For four shots, it takes roughly 5 minutes to brew, and I plan on taking the recommendations of others and cleaning/descaling with vinegar on a regular basis to prevent any slowness. I do the same for my Keurig, it's just part of basic maintenance. The steaming attachment is kinda cheesy with the plastic case, so I just take that off (I find it's easier for me to clean without it). I use it to heat/foam my milk, and as I mentioned in the title, it foams like a beast! I use rice milk, and have had NO problems whatsoever in building an absurd amount of foam. It takes a few minutes and some angling, but it's not a pain by any means, and as a foam lover, totally worth it. For $40, I love this machine. The plastic bits aren't as fancy as a professional espresso, but I'm in this for utility, not looks. We make 2-3 espressos daily, and on Sundays I pre-brew a quart jar of white coffee so I can add it to my breakfast protein shake with ease. It gives me a great extra kick to the day, and it's great knowing that a week's worth of coffee has already paid for itself.
reviews.review_header: Works great, and foams like a beast!

reviews.review_text: Great bargain. I'm very happy! This is a powerful espresso maker. I've always had basic Krups espresso makers with the nob that let you steam while you were brewing coffee.They are OK. I don't own a coffee tamper because the Krups machine wasn't powerful enough to push through packed coffee. If you get this machine get a coffee tamper and use it. When I make café lattes for my husband and I -- I fill the carafe with cold water just a little above the silver band. That way I have enough water for the espresso and milk steaming. I'll let the espresso brew a little so there is maybe 1/2 inch or so of espresso in the carafe then I switch it to steam and take the milk to about 137 degrees, then I switch back to the brew side and finish. We each have a regular size mug of café latte. The frother works very well but we don't like a lot of foam so I won't use it much. The Mr. Coffee brew basket holes are just a titch bigger than the holes in my Krups brew basket. (probably like a micron or so, I'm not an engineer.) I wondered if grounds would come through but there is no problem. I use the first espresso grind on the commercial coffee grinder and all is well. You can spend a lot of money on exotic pump machines and there is nothing wrong with that. But this Mr. Coffee is great and serves the purpose. Once you taste a good café latte or cappuccino you are hooked : )

This is a really great little espresso machine. After a little practice, I'm making latte's to rival the coffee shop! As others have pointed out, the first thing to do is get rid of that plastic cover over the steamer. It only makes a mess, and perhaps keeps their lawyers happy. If you just position the nozzle barely under the surface of the milk, you can make a beautiful foam. The reason for 4 stars rather than 5... the cap and the knob are both too smooth and do not allow for a good grip. You really need to be careful not to accidentally cross thread the cap when sealing the tank. While they're pretty, they're not very practical. Earlier models had a much better surface on both for better control. Overall, a very good espresso machine, especially for the price.

What I like most of MR COFFEE is that the coffee comes out more expreso not that much watery, what I liked the least is the milk steamer it hard to clean it after use its like a race against time you let the steam sit there 2 minutes while you get a towel or something to clean and the milk its already stuck on the metal stick its crazy aside from that everything is good awesome the coffee is delicious well depending on the coffee you buy I’m Cuban so I buy Cuban coffee but I’m sure any coffee is good.
reviews.review_header: Be EXTRA careful with the lid were pour water, when hot the vapor burns like hell first hand experience.

reviews.review_text: Love this espresso machine for the PRICE and I actually got it delivered a whole day earlier than expected which was super cool. My only complaint, and why i'm doing four stars is that it actually burns the ground espresso. It's a very strong, distinguished smell in my house and in my beverages. I use Cafe Bustelo and have never had an issue with this brand having a burnt taste to it (in general) and when I used it for other espresso machines. I'll likely venture out and try other brands of ground espresso too at this point. Low key hoping that over time this machine chills out with the over the top temps so I can have a non-burnt cup of espresso & cream.
reviews.review_header: Love this espresso machine for the PRICE and I actually ...

reviews.review_text: We have had this machine for a year and a half. It is just starting to have that tired feel to it, and I'm about to get another one. My husband drinks a double shot every morning, and then the machine rests until next morning. We have noticed, as other reviews have said, that if you are making two espressos in a row, the second one isn't as good. I've never tried the steamed milk part, but I get plenty of crema on the espresso. You have to figure out the best grind and how hard to tamp the grinds. Making espresso is not an exact science, and that is the fun of it! I use a spice bottle for tamping, which works perfectly. I cannot see spending more money for a machine when this one meets our needs so well. UPDATE - Here is how you make the best espresso with this newer model of the ECM160 espresso machine. First, have your beans ground to Turkish grind, the finest grind on commercial grinders. Or just grind your own beans super fine. For one shot, loosely fill the basket about 3/4 full. Tamp very gently to about 1/2 full. Do all your prep, turn machine on. The espresso will come out fairly steadily, and you'll think its done. Wait. Some crema will bubble out. Wait some more. Finally a solid stream of crema emerges. Leave the machine on for awhile until you are sure all moisture is out of the machine. Otherwise, it ends up in your next expresso, making the coffee watery. It took me awhile to figure all this out, but the espresso is excellent with about 1/2 of it crema. If this sounds complicated, it really isn't. I just wanted to be very specific in my explanation.
reviews.review_header: update to great for single espresso

reviews.review_text: For a cheap espresso machine , it just works. I have been using this daily for about a month. Very tasty espresso. Makes the house smell amazing when it's brewing. Glad I purchased this item.
reviews.review_header: Makes the house smell amazing when it's brewing

reviews.review_text: I hesitated to order this when I saw the reviews, but now it's clear that most low ratings were from purchasers who expected too much from a bargain-priced machine or clearly did not read the instruction manual before operating it. I actually think it is quite user friendly and easy to operate after spending a little time reading the instructions. The handle did feel tight at first, as mentioned it might in the manual, but has gradually loosened up. It's important to clean the steamer after each use, which is easy enough. I just let the pressure release through the steamer after unplugging the machine and then wipe it with a mild cleaning detergent. Anyway, I love this thing! Highly recommend for first time espresso machine buyers or cheap folk like me.
reviews.review_header: I actually think it is quite user friendly and easy to operate after spending a little time reading the ...

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: Overall, this little machine makes as good a cappuccino as MUCH more expensive home machines. (of course, even the best machines won't make a good cup of espresso if you don't start with GOOD coffee, properly ground)... I definitely recommend it. HOWEVER: The steaming wand on my machine clogged after a few months of use... there aren't any instructions or anything about cleaning the steaming wand... let me make a few suggestions that I have mostly figured out by myself, with little or no help from Mr. Coffee: The cover for the wand is unnecessary and bothersome. Just remove it and don't bother. The tip of the wand unscrews and can be cleaned separately. Do that often. You may have to use a pair of pliers to "break it loose" and to tighten it sufficiently when you put it back on-- there is supposedly a built-in "wrench" on the handle of the measuring scoop, but it may or may not actually be effective. It's probably necessary to clean the steaming wand tip often (definitely every use, force some steam out of the wand when you're done to 'blow it clear'... Mr. Coffee recommends that you delime the machine every 40-80 brews, same as with a regular coffeemaker (use vinegar, then flush with clear water a few times)... clean the steaming wand tip at least this often-- probably much more often. You probably want to put a cup or something under the steaming wand while you are waiting for it to get up to temp/pressure... water will drip, the steam will be "wet," etc. while you're waiting... Overall, a decent machine and certainly a good machine for the money.
reviews.review_header: Works great... needs better maintenance instructions

reviews.review_text: I was married to my second wife for almost twenty years. I've had my car for about twenty one years now. But my longest relationship in this life was with my Cappucino Machine - over twenty five years. So you can appreciate that I was upset when my Riviera finally broke for good. Actually that's not completely true. I could possibly have gotten it fixed yet again. But the machine is out of production. Some parts are still available but not all. One of the parts no longer available is one of the seals. The result of that missing seal has been that for about a year now when I try to make my daily cappucino it would spray boiling water in my face. Not a good feature. I would drape a paper towel over it so as to intercept the spray. It leaked elsewhere too. It still looked cool of course. Solid crome over solid brass with a pressure dial and an eagle on top. The last time I saw one on sale they were well over a thousand dollars. But in fact it was the maintenance that cost a lot not just the initial purchase price. I had sent it into the shop every two years for new seals. Each trip was about $150. So a week or so ago when it wouldn't turn on - probably a switch again - I called it quits. I resolved to get a new machine. I expected to spend about $800 (the cost of a new Pavoni). To my delight it looked as though I could get a "starter" automatic machine for only about $400. But as it happens my twenty year old car needed a new transmission and that cost $4,000. So I decided to get some sort of interim machine for now until my finances recovered. I knew as soon as I openned the box that I wouldn't send it back. That was because I immediately dropped the glass carafe on the kitchen floor, shattering it into a million shards. The other problem was that the directions require you to measure the water in that carafe. So I had to improvise my brewing procedure. Fortunately this is a truly simple machine. I have devised a procedure that makes a wonderful cappucino. I am no longer in the market for a more expensive machine. Like the song says "Ich habe genug". Considering what I have been accustomed to spending on my morning coffee, this machine is really cheap. I could just throw it away every year and buy a new one and still come out ahead. It is almost a disposable cappucino maker. My former machine, the Riviera, was all metal. This machine is all plastic. You could sneak it through a metal detector. It is very lightly built. But I think nevertheless that it will last. My sold brass Riviera had a big boiler that took a while to come up to temperature. I would turn it on first thing in the morning and leave it on all day. That meant that the rubber seals inside cooked all day. That's why I had to have them replaced nearly every year. This little machine has a little boiler that heats up fast. I fill it with water and turn it on. Then I quickly find a cup, get out the milk, grind the beans and tamp. These actions take about five minutes at which time the coffee starts coming out. When there's enough (but not too much) I switch it to steam and froth the milk. Then - and this is the important point - I turn it off. It takes me about six minutes to make a cappucino. The Mr. Coffee is only on for those six minutes. It makes a great cup of Joe. It has only one flaw. Chicks are not impressed with it the way they always were with my gleaming chrome Riviera.

Great little basic espresso machine. I love it for iced coffees in the summer, and adding an extra boost to my regular coffees too. Everything about this machine is wonderful, but three things to know before you buy it: 1) The scoop you get free with this machine has a tamper built in... The scoop is very small and the bottom doesn't tamp down well. I spill more grounds when I try to use it. I use a 2TBSP flat bottom measuring cup which is great for scooping and packing, but the scoop works, just buy a tamper. 2) Steam escapes from ALL around this unit. Be sure not to have anything that shouldn't be moist near of above the machine while brewing or steaming. 3) The glass carafe is very delicate. It cracks easily with sudden temperature changes, and shatters if it drops a few inches. It really is a great value, despite these few issues.

Have had this machine for 18 months now, and both my husband and I love the results. Fortunately I'm a reader of directions; you really need to study them carefully before you brew your first pot. It took half a dozen rounds of delicious experimentation to tweak the original instructions. Now I have the process down to a science, with detailed instructions posted next to the machine. In all these months, after many expensive comparisons, we have yet to taste a commercial cappuccino that tastes as good as ours. I did order a steaming pitcher with the machine but found it much too small for our milk use. I have ended up using it just for depressurizing the machine, for which it's perfect. For my household, the best steaming pitcher is an ordinary one-pint glass measuring cup. And the best tamper turned out to be a flat-bottomed scoop from a can of protein-powder I had sitting around. As other reviewers have pointed out, the quality of the coffee beans is critical. We buy the best organic espresso beans we can afford (Trader Joe's has a great blend) and grind them fresh each morning for that morning's two batches. We also use distilled water for the most flavorful coffee of any kind. I had read that caffeine reacts with the chlorine in tap water; it certainly makes a noticeable difference in taste. Tip for a good foam: cold milk in a cold pitcher. At the start of preparations, I pour 1 1/3 cups cold almond milk in my 1-pint glass measuring cup and stick it in coldest spot of the refrigerator. The colder the pitcher, the thicker the foam. This morning, I had placed the pitcher right underneath the freezer motor and the milk had ice crystals on top. For the first time, the froth came out so dense and hard that it looked and behaved like whipped cream! So far, this sounds like a five-star machine. Unfortunately, early on, it developed a problem that cost it one star. The screw at the end of the steam wand lost its thread and has to be carefully forced into place. Last weekend, it came loose at the end of the second round and the machine spewed steam all over the place. I had already steamed the milk to near-perfection, so nothing was lost. The depressurizing process was messy and noisy, and the screw had to be forced out the plastic shield with a sharp metal object. But this weekend I managed to get the screw back in place both mornings, and our cappuccino was better than ever. Not to gamble with our future weekend treats, I'm now ordering a spare machine, just in case. Fortunately the price is right!
reviews.review_header: Makes the best cuppa cappuccino in this town!

reviews.review_text: If you are an espresso fanatic or picky at all, then this might not be for you, but honestly I wouldn't know because I'm not. If you want something that will work well enough for your caramel macchiatos, then this will do the trick. I get a few grinds in my espresso, and the first time it may not work well if you pat the grinds down like it tells you too, but like I said, it does the trick.
reviews.review_header: Good for the price and a beginner

reviews.review_text: To the engineer that posted detailed instructions on how you should use this machine. Your a genius! I have followed your advice from day one and not had one problem with this unit. This is a great little machine for not a lot of $$$$. I have saved a lot of $$$ making my own latte's. Sorry Starbucks I love you but....... I can make my own now :) I Here are the instructions I follow. If you follow the directions included with the machine to a tee your going to get disappointing water logged coffee. But if you have a basic understanding of pressure and steam you'll need to modify your operation of this little machine. What I do is fill the coffee filter holder to max shot coffee level line and use a coffee tamper to compress the espresso but don't pack it to tight just a simple tamp is all you need because your going to want to stop the excess water rush when the thick black coffee and cream stops pouring. I use only purified water unless you want your machine to last only 1 year from mineral deposits, and I fill glass carafe to reach the bottom of the metal band to ensure more than enough water and steam to do the job. With everything in place i.e. power off, coffee filter holder fully locked in, steam cap screwed down tight, frothing arm extended and ready with cup and milk standing by... I then turn the machine to knob to steam first to allow the machine to build pressure and steam without prematurely diluting the coffee filter holder, as soon as the frothing arm starts to sputter and produce steam with a hint of water I quickly switch the control knob to brew coffee position which brings in only hot steam and water trickling out only dark thick coffee and this is where you have to be rehearsed to act fast and operate the machine effectively! With the thick black coffee trickling, get your milk cup ready sitting under the frothing arm ready to be lifted up as soon as you see the brewing coffee go from slow tricking thick dark coffee to cream foam. It should have reached the first like on the coffee pot at this point. Now GET READY to turn the control knob back to steam the INSTANT you see that the slow dark cream foam trickling out slowly starts to speed up. The moment before you see the slow dark cream foam trickling out start to speed up to water, I Instantly raise my milk cup submersing the frothing arm under the milk to avoid splatter while simultaneously switching the control knob to steam, which instantly stops the brewing process to the coffee filter holder preventing water dilution. Turn the knob slowly once on the steam side and work your way up to full steam if you switch too quickly you will get a milk volcano lol. Once your milk is frothed to your liking. switch the control knob to off. That's it, perfect Espresso. Be sure to once you've made your coffee clear the rest of the steam from the unit once your done and clean the froth arm. I wipe the outside of the plastic cover then take it off and wipe down the metal portion to clean the steamed on milk off. Then I replace the plastic cover and turn the steam back on to clear out all the rest of the water and steam from the unit. This will clean the frothing arm but also release all the pressure that has built up in the machine. Once all the steam is released take the lid off the top of the water compartment and let the machine cool. Doing this when not in use will help prevent premature compression damage to the sealing gaskets, I only slightly keep both the steam cap and the filter holder screwed in place. If you lock them down to full tight position when not in use, I find that it will prematurely compress the sealing gaskets and they will start to leak early making brewing ineffective. Having said all of this, as a protective disclaimer I must say that this is what “I DO” and I'm not recommending any of these operating actions to anyone. "You should use the instruction book to a tee for OK strong watery coffee if that's what your after." Thanks E. Gonzales for your review. My coffee machine works like a charm and I have beautiful crema on my espresso every time. I did tweak his original instructions for user use and understanding as well as maintenance. ENJOY!! Your now a barista!
reviews.review_header: Awesome Espresso machine for very little $$$$$

reviews.review_text: I received my unit a while ago and, after getting used to fiddling with all the pieces and waiting for the "explosion" described in other posts, I am completely satisfied and somewhat disappointed (no explosion). I can see where other reviewers might be mislead into thinking the cord is very short but all you have to do is turn the machine over and actually look at the place where the cord is stashed to see there is a pretty lengthy cord wound around a very clever stem in a hidden compartment. As for the quality: I had been using a Hamilton Beach machine that is very different in operation so reviewing the instructions fully really was a must. Based on other comments, clearly most people don't read or follow the instructions because everything you need to know is there in black and white. The brew function is very quick and only takes about 15-20 seconds to heat the water in the reservoir and start running hot water through the grounds. The whole process is very quick and you can fill the carafe with 4oz in less than a half minute. My other machine had a reservoir that you could leave full but this machine discourages that. I use a Brita filter for all my water so the chances of mineral buildup are reduced a little. Seeing how hot the reservoir gets, I would not recommend leaving water in the reservoir. The carafe has a slotted lid so the spout from the filter fits neatly into the top of the carafe so there is no spilling or splash. The steamer arm is fixed with no allowed movement but it is spaced high enough and far enough out from the main body that using a pitcher or coffee cup to froth milk is very easy. The booklet goes into very specific detail about how to clean the froth arm but the pressure of the steam basically blasts the nozzle clean if you allow the unused water in the reservoir to exit through the froth arm when you are done making your foam. A barrista friend of mine steams a clean towel then uses that to clean the foam nozzle on her own machine. I find that works well between proper cleanings. One note is that Soy milk froths well but leaves a film from all the dissolved solids. If you use Soy milk, plan on cleaning the nozzle frequently as the particles get to be like glue if they are not wiped off shortly after being warmed. As for which grounds to use, I have tried both standard grind and espresso grind coffees and you definitely need to find a finer ground of coffee for use in this (and any) espresso machine. I have a lot of Starbucks standard grind coffee to use up so I simply sent it through my Cuisinart for a few minutes to get it broken up finer. It seems to work equally as well but there is a noticeable difference in brewing strength. Overall, I am very pleased.
reviews.review_header: A delicious expresso in less than 20 seconds!

reviews.review_text: Makes ok cafesito, "loved the steamer while it worked" that was the whole reason for the purchase, it did not last long, the steamer stopped working in three months, the coffee maker side works ok but not the steamer side, mind you I empty it after every use not to keep it with preassure inside. I would not buy this again, my ten bucks cook top coffee maker do just as good if not better cafe cubano and without the steamer for the milk it is way over price. Revised 01/10/14 from above post. After a tip from TwiligtStar my steamer/foamer is back to working. Apparently my way of cleaning the wand was not good enough. I was letting some steam out after I was done foaming as he suggests and was also using a cup of water with Dawn detergent to foam up and clean it after every use, it's not enough it still got clogged. I unscrewed the tip and cleaned both the wand and tip, a thin wire for the wang and a needle on the tip, runned a full load of steam and I'm back in bussiness. What can I say, foammmmmyyyy cafe con leche and my morning cigar just gloooorrriiioooouuuussss. I would now recomend this unit with the mindset that you have to pay extra attention to the cleaning and care of the wand.

At first, I thought about giving this product a lower rating, but I changed my mind, and here's why: First, and most important to me, this machine makes good espresso. Furthermore, it makes it fairly quickly and quietly. Couldn't be happier with that result! Second, and here's the negative, I need to address the auto-frothing wand. I don't know if anyone else has experienced this or not, but the auto-frothing wand that came with my machine was a piece of plastic crap. I had to experiment several times, but each time I used it, I was disappointed. The results were always the same, huge bubbles in the froth on top and hot, thin milk on the bottom, not exactly the foamy, creamy experience everyone wants! I watched some videos on how to froth milk, but no matter what I tried, it was always the same. Then I had a friend who works as a barista at a local coffee shop try it, but she also could not get anything but huge bubbles and hot, thin milk. We decided that the machine produced too much air pressure. I was considering returning the machine, but I decided to try to take the plastic auto-frothing wand off and try to do it manually. My expectations were low, because I thought the fault was with the inner workings of the machine. I'm glad I tried the manual way though, because it actually worked! Using the video techniques I found for manual frothing, I was able to get much closer to making the smaller bubbles for the foam and a creamy consistency throughout the milk. Obviously, it wasn't perfect because I'm still a noob, but I'd imagine someone who really knows what they're doing would easily pull it off. Having said that, I believe the issue was that the auto-frothing wand actually allows way too much air into the milk in the initial frothing stage. However, going manually, I was allowed to control exactly how much air was being added and how quickly it was being added. So, my advice, ditch that little plastic piece of garbage and go manual! It may take a little more practice, but I believe it'll pay off. Third, as pretty much all the other reviews have said, the scoop really does not work as an effective tamper. However, I would not pay the $10-$18 necessary to buy an espresso tamper. For one thing, it's a uni-tasker, which is almost always a big no-no and a good indication that you're wasting money. For another thing, if you have tools at home, you could easily make one yourself. Or, you can do what I did and just use the top of a medicine bottle that you have lying around. A lot of them have the 49mm diameter you need or close to it. Finally, in summary, you can't beat the price on this machine, and it does it's job well. I've had it for about a week now, and it's already been through a quite a few uses. It's worked great! Just make sure that you're cleaning it properly, releasing the pressure after every use, and making sure that no water is left in the machine between uses (that should solve the "exploding" problems that other customers have experienced). The only reason that I didn't give it 5 stars were for the uselessness of the auto-frothing wand and the scoop. Other than that, it's a fantastic buy!

Have purchased two of these in the past two years, liked it so much I bought one for work. They coffee maker is the most resonable priced unit out there and have had absolutly no issues with either machine. If you like expresso and you're on a budget you can't go wrong buying one of these. Once I took this on a vacation with us and ended up breaking the pot, was able to find a replacement on Amazon so parts are even available.

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: Espresso at home for Cafe Americano is great. And cost much less than always grinding your own beans every morning. Now I use the block pregroung esspresso Cafe Bustelo from Wal mart at $2.88 for 10oz and a better cup of coffee than any grind your own. Don t need the milk steamer.
reviews.review_header: Espresso at home for Cafe Americano is great. And cost much less than always grinding your ...

reviews.review_text: My wife drinks a can of Monster drink every morning. Well, at least she used to. She is a family practice doctor and gets pretty worn out. The Monster drinks helped her get started in the mornings. I bought this device to see if I could cure her Monster Drink Addiction. It has worked so far. Each morning I now make her an Espresso, a Latte, or a cappuccino. This device makes either of them pretty simple to produce in about 15 minutes counting preparation and clean up time afterwards. After a couple hours of watching youtube tutorials online I not only understood what the differences between the three drinks are, but how to actually make them. If you need some help to understand how to use your new espresso machine, watch this tutorial. It's pretty darn good -- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DxA5EB-gHcE Youtube is also how I learned how to use the steam wand. A little tricky but once you know how, it's not all that difficult. If you want to learn, check out this video. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qsHacrTIXh4 The guy isn't using a Mr. Coffee espresso machine, but the principles are the same. It sure helped me a whole lot. My wife claims that the drinks I create for her now make her even more alert than after previously drinking her Monster drink, and she also actually likes the coffee taste even more than the Monster drinks. Do not order the Terry's Tamper for Espresso device that is listed along with the 12 ounce pitcher as a package deal. You will end up returning it and then ordering another one just as I did a few minutes ago after receiving it in the mail yesterday. This Tamper will not work with your machines filter unless you are brewing 4 cups. With a two cup amount, the Terry's Tamper will simply not work. You won't even be able to touch the coffee grounds with this device because it has too large a diameter. I considered dropping one of my 5 stars for that reason, but that wouldn't be fair. It has nothing to do with how well the espresso machine works, but it is certainly very irritating. I don't know how long this device will last, but at $29, my gosh, it really isn't that much of a pain to buy a replacement. I knew nothing about coffee, Espresso, Lattes, or Cappuccinos before buying this device. I had no idea what made them different. I did not like coffee, and had never made regular coffee or either of these three other variations before. I still don't like coffee, but my wife does, and that is why I bought the machine. Two months ago I bought a large supply of monster drinks when they were on sale. I now have 200+ cans of Monster in my basement. I expect that my wife will want an occasional can of Monster, so I'm ready for at least 200 cravings that she might have. I hope that after the cans are gone, I will never have to buy another one of them again. Going to the store, buying and grinding the coffee beans right there in the store, and then making the Espresso at home on this very cool device, is a lot easier than hauling home cans of Monster, and probably a whole lot healthier. We like it a lot.
reviews.review_header: I actually may have found a cure for my Wife's Monster Drink addiction.

reviews.review_text: Years later, still makes coffee. Take care of it and it won't disappoint. Remember, defects ha, your experience may vary, but it has a warranty! Be careful filling the coffee, the machine can be picky about grain size and coffee level. Worst case, you get bitter coffee. Read the manual, it should all go smooth!

My latte habit was out of control... and I'm vegan so I need to go to a high end place like Starbucks so I can get a SOY caramel latte. When I figured out that I could have had my kitchen counters re-done for what I spend at Starbucks in 6 months (!), I knew I had to learn to make my own lattes. I bought this little sweetheart and gave it to the DH for the kids to give me for xmas. I read all the reviews and the directions, plus looked up Starbucks syrup-pump volumes online. So I knew there would be no tamper per se (the scoop is the tamper) or pitcher (I just use a ceramic syrup pitcher). And I knew how much syrup I wanted (see recipe below). First time out, the brew was bitter and the milk was cold. The directions say that too fine a grind makes a bitter brew (oops), but I knew from the reviews (thanks, reviewers!)that your tamp can compensate for that. So since my grind is too fine, I tamped very lightly the second time - that fixed that problem. Also my milk wasn't steamed enough because I hadn't put enough extra water in the reservoir for steaming - the second time I followed the instruction manual amounts for cappuccino, which gave me enough extra water with which to steam my milk. Problems solved! Latte was perfect that second time around. My recipe for grande soy caramel latte: Espresso for 2 cups, water for 2 cups cappuccino (manual says 5.5 oz but I know that 6 oz = 3/4 cup so I just throw in 3/4 cup because that's easier...), brew, plus 1/8 cup of syrup (grande = 4 pumps ... at .35 oz per pump, per the SB website, 4 pumps= about 1.5 oz = which is more than 1/8 cup, but I want a little less sugar), plus 4ish oz vanilla soy milk (or milk of choice of course)- steamed. Put the syrup in your mug first, then the brewed espresso, then pour the steamed soy milk while using a spoon to hold back the foam, then use the spoon to plop the foam on the top. YUM! :) Enjoy!
reviews.review_header: YAY! First timer here - making perfect lattes within minutes!

reviews.review_text: I love this thing! Followed my gut and a lot of the reviewers advice and got it. It's great. Don't get it if you make more than 2 cups of coffee at a time, it will be too small. Pros: You can froth the milk for capuccinos in a flash, you just need a bit of practice. It's small, so it doesn't take up all your counter. Easy to operate and clean Just the right amount of coffee for two, no leftovers, no waste. Good price Cons: Not so easy to regulate the amount of coffee vs water, you just have to eyeball it. This means you have to shut it once you get enough coffee or it will continue to brew until it runs out of water. So either shut it off on time or add the exact amount of water you want. Frothing pipe doesn't move The lid can be hard to open and close (otherwise the steam like out of it) Doesn't come with a pitcher
We have been using a Mr.Coffee espresso machine for years. The more expensive espresso machines don't work as well.
reviews.review_header: We have been using a Mr. Coffee espresso machine ...

reviews.review_text: Just made my first beverage!! I always loved the Starbucks white mocha however looking at the cost of all my coffee as I knew there had to be a way to do this at home. After doing research I looked for my own espresso machine/steamer. All of them were over $100 and I found this one for $40. Since it was so much cheaper I read a lot of the reviews before purchasing. I just made my first drink and it tastes so yummy! Make sure you read the directions or watch an online tutorial to use the machine otherwise you will be lost and may end of breaking the machine. Also be sur to clean everything first including just running water through the machine without any coffee (the instructions explain this too). I watched a tutorial on YouTube on how to make the drink and use the machine so that was really helpful. The only thing I would recommend based on reading the reviews as well is to buy at least a 12 ounce frothing pitcher. I bought a 10 ounce and it seems a bit small. Also some reviews say to buy a tamper however you would be fine just using the spoon that this machine comes with. Ive never been a barista or anything so this machine is perfect for me. For my flavorings I got Ghiradelli sauces for $20 for a pack of 3 on amazon (chocolate, white chocolate, and carmel). I would suggest this come with a frothing pitcher, thats my only negative. I did my research so I knew what to expect but if I didnt know that I would have been a bit frusterated. All in all, so far so good!! Now, back to my mocha :)
reviews.review_header: I always loved the Starbucks white mocha however looking at the cost ...

reviews.review_text: People who say their expresso coffee makers blew up on them, must be idiots. It boils the water to produce steam and once the steam is gone, so is the water. The steam either comes out to steam coffer or to steam milk. There is no way, this could blow up, even if it was plugged up, there wouldn't be enough pressure to blow it up, no water left, no pressure. THIS IS A GOOD EXPRESSO COFFEE MAKER and should cost allot more. Enjoy, And don't worry about it blowing up, can't be done. UPDATE: You don't want to OVERPACK your coffee to hard, it will create to much back pressure and steam will come out everywhere. You do want to seat and seal the coffee pot handle, all the way to the right, not just the middle or it will build up pressure and leak. Turn it pass center and a little to the right, for a good seal. Don't forget to turn it off and you might release the pressure, by turning it to 'steam' for a 'few seconds' and then off.
reviews.review_header: For less than $40, this is a great expresso coffee maker!

reviews.review_text: For $40 this is a good espresso machine. Very simple, easy to clean, measured amounts. It lasted us over 2 years with a good 1-4 uses per day. The only reason we threw it away is because the side knob handle broke off. Otherwise it was still functioning. The side knob pole that goes from the knob to the machine is made of plastic and ripped off the hinge. So one thing to be careful on is to always hold the knob at the base and turn it slowly to avoid damage. The day it broke I was in a rush and grabbed it at the tip and twisted the internal plastic pole. I suspect over time more crap got into the metal and made it harder to turn. But I will admit I wasnt very good about cleaning it, too lazy. When the coffee tasted like crap is when I ran the vinegar and cleaning instructions... bad espresso machine owner, BAD! But I feel the "Mr. Coffee ECMP50 Espresso/Cappuccino Maker, Black" is a superior product and 100% worth the $80 they are asking. There is a significant difference. It foams, unlike this model, and the taste is better. (Angy's lazy espresso cleaner husband)
reviews.review_header: Good espresso machine the Mr. Coffee ECMP50 is superior

reviews.review_text: People are dumb here. Honestly all these bad reviews are either from ppl who don't know how to read a manual are are getting psid fore writing bad reviews from other competitors. This machine does exactly what it says it will do. Period. Whoever says the milk doesn't get hot is wrong. It steams very well. You actuslly need to use cold milk to froth it, that's the only way to get good bubbles, just ask any barista. Also, you need 2 percent milk, heavy milk won't froth well, with any machine. I gave it 4 stars because it doesnt come with a tamper. You need to buy a metsl tamper and li girly tamp your coffee. Crema comes out when you tamp good. The frother is short, but I got used to it after a week. This machine is good. I use it all the time with GOOD coffee and FILTERED water. Like starbucks or DD. Not chesp bustelo. Its worth the price, and love it.
reviews.review_header: People are dumb here. Honestly all these bad reviews are either ...

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: The greatest thing about this machine is indeed the price. You can buy a new one every year and still pay less over ten years than you would for some of the expensive machines out there. And there is nothing to say that the expensive ones will even last that long. It does make a good, strong cup of coffee, and that is its major strength. It is also easy to operate and keep clean. The frother is quite effective. Overall, I like the simplicity of the design. There are lots of extra, unnecessary parts to fuss with. This is the third one of this model that I've had. There are, however, several negatives. First, this is not a real espresso machine. It uses steam, not pressure, and it will not give you any real crema. The selector knob can be a bit difficult to grasp if it's dry and/or you have dry hands. The lid to the carafe becomes increasingly loose as the tabs designed to hold it in place gradually give way. I had to glue rubber surface savers onto it to keep the lid from falling off. The carafe lip is poorly designed and will dribble if you aren't careful. The plastic "keeper" for the coffee basket won't last. I prefer to put a little duck tape around the inside basket and have it stick in the holder on its own. Finally, the selector knob on my first machine broke after about eleven months of use, and my replacement machine has just died due to the same problem. So, it's lasted a bit over a year and a half, and that is probably not too bad, but I'm thinking of moving up to something different to see if I can still get a reasonably inexpensive machine that will make good coffee. Bottom Line: Good coffee at a low price.
reviews.review_header: Great Price But Not A Real Espresso Machine and Not So Durable

reviews.review_text: I gave it 4 stars because for such a simple small machine it does exactly what I need it to without paying a high price. I was hesitant to try it but it got pretty good reviews and was the cheapest machine I wanted to buy. It's not fancy like the ones I wanted but the espresso tastes fine. If you enjoy espresso and don't want to blow your budget on an expensive machine get this one. If you are making a single "2" serving I would add extra water so you have enough steam to froth milk then steam wand clean in water after wards. It seems if you vent all the steam there is really only one drop or two of moisture left in reservoir which will quickly dry if you leave the tank lid off for a minute or so. update 1/12/2014 the machine still works fine but I am upgrading to a De'Longhi BAR32 Retro 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker. I really prefer the espresso with thick crema. This Mr. Coffee is a steam driven espresso machine, it makes espresso a bit on the sour side for me. But if you aren't that picky this machine will do nicely for you.
reviews.review_header: Competitive pricing for a good product

reviews.review_text: **edit 3/17/16 After a little over a year, the cap crack and shoots steams out of the top. No way to fix without buying a new cap.. I bumped it down to 3 star due to the length of life this machine had for me.. Other than that it was great! And I loved my coffee in the morning! Now I'm cranky and need to purchase a new one.. I'm not sure if I'll give Mr. Coffee another go, but we will see. ---------- BYE BYE STARBUCKS ESPRESSO!! HELLO MR COFFEE ESPRESSO MAKER!!! It took me awhile to learn how to make a proper espresso but once i figured it out it was awesome!. Now I only go to Starbucks to buy bags of coffee and im saving lots of moolah doing it!! I just need to start growing and roasting my own coffee =)

Works great, my only complaint is that the paint on the knob to turn it from making espresso to making the steam arm work has faded very quickly. We've only had the machine for less than two months and the paint is completely gone so we're pretty much going on guessing/muscle memory right now when we use the machine but that's not very convenient for our guests or house sitter. Otherwise, functionality of the machine is great for a little inexpensive machine to get some good espresso on the daily

Purchased this item after reading over 60 reviews, both good and bad. One of the reviewer's complaint was the plastic smell and taste, yes there is a strong odor when opening and unpacking. I ran water through the system several times which helped. My first try I used the plastic sleeve on the steamer that gave a plastic smell and taste. I Remember reading a review that mentioned that they removed the plastic sleeve to keep the milk from splattering everywhere. When removing the sleeve the plastic taste was gone and the milk doesn't splatter! The instructions were clear and easy to understand. It does mention that it will take time to master the steaming of the milk. I would have given this item 5 stars, but I agree with one reviewer that the plastic smell is strong.

I was surprised that this cheap little machine had higher ratings than so many more expensive models, so it seemed like a no-brainer. It arrived last week and so far, I'm very impressed. It makes good espresso and I'm especially impressed by how well it froths the milk. Steaming milk tends to be a noisy process, but this machine is the quietest I've used. It's also fast- I've typically started the milk in the microwave to speed up the process, but with this machine, it goes from fridge to frothy in only a couple minutes. The foam is also robust enough that the caramel sits on top before it settles down, which is more difficult to accomplish with the skim milk I use. The only drawback I've found is that the espresso is a little slow to start brewing, but that could be a result of the filtered water I use right out of the fridge. Overall, it seems to be a very good little machine and you can't beat the small footprint on the counter- a definite plus if you have limited counterspace like me. An additional note- I haven't used plastic snap-on frothing tip yet, as I just haven't seen the need. Just make sure you clean off the steam arm carefully after each use, as in the past, I've found that any residue that develops quickly becomes impossible to remove. A wet paper towel used right after you finish does the trick.

My wife likes her coffee dark and strong. And when I say "dark and strong," I mean that she finds the darkest roast she can - the closer to pitting soil the better - and then uses 7 scoops (not the normal 5) for a 10-cup pot. Even at these settings, though, sometimes her coffee just wasn't strong enough for her. It was really only that first cup that did it for her. Teh rest of the pot was just a tad weak. We tried going to 8 scoops, but that was too much for our coffee maker. It often spilled put of the basket while brewing, getting grounds in her coffee. I suggested making two pots each morning, but she didn't want to do all that before going to work. She just wanted to turn the machine on and pour. We tried a Keurig, filling the reusable K-Cup with our own coffee. That still didn't do the trick. So, I decided that we needed to try an espresso maker. Of course, I wasn't going to spend $150 or $300 on an experiment. So, I got her this one for Christmas. It's been wonderful. She gets exactly what she needs from her coffee now. I was worried at first. Some of the reviews mentioned problems with brewing, and it doesn't come with a tamper. We've had no brewing problems. As for a tamper, a bottled of Mrs. Dash's seasoning works just fine. The two other issues that kept coming up in reviews were the fact that the wand was immobile and that the machine wouldn't steam. Yes, the wand is stuck in place. That can be a problem if you're too energetic in your frothing. If that's an issue for you or your mugs are too big, you probably shouldn't get this machine. For us, we figured out how to move our pitcher in smaller circles, and it's been just fine. As for not steaming/frothing, I think I figured out the problem that most people complaining about this are having. This machine holds enough water for 4 "cups" of espresso. If you pour in 4 and make 4 shots of espresso, THERE WON'T BE ANY MORE WATER TO STEAM/FROTH YOUR MILK! So, you'll need to do one of two things. First, you can pour in 4 "cups" of water while only making 2 shots of espresso. This has been fine for us. Second, you could make four shots of espresso, refill the water, and then steam your milk. This is where the real drawback comes in, though. You obviously don't want to do this too quickly because you might burn yourself releasing the little bit of leftover steam. On the other hand, if you wait too long, your espresso is cold. This is probably what you want to think about most before buying this: "Do I usually make 4 or more shots of espresso that need steamed/frothed milk?" If you do, I'd say this machine won't be for you. However, if you can get by with making 2 or 3 shots, you should enjoy this. And, most of all, if what you want is a very good, very inexpensive espresso maker, this is for you.

Update: After 5 Days of Use The machine is still a good low cost espresso machine and I retain the 4 stars. However, I have to take back the fact that it's a fantastic coffee machine. If you use the specified amount of beans with the water, it makes a great espresso. However, trying to use it as a coffee machine by adding more water is not so good. The problem lies in the the fact that the pressurized steam water literally shoots like a jet rocket half way through. This cause the water to essentially pass through the grind that's already been drained of flavor super heated, adding a cigarette/ashe taste to the robust inital drain. I wasn't expecting so much pressure from the machine. Expensive pump based machines aren't like this and can be used as a coffee like machine. I'll just use it as an espresso machine, as it was meant to be. My Mr Coffee 4 cup coffee machine, which is discontinued i think, still is the best coffee machine. ----------------------------------------------------- I'm a very picky coffee drinker, who is also budget conscious. I've gone through years of evolution in my coffee brewing techniques to try to brew the best tasting coffee at the lowest price. My current setup is a 4 cup Mr Coffee coffee maker with a Krups burr grinder. Previously, I used to use a Krups coffee maker with a cone filter and the typical low end spinning blade grinder. I was reasonably satisfied with the current setup, but wanted a stronger punch to the coffee flavor, closer to an espresso. The Mr Coffee coffee machine is the best coffee maker, because it had a water drip that wasn't just a one hole in the center like 99% of the coffee makers, but had multiple drip holes that truelly spread the water over much of the beans. This extracted the maximum flavor from the coffee beans. However, I still felt that a hotter water like steam and more concentrated wetting of all the beans would bring out the maximum flavor. This is where Mr Coffee ECM160 espresso machine came into the picture.
