Because the water comes down as super heated steam level into a tiny sealed container spread over the entire surface area, the maximum flavor extraction is achieved. This makes a fantastic strong flavor coffee with equal amount of beans as my previous coffee machine, which means I can use even less beans and still make a better tasting coffee. I can put in 2 servings worth of coffee grind with 4 servings of water (espresso), which equates to about 2 cups of coffee, and it still taste better and stronger then when i used twice the amount of beans in a regular coffee machine. If your used to using a coffee filter so u don't get the fine coffee grinds, you will initially be dissapointed with the murky trasparency of the coffee. However, the way to get around this is use a metal mesh Krups cone filter, as a filter to pour the coffee into your mug or cup. This removes any large grinds and you end up with a fantastic coffee with incredibly strong robust flavor. As far as making an espresso, all you need to do is just use less water. It does create that mild foam that most expensive espresso machine make, but not as good. But the flavor is almost identical to a $200 espresso machine I've used in the past at work. I can't speak for the foaming stick, cuz I don't make cappucinos. Now, why only 4 stars ? Well, the huge power on off wheel on the left is an overkill, and takes up alot of space. They could have just had 1 on/off switch for brewing and 1 button for the foaming stick. As mentioned by another reviewer, the aluminum molded water container/heating element could be health issue if it ever degrades over time. IMO, it will be fine as long as u follow the direction to NOT open the pressure lid until the machine has fully cooled off. This is to prevent the water drying up inside the aluminum holding tank while it's super hot, causing the minerals to deposit and break down the aluminum from both heat, minerals, and chemicals. It also does not come with a tamper, and the plastic scooper it comes has an inadequate tiny flat bottom that your supposed to use as tamper. It does not fit properly to tamper down the coffee without making a mess. You do need to use a real tamper or, if you don't want to buy a tamper, you can use anything round that is flat and large enough to press down the coffee grind uniformly. A 49 mm tamper fits perfectly, as it is large enough for full 4 servings of grind and small enough to go lower to press down 2 servings of grind. It doesn't come with a foaming container, but I didn't expect it to. However, I think it should have come with atleast a cheap plastic tamper that fits. Now the bonus of using this machine over a regular coffee machine, is that you don't have to buy coffee filters AND you don't have to use those white cholorinated 4 cup coffee filters. That means your not drinking any more chlorine or any chemicals that came from the paper. A health benefit. Other then that, for the price of $37, it's a great deal. It makes the best coffee u could possibly make and will save you on beans to pay for itself over time.

When considering purchasing an espresso/cappuccino machine for the first time, don’t break the bank! Get one like this to kind of get into learning how to mix the correct blend etc... before purchasing one that is high dollar. So far this thing gets it done every time! Plus, when it “goes up” on us, we are not out a bunch of money!
reviews.review_header: Great for the entry level espresso/cappuccino enthusiast!

reviews.review_text: Works well and quickly. The 'on' light is clearly visible, the previous machine had a faint one on the side resulting in frequent oversight to turn it off. Well this is NOT a pump machine, but fortunately my taste buds are sufficiently tolerant. I took one star off because the handle on the grind bowl broke when I banged it on the mulch can. (That reminds me ... I replaced the sieve basket with the one from my old one, that stays in the grind bowl, since the one on this machine is loose.

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: I had this machine for awhile before I bought my Capresso Classic 18 bar pump machine. (which I really love) For the price, this machine is really quite good. It makes lattes that are even better than my current pump machine, which I paid nearly $200 for. (Probably because I haven't mastered the technique of making the latte with the smaller shots of real espresso from the pump machine). This espresso machine puts out a good deal of strong coffee. It is not technically espresso, which requires higher pressure than a steam powered machine can muster. So I agree with the reviewer who says that if you're looking only for espresso shots, you don't want to go with this machine. It will not give you that amazing taste that comes only from a proper shot of espresso pulled from a pump machine that is at much higher pressure. But if you're looking for a machine only for lattes, cappuccinos, and other such drinks, this is definitely worth the money. (Currently $29! What a deal!) I give it 4 stars not because it is 4 stars when considered beside other espresso machines in the market. My standard, rather, is that it is an amazing purchase for the price and will definitely fill the craving for those who are putting all the money into Starbucks and want to cut back on this costly, overpriced habit. I recommend also investing in a 6 pack of Torani chocolate syrup, which is what you need to make a delicious mocha latte. You can also get it in other flavors. This machine will also be more than sufficient to make a frappuccino. What I do with frapps is to freeze the espresso, put a little more ice in the blender with the frozen espresso (you may not even need more ice given how much "espresso" is produced with this machine which, as I said, is far more than with a pump machine), some milk, and then some Torani syrup. You will be making frapps and lattes that rival Starbucks with this machine (and a little practice).

Trust me. As a stock trader & night owl who lives on the West Coast, I start every day 3 hours behind Wall Street. So, NOTHING is more important to me first thing in the morning than getting a quick, easy, perfect cappuccino. Seriously. Nothing. When my third Krupp's espresso machine died after years of heavy use, I decided to change things up. I bought a Mr. Coffee ECM160 4-cup Steam Espresso Machine and at the same time, bought a Capresso espresso machine. This way, we have one at home and one in our RV. I chose the Capresso because I ADORE another product from Capresso: Mllk Froth Pro (You simply pour the milk into the non-stick, easy-clean pitcher, and press start. It's perfect every time and frees me up to feed the cats while the espresso and milk froth are in the making.) I chose the Mr. Coffee simply because it was the maker of my first drip coffee machine which lasted for decades. It's a name I know and trust. Even tho the Capresso was $10-15 more expensive, the Mr. Coffee choice is by far the best. It takes up less space on the counter and less space vertically. Its lid is crazy easy to open and close in a hurry, while the Capresso lid lacks grooves, so it's extremely difficult to open and close (it requires rubber gloves, someone who's very strong, and has lotsa patience to wrestle with it every morning in order to finally twist it on and off). In addition, the Mr. Coffee brews faster than the Capresso espresso machine, finishing at the exact same time as the Capresso Milk Froth Pro! Ahhhhhhhhh. Perfect every time. Amazingly easy. The Mr. Coffee espresso machine + Capresso Milk Froth Pro are a match made in heaven & absolute staples in our kitchen! =^.^=
reviews.review_header: Go with the Name you Know & Trust

reviews.review_text: Love the simplicity of this coffee maker and make great latte with it. But as other reviewers point out, the side knob handle broke off after 2 years of regular use (less than once per day), just like a time bomb. I wasted 2 units in the last 4 years with the same problem and just ordered another. While all other parts seem in good condition, the manufacturer should use better material for the knob pole instead of poor plastic, or make it replaceable, to extend its life. The newly ordered unit is slightly different from previous 2 and looks cheaper. I wonder if it would last any longer? Otherwise, great little coffee maker, tucked nicely under the cabinets.
reviews.review_header: Love the simplicity of this coffee maker except its short service life

reviews.review_text: super easy to operate and now that I'm a pro at frothing the milk I realize how much of a rip off my local coffee shop is because this 35$ espresso maker out performs either there stainless steal several hundred or thousand dollar espresso makers or there effort is weak ....either way at 5 bucks a pop plus tip at the coffee shop that's 5-6 trips and you could grab this lil gem and a can of descent espresso and a gall of milk 10$ do the math it pays for itself in 2 weeks !!! I'm really happy with this product !
reviews.review_header: 5 bucks a pop plus tip at the coffee shop that's 5-6 trips and you could grab this lil gem

reviews.review_text: I had one of these several years ago and used it all the time. When I started looking for a new machine I tried a higher priced unit and ended up sending it back because it was horribly loud. I decided to get new and improved version of my old one and it works great. The frother doesn't seem to work very well but I found that if you take the little plastic thing off it works great. This isn't an expensive elaborate machine but it works very well for the money. Looking at the reviews for the more expensive and even the real expensive machines I notice that this machine got the most and best reviews. Now that's saying something.

Good entry level espresso maker. Though it doesnt make high quality espresso, it is an excellent machine to practice on. I bought this for my girlfriend, and she loves it. She has been practicing on making lattes and mochas. We’re considering on upgrading to a higher quality machine, but so far, she loves it.

Got this 1/2 off ($40), and for the price this is one of the best purchases I've made on Amazon. It's absolutely NOT the quality of a more standard / expensive Espresso machine. However, it does the job quite nicely. The steamer works wonderfully, and the filter is high quality and the espresso tastes great. At this price I'm thinking about buying another one for my office. I've used it a number of times and have not yet run in to any problems. We'll see how long it lasts, but at $40 these things are practically disposable.

I would have gave it a one-star but Amazon has came up and gave me another coffee maker because when I had received it it was broken so Amazon took care of me and it works beautifully and till today I'm still using it awesome
reviews.review_header: ... so Amazon took care of me and it works beautifully and till today I'm still using it

reviews.review_text: I had one of these that lasted for three years of daily use and loved it. I bought this one when the other one finally gave out, which I thought was a great idea considering the low price and how long the old device lasted. When the new one came, it worked beautifully, but it left a horrible plastic smell that lingered in our kitchen all day. I rinsed it with vinegar, etc., and the smell, after a week of use twice a day, still is just as strong and horrible. I called Mr. Coffee, and they were very polite and helpful, said they had heard of this problem before and said they would replace it. They sent the order through, but it hasn't been shipped yet. I called today, and the representative was not nearly as nice as the first representative, and said he had no idea when it would ship. Meanwhile, I am going back to "cowboy coffee" while we wait (and wait and wait) for our new coffee machine. Apparently when these work, they work wonderfully, but when they don't, it's awful. The smell makes me want to gag and I'm sure it can't be good for you to drink the coffee that comes out of this pot. If the replacement espresso machine comes in timely manner and doesn't smell and works properly, I will update this review, but for right now, I'm disgusted. UPDATE: I finally received the replacement coffeemaker over two weeks after I ordered it, arriving two days later than they promised me after I called, but it did arrive. The new one has a very slight smell similar to the other one, but just barely there. It works great, and for the price, you can't beat these little coffee makers (as long as you don't get one that smells).

We used to have one of these years ago that lasted for years and finally gave out. We decided to go with a fancier "pump" style machine. We had it for about 3 months when we started having problems with it. My husband was repeatedly having to take it all apart and clean everything out. From the beginning I never did like the flavor of the coffee and yes I know that coffee is important, but we were using the same brand as our old machine and it was always delicious from that machine. Finally the new one gave out completely and we were not happy! 6 months was all we got out of it and it was not cheap. Decided to go back to our good old stand by and we found this one - quite a bit more modernized than our last one was. We love it! Thank goodness we can now have our delicious espressos again.

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: I got this as a Christmas gift. This was missing the bottom tray that holds the cup in place and we contacted Amazon. They said they couldn't send us just a part, but could send us a new espresso machine. Initially they said we had to return the unit with the defective part, but then later said that we didn't have to worry about it and we could just keep both. We were very impressed. We really like the machine, it is simple, easy to use and now we've been having lattes every day. We couldn't imagine returning the unit and going without our lattes. The espresso coffee (La Llave) is much better than any drip coffee we've been using.
reviews.review_header: Great unit, good price, yummy coffee

reviews.review_text: I'd just burned up my Melita espresso machine which was less than a year old. I needed to replace it, but didn't want to invest tons of money if these machines didn't last more than mine did. I saw the Mr Coffee forty-dollar-wonder and thought why not? There's a bit of a learning curve here. The Melita machine was pump driven, Mr. Coffee's is steam driven. I didn't realize this when I bought it. (I'm not sure I would've understood the difference) The first time I used it, I blew milk all over the place....the coffee was good, tho. I fiddled with it for a day or two and stopped hating it rather quickly. I foam into a receptacle that is wider on the bottom to help contain the bubbling. I love that you can make 4 shots worth of really, really good espresso at a time. I love the steam-driven foamer, which makes the milk very hot and nicely foamed. I really love this little machine...it has a small footprint and makes really, really good espresso. I love the lattes made with it, as well. I'm happy with it and will get another as back-up.

After reading the instructions, it's very easy to use. You've got to make sure to let all the pressure out before opening the top at the end. Everything is easy to clean except for the metal part of the steamer. The milk splashes a lot when steaming and gets cooked onto the metal part. You can't really avoid this either since the steamer doesn't have real settings. Just on and off. In the picture, it shows the steamer sticking out making it look easy to access and use but it only sticks out a little bit and can't get into very deep cups. It's perfectly fine in that sense if you're using an actual steaming cup but I using use my coffee cups. As for the coffee, you need more coffee grounds in ratio to water than it states in the instructions for you're just getting strong coffee, not an espresso shot. All in all, it's not a bad price for what you get. It suites my purposes just fine and I like using it. The end result if done right is very delicious.
Very happy with this machine so far. My first espresso machine, and tastes great! I replaced my Keurig with this, so now better and stronger coffee.
reviews.review_header: Very happy with this machine so far

reviews.review_text: I started drinking lattes more instead of coffee from a Dr Oz show I watched. Lattes are better on the stomach and have more protein from the milk content. The lattes are expensive after a few times so I decided to order this. I did the reviews and decided to go with this one. Awesome little machine, just got it yesterday and have used it to make espresso and steam milk for the latte. Get a separate tamper as this does not come with one. Don't waste money on more expensive pump driven ones as they break easier. I broke the glass carafe by accident and was able to overnight a replacement one very easily from amazon. Almost all the parts are replaceable as well. Works great to heat up and steam milk for hot chocolate for my kids too!
reviews.review_header: Great machine, great price, makes a great gift too!

reviews.review_text: I first purchased another espresso machine from amazon and couldn't get it to work, to save my life. Every setting just resulted in boiling hot steam coming out of the steam wand. I read the directions over 3 times and it simply wouldn't work. I'm convinced it was something I was not doing correctly. Regardless, sent it back and purchased this one instead (a lot cheaper to begin with) and it worked 100% right out of the box. Just made my first double shot (will work on my tamper pressure) and it came out with a nice layer of crema atop of the espresso brew. Clean-up was 10 seconds. The puck came out in one tap of the basket and I simply washed out the few loose grinds in the filter and washed my two bodum espresso glasses. If you are just entering the world of espresso, don't know what machine to get, but want to just get one to get started. You will not be disappointed with this machine.
reviews.review_header: Does just what you ask it to do

reviews.review_text: I'm pleased with this bargain buy. The espresso it gives me is pretty good and not much trouble to make. It's not really more work than using and cleaning my regular Mr Coffee coffee machine. I highly recommend you buy the Blue 49mm Espresso Tamper Stainless Steel Coffee that is an almost perfect fit. It made a huge difference to use it to to get a firm, solid pack of the grounds. With this tamper, the espresso was thicker and richer (not as watery) as it was using the free little plastic spoon as the tamper. This espresso maker does still not produce that thick espresso "syrup" you get from an industrial strength machine or Starbucks but it is a great starter. Have modest ambitions and you'll be pleasantly surprised with this product.
reviews.review_header: Great bargain & not a bad product!

reviews.review_text: I love this thing... As long as you take care to clean it after each use and give it a good detailing every so often, it will work like a charm! Here is my routine - I hope it helps someone out! 1. Fold a paper towel and put it on the counter. Take the small espresso basket out of the holder and put it on the paper towel. Fill with desired amount of espresso, and tamp - not too hard! (ps., do you have a Misto olive oil sprayer? Turn it upside down and use that to tamp. Your welcome. :p) Make sure the edges are clean and place in the holder. Use paper towel to wipe tamp-er. Lock the holder into the espresso machine. 2. Using glass carafe, fill espresso machine with desired amount of water. (I generally make a latte, so I fill it with enough to make the espresso and steam too!) Put the lid on the carafe and slide into place. Do not screw the top on yet!! 3. Plug in the espresso machine *with the screw-top off* and turn to 'brew'. If you're steaming milk, take out the milk and pour into steaming cup. Set on the counter. 4. Once the water starts to make noise and is about to be or already boiling, quickly screw the top into place. This method ensures that no yucky warm water filters through the espresso and weakens it/changes the flavor. Since this little guy just works off of steam pressure, screwing the cap on when the steam really starts is the best way to avoid this. Be a bit careful, by the way. 5. While the espresso is brewing, I like to put my sugar in the mug beforehand. Remember that paper towel? Wet it. Once the espresso starts to change color or the machine makes a slightly different noise, get your milk ready, stick the nozzle in, and steam. I won't go into the method... You'll figure out what works for you! Once you're done steaming, use the wet paper towel to immediately wipe down the steam nozzle. 6. Pour your espresso into the mug, followed by your milk/foam. Fill the milk steaming cup with water and re-insert the nozzle. I rest the cup on top of another upside down mug so that I don't have to hold it. Now unplug the machine, turn the nozzle to steam, and let the rest of the steam out into the water. This will release the pressure as well as cleaning the nozzle! Enjoy! My only complaint about this machine is the position of the steaming nozzle. It is way to close to the body and not at all adjustable. Otherwise, it's a pretty good solution!
For the price this coffee maker is great. Is easy to handle, small so it doesn't take a lot of counter space and the coffee quality is very good.
reviews.review_header: For the price this coffee maker is great. Is easy to handle

reviews.review_text: This cheap little boiler espresso maker works pretty well as long as you get the grind right and never make more than half of the pitcher full at a time. I bought this to replace an identical one I've been using daily for over 12 years that finally died. It was just to be a temporary replacement for a nice Braun pump machine that I never got around to fixing because I never remembered the value of its burned out thermistor when I happened to be at an electronics store that carried such parts. Makes perfectly acceptable espresso for one and doesn't take up much counter space

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: Let me first say I have only had this machine for a week, however I love it. The machine is inexpensive. I think I already saved its equivalency in making coffee at home. The espresso tastes great and the machine is very easy to use. The milk steamer works great. Definitely get a pitcher if you use the milk steamer. So as long as the machine doesn't break in a 3 months, its a 5 star buy.

My Kyrups 963A finally died after 21 years of daily, sometimes twice daily use. While I took good care of it and had to improvise when parts broke, the steam cap finally gave out. The plastic just crumbled. I lived in Italy for a year and know good espresso. The 963A was not a true espresso machine, however, I wasn't and probably never will be ready to drop big bucks (i.e., hundreds) just so that I can get espresso froth. I can get good espresso with good beans. That's the key. I need strong coffee and caffeine! :-) So, I turned to the Mr. Coffee ECM160 4-Cup Steam Espresso Machine. It's a backward engineered version of my former Kyrups 963A. I can use the 963A's carafes and lids. After running a few carafes of water through to clean it, the first batch was good. I like this machine... but I would not bother with black frother attachment which is suppose to help. On both the 963A and the ECM160, you'll have better control of frothing cream/milk without the attachments. Use the metal tip alone like I have for the last 21 years and you'll find it flexible, easy to control and fun at times improvising. I might rate this a 5 star in 3-5 years... if it makes it that long. Some parts are as robust as the 963A. However for 40 dollars, you get what you pay for... and I got something that's worth that amount of money. Time will tell on this one... My 963A was a 5star+, rest its dear soul.

This little machine has impressed me! When we first got it, I will say that I was a little disappointed, but I played around with it, and I've worked out some of the quirks, and it's actually quite a great little machine. First tip: Fill the carafe to the top of the metal line to get the amount of steam you need to froth your milk. Second: Invest in a good tamper. The measuring cup isn't great. Third: Take the guard off of the steaming arm. This machine actually produces an impressive amount of crema despite the fact that it's not a pump machine. It beats Starbucks in our book! I'd recommend it to anyone.

This is my second purchase- I lost the silver metal steam screw in attachment and never could find a replacement-don't lose this part. Does a good job of espresso and steams frothy steamed milk. It is messy however and takes awhile to clean up. Best to use white vinegar to keep scale down and clean off frother attachment. I am careful to use bottled water for steam. Make sure not to pack the coffee to tightly or you will experience a messy drip- pack lightly and use the back of the spoon measurement that is provided

I totally love this machine. I'd say I got my money's worth out of it the first week! Literally, all you have to do is make like 6 or 7 Latte's and BAM! you just paid off your machine :) I have 2 things I highly recommend though. 1. Buy a "Frothing mug" AKA: the thing to steam the milk in. (it's like $8 on amazon)... You will need this! 2. Buy a "Stamper" AKA: the thing that smashes the coffee into the machine. (like $6) Trust me, you want/need this! If you buy the above 2 things above (because you need them and they are not included) you will be totally stoaked with this machine! Total purchase price with two additional items above is like $50 bucks roughly, but seriously... This machine rocks for that price! I hope you enjoy it as much as I do, (which is honestly like 3-4 times a week... sometimes 2 or more times a day though, plus my girlfriend makes stuff occasionally.) This is a winner for sure!

DISCLAIMER: 1. I have never owned another espresso machine. 2. I have been using this machine consistently for about a month. -- DETAILS: I purchased this machine because years of experience with products in general has taught me that one should go cheap on the first go and then when one has some level of expertise with the medium (be it coffee or cooking or computers or musical instruments)--THEN go spend the "bigger bucks" for something which you can utilize with some acumen. The first few times you will probably fail to tamp right and get either a too-bitter slow brew or a too-weak fast brew; but if you're that skilled as a barrista you wouldn't be mucking about with this type of machine anyway! The build quality seems acceptable for what is a truly entry-level device. The carafe, however, seemed frail even when I first handled it; and the frailty was proven when the other day it fell a few inches and shattered on a granite surface. Luckily I have thick-bottomed glass tumblers which serve as an adequate stand-in; measuring water by eye is easy enough anyway. -- PROS: * CHEAP. * Quick and easy setup (3-5 minutes to create a latte; parts are pretty idiot-proof in handling). * Easy cleanup (all parts removable, and the wand is easily wiped clean with a coarse brush when the plastic sleeve is removed. CONS: * Treat gently as the parts are as fragile as the price suggests! -- CONCLUSION: Definitely worth it as a "my first espresso machine" as at this price point you really can't go wrong and it's too simple to screw up too easily. ********** EDIT ********** I've upped it a star. Why? I have finally mastered the frothing procedure properly. Turns out you should just keep frothing the milk, keep frothing, keep frothing... THEN it will be "proper". I've removed all my "novice error" complaints. One star off still for the cheap carafe. ********** EDIT #2 ********** Keeping it at 4/5 stars even tho this one got consigned to the rubbish bin (lost the attachment for the wand) as I learnt something quite useful for frothing: 1) Buy a proper metal pitcher (12oz will do). 2) CHILL IT. 3) When frothing a chilled pitcher will allow the milk to froth properly!

I own two of these espresso makers. Do not use froth pipe. Tremendous value. Fast, good taste, easy to use and clean. Don’t waste money on expensive large espresso maker. Can use small generic replacement pot if glass breaks.

The coffee maker works great and serves its purpose. It was actually a gift for my daughter in law and she loved it. I used to own a Mr. Coffee Espresso Maker and the elegant look has changed a lot it somewhat looks very cheap.

I bought this recently because I realized I was spending FAAAAAR too much money on expensive espresso every day. If you're a coffee snob (and I mean that in the nicest way possible!) perhaps this isn't the machine for you, but for someone who just likes to get a little caffeine buzz in the morning and may or may not be bored with standard coffee, this is great. Pros: Brews quick, tastes fine, does the job. Cons: The steamer arm is a little short and when you're steaming in a mug you (at least, I) tend to bump the cup against the side of the machine, which leads to little spills every now and again. It also brews so quick that you have to keep an eye on it, to make sure it doesn't overflow. But really the cons are minimal and this is exactly what I needed. Cappuccinos for everyone!

I am not much of a coffee aficionado. I do not drink any coffee other than espresso and this is the first coffee making machine I have ever owned or used. After being introduced to Cuban espresso in Miami I have immediately become addicted to it. If you have not tried Cuban-style espresso, then do yourself a favor and do so. Id recommend Pilon or Cafe Bustelo coffees. This machine allows me to recreate this type of espresso and make it well. I am not so much interested in the cappuccino milk frothing arm but have used it to some success. Id say that if you are are cappuccino drinker, you may be better off going with something a little nicer, but this guy does the trick to make good espresso and its cheap. I am very happy with this product. The one thing I will say is that make sure you know what 4-cup means because 4 cups(2 shots) is essentially what I drink at one time. This is not a machine to make the whole family espresso with at once.

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: This is a great little espresso machine. It is very easy to use. Just fill the top with water and set the button to brew for the espresso. Then set the button the opposite way for the steam. The steam valve is a little short for my milk steamer so I had to tilt it quite a bit but I made it work. And the scooper that was supposed to serve as a tamper didn't work too well. It is too curved so you may need to invest in a tamper as well. But, otherwise it works great.

Steamer: pretty good! It steams about the same speed as my Breville Infuser. I was able to get good microfoam. But: the steamer wand does not move any. And it doesn't match some of the photos here. Coffee making: it doesn't make espresso. But it does make really-strong coffee that's quite good. It's similar, or stronger, than what you can achieve with an Aeropress. I first tested with an espresso grind, 18 grams (2 scoops), tamped. The machine just couldn't force the water through the grounds. The safety steam vent spewed, but no coffee came out. I went down to medium grind, 18 grams (2 scoops) tamped. This made strong coffee, about 45 ml extract in 35 seconds' time. Remember: at least 75% of the coffee drink quality comes from your BEANS and WATER. I tested with excellent CounterCulture.com beans. Four stars because: -- Steamer works well -- Portafilter and steam boiler can achieve strong coffee -- Steam wand does not articulate -- What's this giant pot for? It can only make 45-90 ml (2-3 fluid ounces) at a time.

Works right out of the box.I never use the milk spritzer- not my taste. Over all, just what I wanted. I must complain of the ovoid control knob on the side, and the odd-shaped ovoid filler cap on top. They are some kind of design flourish, but NOT of ergonomic value; one's hands must be dry and at times turning the unit on is a two-handed operation. Some sort of texture is needed to improve grip in both cases. However, the unit maintains good taste in my preferred coffee, and I experience greats satisfaction in my morning brew.
Perfect for our needs. We use it probably twice a day. We are just getting into espresso, so we didn't want to spend too much on a machine, so this one was ideal.

Fantastic. Does everything that it says it does. Perfect size for one or two people. Only flaw is a frothing container should be included. Nobody should try to froth without proper container.You will get burned. Excellent for the first time user.
reviews.review_header: Love it..Perfect for me.Easy to use&clean.

reviews.review_text: Works as expected. Nice item, but I will upgrade soon.

Bigger expensive machine died a while ago, read the reviews and decided to try it. The materials are cheap, which means it will have to be kept clean and instructions followed but my daughter had one at work and it survived and it makes OK froth and espresso. We clean the milk nozzle by submerging it in a cup of water and steaming for a short time. As soon as the plastic smell goes it will be fine, but we are pretty rough on stuff so we will see if it can survive. We use the same Pilon in a can we use for Cuban coffee and it works just great.
reviews.review_header: Close enough and inexpensive enough to make us happy.

reviews.review_text: My item arrived in time. Here's the thing, this is a machine that's not professional, it's meant to be simple for everyone to use it. As a barista I can say it's a quite decent machine, you can even pull off nice latte art if you use the frother bare, without the black piece, trust me, just throw that piece away. The milk will have better texture. The only thing thats kind of a drawback it that in order to use the frother you have to brew your espresso shot and in order to brew another shot you have to depressurise the machine, otherwise when you take out the portafilter, the pressure will escape through the grouphead and it will explode...and there will be coffee everywhere. So get to know well how to use the machine and you'll get the best out of it. I've had mine for a year and a half and it still works.
reviews.review_header: Its a good machine for the value

reviews.review_text: At this price point, I think that this machine has easily paid for itself. I love my Mocha in the morning (especially when winter comes around), and I was not happy when my previous espresso machine died (especially since it was a high quality machine). I bought this one as something to tide me over until I got around to buying a better one, but I now suspect that this will last me for some time. This makes a good espresso, and it is super easy to use. Having the one switch that converts between espresso and steamer functionality makes it nice and easy. The beaker to hold the espresso means you don't have to try and line up espresso shot glasses, and the markings on the beaker make it easy to see how much you are getting. On the negative side of things, this is a case where you get what you pay for - at the cheap price, do not expect the moon. There is no crema evident, however if you are making a Latte or a Mocha or ... do you really care? I am grinding my beans fresh before making the espresso, and using a fine grain, with a medium tamp down. So I would have expected at least a little crema. The beaker has a marking at the equivalent of a double shot, however it is not marked as that. Twice that marking is marked as 2 cups, and the next marking is 4 cups. However if you do make that much coffee, expect it to be fairly diluted - to be fair, I would expect any espresso machine to make diluted coffee if you make 8 shots from a single basket of ground coffee. The beaker also contains a lid that makes it easy to center the beaker below the nozzle, however I am not sure that this is needed. The lid (if put on correctly) results in the coffee markings being off-center. Hardly a big deal. This machine does not have a water reservoir, and I have mixed feelings about this. My (far more) expensive machine had one, and that meant I would only fill up with filtered water once a week, or could fill up on the fly if we drank more coffee than normal. However this machine requires a refill of water each brew, and it is important to ensure that the pressure has been released before taking the cap off totally - fortunately the cap seems to have been designed so that it starts releasing pressure long before you could possibly get the cap off. While I have put everything through the dishwasher, the shiny metallic sheen on the holder for the coffee basket is paint on top of a not-so-shiny metal, and that paint does not survive the dishwasher. Do not expect it to be shiny afterwards. :-) While it seems that I have posted a fair few negative comments, every single one of them is extremely minor nit-picking. At the end of the day, it is the espresso itself that matters, and this makes a good brew.

Happy purchase on my favorite machine in the house. This is my 4th one, not because they broke, all are working fine. I have just put them at all our condos so I will never be away from my espresso machine.
reviews.review_header: Happy purchase on my favorite machine in the house

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: For the price, this is awesome. It makes espresso shots in a matter of minutes, and then the frothing piece heats up fairly quickly as well. I'm still struggling on "how to froth milk" but I think that's a user issue than a device issue. Haha. It does not come with a frothing cup but easy to find one for your liking. Overall, a good purchase, and I've used it multiple times so far and have had zero issues!
reviews.review_header: Cheaper Than Most, But Works Awesome!

reviews.review_text: This is a great coffee machine. Having used it for 2+ months, I must say I like it it. Every day, the first thing in the morning is running to it and enjoy the pure taste from it in a few minutes... And one more thing: I had a bad experience with it. It got an explosion due the over pressured vapor breaking the plastic inner part of the sealing cap. Fortunately, no one was hurt. The praise I want to say is, the following customer service experience was smooth. I'm happy with the result though it takes some time to wait for the coffee joy. I would recommend this company and the product to anyone, who is looking for an espresso machine. The only reason I do not give a five star is because its entry level quality. It's not bad, but it is not boutique.
reviews.review_header: Overall Good Quality, Great Customer Service Experience.

reviews.review_text: First it DOES NOT come with a tamper or a frothing cup and It's not the best coffee maker in the world but I feel like it comes really close to it! I especially love the frothing wand and the fact that I can make two drinks at once. Mine didn't come with instructions but with a few Google searches and I managed. If it ever breaks which I'm sure someone might accidentally drop it, I would buy this again!
reviews.review_header: Love it and i would buy it again!

reviews.review_text: I was fighting some things on this but found a great video on Youtube. I think it has a cheaper model than this with the same type of dials and frothing wand. Just type "Make cheap Mocha with a $30 Espresso Machine ECM250". I read through the instructions and gave her a try for the first time jamming the steam wand down into a coffee mug of milk. Wow, haha - like some buyer mentioned in here about getting nothing but boiling milk was a true enough statement and burned myself along the way, my hands and fingers were splattered with boiling milk all over the place! Keep in mind, I've NEVER done this or even seen someone do it. Oh, and taking off the top without depressurizing it when I shouldn't was another learning curve, it burned my fingers AGAIN. Anyways, I couldn't get the micro-foam until I did some research and watched several videos on You Tube about how to do it. So, I tossed and turned about this my first night of ownership and woke with determination! Oh... did I earn some kisses from my bride when she was licking the spoon from a cup of Micro-Foam, and yes, from 2% milk, not whole milk as was mentioned in many of the videos to use. Micro-Foam: I had ordered the 20oz Stainless Steel Frothing cup with a Temperature Gauge and proceeded to make it happen! Like me, if you don't know how to do this, you need a temp gauge. But, using a cold cup with cold milk about 10oz, half the container inserting the steaming wand all the way down and let it set, gently moving the cup up and down. When bubbles start, just put the wand in as deep as it will go. The steam wand IS short and close to the sides of the machine, but making do and using all my senses began to notice when the milk hits about 90 degrees a sweet spot begins form (funny sounding noise) that can be massaged until the temp hits 155 degrees tops. IMMEDIATELY take the brown wand extension off and drop it into some water, wipe the wand with a wet towel. Tap the mug on the counter if any large bubbles are present and whirl the frothing cup. Espresso: I need some better grounds than pre-ground stuff. "Pending"

Excellent basic espresso maker: easy to operate, clean, and with the usual accouterments. This thing is a little work horse that we use 2-5 times a day in my office, five days a week, for years. Like any product using tap water you will have to clean it - or it will eventually get plugged up and break. But, if you take care Mr. Coffee, Mr. Coffee will take care of you!

Bought to replace a broken unit that had been in home service for several years brewing 3 to 5 individual cups of "Americano" style coffee daily. No partial pots left over and wasted. Improved shape of the new unit's control and reservoir knobs are much easier to grip than the previous unit. Happy with this unit too.

I was really tired of my drip coffee maker and wanted a better tasting coffee in the morning. I decided, with some trepidation, to go for an espresso/cappuccino maker. Before I bought this espresso maker, I read through most of the previous reviews but I wasn't totally sure what to expect of this very reasonably priced espresso machine. Could this really do the job more expensive espresso makers would do? YES! I love this little machine! I did what other reviews had suggested and followed the directions to the letter. They are straightforward and following them ensured wonderful coffee from the very start (OK, maybe my very first attempt wasn't perfect - I didn't steam the milk enough but since then every cup has been great). I don't know why you'd want to buy a more expensive machine when this one does the job very well in my opinion. Perhaps my only gripe would be the lack of tamper (the back of the coffee scoop is supposed to serve as a tamper but does not do it very well) and lack of frothing jug, but this can be easily rectified by buying your own.

Just have some difficulties with frothing as milk sticks very easily to metal tube and it is hard to wash out afterwards. But it does work perfectly and I am getting better with lattes and chai teas. So pretty good machine for the price
reviews.review_header: Overall good machine for the price

reviews.review_text: This appliance is working great, is a good value, and I'm really enjoying it. It makes delicious lattes, and as I've become more proficient in increasing the milk's volume, I discovered my favorite Krupp's 12 ounce pitcher is no longer large enough. Both 1% and 2% milk work very well with equal success, and I don't bother using the frothing aid. But I always chill the stainless steel pitcher before adding cold milk and starting the frothing process. This appliance maker would do well to re-engineer the oddly shaped, texture-less water reservoir cap and control knob. I also agree with others about the too-short electrical cord (yes, it's completely unwrapped).

Brew had a oily metallic smell but disappeared after two uses. Cord is coiled underneath and can be uncoiled to desired length. No utensils needed to uncoil. Make sure the coffee holder is tight and snug before operating so it does not burst. Fairly good coffee but the steam is uneven on the coffee coffee grind and the result is weak. This may be technical problem. I am keeping the Espresso machine.
reviews.review_header: Fairly good coffee but the steam is uneven on the coffee ...

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: For the money you can't beat this!!! Make sure you have a grinder because you need really small espresso grinds and the correct size tamper to stuff it in there! Works well if you just make one round at a time. Going back to back uses the left over steam pushes some coffee out before it's really ready and messes up that drink.
reviews.review_header: For the money you can't beat this!!! ...

reviews.review_text: This is a good machine for beginners and people who aren't gourmet critics about their coffee. It gets the job done and makes it fairly simple to brew espresso. I have only brewed "2 cups" at a time and not attempted 4 yet, but I've consistently gotten a well-balanced brew with a nice crema. Although a devoted coffee snob could find criticisms your average Starbucks drinker should be satisfied. As others have noted you should buy a frothing pitcher if you don't already have one, as this machine doesn't come with one. Don't get one too large or the steam wand won't reach deep enough (see below). The main weaknesses are related to the steaming function, and each can be resolved with a work-around: 1) The steam wand is just a bit short, meaning even with a relatively small 12-oz frothing pitcher the wand can't quite get as low as you may want because the rim of the pitcher will be bumping up into the arm of the wand. You can compensate some by tilting the pitcher to make the milk deeper at one end. 2) The wand is also positioned directly up and down with no tilting possible, which makes it difficult to get the necessary angle to get the milk rolling--though after some practice I was able to achieve rolling milk by tilting the pitcher towards myself (front) and keeping the wand on the left side (machine side) of the pitcher. Although the manual instructs you to move the wand around, being able to get the milk rolling without moving the wand around is critical to creating the velvety microfoam that is the difference between a great latté or mocha and an OK one. 3) The steam wand also came with a "frothing aid" - a plastic cover with additional holes in it. I guess this is supposed to be helpful, but for my part I was unable to produce microfoam until I removed the frothing aid and just used the naked wand. 4) You can't easily steam without brewing espresso first (ex: to steam some milk for a child's hot cocoa, sans espresso), because the brewing process is needed to heat up the water for a few minutes to build up the steam heat and pressure. If you try to turn the steam function on without brewing first, the heating element comes on but you don't achieve enough pressure because the steam valve is open. If you try to run the brew function without coffee in the filter, the water floods through much faster and you end up trying to steam without enough pressure because the the water isn't hot enough yet, or you run out of steam very quickly because so much of the water ended up in the carafe instead of coming out as steam. Thus, the only way to steam without brewing first is to add a full carafe of water to the machine, set to brew, and let the carafe fill up to the 4-cup mark before switching over to steam.

I have had this thing 2 and a half years and it still goes. I thought about dropping a lot more money on one before I bought this, and as I really just wanted a basic cup of frothed milk on brewed 'espresso', I was good with this. You don't get the crema, but if you care that much spend 6 times as much before you will hit a machine that will meet your requirements. I will buy this unit again once mine breaks. I am probably at over 300 uses on this thing now - I have descaled it twice and it doesn't seem like it will give up any time now. Strangely, the glass cup is more likely to need replacing before the machine, as the metal got loose around the grip. That is the only mild problem I have had.

I might as well open a coffee shop with this product. Its fast its simple and it makes my mornings a lot faster than normal. All i do is brew the coffee and heat the milk with the steam function and my morning coffee is good to go!. I love the storage compartment for the power cable as i can just store it up later if i want to as well as the cover as it provides no spills. My only complaint is that it does not stop brewing until there is no water left or you switch the knob to off.
reviews.review_header: All i do is brew the coffee and heat the milk with the steam function and my morning coffee is good to go

reviews.review_text: I purchased my first Mr Coffee Expresso system for my son when he went to college. He loved it. When he came home from college, he brought it home with him and we used it during the summer. When he went back to school, I had to buy myself one. That was 2010. I just replaced this coffee pot (7 years later, my son still has his). Mr Coffee system is extremely convenient for making one cup of coffee at a time. I really don't use the steamer, so I can't comment on that, but I love the coffee maker.
reviews.review_header: This is my third and I've loved them all.

reviews.review_text: I've been using this for a week now with a frothing pitcher (12oz) and tamper. It smelled a little like burning plastic the first few times I used it, but that went away quickly. This machine is definitely worth the price, but the scoop is NOT a tamper so you have to buy one. I found a cheap on for $7 and it works great.

I had this exact same model for the last 5 or 6 years and wanted to replace it. This new model is the same except for like other people said, the water cap has a very plasticky smell which is very obnoxious and I wouldn't really recommend buying it until they replace that with a no smell cap.. luckily I was able to use my old machines cap so I kept the coffee maker , otherwise very nasty smell on the screw-on lid..
Fast shipping, as described. Makes a great latte and cappuccino. Must do one cup at a time. The sleek stainless steel and black look fit into the look of our kitchen nicely.
reviews.review_header: Makes a great latte and cappuccino

reviews.review_text: I owned a Krups years back but just recently got back into drinking espresso and latte again. I'm very pleased with this one so far. I'm especially pleased that the steam really heats the milk completely when frothing. It just seems to work as good as I had hoped despite the low price. I'm especially happy that it has a metal water tank and brews into glass, keeping hot water away from plastic parts. This product feels sturdy and well-made. ETA: I have owned it for a year now and I continued to be pleased. I ordered a metal tamper, a metal frothing pitcher and read up on some how-to for brewing espresso on the internet. Be sure to descale with vinegar. Very happy for the price I paid and it keeps me away from the coffee stands and saves some money.

I bought this because my dunkin donuts mocha latte habit was really beginning to add up. What a great purchase! I can now make hot mocha latte's comparable to the dunkin donuts ones (almost as good as paneras). I did buy a tamper to pack down the coffee grinds. At first it's a little confusing (directions are bad) - on how to use the frother. Here's what I do...fill the water up to the 2cup mark and then a little more water (this is what you'll use to steam). Turn to brew, when once espresso hits the 2cup mark on pot, switch it to off. Then get your milk cup ready to froth and turn the dial to steam. Problem is you never know how much extra water to add to get the right amount of steam. I also think it's a pain to clean up the frother. So here's what I do to make a delicious hot mocha latte: 1. fill pot up to 2cup mark with water, pour in water reservoir 2. use tamper to pack down ground espresso beans (lavazza is good, 6.99/can at grocery store) 3. turn to brew 4. meanwhile, heat my milk in coffee mug (2/3 full in 16oz cup) - in microwave about 1:45/2min. 5. add a teaspoon of davinci chocolate sugar free syrup (or similar, like torani) to my hot milk cup 6. then pour in espresso and stir YUM! Whole thing takes about 4 min and clean up is a breeze. Much better than spending 2.64 a day at dunkin donuts. I highly recommend this affordable espresso maker!
reviews.review_header: Excellent buy for $39, makes great lattes!

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: This machine has been a great addition to our house so far! I've had zero problems and think it makes a great basic espresso/latte. No, it is not a high dollar top of the line machine, but I knew that going into the purchase. It meets our needs quite well which is a morning soy latte. The soy milk foams nicely and the machine heats up and works quickly compared to others I've owned. Make sure you are cleaning the steam wand (water submersion and blow-out) every use or it will clog up.

This is our second Mr Coffee espresso machine. The last one finally died after about 10 years. Although I feel the appearance of this one is on the cheaper side, the retro looks are good enough and the value is hard to beat. We also bought a 49mm tamper to help improve the quality of the espresso, which was a good suggestion from others on Amazon. It's not a snug fit in the filter, but it's close enough to give a good tamping. For our general use, this machine is a very good value.

The Mr. Coffee Espresso System is easy to use and easy to clean with the exception of the milk steaming wand. Given that milk spoils quickly, a steam wand cover that is easier to clean would be an improvement. The coffee that the Espresso System makes is excellent. I would recommend this product to others.
reviews.review_header: Coffee Espresso System is easy to use and easy to clean with the exception ...

reviews.review_text: This product was so inexpensive, yet works so well. I would give it 5 stars but the frother on the side takes a while to froth milk and is hard to clean. I purchased a separate milk frother to avoid the hassle of cleaning the one on the machine and now I'm saving a fortune by making a perfect latte at home.
reviews.review_header: I purchased a separate milk frother to avoid the hassle of cleaning the one on the machine and now I'm saving a fortune by makin

reviews.review_text: If all you are looking for is a machine to get you going in the morning with a nice cup of espresso, GO FOR THIS ONE!! CAUTION: do not put the chrome plated espresso handle in dishwasher..
reviews.review_header: Ditch the $$$ ones if you are Not a coffee Connessiour..

reviews.review_text: We've had this type of Mr. Coffee Espresso maker for many years. It is great that they are still making this simple to use, but very good machine.
reviews.review_header: It is great that they are still making this simple to use

reviews.review_text: I have learned a lot since purchasing owning this little machine. Now I struggle to drink coffee anywhere but home. A good dark roast Columbian coffee and a touch of Bialys Irish creamer, that's heaven in a cup! Make sure you don't skimp on the coffee, buy whole bean and grind it your self.
reviews.review_header: Makes a great cup of espresso.

reviews.review_text: I was skeptical before purchasing this item; it's inexpensive and the reviews were not fabulous, but I wanted an espresso maker and we 9husbanad and I) couldn't afford one, so this was the only option. We took the plunge and I'm happy we did. This little thing has turned out to be fantastic! I don't know how we lived with out it. We have owned this product for nearly 6 months and here are my tips: 1- Buy the temper so you can pack the espresso bean 2- the pitcher is worth buying but isn't totally necessary (you can use a coffee mug if you really wanted to, the pitcher is more convenient) 3- clean the maker every time you use it, but it is especially important to clean the milk steamer every time you use it because you can get build-up (you would have to do this with every espresso maker) 4- Give the maker a really good clean about every week. I put water through it a few times, it doesn't take long. 5- make sure you use all the water every time you use it 6- don't over-fill anything Don't be alarmed! These tasks are typical up-keep for any espresso maker. Believe me, the little extra work is worth it since you can get up every morning to a latte or cappuccino without paying the crazy prices at a coffee shop. p.s. My friend has this same espresso maker and she has had it for over three years without any problems =)

I bought this for my wife and it is already saving us money from Starbucks. I figured if she liked using this then we could get a nicer model some time in the future. After using it I think I'll just wait until this one breaks which will hopefully be a few years. She makes herself an amazing latte every morning and they actually taste better than most I've tried. The machine is easy to use and we have had no problems with it. I highly recommend it. Happy wife happy life.

Great for the price. Haven't had any real problems with it. It's the best low-cost option for an espresso maker I've found. It looks nice on the counter. If you want something that will be flawless and gorgeous, spend more money, though. In the meantime, this will get the job done fine

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: i got this machine a couple months ago and is working perfect, there are a few things i want to share, the first one and is probably why some of them blew up is because people don't clean the machine; after frothing the milk you ALWAYS have to clean it, take an empty cup, fill it with cold water and activate the steamer, do this 2 to 3 times until there is no milk in the water. second to do an espresso first heat the water in steam mode and when you start getting some steam, switch it to brew mode; turn it off when coffee reach the 2nd line (2 cups)., then after use, unplug the cord and release the contained pressure turning into steam mode until all the steam is out. ALWAYS repeat this before you open the reboiler ( you will save the top seal), ALWAYS empty the reboiler. THE KEY OF THIS MACHINE IS KEEP IT CLEAN. great machine for value.
reviews.review_header: Is all you need- just keep it CLEAN

reviews.review_text: Don't spend hundreds of dollars on a expensive esspresso machine. This is a fine product. The smell of plastice evetually goes away, but it lingers for about 5-6 uses. I barely use the frother but it should be kept clean along with ghe rest of the machine.

I purchased this to replace one that I had for 10 years. There is a plastic piece that holds the metal cup in place when you dump the old coffee out. That plastic part is poorly designed and falls off. The foamer is not as long as my old one and doesn't reach the bottom of my cup.

I really wanted to get into making espresso at home as I always found myself going to Starbucks or other local coffee places multiple times every week. I investigated buying an Illy Pod machine, however when I went to visit a friend in L.A. she has this exact machine and made me some espresso and it was wonderful. So instead of spending $150+ on a pod machine or a super fancy machine I decided to give this little guy a chance since she loved hers so much. I am glad I did an I will tell you why: Design: This is a really nicely designed espresso machine, it is small, simple, and overall looks nice sitting on the counter. It isn't fancy as it just has a turn nob to make espresso or use the steamer. The top of the machine can be used to hold anything, I put a few small espresso cups on top and it looks nice. Ease of use: It really doesn't get any easier than this to make espresso. Simply fill the water up to the 2 or 4 (cup) line and pour into the top, and pack the espresso into the holder up to 2 or 4. The espresso holder simply lifts and locks into place. Turn the nob and it will start brewing, and once you no longer see espresso coming out you can turn it off. Espresso: I have used Fresh & Easy Espresso and also Lavazza espresso and it tastes great with this machine. I mix mine with a bit of soy half and half and I am good to go, or throw hot water in for an americano. Many people rate the espresso machine based on it's ability to make that nice froth on top of the espresso and you will see a bit here when you make the coffee. It is complete steam based system and it seems to work fairly well. The froth on top of the espresso isn't extremely thick and I am assuming higher end machines will do this better. I will say that once I bought a Tamper to pack down the espresso it helped a lot, so invest another $6 or so to get one of these and it will make a pretty decent difference, if not just for the ease of use. Frother: On the side of the machine is a milk frother/steamer. I didn't read the directions so I honestly didn't know how to use it until my friend from L.A. came to visit. All you have to do is add water to the little steam icon on the cup and pour it into the machine. Then turn it on and give it a minute. The steam is hot and pretty intense. It actually does a nice job of frothing milk or soy as long as you figure out how to use it. TIP: I like to turn the machine onto Brew after I am done frothing as there might be some water left over. Summary: This machine by far is the best bang for the buck. I have had it for around 2 months, and my friend has had it for a year and it is great. I still occasionally go to Starbucks, but it is great to just have it available right in my house. For $30 definitely give this little guy a try.

After finally finding a good ground Espresso, I made the best lattes ever. I get to control the foam, flavor and temp. unlike when you go to SB and pay sometimes 4 plus bucks. It takes a few to warm up before brewing the coffee part but once it's done the steam kicks right in just like promised. The foam is great. I Don't use the Krups cup they suggested you buy with (I bought it, before I knew better). I have a large heavy glass mug I use and like it better. No pouring from one thing to another, I just scrap off excess foam and add the coffee..DONE Glad I didn't pay for the expensive machine when this one does the job for me. The only part I don't really like on this model is the steam tube in towards the back of the machine and you have to turn the whole body to use.
reviews.review_header: my Homemade Latte was Better than Starb's

reviews.review_text: This is great if you already know how to make lattes and such. Its cheaper and 100% worth making lattes. I was terrified it would explode for a while but then I determined that the people who let THAT much pressure build up clearly had no idea what they were doing. Update: it's been several months now and it still works good as new. I have still had no leaking, explosions, or the like. Great machine.
reviews.review_header: This is great if you already know how to make lattes and ...

reviews.review_text: This is my 2nd Mr. Coffee. The first one I got from target. It does the job..but I was "cranking" the espresso container too tight..ended up leaking all overt the place. Other than that..I like this item. I would recommend it to a friend.

Love it for my Cuban coffee!! The glass is a little thin so I’ve already broken one but that was my fault. Steps slow enough so I can pull out enough coffee then make my sugar mixture for the perfect cup of coffee.
reviews.review_header: Love it for my Cuban coffee

reviews.review_text: The best investment. Love this coffee/espresso maker. Easy to use, perfect for my husband and me. Makes us our favorite Dutch Bros coffee with one use. Very tall glasses. Carmelizer and Annihilator. Just love it.
This product is okay, though you need to use extra coffee to get it as strong as the manual espresso maker I was used to. It does brew quickly, though, and I haven't had any problems with it so far.
reviews.review_header: This product is okay, though you need to use ...

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: Excellent cappacino! No more Starbucks! Make the perfect mocha with 100%cacao dutched chocolate powder, Splenda, pinch of salt, and 2% organic milk! This machine paid for itself in a week and the homemade mocha tastes SO much better than coffe shop version.

This steam machine is a heck of a lot more reliable than any pump machine I've had, including the last two by DeLonghi. Nothing worse than anticipating that first cup and having your pump machine refuse to pump. The DeLonghis did just that once every 7-12 cups, for no reason I could ever discern or even guess. This Mr. Coffee isn't perfect -- very lightweight (shifts around on the counter), there's no indicator for whether there's water in the tank or not (weak coffee all over the kitchen floor a couple of times), and there's never any crema (no matter how I make it). Still, I gives me what I want -- a cup of coffee -- every morning.
It's simple to use, makes great espresso. I'm still learning to swirl and froth the milk, but the machine delivers a potent steam stream.

This is the third Mr. Coffee espresso maker I have purchased over probably the past several years. This version of the product finally has a carafe that is sturdy enough to be used (previous ones were made of a very fragile glass that broke easily). The maker itself does not seem particularly sturdy, however. It gets the job done, but I feel that the product is designed to have a life expectancy that just exceeds the two year warranty that can be purchased with it.
reviews.review_header: This version of the product finally has a carafe that is sturdy enough to be used (previous ones were made of ...

reviews.review_text: Always liked espresso, but the stuff you get at the quickie mart always makes me sick, because it's not real. This is the real thing. Made the same way they made it for me in Italy, or Spain, only easier to use. It arrived on time, and in excellent condition. The packaging was easy to get into, in other words, it wasn't adult proof. It's actually a gift for a friend of mine, but we're keeping it at my house, so when he gets here in the morning, we can all have coffee. Yum...

We had a Krups model FND1 for many years and very satisfied with it. Eventually the boiler cap failed and we couldn't find a replacement, it was so old. Originally, we had paid $50 for the Krups. Paying over $100 for a new machine seemed ridiculous, and this Mr. Coffee seemed like the best compromise, especially since we could use the glass carafe from the old machine if we would break the new one. Lo and behold, when it arrived, the construction is exactly the same as the Krups with a few minor improvements in the knobs, the shell, etc. The boiler cap is 1/16" smaller in diameter, that's the only real difference. So we trust this machine will keep us in strong coffee and foamed milk for many more years. We were also very surprised and pleased with how quickly it was delivered, just two days even though we had selected the free shipping option. Of course, being in the next state from the warehouse may have had something to do with that. Two caveats: the plastic air siphon on the steamer wand is overkill, get rid of it, and the instructions fail to note that you must unplug the machine before releasing the pressure through the steamer wand.

Got this a year ago for just under 40$ I use it daily, sometimes twice a day Have had no problems with it Makes great mochas (Ghirardelli white chocolate powder Smuckers caramel syrup makes better white mochas then Starbucks at a fraction of the price) It can be hard to find the Ghirardelli white chocolate powder in stores so I just order it online, its still cheap. You can get 10 lbs for 50$ including shipping. Lasts a long time. Everything works the way its supposed too Follow the instructions and use the vinegar to clean it when it starts to slow down and it will keep working like new I wipe it down after each use to keep it clean, still looks like new All the parts are still strong After 1 year with the proper care its still working like new! you cant find a cheaper espresso maker. Even if you had to replace it after a year it would still be worth 40$ My parents have paid for espresso makers 4 times more then this and had nothing but problems. If this ever dies on me I'm just going to buy another one. Can't recommend this enough

A great at-home unit for those who are avid coffee drinkers and do not want to make the daily trip to your closest coffee shop. However, it is what you pay for. I've worked as a barista so my standards are a bit higher than most. Personally felt like it was not strong enough for a well-pulled expresso and the frother did not do the job.
reviews.review_header: A great at-home unit for those who are avid coffee drinkers ...

reviews.review_text: This little thing works GREAT!!! We have officially become baristas at our house and after making four venti sized cups, it has paid for itself LOL
You know, you have all them fancy espresso makers, but this one makes Americanos. Makes sense to me, easy to use, cheap.

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: I love this espresso machine works great and for the price you can't beat it. I had to return one because of the sealbut got a replacement in 1 day. Happy Customer.
reviews.review_header: I love this espresso machine works great and for the price ...

reviews.review_text: I had a mr. Coffee with steaming before and last me almost 3 years with no big issues. I bought this ones on january and still working fine. Steaming is good for a home basic coffee machine. Honestly the steaming is better than my older model ,is faster. I really enjoy the coffeea in this machine. #coffee lover.

I like this machine, not in love with it though. I am used to the steam arm not moving bc my last machine was like that. My machine came with the lame, crappy plastic steam arm condom and was missing the screw on steam arm tip. That plastic cover is USELESS and messy. Otherwise the machine functions normally.
reviews.review_header: I like this machine, not in love with it though.

reviews.review_text: This is a good little machine, but does require a bit of trial and error, I think, to get a nice cup with froth. I read reviews online which proved very helpful. One tip I followed was to purchase a stainless still pitcher to use with the frother. It was amazing the difference in the amount of froth. That being said, I discovered just using the stainless steel pitcher with a battery operated handheld frother that I already had, also produced amazing froth. So if I had to do over again, I probably would not buy the machine, and just use the handheld frother with the stainless steel pitcher, adding the froth to my coffee. I did not purchase the machine so much for espresso coffee, but for the latte feature. With my regular Mr. Coffee machine, I can make a pot of coffee and let it warm for a couple of hours without tending to it. With this espresso machine, you make a cup or 2 at a time, and drink immediately. But, it does make a nice strong espresso coffee, if that is what you are mostly interested in. As for delivery, Amazon proved once again to be quick and efficient.
reviews.review_header: Mr. Coffee ECM160 4-Cup Steam Espresso Machine

reviews.review_text: I owned a Mr. Coffee espresso machine about eight years ago, and I was pleased the way it functioned. I gave it to a family member because I turned them onto making lattes. Right now I have a Krups espresso machine that I bought after I gave the other one away. I was satisfied the way the first Mr. Coffee functioned, so I bought this updated Mr. Coffee espresso machine for a friend of mine.

This espresso machine is A-mazing! I bought the recommended tamper and 12 oz. pitcher to go with it. I fill the pitcher up just about 1/2 way and when I steam the milk, I get so much froth it almost overflows! The key to small frothy bubbles is to keep the steam handle fully emersed in the milk. To have enough steam you need to add about 2 to 3 ounces extra water to the water reservoir (if making 4 cups I usually fill the espresso pitcher to the top of the metal band). When the espresso has brewed the requested # of cups simply switch the power to steam from brew (less mess if the frothing arm is in the pitcher ready to go when you do this). If you follow the directions, clean after each use (Especially the frothing arm...immerse in water and run a small steam cycle after each use and scrub with a scrubbing sponge), and this will be a great addition to your kitchen for a long time! We are hooked. My husband is already talking about getting rid of the coffee maker! Love it!!!
Super nice system that is easy to use!! We have tried it a few times and have not been disappointed!!
For the price makes a great cup of coffee saved a lot instead of going to the coffee shop Paid for it self in saving cheap price but works that is all you need

I love my espresso maker, it makes great espresso. The only downside to this product is the built in milk frother is useless as a frother, but that's not its fault. Frothing milk properly for a latte or cappuccino requires more than just blowing a little compressed hot air into the milk. The good news is that the frother setting isn't useless, it makes an important pressure release valve so you can safely turn it off and unscrew the lid after you've unplugged it and used the frother to expel all the excess pressure, avoiding steam burns. Over all, I gave this espresso maker a 5 because for its price, it's hard to find a comparable espresso maker. It makes good espresso, and that's all it does. The fact that it only makes espresso is actually a plus in my book, complicated latte and cappuccino makers with internal milk bags and creamer are a huge pain to clean and always get clogged. This espresso maker has simple cleaning instructions, and only requires a full cleaning about every other month, and it's fairly simple to do. It's a good simple, durable, easy to clean espresso maker and I love it!

We originally purchased a DeLonghi machine that was about 3 times the price of this one on sale. It worked for a dozen cups of coffee before dying, and was difficult to clean. This machine makes excellent coffee, has not pump to maintain, and my wife says it makes better coffee than the more expensive machine. This machine comes apart easily and is very easy to maintain. The only problem my wife has run into with it is figuring out the steamer function, but that's likely just an issue of not reading the directions...

name: Mr. Coffee 4-Cup Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother

reviews.review_text: We've had this since Christmas, and so far, my wife is loving it! Very reasonable price, and it makes the Espresso coffee as my wife was hoping. All the parts worked out of the box, and there are instructions just in case you're not sure how to work it (like me!) So far, I'm very happy for this purchase. It also is fairly small, so it doesn't take up too much space on the counter, which is something to consider. Good product for a good price (unless you are a high end espresso snob or something, which neither my wife or I am not).
reviews.review_header: Good Espresso Machine at a Reasonable Price

reviews.review_text: Bought this product and followed the instructions on making Cappucino and Latte. Instruction says brew and switch to steam frothing. Did not work. Reverse the process. Put the desired amount of cups in the machine and turn on to steam. Frothing works great in this process and once you get the frothing you want, then switch to brew. Clean the frothing machine after each use to be ready for the next one.
reviews.review_header: Frothing works great in this process and once you get the frothing ...

reviews.review_text: I was having mocha and Bob Marley withdrawals and I had to buy this, it still holds up I just don't know how to make the fancy foam art yet, still practicing
reviews.review_header: Caffeined here, ha ha, great for its price

reviews.review_text: For what it is this thing works really well. We have used it a lot now and it works flawlessly.
reviews.review_header: For what it is this thing works really well. ...

reviews.review_text: Once you've had expresso and cappuccino made with this, you'll never drink regular-brewed coffee again! It's construction is very impressive! I'll place my fresh-brewed expresso or cappuccino coffee up against Starbucks any time. Even the generic brands of coffee brew up just as good as the more expensive name-brand varieties! It's unusual for me to be as excited over a product, but I you would like to talk to me about this coffee-maker, call me, Jim, at 423-653-5937.
reviews.review_header: Once you've had expresso and cappuccino made with this, ...

reviews.review_text: I was very nervous about buying such an inexpensive espresso machine, but was convinced by all the great reviews here. I was not disappointed! This machine paid for itself in about a week and makes delicious lattes! Don't bother buying a tamper or a milk jug, a mug and the coffee scoop/tamper that are included with the machine work just perfectly. Tip: After steaming the milk clean the milk steaming part of the machine IMMEDIATELY with a wet rag. Makes cleaning the machine a cinch as well. Can't say enough good things about this machine.

For the price point, this is a wonderful little machine! I used it to make lattes on the weekends and it consistently performs its duties quite well. It is a little slow on the espresso brewing, but it gets the job done better than the previous machine I had. It steams milk in a reasonable amount of time. Keep in mind that this is not a terribly expensive machine and you are not going to get top of the line functionality. If you are patient and kind of like the process of making your morning lattes, this little machine is a sure bet.
Excellent first espresso machine. I feel like the mayor of iced americanoville.

I would not call myself a true purist of coffee, that being said I am frugal with my money and I do love my espresso so when I say this coffee maker can put out a shot of espresso or more extravagant drink as good if not better than any coffee store that I have been to, I know what it means. It is fairly cheap and it is very easy to use. I have only owned the thing for a week so I cannot speak to durability.
