The Delongi has been in use for over six months, and I have made a couple of modifications to address design shortcomings: 1. The issue with the frothing tube being unable to easily accommodate a 12" pitcher was solved by raising the height of the machine by setting it up on stacked, glued-together ceramic tiles, which I then placed on a thin piece of flexible plastic used to put under rugs so they don't slip. Machine raised; problem solved. 2. The plastic frothing nozzle threads can easily be worn so steam escapes from the top. It was advised that the nozzle be removed after each use, but I didn't want to deal with the stripped threads at a later date. So after each use, I run a pitcher of clear water under the frother, turn it on, and let the water spit and froth up, cleaning the inside without having to remove said nozzle. 3. I hardly ever have to heat it up beyond 5 min. or so, and it works great. 4. Forget the cold milk thing. I'm crazy about half espresso/half milk. So I put the amount of water I want, right out of the tap, then add skim milk powder....mix it up and hit it with the steam. The forth is so dense it comes straight up over the side of the pitcher! You may not like it that stiff, but it's a suggestion for those who do. 5. Try an Italian roast coffee....darker and sweeter. Mmmmmm. When this baby dies, I will replace it with the same machine. A lot of bang for the buck here. It's a great product.

The main issues with the machine have been mentioned in several reviews. The steaming wand is hard to use with the space supplied underneath even with it swung out. I had to put the machine up on a 6" platform to make it easier. I purchased a 10oz steamer cup but it was too tall until I raised the machine up... even then I found a 2 cup pyrex measuring cup worked best for the froth of the steam milk as it gave more volume to get the frothy milk. The machine is easy to clean. I typically just fill the pyrex measuring cup with water and run the steam to clean out after each usage. So I am not taking the plastic steamer piece off as it seems the threads will strip doing this alot. It produces nice espresso and frothy milk... so it is a keeper at this price! If DeLonghi would just increase the space where the cups go it would make it nicer!!

This is my second one. After 3 years of daily use, sometimes making 3-4 drinks, my last one started having issues. So I bought a new one. Love it. I have a routine down, takes me about 3 minutes and I have a wonderful latte in my hands. Faster than a coffee pot. And as for the reviews of having a hard time getting the coffee out, please remember this is not designed to be a professional espresso machine. The only time I had problems with getting the grounds out was when a pro barista took over and put too much weight on the grounds. She was told to keep her hands off my machine.

For the money this may just be the best espresso machine on the market. I bought this for my daughter's Christmas gift and she loves it! She even packs it up for weekends away from home! Lol.. seriously, I consider her taste and mine to be reasonably refined and we are both very pleased. This compact machine makes a delicious espresso with a thick layer of crema and the frother works perfectly to steam and/or froth your milk to create your favorite espresso/capuccino/latte... Don't hesitate to buy this machine in spite of the bad reviews some have posted. After all, most people who post do so because they have had a bad experience... So out of 1,000 happy customers maybe 50 would write reviews - most of them because (like me)they enjoy telling the world what they should do..lol and out of 1,000 Unhappy customers more like say 500 would write a review because, let's face it, people like to complain - mostly in the form of public service.. ;) I'm not saying that there aren't some legitimate issues with certain specific machines. I'm just saying maybe look into what people are saying about the manufacturer's customer service and return policy as opposed to looking for that ever illusive five star rated item (those people were compensated for their "honest" and "unbiased" reviews) Lol
reviews.review_header: For the money this may just be the best espresso machine on the market

reviews.review_text: I have been using a Salton Three For All steam espresso machine for about 30 years (yes, the same machine). I could never bring myself to spend the money on a pump machine (they used to be really expensive). I decided I really needed to upgrade, so I did some research and found this machine is highly recommended all over the internet. Here is my experience with this machine: The instructions that come with the machine are almost completely useless. Really. I learned how to use it from YouTube and Amazon reviews and questions and answers. I let the machine warm up for 20 minutes, followed the instruction booklet to make espresso, and nothing happened. I watched YouTube videos, I searched the web for instructions, and found nothing. Finally I read the questions and answers here on Amazon - WOW, you folks are super helpful. I followed one person's recommendation of putting some water into the machine's reservoir, and pulling the reservoir out and re-inserting it a few times - then turn the dial on the machine to the steam function, turn the steam dial on top and run it till water comes out of the steam wand. This primed the machine and, yay, out came espresso! Now it works perfectly every time with no additional priming needed. Now I leave the reservoir in place and just refill it through the top of the machine. I saw a YouTube video where a guy had his machine set on top of a rectangular Pyrex baking dish and this is a good idea, I do the same. I might build a nice stand of some kind because the machine is not exactly the right size for the baking dish and I wouldn't mind something that looks nicer. I don't understand everyone's problem with the tamper on the machine. This thing is great! I scoop the coffee into the filter, then, holding the filter with my fingers, place a thumb on the tamper and pinch the filter and tamper together to tamp the coffee. You can go as firm or as light as you want. I can't see buying another gadget just to smoosh my coffee into the basket. The steamer wand is the ONLY thing on this machine I take issue with and I really don't like it. The wand has an internal spring holding it to the machine, so if I pull the wand out to steam the milk, it springs back and drips milk all over the machine before I can get a cloth to clean it. It also has a bend that doesn't allow the tip to get into a deep container, yet if the container is too shallow, the milk can overflow as it is steaming and expanding. It's not quite a deal breaker for me, but it is irritating. I steam my milk in a coffee cup or a pyrex measuring cup. I can't justify buying a pitcher just to steam milk. The clearance under the filter holder is very low - 2 & 1/2 inches or 6.35 cm. I use a large shot glass and it works great for me. A small cappuccino cup or a demitasse would definitely fit. The machine takes time to warm up. I turn it on in the morning, go do something else for a few minutes, then come back and make my coffee. I have to hold the cup while the machine makes the espresso - the machine vibrates and the cup moves back away from the coffee spouts - I have to hold it in place. I have a bag of Caffe D'Arte "Taormina" coffee and I ground up some with my blade grinder and made an espresso. The sky opened up and the angels sang! It was great. Then I went out and bought some illy and some Lavazza, already ground, in a can. I made some espresso with each and it was truly, honestly, awful. I just did a test this morning with all three coffees, tamping lightly and tamping heavily, and the Caffe D'Arte wins, with illy coming in second. The Lavazza just tasted super bitter. Maybe it's because it's already ground and has been sitting around a while - no telling how long the cans have been sitting on the shelf. The D'arte is roasted in Seattle, I live in Portland, and I ground it myself, so it's got to be fresher than coffee roasted and ground in Italy then shipped here. All in all, this machine is great for the price, especially as a Warehouse Deal. I've had it a week and I like it, but I would want some things to be different when this one retires and I need to shop for another one. I'll comment on longevity after using it a while.

I like it for my at home use, but it has its issues. The distance between the underside of the top of the machine and the bottom where you would sit a frothing pitcher is short. Its short short short. So much so that whenever I use the machine, I have to drag the machine to the edge of my counter, turn it sideways where it is parallel to my counter, so that I can steam the milk. The machine is just not tall enough to put and pull a frothing pitcher out. You have to be on the edge of a counter. Otherwise you won't be able to easily maneuver a pitcher to steam the milk. I bought a 12 oz pitcher which is the smallest pretty much, because anything bigger is just not going to work here. Look at the pictures in the ads. The only way to maneuver the pitcher in and out of the frothing wand is if you have it hanging off the edge of your counter It vibrates. When I put my shot cups under the machine and the shots begin to pull, it shakes and the cups shift a but. You have to hold them until the espresso shot starts to pull. The machine is just not substantial enough to stay put so yes your cups will shift until there there is something in it to keep it still. Thats about it for me for this machine. The shots it pulls are flavorful and I enjoy them. I dont understand what people mean by the tamp "sucks". Most people use the back of spoon or something--the attached tamp serves its purpose.You dont have to refill the reservoir often which is great--for at home use, this is a great and affordable machine. This is 2 months after having it so hopefully it will maintain.
reviews.review_header: Dig it but it has its nuances.

reviews.review_text: Not knowing much about coffee or how to make it, only knowing that spending $5 every morning was too expensive a life for me, I read several reviews about espresso machines. Let me tell you people on Amazon have strong opinions about coffee! Espresso machines that some people raved about, others despised with all the loathing of their being. As someone who trusts reviews to give me the real deal, this made getting an espresso machine a very difficult decision. I'm not sure what finally tipped the scale in this particular product's favor (several months have passed), but I bought this one. I freaking love it. It's really easy to use, and to clean. There's nothing I don't like. And I've already saved the amount of money on this espresso that I would have spent on morning coffees from a coffee stand.

This espresso machine is AMAZING for the price! I did a lot of research before buying an espresso machine and it came down to this one or another that was over $800. This is my first espresso machine and my coffee tastes like I bought it from the coffee shop. I've had it for about 3 weeks and use it daily. This machine is super easy to navigate and use. I was able to make the perfect latte on my first try without having any experience in using an espresso machine before. I mostly make lattes but I've been experimenting with making frappes. I love how easy it is to use and clean. The water reservoir holds more than enough water and is easily removable for refilling, or you can just add water to it, using a cup (easier and less time consuming). The manual says to let it heat up for 15 mins before using it but it's usually ready after about 2-3 minutes. I've heard people say the espresso turns out better if you let it warm up longer, but I think it's perfectly fine after only a few minutes. The machine is small but I have no issue with it. My milk frothing pitcher fits perfectly under the steamer, just make sure you don't buy a pitcher that is too large; there's really no need. I don't really use the top for warming my cups but I've touched it before and it does get pretty warm. I really don't know how I was surviving before I got an espresso machine. Tip: If you can't seem to get the espresso to come out when you first try it, make sure the steamer knob is turned completely off. The first day I got my De'Longhi I thought it was broken; I tried everything to get it to work. I eventually tried the steamer to see if it worked and it did. I turned the steamer off and tried the espresso again and voila! it worked!

Hesitant to get a smaller espresso machine yet not wanting to spend over $200 for one of the more robust looking machines. After MANY uses, I really like my new De'Longhi machine. It is actually very solidly built, great pressure and easy to use. It's small enogh for apartment counter space and it's smaller than my Keurig AND you aren't filling the landfills with all those darn empty kcups- that fact alone made me get this. Well, that AND saving a LOT of money from driving to and buying the exact same drink at a retail where they expect a tip for handing you a drink. SAVE YOURSELF A LOT OF MONEY and make your own espresso drinks! Be sure to buy a good tamper (the thing on here is not adequate) as you MUST tamp down the espresso at 35 lbs of force to get it tight to extrude the best, strongest espresso. And if you plan to froth, get yourself a good milk pitcher. I use it 1-2 x every day and so far it is a great thing! If it changes, I'll update, but for now, I'd HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

It make a great cup of coffee as well as espresso. Not a purist here and most of the time I use medium roast coffee that I grind myself in a regular grinder at work . When I need espresso strength then its there. I have a $500 version of another brand that looks expensive , grinds the espresso and does a great cappuccino as well but takes up a lot of space and well its 500 dollars . This model looks okay although the metal grate is already scratched after a few days and shakes on the counter top when pumping out the coffee. But to be honest the coffee is even better than my 500 dollar version so its well worth it. It has built in tamper which works just fine and a steamer that works well but I dont really use it that much for that.
reviews.review_header: Great tasting cup of coffee that exceeds a much higher priced coffee machine.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I am certainly not an expert judge for home espresso machines. During the last 5 years I have had 3 Mr. Coffee espresso makers; 3 because the plastic parts on the carafe keep breaking, and one machine burned out after only 6 months. The coffee from them was just that: Coffee. No froth. I kept buying them from my local Bi-mart store here in Oregon, and they were cheap. I finally decided to spend more money and ordered this DeLonghi EC155 after researching reviews on the net. I have no way of knowing if a $300 or $400 home espresso maker makes better espresso, but I am very happy with my $100 plus shipping DeLonghi. The coffee looks and tastes like that from commercial coffee houses. There are a couple quirks regarding the design that I don't care for, but they are not deal breakers. The space allowed for the cup to fit under is simply too short. I had to go to Goodwill to find the right size of cup or carafe that would fit underneath. Yes, I could have ordered the ones advertised from the DeLonghi company, but I chose not to. Also, the vibration from the pump tends to move the small container around a little, which requires me to hold it in place before enough coffee dispenses to hold it in place. I have yet to use the milk frother. I prefer hearting milk in the microwave, mixing my additives into that when hot, and then pouring in the coffee which has very nice froth and crèma. This also saves me from cleaning the frother. I needed a compact design for my space requirements, and this is a perfect size for that. Don't let the maintenance instructions deter you. They sound intimidating until you see what they are talking about. I absolutely recommend this machine.
reviews.review_header: Coffee house espresso taste on a small budget

reviews.review_text: My husband just discovered a love for coffee and espresso after our twins were born last year. Like everything else he has to have the best of the best and after doing extensive research decided to purchase this. I love my old drip coffee maker and vowed to stay true to Mr. Coffee but after two weeks in our home I have found myself cheating on him with our De'Longhi - and for good reason! It makes a delicious shot with a beautiful crema, is super easy to use once you know what you're doing and clean up is a breeze. I love that I don't have to refill the water tank before each use, it takes just a minute or so to heat up and less than 30 seconds to fill the cup. With it being October I have been able to satisfy my craving without breaking the bank by making pumpkin spice double shot lattes at home every morning! My only complaint is the frothing wand is too low and it is hard to find a cup that will fit under it and still contain the milk I need for my latte. We put it on top of a box we had laying around and that works until we get our hands on a pitcher (assuming that will fit). Other than that it makes a perfect frothy steamed milk in no time. Also, when we first got it we thought it was broken and were ready to send it back. It was awfully loud and would not heat up. Thankfully it was bedtime for the twins so we just left it to do its' thing and when we came back we were happy to see it just needed a little more time to warm up. It has worked perfectly since then. After reading some other reviews I am hoping it lasts but will update if there are any issues down the road. Excellent product, great value, highly recommend!

This espresso maker works very well! It brews a strong espresso and the steam comes out hot so I can steam my milk quickly. This product comes with a single shot or double shot insert for the coffee grounds. I always use the double as I find the single is too small and does not make enough for my coffee needs. It is very easy to use and holds plenty of water in the reservoir for multiple cups of espresso. My only complaints are that the machine vibrates so much the cup I use to catch the espresso must be constantly held or it will rattle right off the base. Also, the steamer is so close to the bottom it is hard to get a steamer cup out without spilling once the volume in the cup has increased. A few flaws, but works fine if these are not issues for you. I would probably spend a little more money in the future to get something better, but this is great for the price range.

things to keep in mind, this is a light duty machine, meant to fulfill the needs of one or two coffee addicts, not a starbucks. the wand for frothing is short, a 12oz pitcher is fine the tamper is meah, get a 52mm tamper, be aware that a good tamp with this machine takes a long time for extraction it can do single, double or ese pods, the large gasket in the single shot basket needs to be swapped for the smaller one (included in the double shot basket) for a single shot. rule of thumb, if you are using grounds, small gasket. the large gasket is for ese pods, otherwise you won't be able to fit 7 grams. some reviews complain that the single shots were watered down, i suspect the large gasket is the reason, it does take up about 2 grams of space. the ese pods work great, this machine also has a good aftermarket following for customization and parts the drip tray could have been better if it slid directly out, you have to tilt to remove it. everything is manual so you'll have to count to 26 and purge before and after the shot to keep the pump clean over time, theres no backflush on this. frothing wand again is small but works pretty well, prime the wand and wait for it to stop spurting water. try not to switch back and forth between froth and extract, it takes time to reprime and you are running a dry pump during that. temps between froth and extract are different too. cup heater works, takes about a half hour of standby heat and has a lip that keep cups in place, although using the purge water from pre extraction is a much faster way to bring your cups up to temperature. wash out the water tank monthly with regular use using a 1/4 c vinegar and water run a tank or even two when you first get the machine, shavings and fluid may be seen, this is typical
reviews.review_header: great machine for singles or couples

reviews.review_text: Definitely thE best small, manual espresso machine I have owned. Great espresso using less coffee. Reasons for 4 stars: 1. Does not come with a carafe. Don't buy one; it won't fit. Purchase espresso shot glasses instead. (You can make just one at a time.) 2. The portafilter/coffee basket is difficult to install. Rather than placing a hand on top of the machine to steady it while you twist/lock the portafilter/coffee basket in place, the machine is so lightweight that you have to hold the machine in place while trying to lock in the filter/basket. This can be tricky. For my family, definitely worth it!!
reviews.review_header: Excellent espresso! Just a couple of Cons....

reviews.review_text: The EC155 appears to be a great little machine. When I received the package, I was shocked at how small this machine is! But it is a powerful micro espresso factory! The 1st shot was full bodied and flavorful, with great crema! All the shots have keepers, so far. I bought this machine to hold me over until a part for my 10X more expensive machine comes in from Italy! The part cost more than the EC155! I'm not saying this produces espresso shots as good as a $1200 machine, but it ain't bad at $1100 less!! I can definitely live with it! This machine a great, affordable countertop wonder! I'll continue to use the De'Longhi EC155 after my big machine is back in action. I'll just move the De'Longhi to my studio, as a daily workhorse! As long as I pay attention to the proper 1oz or 2oz shots, use correct grind & tamp (not the standard 30-35lb, just a nice firm tamp like the instructions say), with good quality fresh ground beans, I think it'll serve me well! The milk steamer works well too! The only complaint I have with the machine is that the panarello tip is plastic! Charge $2 more, give us a stainless steel tip, otherwise, no problems! If you are in the market for a cheap, well made espresso machine, take a look at the EC155. I recommend the De'Longhi EC155.
reviews.review_header: The EC155 appears to be a great little machine

reviews.review_text: My wife uses this espresso maker everyday, and it works great. The first time you make espresso with the machine will be a learning process, but it's not rocket surgery. Follow the directions included and you should be fine. Don't believe all the propaganda about tamping to exactly 35lbs of pressure or using a coffee grinder everytime you brew. All of that is nice, but this machine works fine without overly complicating things. Follow the instructions...or watch a youtube video if you don't like reading. Your espresso will, most likely, turn out fine. The best part will be you didn't spend $500 on an espresso machine ... which may make your beverage even more tasty.
reviews.review_header: and it works great. The first time you make espresso with the ...

reviews.review_text: I love espresso, and this little baby makes a great cup. Here are a few points that might be useful for you to know: Good points: *It doesn't take up too much room on the counter and looks nice with it's silver metal accents. *The water reservoir is a good size, you can make about 8-10 shots before you need to refill it, which is very easy to do, and there is a clear section behind the basket which shows the water level. *Fast heat-up time (only about a minute), good frothing wand, no wait time between frothing and brewing (though you do have to wait a little between brewing and frothing). Be warned: *Frothing wand is only 3 1/4 inches from the counter top. Not a big deal, I just went and bought a frothing cup that is about that height. *Distance from grounds basket to tray is only 2 1/2 inches, I usually use a small espresso cup. *Built-in tamper sucks, buy a good metal one. *You don't end up with a nice dry puck, the grounds basket is a watery soup after your espresso is made, so I dump it down the disposal. *You will end up drinking more espresso than you mean to, it's that good! Seriously, I chose this machine after a lot of online researching, and decided on this one based on its outstanding reviews and great price. What led me to it were the reviews of another DeLonghi, the EC140B, which is an older and less attractive model, but had reviews from people who had owned theirs for 6 and 10 years! I'm hoping that this one will have the same longevity. -----> UPDATE: I've now had this machine for 8 months and it started running very slow. I'd been using only distilled water, so I knew it wasn't a calcification issue, so I looked into it and it turns out machines like this one (no backflushing) need to be cleaned every month or so to remove built up grounds that work their way inside the machine. So I ran some cleaner through it and all this nasty brownish liquid came out, and now it runs great again! So remember people, take good care of your things and they will take good care of you. A lesson I am still learning... - and to answer a question commented on this review, my tamper is 2 inches in diameter.

I just received the DéLonghi EC155 and was pleasantly surprised how easy the initial cleaning and setup went. I did not receive any discount or incentive in the purchase of the unit. Packaging was simple and easy to open. The unit was well protected for shipment and had no issues on unpacking. I am extremely happy with the easy of use of the EC155, and with the taste and appearance of the espresso. Having read the other reviews, I was careful to seat the water reservoir properly and to follow the initial cleaning instructions. Within 15 minutes of opening the box, I was enjoying a very nice espresso. Yes, it did vibrate and rattle a bit while brewing, but it was relatively quiet compared to other espresso machines I have experienced. It is far quieter than a coffee mill or most other kitchen appliances. It did not wake my wife sleeping near bye. The crema was dark and rich and the taste was full bodied with no hint of excessive heat damaging the brew. Overall, I could not be more pleased with the DéLonghi EC155 in its initial use. I will update this review if I have and additional information or problems.
reviews.review_header: Very good Espresso at a bargain price

reviews.review_text: This is a great espresso machine and it's the biggest bang for your buck. I have been using this machine for 8 months and I have no complaints. If you follow the instructions for use, you will be making your favorite cafe drinks in no time. On average I make 10-12 medium drinks a week. (One for me, One for my wife.) There are some who complain you have to wait 15 minutes for the machine to draw your first shot. It's not a big deal. I usually turn the machine while I'm getting ready in the morning and then make my drinks. I have pulled quality shots at just under 10 minutes. The tamper works great. If you are looking for an affordable espresso machine that makes great cafe inspired drinks I would highly recommend this Delonghi espresso machine. You will not be dissapointed and will save yourself a lot of time and money going to your local coffee house. Enjoy! Ciao!!
reviews.review_header: 8 months and loving my espresso machine!

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: Before the review, I should mention coffee is serious stuff around my house. I roast my own carefully selected coffee in more than one way depending on the flavor profile I am trying to achieve. I grind my own coffee immediately before I brew my coffee, and I brew such coffee in a variety of ways depending on the coffee itself, situation, number of people, etc. I have a variety of different french presses, pour overs, a very portable Primula, the Hario cold coffee brewer, an immersion Bonavita, an Oxo Barista Brain, and even one of those horrible Keurigs in my house. So I have a good idea about coffee taste, if it is still personal opinion. I do not drink a lot of espresso, but wanted to have the ability of doing it at home. This had the best reviews all over, unless compared to expensive machines, most of them over twenty times the price of this one, which I would never pay. It is a pressure machine, so unless you modify it (not recommended), you cannot "dial" your shots (as in altering substantially the espresso by playing with the grind settings). It is very simple once you figure out the direction of the filter on the porta filter (made that mistake); quick, and it makes a very good looking espresso (or two - it comes with a single and a double filter), with an impressive amount and appearance of crema for such a cheap machine. The coffee tastes very good, the machine is very easy to clean. It occupies very little space and is very light (which can be a little problem as you have to hold the base to twist the porta filter). The water basket is removal which makes it very easy to fill it up. Is it perfect? Of course not. It is made of cheap plastic, and although the espresso is very good, it certainly does not match a 5K machine. It is also very short, which can be a problem when you try to fit a milk frother to make cappuccinos (I have not, but the height is REALLY limited). I also do not know how long this will last, but given the price range, easy of use, and taste, I am very happy.

First what I think could be improved: First: It vibrates... a lot. I have to hold my espresso cup in place and rest my hand on top of the unit to reduce the vibration. Second: There's not much clearance for your espresso cup. You can't install the coffee filter with a cup already underneath. Yes, I have three sizes of espresso cups and they all fit fine. You won't be able to fit your tea cup or mug to catch the coffee to make your cappuccino, if thats what you plan on doing. However, you can do it like they do in the bar... froth/steam your milk in your mug then pour your espresso in. Third: The coffee filter comes right out when you turn it over to empty it. I have to grab it in one hand and when it's still moist I have to use my finger to empty it into the trash. You wan't be able to "bump" it out like they do in the bar. What I like: * It's nice and small; it doesn't take up much space * It's a real espresso maker (15bar) which means if you use the correct espresso grind you can get a perfect espresso with cream and all! I can make a mean moka, but this machine makes the my moka espressos look and taste sad. :) * It heats up quick. I usually place a cup under the outlet without the coffee while the water is heating up to let the colder water drip out and when the light comes on I put the coffee in and put a new espresso cup I pre heated in the sink with hot water. (I like mine hot) * It includes a second coffee filter that has twice the capacity for when you are making one for a friend or if you prefer, a double espresso
reviews.review_header: With the correct grind... Just as good as the bar

reviews.review_text: I work at a family owned appliance dealership and we sell high end automatic coffee systems. I can't afford or justify the expense of one of these systems, but I have come to appreciate a coffee brewed by forcing hot water through a "puck" of fine coffee grounds. The flavor and "crema" really is hard to beat. This machine requires that I do the work myself, but brews coffee in the same way that our high end machines do, resulting in a fine cup of espresso or lattes. There are a few cons. Most notably, this is an italian made machine, intended for small european espresso cups. A standard coffee mug will not fit and our large 16 oz mugs won't even begin to fit. I remedied this by purchasing a 12 oz stainless milk frothing pitcher and a 5 oz stainless cream pitcher, both from amazon for several dollars each. The 12 oz frothing pitcher just so fits under the frothing wand and the 5 oz cream pitcher fits nicely under the brew unit. I brew the espresso into the cream pitcher and dump it into a preheated mug, then froth the milk in the frothing pitcher and add it to the mug. It's an extra step, but it is very doable and it's a small price to pay for quality espresso from an affordable machine. Temperature is a bit of a struggle, but it is possible to get a good hot latte if you preheat your mug with hot water. Overall my wife and I are happy with this machine and would recommend it to anyone willing to spend 3 minutes on a great cup of Joe.
reviews.review_header: Great espresso at an affordable price

reviews.review_text: I've used two of these machines for over a year, both at work and at home. If you want an inexpensive, basic espresso machine then this is a great choice. It's compact, simple and makes a pretty decent cup of espresso. The steamer also works great as long as you don't need silky perfection. As stated in other reviews there are some compromises. You'll need a not-too-tall espresso cup, a smallish frothing pitcher, and you might want to invest in a metal tamper as well. Heat up and steam times are very reasonable, and I've had no issues with either machine (descaled both of them once over the course of a year). One comment on the brew baskets. The ones that come with this machine are pressure compensated which means they are forgiving with respect to dose, grind size and tamping. Some reviews recommend removing the pressure valve. Do that only if you are willing to spend time "dialing in" the machine with respect to dose, grind and tamping. If you are using pre-ground coffee (even if advertised as "espresso grind"), or don't want to hassle with this, then leave the baskets alone. Yes, you can get better shots if you put in the time, but I suspect for the many people that just want a double espresso for their latte, the out-of-the-box experience is the better choice. And finally, periodically you need to remove the mesh screen at the top of the brew head (where the water comes out) and clean it. It is held in place with a phillips head screw. Over time coffee and grinds back up into this screen and a buildup forms that can impede water flow. Also you should descale the machine periodically if you want it to last. I enjoyed my EC155 so much that I've upgraded to a Breville BES870XL at home. The Breville is a step up in all areas, but for 1/6th the cost it's tough to beat this DeLonghi if you are just starting out.
reviews.review_header: Best bang for the buck espresso machine out there.

reviews.review_text: I usually refrain from writing and reading reviews, but as a long time Espresso drinker who has owned several machines and whose friends owned various machines, figured this could be usual to someone. This machine will give you the most bang for your buck. To find a better machine to make simple espresso daily you will have to spend at least double, if not triple the money. This machine, like almost all other low priced non commercial models, does not have the brass boiler necessary to be considered 'high end' or even professional. So why spend $150, $200, or even $300 for something that isnt up to par when you can buy this little guy. They usually work solidly and last for about a year before beginning to wane. You will see a decrease in pressure and after about a year descaling will do very little to help performance. But for that year you- you get a dam good espresso for the price....

This is currently the least expensive home espresso machine I know of. I drink 48 ounces of latte per day. If you are an experienced home barista on a budget, this is a great machine. I also own a Pavoni la Picollo, but I use the daLonghi daily. Pro: easy to use. Requires minimal counter space. Once you perfect your technique, you can make better drinks that you can buy at any espresso stand. Con: The system for suppressing the steam flow starts to let water leak out after a few years of daily use. You can stretch out its useful life for another year or so with hacks, but this part of the machine cannot be repaired. Also, older versions of this model had a larger H2O capacity and could easily accommodate a large steaming vessel. At the sub-$100 price, I just buy a new one every 4 years. I generally keep parts like the coffee baskets and steamer nozzle, etc. My cost works out to about $25/year. The milk, coffee, etc for 48 ounces of latte cost less than 50 cents. Two 20 ounce lattes at a stand cost $6-$8.You do the math on how much you save. And it takes no longer than walking to an espresso stand, waiting for your order and then walking home. Last year I bought a Tesla with what I have saved on lattes in the last decade. Buy this machine.
reviews.review_header: Buy this machine if you love latte and want to buy a new car in ten yeats

reviews.review_text: It's fantastic. It makes great espresso, incredible lattes and cappuccinos. It's a great price. Some of the negatives are just silly. Here's a few of them: 1. People don't like the tamper. Really? Then buy a tamper. But honestly the built in one is fine. 2. It's too light. Well, it is true it is on the light side, but if it was too heavy people would complain the other way. "This thing is so heavy!". It's fine. 3. it's too low. It isn't too low for me, but if it is too low for you get a piece of tupperware or something to use as a pedestal. What's that cost $5? Want to get fancy? Get one of those $15 pedestals meant for Kuerig machines and keep spoons and sugar packs in there, or something. Better than getting a more expensive machine. The only reason why I didn't give it 5 stars is I've used a $500 machine and it was more awesome. But not 500% more awesome. So unless you are a millionaire who wants to waste money, get the mostly awesome De'Longhi.

i REALLY love it. i initially ordered a steam based cheap espresso maker, and wasn't satisfied with the performance. After 4 weeks, i decided to plunge down a bit more, with the help of a bit of research, i settled on this EC155. MAKE SURE you PUSH the reservoir bucket DOWN into the unit. it takes a bit of force. But you need to push it down until you hear a click, otherwise you'd be standing there trying to figure out why there's nothing coming out, and nothing is frothing. Pros: the most notable pros that really hit home for me with this unit is it's constancy with frothing. it always comes out perfect, thanks to the powerful 15 bar pump system. i also like the self adjustable valve that allows you to start the pressure low and quickly ramp up as you need. it's simple to use. one knob, one valve. you don't need the manual to figure it out. The Cons i can think of: it's really too bad that the two filters included are not enough to make a double shot equivalent Grande starbucks cup. the biggest filter that's included with the package is only enough to make a Tall size latte. i have a bunch of reusable starbucks grande cups at home, so i use it as a reference. you would have to brew the espress twice to make a grande starbucks cup. the frothing tube IS pretty short. i can see how that can be a problem for most people with regular sized tin cup. for me i use a glass unit that isn't very deep in depth, and therefore fit perfectly. The outlet where the espresso comes out also is pretty short, which could be a problem for some. my espresso cups just fits under it. Edit: May, 8, 2017 ok, after about two years constantly using this thing, probably twice a day at least, it's starting to show signs of wear. i think some kind of seal inside is wearing out, because now everytime after i turn off the pump after the espresso reaches the top, the nozzle continues to drip a lot. so i think some kind of internal valve is starting to wear out. my only other biggest annoyance is the frothing nozzle is too low. i pointed this out in the very beginning and it's still an annoyance. you really just have to get a small stainless steel frothing cup. there is no way around it. the unit shakes quite a bit while pumping out the espresso, so it makes the cup move. you'll have to hold the cup. overall, for the price, and the abuse it went through over the past two years. i would say it's a pretty good bang for the buck. i am guessing this thing might die in another year. i am already starting to look at other pump based units. i was afraid the plastic frothing nozzle might strip out from me taking it off to rins and put back on after each use, but surprisingly it hasn't. the level of crema and layer will also depend on the type of espresso bean you use, the pressure of tamper you press. the harder you press, the darker it comes out, and less golden brown. some beans will give more brown color and more crema than others too. Pete's espresso bean for example is on the more extreme spectrum of too much crema and too brown, while Star Bucks espresso bean more frequently produces the three layers of black bottom, golden middle and crema top. if you're really anal, you can get a consistent perfect cup each time by knowing your beans, and knowing your tamper pressue. but for me in such a hurry everyday, i can live with the slight variations. this makes me really appreciate the professional baristas, and the kind of effort they put in to put out consistent lattes cup after cup. with this unit, my wife and i have drank so many lattes and got to experiment with so many different kind of beans, and variations flavors of lattes (you can experiment by adding your own caramel for caramel machiatto, or Hershey's chocolate cocoa for a Mocha Latte, and many more). this unit really opens up your world without breaking the bank.
reviews.review_header: Best bang for the buck for serious espresso maker. (2 year long term update)

reviews.review_text: This espresso machine has been a workhorse for the 6 months I've owned it, delivering maybe 2-3 espressos per day for me and my family. After tinkering with the right ground espresso setting (have your coffeehouse grind the espresso on setting #4 instead of #3), I've had zero problems with this maker and it has delivered above average espresso and cappuccinos every time. I clean it out with a vinegar wash once every three months. It's definitely a cheaper espresso maker option, and it probably could be made of better materials, but it far outclasses a few other espresso makers I tried in its price range. I don't think this espresso maker will last forever, but if it lasts another 6 months I'll be very pleased, especially given how much it has saved me compared to buying my espresso at coffee houses.
reviews.review_header: Workhorse that delivers above average espresso

reviews.review_text: Great value for a 15 bar machine. I've had 2 of them over the last several years. The frother wand set up is not spectacular, and I don't bother with it. I recommend a stand-alone frother such as a Breville. If you use this strictly for the espresso, you'll be more satisfied with it. The ESE pod feature is nice - I keep some Illy decaf pods if I want an evening fix. For regular (and utterly convenient) espresso, I recommend Illy ground espresso (black label), otherwise, I use fresh beans from a local roaster and use my JavaPresse hand grinder. (Measure GENEROUSLY, and tamp really well). I have experienced occasional leakage under the unit, but it's not a deal breaker for me. I just wipe under the unit after I've cleaned up after pulling a shot. I threw out the metal grid below in order to increase the brewing space and avoid the built-in tamper - which is a hoot. And yes, it is danged loud and vibrates like hell. BUT... Overall, a pretty decent little machine, especially for those new to home espresso machines. I do eye the more expensive machines with occasional lustful thoughts (I'm looking at YOU, BREVILLE...), but the Delonghi simply does a competent job of providing good espresso, without giving me any real justification for a fancy upgrade. I'm not in love, but let's call it a plain vanilla, no frills, solid LIKE.
reviews.review_header: Produces GOOD espresso for a GREAT price.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: Five stars for the espresso that comes out, three for the design - I guess that makes four stars. I use finely ground espresso (freshly ground, usually) and tamp it down just enough, plus filtered water from the fridge. This produces wonderful flavor, great crema. For the price, you really can't ask for more. Other comparable units cost much more and, at least the ones I've had, didn't produce anything better. My gripes with this machine, after a couple of days, are: - This thing vibrates so much while brewing that you can feel it along the countertop. So the cups sitting under the filter holder are steadily dancing away from the espresso being poured unless you hold them in place as the espresso comes out. (Make sure to have one hand available to turn the knob again to stop the water from coming out, there is no auto stop.) - The filter holder cannot be aligned properly when coffee is in it. It's not that I'm using too much coffee, it's the insert that prevents the full 90-degree movement. No big deal until you don't pay attention to the dispensing holes - which are not aligned with the holes in the drip tray as a result - and have your espresso running into the drip tray instead of the cup. - The machine is not well insulated. ---- All in all, though, I'm happy with this little espresso wiz. I paid about $85 for the machine, which translates into fewer trips to the coffee shop than I've had espressos since buying the machine, so it's a good deal. Until I can afford one of the higher-priced models, I'll be perfectly content with this one. One more thing, for those of you who, like me, don't pay attention to dimensions in descriptions: There really isn't enough clearance for a regular coffee mug. If you want anything other than an espresso (like the watered down stuff called Americano), you will have to pour your beverage from a small container (espresso cup or shot glass) into a bigger cup or mug. Not a big deal but worth mentioning.
reviews.review_header: Great crema (foam layer) and wonderful flavor - see review for what's not so great

reviews.review_text: I really like this espresso machine because it's slick, compact, easy to use, brews good coffee, but I can't give it 5 stars because it's really only meant for espresso: 1. If you prefer a full cup of strong coffee, it's a little painful because even though the coffee grind holder comes in 2 sizes, the 2 sizes are too similar and neither one provides enough room to load a sufficient amount (larger holder is 2'' in diameter and 3/4'' high, if you're lucky enough to fill it without spilling any). 2. The only cups that will fit under the holder are espresso cups, the maximum height being 2 1/2 inches. 3. The "ready" light doesn't stay on long enough to fill more than one espresso cup. I've read a review that just says to ignore the "ready" light and just keep going, but then the water isn't really hot enough to extract the flavor, so it defeats the purpose. 4. My previous espresso machine would just run until all of the water was exhausted, which I liked because I didn't need to monitor the machine as it was brewing. With this one, you have to be on top of it.

So happy with my purchase! Its a great machine and so easy to use. Makes great espresso! After weeks of youtube videos and research, I choose this based on recommendations. Very happy I did! Update - its been months of daily use and this machine still surprises me with great cappuccinos and lattes. Tips I've learned: - fill the large coffee filter with 2 tablespoons of good expresso. I splurge and use Lavazza I get from Whole foods. Figure I'm saving enough not going to Starbucks anymore. - bought the tamper recommended on Amazon and it works great. Way better to compact the coffee than the one that comes with it - use Almond milk and it froths super nice - had to raise the unit for better use. A pod drawer works great and looks good too

This is a star! We have gone through two Rancillio expresso makers that were over $500 each. Each one gave out after 5-7 years of use and during all that time I was never able to get a good crema from either of them. We decided it would be too costly to mail them in for repairs as each needed a new boiler and we could not replace them ourselves. I decided to try the ROK.....no motor, no boiler, no serious parts to break down and only $200. We used it for over 2 years but with all the preheating were never able to produce a hot cup of espresso and could never get any crema at all so I yearned for the authentic flavor of a "true" espresso. The ratings on this inexpensive espresso maker were so good that I was convinced to give it a try.....I am so glad I did. It amazes us twice a day when we have our morning and evening espressos. The crema is there regardless of which coffee you use; it heats up in seconds, not minutes. It does not require a unique touch or twist to tamp the coffee, it simply and easily produces the best cup of espresso we have had in our 15 years of making them at home with some "state-of-the-art" makers. I have not used the steam wand because when we used the ROK there was no steaming mechanism available with it so I had to use a different method and have stayed with that method. It is simply using a stainless container with a top that has a plunger with a screen (the link: (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000X7GF40/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1) ; after 20-30 pumps the milk becomes frothy at which time I transfer it to a glass container and put it into the microwave for about 30 seconds and that causes it to heat and rise. You end up with fine froth and hot pourable milk which are both required for Cappuccinos. The entire process is fast and easy and we are delighted with the quality of the finished product. You can use this espresso maker to produce just one or two shots of espresso and the turn around time for making more is negligible so you can serve many people quickly. We highly recommend this small (another advantage as it takes up less space than the bigger makers out there) and very efficient espresso maker and let's face, you cannot beat the price!

Just want to say that this is easily the best espresso maker out there for the money you're paying and what you're getting. I have had the same one three years now and it's still going strong. Everything you need is there- steamer for lattes, polypropylene water reservoir, and the little compacting element on the right side is very convenient- the entire process can be done right there. Occasionally I soak the filter cups in baking soda solution, and I only use charcoal filtered water in the machine, so the taste of the espresso is still great. I have a friend who has had the same one for four years who inspired me to originally buy it! Great little machine, can't go wrong.
reviews.review_header: Hands down best bang for your buck

reviews.review_text: We bought this as an alternative to spending major $$$ on Starbucks. Starting from the beginning, assembly was a snap. All of the parts in the box were either wrapped in foam that tore easily or tape that had little edges that you could lift with your fingers. Once all of the parts were out we gave them a quick wash and then went through the cleaning cycle on the water pump and insides. The video on the amazon page covers this pretty well. In terms of spooling up espresso, the double shot hopper took a little getting used to. The opening is a standard ish size, so you just drop your espresso coffee in there and then tamp it down. I found it was easier to do this while the hopper was in the expresso arm / connection assembly (not sure what it's actually called.) After you put the coffee in it you have to kind of force it into place and then rotate the arm. You don't actually need to rotate it all the way until it's parallel with the knobs on the front, but just enough to hold it in place when the boiling water gets pumped through it. At this point you just make sure you've got water in the tank and then flip it over to "on." There's a little green light that will let you know when the water is hot enough to use. Once you get the green light you flip the knob over to brew and it'll start to pump out the coffee. It'll make about one shot glass worth of espresso before the heat runs out. Also, it will continue to pump the water through until you flip the switch back, so you'll need to pay attention to how fast the cup is filling up. If you're running a double shot you'll need to repeat the same process a second time. Pretty straight forward. After you're all done, there's a milk frother feature that works more or less the same way. Turn it to the "steaming" function to get it heated up, and then use the dial up top to control the flow of steam. I'd recommend that you blast the steam a couple times before and after using to get any moisture or cream out of the assembly. Only three gripes I have about the machine: It's really close to the ground, I had to put a box under it so I could get my frother underer the frothing wand. It's really short in general. You've got to use expresso "shot glasses" as opposed to actual coffee or espresso mugs since there's about 2.5 inches of clearance from the metal grate to the espresso hopper. You can kind of alleviate this by removing the grate, which I did. It vibrates. A LOT. When brewing espresso. You may need to hold your cup to keep it from moving around or spilling the espresso. Overall, I would recommend the machine for the price. We've had it for a couple months now and I can't speak to the longevity of the pump, but I'll update the review if I run in to any issues.
reviews.review_header: Great espresso machine for the price, frother works well, much better than going to Starbucks!

reviews.review_text: Just perfect for a wonderful creamy espresso. We thought that the steamer is hard to clean. But reading the manual :)) we found that the end of the steamer can be detached for cleaning. The steamer is also great for reheating tea. In other reviews was said that the cups would move on the metal plate. We had this at the beginning too, though don't mind to stand next to the machine for the seconds until the coffee pours out. It looks always so creamy delicious. And after a while this changed. The cup hardly moves and we don't have to hold it on the plate. The best part of this machine - beside the delicious coffee - is that we don't have to buy the extremely expensive cups. It just needs normal ground espresso. It's cheaper and we are more flexible in buying the coffee.
reviews.review_header: Just perfect for a wonderful creamy espresso

reviews.review_text: I have previously reviewed the earlier model of this espresso maker, and I gave that version 5 stars. I'm giving this version a tentative 4 star rating, only because I'm comparing it to the older version and I am adjusting to the changes! This model is a lot smaller than the previous version, which makes operating it a little difficult. I didn't have any espresso cups that would fit underneath the spout, which was a problem obviously! Currently I am using a small cup that they use in restaurants to serve sides. I am still searching for an espresso mug that is the appropriate height (it needs to be about 2.25 inches or shorter - be aware of this!). The steamer spout seems to be a little easier to operate than the previous version, as I'm not spilling quite so much milk when I try to remove it from the spout. It's still a little shorter than it could be, but it's still pretty easy to operate and no real complaints. I do like the updates in this version. It seems to be a little more "coffee shop" in appearances, as it is not so rounded and they added some more of the "stainless steel" looking features. I think it is a sexier machine than the previous one, if an espresso maker can be sexy :) I also like the water tank being underneath the back hatch, along with a place to store the extra espresso pod that comes with the device. The only issue with the back hatch is that you have to move the machine in order to open it...if your machine sits against a wall like mine does. Overall, I am thankful to have my morning espresso again...thanks to this machine. It produces a lovely cup of espresso and steams my soy milk perfectly each time. I plan to clean this machine more frequently than I did with the previous one, and hopefully I can make it last much longer than three years.
reviews.review_header: Some changes from the previous model - but still a great machine.

reviews.review_text: I've never owned an espresso machine before so I had no idea what I was doing. The directions were easy to read. The one thing that stood out to me was the directions say it needs 15 minutes to warm up and I was about to return it because mama don't have time for that, but in reality it takes maybe two minutes. Get some good espresso coffee and a taper and your own metal cup for frothing the milk. Get a shorter cup because the wand doesn't really reach down too far. I have been microwaving the milk first and that helps keep it at the perfect temp when I combine it with the coffee. The machine shakes a lot when running, which led to espresso everywhere, but I just put a dishtowel under my espresso cup and it's fine now.

It has stood the test of time, about five years that is. That's pretty good. It's still going strong. I admittedly haven't used it every day, but I keep it at work so it get's used about four times a week. No problems with leaking as some cheap espresso machines will. It is pretty plasticky in construction, but that's what you get for a sub $100 espresso machine. It takes E.S.E. pods just fine. It's everything people have said in terms of value. It's a steal overall. I wish it had a cup warmer and that I didn't have to hold on to the cup when brewing (it vibrates a lot and the cup travels if you don't hold on to it.) I normally write more thorough reviews. All I know is it makes a great shot of espresso without a lot of fuss and it's been very reliable for me. You can't go wrong with this for E.S.E. pod use.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: This is an espresso machine I would recommend for someone who wants to make espresso or latte/cappuccino at home but has budget and no intention to become a professional barista. Overall, it is a rather good bargain, and if you do have free time and are willing to change the steam wand, I believe this machine will meet most of your demands when making a good cup of Italian Coffee. 1. It can brew good espresso that has crema. 2. It does the job when frothing the milk, BUT the wand is somehow a little bit shorter, so either you change the wand or you need a rather small pitcher (one that is 10-12 oz and 3.5-3.7 inches in height would be ideal). 3. A friend of mine who has been using this machine for over 1 year says that the original wand will suffer from water leak eventually, he solved this problem by changing the wand himself, which is not a very difficult thing to do. (Or you can just change a stainless wand head, but keep the original tube of the wand) 4. If you want supreme crema, you might want to change the original filter into the non-pressurized one (but from my experience, the original filter is doing pretty good for me). 5. This machine is not good for making a huge amount of espresso/latte at one time, so I would say this is pretty much a "one person's only" machine, but it's ideal for small household.

I’ve had mine a little over 1.5 yrs and, while I’m pretty satisfied with it, the pump is starting to fail. We’re talking about 2 (occasionally 3 espressos/day). So about 5000. Not sure if that is the normal life expectancy of these things since it’s my first one, but that is the reason for the lower rating. I would have expected slightly longer life out of these things. ****UPDATE**** Got a message from customer service in response to my post. Pretty impressed! They suggested I de-scale the coffee maker which I did. I don't think it helped much since I use filtered water anyway and I think most of the hard minerals are filtered out, but I could be wrong. So I took the whole thing apart and cleaned everything as best I could. Moved some hoses around to make sure they were secure and all. Now it "seems" to be working a little bit better. There is still some leaking coming out of the steamer when I make espresso but not as much as before. So I'm bumping it up to 4 star. Again it makes great coffee....when it works.
reviews.review_header: Great espresso maker for the price. Short life though.

reviews.review_text: I like it, It makes good espresso and foams the milk well...but... The clearance is small about 2.5" so it is hard to fit a cup in there. You can remove the drip tray, but it still won't take a normal coffee cup... I guess I need to go find a second hand cappuccino cup somewhere. Also, I'm not wild about how it vibrates when dispensing the espresso. It is sort of comical to see the cup vibrating and dancing around under the dispenser. I wonder though: does the vibration indicate that something is wrong with the pump mechanism? Still, the coffee comes out nicely and I feel good about that. I hope the vibration doesn't mean it won't last.
reviews.review_header: Does my coffee well with a bit extra vibration... which concerns me.

reviews.review_text: Bought this to replace a De'Longhi EC702 that was twice the price and only worked well for about the first 6 months, then kept getting worse -- pressure issue, strange noise, coffee taking forever to drip through -- until it was finally useless by the 2-year mark. Hesitated about buying another De'Longhi, especially a much cheaper one, but the reviews were good and I liked the smaller, more compact style. So, we've used this at least twice a day for 8 months and it's as good as the day we bought it. Much better value for money than the more expensive EC702. Even if we only get a year out it, it'll be worth it. --------- UPDATE: About a week after I wrote this, problems started. Intermittent pressure and slow or no coffee coming through. We took it apart and cleaned what we could but no luck. Sigh. ----- FURTHER UPDATE: We're on our second unit which we've had for just over a year. I've added two stars because my husband figured out how to fix it when it starts losing pressure! We had the same problems as the first unit after a few months - started getting sluggish as though blocked. He took it apart, gave it a good clean, put it back together, and it's been working like a charm ever since, fingers crossed. We began using filtered water so maybe that has helped. It really does make excellent espresso for the price, and for as long as it keeps working!

I was waiting a couple of Year to write this review since I wanted to see what will happen with my DeLonghi before I gave it the 5 Stars I originally planned for it to have, and I’m glad I did… In the 4 years I have owner this machine it became the house favorite, surpassing the kids the TV the pets and even my bed, it is probably the most trusted family member at this point  all jokes aside We love this machine.I think a review is nothing without Positives and Negatives/// well if it has negatives! So here we go; Positive: 1. The Value is amazing, I believe we originally received it at target, (just to find a better deal on amazon) for about $79 plus minus some coupons! 2. The maintenance is super basic and also very calming, after you take it all apart you have about 10 pieces, that includes the second “smaller” coffee grind holder…( I don’t know if that is the professional description, however if there is a petition to call it that I WILL SIGN IT) 3. The Control you have is great, you basically say STOP and GO, we have been playing around with the Idea of purchasing an automatic just to sit back and realize that the size and functionality just makes this one better than most of the $700+ appliances we’ve tested. 4. Did I mention the size??? Small and compact! Noone likes clutter in the kitchen… let me take that back, some people love it… however we do not!  The Negative; 1. It vibrates, sometimes so hard that the cup moves and even though its not a big issue it can be if you don’t pay attention 2. It’s a little louder now than what it used to be, however It will not wake up my kids on a Sunday morning, so It cannot be that bad, considering they hear me breathing they come running…… 3. The steamer isn’t the greatest it takes quite some time for the water to get ready and it might come out liquid instead of steaming gas  Overall if it was a little faster I would probably use the steamer more than I am now, however besides that this little guy will run circles around any Keurig! Enjoy the coffee people!
reviews.review_header: LIttle Guy with a Big Punch

reviews.review_text: I lived in Italy for almost 10 years, and one of the many things I miss since returning is having the ability to get a decent Caffè (espresso) practically anywhere. (Starbucks just doesn’t do it for me) My stovetop Macchinetta works fine, but it’s just not the same. I have a very limited budget so I thought any kind of espresso maker would be out of the question. I recognized the De’Longhi brand from my time in Italy, and the EC155 was affordable. I was impressed by the reviews so I decided to take a chance and buy it, although my expectations were very low. I am so happy with my purchase! Yes, it is a very basic entry level espresso maker, and yes it may not last a long time, but for what I wanted it is perfect. I am not an espresso connoisseur, but to my taste the espresso is great and I couldn’t believe the crema the machine produced. The short steamer wand doesn’t bother me as I rarely drink cappuccino. The built in tamper isn’t the best, so I bought a separate one. The machine is mostly plastic, so I don’t expect it to last a lifetime, but I think it is exceptional value for the price and the quality of the caffè it produces.

Its been 8 years since my last espresso machine! I had owned a variety of them over time, in various price ranges. I did not think I'd be the proud owner of another, And yet I am. This machine brews and steams as well as some, and far surpasses others and all for an amazing price! My first cup was ok, barista error, I will add more beanage next time. I have seven more days ( cleanse) , till I can enjoy my first cup! I'm sooooo looking forward to it. I absolutely love my wonderful little espresso maker, I could not be happier! !!! Love, Love, 💘

For the price this machine is utterly amazing. I have had no problems with it. I followed a YouTube video for the basics. I like what you can do with the machine. PLUS: It doesn't automatically control the Expresso amount so you can adjust the shot to your needs. You can adjust the steam a bit and the top provides a nice space for warming the cup. Easy clean of the water container. The wand works incredibly well. MINUS: Plastic instead of all metal Small area for cups Cheap pressing wand (plastic but it works Vibration when it makes the shot. For the price I can't imagine a better expresso maker and I tried a more expensive model (Cuisinart) and liked this much better. The flavor is spectacular and so much better than Starbucks burnt coffee. I highly recommend that you get a hand grinder with a good quality coffee and grind it yourself instead of buying expresso coffee. If you're obsessed you could roast your own beans as well.
reviews.review_header: For the price this machine is utterly amazing. I have had no problems with it

reviews.review_text: We were skeptical of buying this because it was so inexpensive. We bought one that had been returned but was still brand new and got a really great deal. We saw this one at a target before buying it here and it seemed very cheaply made, very lightweight and almost entirely plastic. However, since we were getting a great buy, we decided to try it and we are so glad we did! Although this is the first espresso machine we have ever owned, so we do not have anything to compare it to, we really like the way the coffee comes out. Almost daily, my husband makes a great cappuccino. We have been using it for 10 months without any problems.

The average review for this item is 4 stars...but if you consider the actual cost...it should be 5. You will see reviews at 1 and 2 stars...essentially, these people's expectations, imho, are too high. It can't actually do the work for you, but it can come close. You have to have the proper grind number 1. You have to load the grind in appropriately, unless you are using the pods. I have done both. Loose grind is way cheaper, but the pods are so easy, but maybe not quite as strong, since you can tamp down the grind (if you know to have a tamper, they sell them on Amazon too). You can't allow it to brew too long, weakens the results. I generally use this for lattes for the my wife and me. I tend not to use the wand for the milk instead use a aerolatte milk frother. A great discovery was the find out that lithium batteries really produce great results with the frother...spins much faster and is so much easier than dealing with the wand and its cleaning. I have had this for two years now and am very pleased...it stays on the counter during the winter until I switch to iced lattes in the summer. With iced lattes I add splenda, so I can use just a nice instant coffee which I make with just a little water...really strong and then add ice and whole milk...super. So, to summarize, to expect this thing to perform like a $300 machine...you are expecting too much, but with some actual understanding of how to make a good espresso, or latte, this unit provides the most essential too. Don't blame the unit if your imagination and understanding can't provide the expected results...

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I'm on my third machine. Discovered that there is a learning curve to a pump style espresso machine. My first one worked great after I learned to prime it before expecting a great cup of espresso. With no coffee in the basket, run it as if you were making a double shot. This will allow water to flow through the entire system before any real pressure is applied. Then, always, always, ALWAYS verify that you have enough water in the tank! Running out of water mid-pull is disastrous. If it does happen, let the machine cool completely and run it without coffee in the basket several times. You'll hear air escaping when it is running. Once you can run water through without hearing any air you should be good to go with coffee in the basket. Using either the single or double shot baskets, make sure that the compressed coffee grounds are exactly level with the top. I have had good success using the built in tamper by holding the handle of basket holder and using my thumb on top of the tamper to apply some extra pressure. My preferred drink is a Caffe Machiato using just a splash of organic coconut milk with a french vanilla flavor. I rarely use the steam spout. I have found frothed milk to be a bit of pain and time consuming no matter what machine I have used. Keep it cleaned and descale often and it will keep in espresso for a long time. Even with my mistakes in the beginning, each machine has lasted me at least two years. At three Caffe Machiatos a day, I'm way ahead of the curve on the money spent on these machines compared to paying for my coffees my by someone else.

I had a Francis Francis X1 that finally died. It came with an ESE handle. While I enjoy making my own shots, I found the Italian ESE pods to always produce a reliably excellent shot with perfect crema. I use a wand frother in a cup of milk that I have microwaved, if I am interested in a latte. Usually I prefer a regular shot. The E155 works perfectly with the ESE pods. If you want to use bigger cups, I found that if I remove the perforated metal piece, it leaves me plenty of room for a cup. Heavy cups won't move, but the regular espresso cups move. I bought a rubber pad for the perforated metal piece, and that solved the moving cup. I think most espresso makers make noise, so that isn't an issue. The plastic is fairly breakable feeling, and I couldn't turn the handle to load a shot without holding the top of the machine with my other hand. It seems possible that the plastic will have a definitely shorter life, but for the money, it is worth it. I had to pay more than the cost of this machine to have my Francis Francis fixed, so this is the route I took. The tamper isn't too friendly looking... just buy an inexpensive one, if you want to make your own shots. The ESE pods are all available on AmazonPrime. Try one of the samplers to see what ones you love, and then you can buy a box of you favorite pods. A favorite ESE of mine is Kimbo. If you have the extra money, sure, go whole hog. If not, this machine makes great espresso. For an espresso machine to work well, you also have to clean it regularly and decalcify every month or so. Oh, and if someone made a simple ESE only device, I would happily buy it...for some reason I could find none.
reviews.review_header: Have yourself a great cup of espresso!

reviews.review_text: I have owned this espresso maker for four years and have made an average of 3 cups of coffees per day. That is approximately 4,380 espressos before it broke. Not a bad deal if you ask me. It's motor is still working but the pump just gave out this morning. My husband and I took the whole thing apart, cleaning everything carefully but we conclude that a seal in the pump has finally seen it's last day. After doing some research I went ahead and bought the exact same machine, the EC155. I still feel like this is the best value if you want real espresso. To buy an espresso machine that has an automatic turn off the price jumps hundreds of dollars. When I first got this machine I would absent mindedly leave it running and have a mess, but now it is such a part of my routine I can't remember the last time I had a spill. So to me the automatic turn off feature is not worth the money. I use fine pre-ground espresso. I did buy myself a real tamper like many people have suggested but when I misplace it the built in one works fine, although it's not preferable. Over the past four years my husband and I would clean the filter when the machine started to run slow, which was about every three or four months. We really can't clean the filter with soap, water, and a scrub brush, it is still not enough to clear the tiny holes of coffee grounds. My husband discovered that he could take the filter apart, and hold it with plyers, or set it on the ground outside, while washing it with our electric pressure washer. This may sound extreme but it only takes a moment and it does the trick. We probably ran a vinegar solution through the machine about once a year. The coffee still tastes great and I'm looking forward to another 4,380 cups of delicious brew when my next EC155 arrives.
reviews.review_header: Owned the De-Longhi EC155 for four years

reviews.review_text: I love the this machine although it is different from those I have used in the past (BELLA BLA13683). De'Longhi EC155 makes only 1 to 2 cups at a time. We make cafe con leche every morning aside from drinking 1 cup. I now make 2 times espresso in the morning, 1 & 2 cups. With BELLA BLA13683, I could make 4 demi tasses at a time. I also had to upgrade the regular coffee, Bustelo or Pilon. I now have to buy their premium brand and mix with their regular brand. With BELLA BLA13683. I used the regular Bustelo or Pilon brand. Last, you can only use demi-tasse and does not comes with 1 or 2. BELLA BLA13683, came with glass 4oz carafe. I still recommend De'Longhi it makes a better brew!
reviews.review_header: I changed from BELLA BLA13683 to De'Longhi

reviews.review_text: If you're shopping for this espresso machine, you're probably a newbie. No problem. The good news: this machine is perfect for you. It's easy, small, simple, and makes very good espresso. Here's what you'll need to go with it. First, you'll need some small espresso/cappuccino cups because this machine pours your espresso straight into a serving cup. Whatever you pick, they have to be low because there isn't much room under the spigot. 7 ounce cups are perfect. You may read reviews that tell you that you need a "tamper," a small tool for pressing the espresso down into the machine. I'm sure it wouldn't hurt, but you don't really need it. The machine has one built in that will do the trick. You shouldn't be mashing your ground coffee down anyway because then the steam can't get through the brick you've made. Next, if you plan on steaming milk - and you should - then you're going to need a steaming pitcher. This one is perfect: http://www.amazon.com/Update-International-EP-12-Stainless-Frothing/dp/B000MR6I9I/ref=pd_sim_k_2. The price is right and this one is suitably tiny, because there isn't much room under the steaming wand. Get this one and it won't be a problem. If you're going to grind your own coffee - and again, you should - then you'll also need a grinder. Yes, you can go cheap on this one. But believe it or not, your grinder is as important as the machine. Cheap grinders spin fast and that speed burns your beans. You want a slow grinder. This one is great: http://www.amazon.com/Bodum-Bistro-Electric-Coffee-Grinder/dp/B0043095WW/ref=sr_1_1?s=home-garden&ie=UTF8&qid=1359610978&sr=1-1&keywords=bodum+coffee+grinder. Wait! What kind of crazy person spends more on the grinder than the coffee machine? The kind of person who wants a good cup of coffee. Speaking of coffee, you need beans. Any beans will do, but you're better off with an espresso roast with this machine. Here is a great espresso roast: http://www.amazon.com/Coffee-Bean-Direct-Italian-Espresso/dp/B002GWFA1Y/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1359611478&sr=8-1&keywords=coffee+beans+direct. Finally, don't be intimidated, but you're going to need to read the directions. It's simple, but there are a few steps involved. For example, yes, the machine needs to pre-heat for 15 minutes. No sweat. When you're ready to go, there are two trays for the grounds. The big one is for a double (two cups being filled at the same time) and the small one is for a single. You'll need to hold the cups while the machine is working because of some minor vibrations. The complaints about the vibrations in some reviews are way overblown; it's no big deal. For a cappuccino, you fill half your cup(s) with espresso. Then you rotate the dial to activate the frother. Wait until the light turns green, then release the steam and heat a few ounces of milk in your new pitcher for less than a minute. The lower the fat in the milk, the easier it froths. Then you pour your milk and spoon the foam into the cup(s). Easy and rather fun. Don't be intimidated.
