If you've gotten far enough to start shopping for espresso machines, it's totally worth taking these additional steps. You are going to be amazed by how good the coffee will be. It's a little more work than I am usually up for on a crazy work/school morning, but it is one of my favorite parts of the weekend routine.
reviews.review_header: So you're ready to move up from that old drip machine

reviews.review_text: This actually makes decent Espresso! If done right it comes out very dark, then turns a rust color then there's the crema on top. This machine produces that! I wanted to make my own Double Shots on ice like Starbucks since we live 30 mins from the closest shop. So after trying another Espresso machine, which produced very weak espresso, I thought I would try this one! It passed! Of course the Double Shot on ice from this machine isn't identical to the actual professional machine Starbucks has, it does come very close and that's good enough for me.

Purchased this for my mother who is a latte/breve lover. And she loves it! It's a very economically priced machine but does everything you need it to make a fancy coffee... and if you drink Starbucks every day, you can literally more make up the difference in this machine in about a month. I cannot say enough good about this machine and the lattes it can make! The ONLY two negatives: She cannot fit her coffee cup under it for the shots (I worked in a coffee shop, I KNOW it's not supposed to but it does add a cup that must be cleaned and is the only way to really improve this machine for the average person). It's not "instant" coffee - but neither is a gourmet coffee from any shop. More than making the coffee, is the heat up time. Takes about 4 minutes from start to finish to make a cup of coffee... but do not let this stop you from getting this machine. I'm being critical for the sake of others, but these are by no means reasons to not buy it. I personally have two young kids, a "mombie" as the saying goes... and I've made it a habit to get the toddler and baby out the door early to stop by her house for a latte before work... now I don't even like regular coffee (and loved it before this machine!). Great machine, great price, and highly recommended!

I bought this machine on Amazon more than a year ago and today I finally decided to write a review about it. I use it on a daily basis and it makes a delicious, steamy and frothy espresso. I use Lavazza espresso ground coffee and it tastes really good. I usually make a latte with the espresso and add some caramel syrup to it. I love it and all my friends love it. This is my first espresso machine and maybe for people who are using those fancy espresso machines (like those with separate steam tanks for the milk steamers), this is a low-end machine...but for me, it is really great and because I love latte so much, after having this machine, I gave away my Mr. Coffee coffee maker and my Keurig mini plus, together with a lot of k-cups..lol. I have seen complaints about the steamer not working, and I had the same problem too, but now I no longer have that problem any more. Make sure you follow the instructions and clean the steamer head properly after each use. The milk froth is done in maybe 30 seconds and it is very rich, silky and smooth. The froth can hold a stirrer standing straight in the middle of the froth without letting it fall. I don't think the milk steamer of this machine can make very dry/stiff milk froth, but I don't like that kind of froth anyway. People complain about the machine making a mess..I don't really know what kind of a mess they were referring to, but if you are making coffee from ground coffee powder, there will always be cleaning-up after, and for an espresso machine, you also need to clean the steamer head, the filter and the filter holder every time you finish using them. The cleaning is very easy and I don't use any detergent. Of course if you use a Keurig or any other pod-based espresso machine, it will be faster and easier and there's no clean up after each use, but using this espresso machine is a lot more cost efficient, and the milk froth tastes a lot better than those made from milk pods from Verismo, and I can choose my own favorite coffee bean (even though I have been using Lavazza only lol)! All in all, this is a good espresso machine for people who want to make their own latte or cappuccino (and quality ones..) at home without paying a lot for each cup.
reviews.review_header: Would definitely recommend for people who want to get their first espresso machine.

reviews.review_text: So far so good. I got this as a cheap replacement for my broken Gaggia Classic. I've only had it for 3 days but it's pulling near perfect espressos using Cafe Bustello's pre-ground coffee (which I love). 5 seconds for a single, 10 for a double. The coffee is firmly tamped using the built-in tamper which actually gets the job done. The basket seems a bit on the cheap side and is just a bit smaller than my Gaggia basket so they are not interchangeable and I can't use my professional grade tamper. However, It does work and it works well so far. Will update if/when something goes wrong with the machine. The water container is a minor improvement over the Gaggia which, while it held more, was frequently dirty because we'd fill it from the top without removing it. (a hassle)

This was my first espresso machine, although I did have experience making espresso during my many years as a server. I mostly have loved this machine, and after 6 years, I can tell the pump is going out so I came here to review it while I shop for my next machine. I’ve essentially had all of the same issues that other reviewers have had. When you turn the machine on to to heat up, it does leak a little water into the drip basket. I’m not sure why anyone would care about this if it’s going into the basket, but it does happen. The steaming wand does leak for a few minutes after you’ve used it. I just put a napkin under it or left the small rag that I use to clean the wand anyway. I personally wasn’t really bothered by this. Also, like others complained, there is not enough space under the handle to fit an actual coffee mug. This was slightly annoying when I realized, but I bought perfectly sized (and fairly inexpensive) espresso cups at IKEA. Fit perfectly so I stopped caring about this as well, as I usually drink espresso straight and don’t need a full mug. But if you do want to use a full mug, you’ll have the added step of brewing the espresso into one cup that fits, and then having to pour it into the mug you plan to drink from. Overall I could not be happier with the bang for my buck here. Six years of pretty much daily use (double shot). I’ve impressed many guests with my cappuccino skills. If you like to try different beans and brands vs. brewing your fave consistently, I might be a little iffy. I’ve noticed this machine is a little finicky with the higher end, more finely ground brands. I use Lavazza espresso consistently. Tastes great, excellent crema. But when I splurge on coffee like Illy, it does not brew as successfully. Maybe 1 out of 5 would be successful. I tried packing it looser, tighter, using less coffee etc. But it seems the machine doesn’t have the power to push through the more finely ground espresso. You’ll get maybe half a shot out, before you can see and hear the machine stalling and/or leaking, and by this point your coffee is burnt. I think this is a great starter machine. Well priced, consistent (for me), very compact if your kitchen is tight. If you are all about convenience then I would go in another direction, as this model does require a little finesse/TLC to learn how to get the best coffee out of it, but I enjoy this more manual aspect and learned more about coffee in general. After a few weeks I could brew with my eyes closed.
reviews.review_header: Lasted me 6 years, just bit the dust. Excellent value, but requires some finesse

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I waited five years before finally buying an espresso maker, so I made sure to read all the reviews before finally purchasing this one. I love this espresso maker!! The only negative thing I could think of is the fact that there is little clearance space for the cup. If you really want to use a larger cup, that could be remedied by removing the little metal cup tray at the bottom. Also, the machine being so low causes a minor hindrance when trying to remove the frothing cup. But like I said, that is minor. You could always put it on top of a book/block/whatever to raise it a little and avoid that 'problem'. The machine comes with two filters, one to make one cup of espresso and the other for two cups. That way, you're not adding too little or too much espresso. I read complaints about the tamper and rushed out and bought one. Honestly, the tamper that comes with the machine is just fine. You're just tampering, not pushing out every single air molecule between the espresso grinds. One of the previous reviewers is from Italy and stated that Italians do not use a tamper when making espresso at home; just a spoon and they tap it a little. So, save your money and skip the extra tamper. You do need to buy a frothing cup, however. But for the price of this beautiful machine, an extra $6-$8 was no biggie. I've had the machine for a few weeks and am extremely happy with it. I bought one for my friend for Christmas and she loves it so far.

I've had the De'Longhi EC155 for about a month now and am getting pretty good at drawing a nice Espresso or Latte. This is not a "push a button and get a cup." machine. First read the instructions and watch several of the nice video reviews on YouTube to show you how to operate it. Several of the negative comments I've read describe things the instructions or reviews address that are easily avoidable. Practicing with the tamper to get the right level of packing will likely be required. I use a metal tamper purchased here on Amazon. Same thing with the steam nozzle - practice a little. I've also used standard Espresso PODs with success. I found that after a few cups I am able to consistently produce excellent beverages. You'll need to be ready to invest a little time for your brew. I allow at least 15 minutes for the water to heat. Don't let the green light fool you. Allow time for the water to heat. Also, open the steam for a moment to allow condensation or other water to drain before placing the frother in your milk. With a little practice the time and steps needed to make the brew just adds to the anticipation. If you haven't used a home espresso machine, there are some good tips available on the internet on things like the time it should take to draw a shot etc.

I am an admitted Starbucks addict. So I bought this as a way to cut back on the cost of Starbucks everyday and I couldn't be happier. There are two downsides however. 1. The thing vibrates quite a bit (at least mine does) while it's brewing. I bought DeLonghi Double Walled Thermo Espresso Glasses, Set of 2 to go with it. But the thing vibrates so much I have to hold the glasses in place as it's brewing or they move around and the espresso will just drip into the drip tray. 2. The steam wand isn't very deep. I bought the New Star Foodservice 28805 Commercial Grade Stainless Steel 18/8 Frothing Pitcher, 12-Ounce and it's very easy to spill the milk after it's been steamed trying to get the pitcher out from under the wand. My solution has been to tilt the whole machine up on that side to lift the wand out of the pitcher instead of trying to tilt the pitcher out from under the wand. However those two issues aside, I would still recommend this machine for anyone who might be looking to cut the cost of that daily Starbucks drink like I did. It works flawlessly and despite those two issues (which are minor in my opinion) it's worth the money.
reviews.review_header: So I bought this as a way to cut back on the cost of Starbucks everyday and I couldn't be happier. There are two downsides howev

reviews.review_text: It is a great espresso machine for the money you pay for it. The espresso coffee comes out very tasty, if you don't dilute it while brewing. There are two things I really struggled with: 1. The milk frother - it is very short and angled in a weird way so it makes the milk frothing process very uncomfortable. You have to find the right pitcher for it - not too narrow and not too deep. The typical frothing pitchers don't work very well since the frother doesn't reach deep enough - it just blows the steam over the milk making it splash all over. I tried the 8oz measuring cup but it was too wide at the top and the milk wasn't frothing well. Also it is pretty cumbersome to clean. 2. In addition, the space between the filter holder and the base is pretty small. It doesn't look that small on the picture, but it really is. You can't fit the regular espresso measuring cups in that space. I had to buy actual espresso shot glasses, so I could measure the appropriate amount of espresso when brewing. The design could definitely be improved...
reviews.review_header: OK fro the money but it has it's design flaws

reviews.review_text: This is a really great espresso maker for the money. I did a lot of research on steam, pump and single serve cup espresso machines and I am really glad I went with this particular model. However, the unit does tend to vibrate the shot glasses quite a bit, but this can easily be mitigated by using a cloth or towel under your glasses. The spouts also have limited clearance, but you can find short espresso shot glasses and cups that fit perfectly. The steaming wand works great too.

Great espresso for $90 machine! Good flavor, nice crema, hot and easy to use. This machine was bought to replace our Starbucks trips. I can say that using Starbucks esspresso roast coffee,whole milk for froth and caramel torani syrup it tastes identical! The only thing that I dont like is the 15 min preheating. I am not really a morning person so 15 is a long time for me to wait. It has some plastic parts so I would advise using it with care to prolong the life of the machine.

So far this machine is working fine. It is very short and stubby. Trying to figure out how to use the steam wand in a way that doesn't force me to dump and spill each time to get it out from under the wand. I wanted something cheap and easy that would get me from point A- having no expresso to point B- having some sort of expresso drink...and quickly. For those mornings when I didn't have time to stop at the local joint. And also to save a few bucks. I'll still be craving the professionally made drinks with the little flower leaves and hearts, but this will do just fine in the mean time.
reviews.review_header: Cheap, and totally fine espresso drink maker.

reviews.review_text: Recently ordered this machine for my office. It makes an acceptable (to me) espresso, but doesn't compare to the higher end models that I wouldn't get for people to use around here. The build feels durable enough, but only time will tell how well it'll hold up. The only real 'problems' so far are the height of the machine, and awkward height of the steam wand. I was hoping we'd be able to fit the cups we already have sitting around here, but they're a little too tall, so anyone who wants to use it will need to bring their own. Another issue is the machine vibrating to the point where anyone using it really needs to make sure their cup doesn't rattle off the machine. We kinda-sorta solved the problem by removing the drain plate and dropping a cut out piece of rubber mat that was sitting around our warehouse to deal with the vibration and clearance issues with the dispensing tray. Elevating the machine with a tile block worked well enough for making the steam wand useable.
reviews.review_header: This thing is probably going to see some abuse.

reviews.review_text: Took a little longer than I expected for the water lines to "prime" so it was a good 10 minutes of the pumping noise with no water before it started running. The pumping noise is moderately loud. Not so loud as a grinder, but certainly louder than a regular drop coffee maker, so you may wake other in the house if they're near the kitchen. Placing it on a rubber pad may help reduce vibration noise (and contain the inevitable mess you will make during your first run). I had trouble cleaning the 2-cup filter because the rubber was glued to the metal casing, which was not the case on the 1-cup filter and as per the instructions, the rubber is supposed to be removable for cleaning. Thinking the rubber was just stuck from the factory, I forced it out and it ended up tearing. I dropped a star because I now have to contact support for a $17 replacement part. Other than that, it's be working very well. The built-in tamper works just fine, and using the correct amount of beans you will get the "puck" when you knock the grounds out, rather than the soup that people have been describing. Be sure the grounds are heaping and gently pad them down evenly. Also be sure to wipe any stray grounds from the edge of the filter as you want the sealing surface to be clean or else you'll spray hot steam everywhere. There is no automatic measure for the amount of water you pass through the grinds, so you have to keep an eye on it. While warming up takes a while, the actual brewing is very fast. I usually add grounds and set the machine to preheat before I get in the shower, then once I'm dressed it's a speedy process and quick cleanup. The unit is much smaller than I initially thought. The two cups in the picture are in fact tiny espresso cups. I'm not sure why I expected to be able to fit a normal mug underneath, but be forewarned you will need to buy espresso cups for this, if you don't already own some. The frother works well but is spring loaded. It doesn't stick out like it appears in the picture. This makes it a little difficult to work with, in my opinion. And the added feature of hot water through the frother is confusing and a juggling act to avoid a mess. Also, the frother is only a few inches from the counter top. I'm guessing they expect us to buy the special milk frothing cup. I would actually prefer the frother be removed, since it really just gets in the way. As far as making espressos, this machine is well worth the price. Just let it prime those pipes and make sure you screw the filter in as far as you can (I've yet to fully lock it to the right; it usually ends up in the middle or just past). Never have I had such delicious coffee at home. This will save you a lot of money if your second home is at your local coffee house.
reviews.review_header: Very good espressos, for the price, with few hiccups

reviews.review_text: This is everything everyone says it is. Perfect cup of espresso, cappuccino at an affordable espresso machine price. Great name and quality. Read the review from the Italian woman who knows her espresso. She knows what she's talking about. I read many reviews about this espresso machine, mostly positive and some negative. People are just to darn picky these days when writing reviews! This is a great machine for the price. No need to take anything apart and customize. This works just as it should. I've been to Italy many, many times and know very well what a good cup of espresso/ cappuccino should taste like. This is it. Use a good Italian coffee and your set. Strong coffee does not need to be bitter, it should be smooth and this espresso machine makes a great cup! You just have to start with a good brand of espresso and a tiny bit of practice.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I've had this for 15 months and I use it for 3-5 shots a day. I'm very pleased, but there are some concerns. PROs: I usually use the ESE pods (Lavassa) because they taste better than the espresso I make with ground coffee. This machine is extremely simple to use if you choose the ESE pods. The espresso has a nice crema and it tastes good. My machine takes only a few minutes to warm up. CONS: - the pod holder includes rubber gaskets that take on the taste of old coffee. I take my pod holders apart frequently to clean them, but the bitter smell remains and some of it gets into the coffee. This may be inevitable, and you can reduce the problem by removing the pod or coffee grounds immediately after making your espresso and rinsing everything. the pod receptacle is made of thin metal and it often sticks into the holder, making cleaning challenging.
reviews.review_header: Good espresso; good price; a few problems

reviews.review_text: 1) The lattes are undoubtedly comparable, if not better than the leading cafes'. The shots pour extremely well and fluidly (depending on the coffee ground. I've pulled espressos with three grounds: Starbucks express roast, Trader Joe's Fair Trade espresso roast, and an off-brand kenyan coffee ground. The first two pulled extremely well with a supreme crema. The last dripped slower than an 80 year old man's prostate-inhibited pee stream. I Four stars, not five: Overall, the process of pulling shots, steaming milk (not simultaneously), cleaning the main area, and cleaning the steamer nozzle takes about 5-7 minutes. Additionally, the steamer is too low, so you'll spill milk when you remove it from your pitcher unless you elevate the machine itself. Don't let that deter you. I've drunk toxic amounts of lattes since I got it. It's incredibly worthwhile if you're an avid latte drinker. Rejoice.
reviews.review_header: Been De'longhin' for Lattes Ever Since

reviews.review_text: I bought this machine here on Amazon 4 years ago, and have used it almost every day. It has served me faithfully, delivering the perfect shot of espresso with a nice crema. It's super easy to use and clean. Mine sits on a small metal stand which allows plenty of room to steam the milk in a jug and bounce it produce a good froth. Since this was my first machine, I was not aware of the "milky gunk" that accumulates in the head of the steamer, so be sure to check and clean yours regularly. Sadly the pump seems to have worn out now so I am back to order this model again. For $80+/- it's still worth it for 4 years of consistent use.
reviews.review_header: Solid machine that makes a perfect espresso or latte

reviews.review_text: Sometimes a product is so well made that the manufacturer must hate that they can only sell them to new customers. DeLonghi has made the perfect Espresso machine and I'm here to tell you that you simply can't spend more money to get a better one. Let me explain... First of all, the physics of pumping hot water through the grounds is pretty mundane and this one does it as well as machines costing 10x more. Does it grind the beans
reviews.review_header: Buy a frother, and an electric grinder and make perfect coffee for peanuts!

reviews.review_text: This is an awesome machine IF you learn how to use it. Like the barista said in his answer, you must pack it tight! I wanted to note an inherent flaw in this machine in case yours stops working like mine did. I took it apart and it seems the hot line going to the water tank is routed in such a way that it sits on a metal piece and gets a hole burned in it over time. Then you will see water come out the bottom when using and you will lose a lot of pressure. I've been using this for 4 years now and it works great. The first year I used it wrong and was packing the grounds lose and it only worked so so. Buy a tamper and pack it tight and don't use real fine grind espresso. Grind your own. Love this machine!
reviews.review_header: This is an awesome machine IF you learn how to use it

reviews.review_text: I bought this as a christmas present for my daughter. I read a lot of reviews on amazon that said it was a five star product, so i went ahead and purchased it for her. It does have some good points and bad points. It is a very flimsy espresso machine, but for $100.00 what do you expect. It was very easy to use also. She tried it at our home first, i wanted to make sure it worked ok. I expect it to break during the first year of use, do to the above of being flimsy. Also unless you are very strong it is very hard to get the handle onto the base for the espresso, but im guessing after so many uses it will get easier, but not sure of that. Good for first time users of making the espresso. This is my daughters first espresso machine. It does make good espresso, IF you have the right espresso pods, i bought the Caffee Borbone espresso Pods ESE type you have to have the ones that say ESE. O and this makes coffee to, but we didn't make that, but im sure if you have the right coffee it will be just as good. Hope this review helps any first time espresso makers out there
reviews.review_header: Good machine and easy to use for first time makers of espresso

reviews.review_text: UPDATE: The first was defective and was easily replaced by Amazon. For the price, this is a great espresso machine. You just need to learn how to make an espresso. Just like you would with all espresso machines. The most important thing I can tell you is simple; buy a digital scale, a burr grinder, and watch YouTube videos. The seal for the frothing valve loosens up and you may need to close it a bit tight. The machine needs about ten to fifteen minutes to warm up. I put my small hand towel on the top to help the heat build up. Get a decent burr grinder. If your grinder is a cheapo like mine, you may need to start coarse and grind on a finer setting the next time or two. IMPORTANT: Each bean or blend will need to be grinded finer or coarser and you will measure more or less into your porta filter. My espressos were completely different and rarely good until I bought a digital scale. CONSISTENCY is important. Another reason to always let the machine warm up. Watch YouTube to learn different methods and decide which works best for you. I don't measure my pour because my scale and cup won't fit. Instead, I watch for the créma to start getting lighter and stop pouring. I highly suggest buying a tamper, because the machine mounted tamper is worthless and you are likely to burn your hand on the group head. FIRST REVIEW: The espresso machine seems to work fine for the most part. Though, this is my first espresso machine, so I don't really know what I should expect. Unfortunately, it has two issues already (within four days of use). The frothing arm leaks and there is also a leak coming out between the front and top plates. I always relieve the pressure when done.

I personally use a double boiler commercial machine at home, but my girlfriends mother wanted one and this seemed much simpler to use. Being a coffeegeek for sometime I was skeptical of this machines ability to pull shots, though I think I was just unwilling to step off the dual boiler high horse. This machine warms up fast, is pretty quiet for a vibration pump machine, and pulls evenly. It uses pressurized baskets so you can use pods, and pre-ground and get pretty solid crema. We use it with Lavazza and Illy coffee and it really tastes pretty good. I can say for certain that this will not give you the brighter 3rd-wave coffee quality you see at many up and coming new café's, but it will give you what you have come to expect as solid coffee from a restaurant or what is reminiscent of a brasserie along the Champs-Élysées. The milk steaming is surprisingly powerful. Again, I usually use a dual boiler machine that has a separate 2L boiler on 1275w specifically for steaming milk... I was not expecting this little thermo-block to push out as much power as it does. It takes about 45seconds to come to steam temp, which you should flush out if you want to go back to pulling shots. The froth enhancer does as it says, and can be trick to use. I submerged the milk so that the line/ridge was just covered, then cranked the power to get predictable cappuccino foam. Not quite microfoam you would make latté art with, but good foam for a dry cap. The pressurized baskets normalize most coffee's to have a flatter/maltier flavor, and lots of pale crema. If you're a coffeegeek, this is probably not your machine. But its built well, pulls great traditional tasting shots and can steam like a champ. TL/DR; This machine is more than you would expect for the price and size. It pulls predictable shots and steams milk well with ease. There isn't much room to alter the flavor of your coffee, but this pulls a solid shot that most would recognize as "traditional."
reviews.review_header: Got it as a gift for someone else, Definitely a capable little machine

reviews.review_text: Update December 11, 2015: Still going! Update July 31, 2014: Still going! There are very good top rated reviews here, and I agree with their high and low point on this machine. I wanted to add two additional items. 1. I've had my machine for three years (April 2010), and although I started with ground espresso, which gave me varied results and a soupy mess, I started using ESE pods and have never looked back! I could not always get the perfect grind/pack combo for a perfect cup, but with the (right) pods I always get perfect crema. I used the now discontinued Starbucks pods, and now the Lucaffe black packaged pods. Cleanup is just a quick rinse of the holder and an empty/wipe of the drip tray. I can power on, make three shots for an iced espresso drink and clean up in about 5 minutes. Just start with a paper towel folded into quarters on your countertop for setting things on, then use it to wipe up when done. Also, don't overextract the pods. Your brew will be weak and bitter. Stop brewing when you have just over one ounce (even though you still see crema coming out). Another 1/4 ounce or so will continue to flow from the basket. If you are using traditional 2oz demitasse cups, this would be stopping at 2/3 cup in order to get a little more than 3/4. Brew one cup at a time. A standard demitasse will reach both spouts. Pods are for a single cup. The dual spouts are for using a 2-cup pack with the grounds insert. 2. I use only RO water, which helps a little with not getting calcium build-up. An unexpected benefit I've had with ESE pods (in addition to quick prep, quick cleanup and consistent results), is that I've never had to run a cleaner through the machine, since grounds are never free to get into the jets. So yes, ESE pods will cost you at least 0.50 a shot, but there's no ground coffee to wipe up, rinse out, or clean up after, and the machine won't get clogged from grounds. I make 3-9 shots a week. It only takes from the time I turn it on until I've gotten my espresso cup down, my larger cup ready and my pods out until I have the green light to brew (about 2-3 minutes). After I empty the espresso into another container, remove the spent pod, insert a new pod and reattach the handle I get the green light at right about that time to start the next shot. Very fast recovery. The only problem I've had started about four months ago, where coffee started leaking into the handle and dripping from the end onto my counter. This seal is after the pressurized area, so it wasn't affecting brew, it was just making a mess. I went out and bought food-safe (it may be labeled for aquariums), silicone sealant. I took the handle apart and ran a bead around the mid-lower basket, where the metal top and bottom portion go together, reassembled, and wiped away any excess that leaked out. Since resealing the basket, I haven't had any more leaks. I would highly recommend this machine for anyone looking to spend less than $120 on a machine, and would buy it again.

I love this little machine! It makes exceptional espresso. You can't beat the price for such excellent coffee. I use it EVERY day. People love coming over for coffee because it tastes great! Pro's: Easy to use It's pump driven so it makes coffee like the big boys (without the expense) Heats quickly Small enough to fit under any counter Makes a wonderful, thick crema I love using the espresso pods - quick, easy, no mess Frother is easy to use, easy to clean Cons: (Which really aren't cons for me since I've worked around them) Short distance between base and grounds basket. I use shot glasses which fit nicely Vibrates while pumping which causes your shot cup to slide across the base. I place a folded paper towel under the cup and use it for clean-up afterwards Short distance from frothing wand to counter. I've placed all my coffee gadgets and machine on a thick wood-block cutting board and use a 12 oz frothing cup. The "built in tamper" is a worthless piece of plastic. I bought Terry's Tamper and it works perfectly Now, after all that, I am on my 3rd machine. The first lasted 5 years. I did very little to take care of it except to flush it a couple of times. The heating element finally went bad. I took very good care of the second , followed all the required maintenance, but the pump was wonky after we moved. (rough move!) My 3rd is working great. The thing is, the machine I'd like to have is well over $1500.00. I can go through a dozen of these little guys and still not have to pay that much money and I couldn't ask for better coffee from a machine that is so compact and easy to use.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: Let me write this from the perspective of someone who is technically-inclined but until buying this product, totally dependent on my local coffee shop to make a good cup of espresso or cappuccino. As a first-time purchase, this is the best machine to start with. I just want to cover a few "first-timer" issues.The only reason I don't give this product 5 stars is because the manual needs to be a little "dumbed down" for lack of a better phrase, but for the most part it does give you the basics. Here are the challenges you'll need to be prepared for: 1) Learn what REAL espresso tastes like. The comments here from others with expertise are enough to educate anyone on what good-tasting espresso is! 2) I finally learned the problem with setting up the water reservoir. It's not clearly explained here because it's not easy to explain. Others have said that when you fit the reservoir tank back in after filling it with water, press down hard. This may not be enough. That is because there is a small, pointy part within the machine that must not only make contact with the rubber-encased opening of the reservoir, but it must puncture it clearly and firmly. This may take multiple instances of removing the tank and putting it back in over and over - at least for me, it did. It took about 6 times before I got espresso for the first time. I almost returned the machine! 3) Use distilled water. It not only keeps the machine cleaner but your espresso and cappuccino will taste better 4) DO Keep all parts clean every day! Don't be lazy, as I was during the second week of use. I stopped cleaning my frothing wand and as a result, it stopped frothing! 5) DO read the manual the first two weeks. It will help you, as it did for me in the above item #4. In the troubleshooting section, it will give you some important tips: http://www.delonghi.com/en-us/products/coffee-and-espresso/coffee-makers/pump-espresso/ec-155-0132104089?TabSegment=support#support
reviews.review_header: With A Tiny Bit More Dummy-Proofing, The Perfect 1st-Time Espresso Machine!

reviews.review_text: This isn't a $20k professional model. And it has a "pressurized" portafilter, which might offend some espresso purists. But this little machine makes a great cup of espresso for an extremely reasonable price. In addition to the machine, you will need a grinder, a frothing pitcher and a tamper. Get a 12-ounce frothing pitcher, a smaller one is just not enough. I've tried three tampers so far and the "Blue 49mm Espresso Tamper Stainless Steel" is the closest, though it is a tiny bit small. We go through between one and two lbs. of coffee per week, and about every three months it is important to de-calcify the EC155. You can tell it's time when the machine continues a slow drip after your cup is made. I've used the "Durgol Swiss Espresso Special Decalcifier" and it works great.

Good bang for the buck, however: 1) You will not get an authentic single cup of espresso if you only use one scoop. Ridiculous. You need, at least, 1 1/2 scoops or even 1 3/4 scoops. 2) The rubber gasket inside the filter is a NO-NO. Over time, it deteriorates. Ruins the flavor and you can guess the rest of the effects. Stupid design. Not sure how this happened if this machine is designed by Italians. WTPH?

This is an EXCELLENT machine for the cost. I'm not a espresso expert, but I know what I like. It is compact, does exactly what it is supposed to. We live in a 5th wheel during the winter so space is an issue, the foot print is small but the quality is not. I use both grind and pods, both work well. I don't remove the frothing wand to clean it except for once a week, I fill the little frothing pot I bought at the same time with hot water and steam it clean, wipe it down and it's good to go. Like others, I use distilled water because we have very "hard" water in our area. I run a couple of plain water shots thru the machine every other day as well, and have as yet not gotten a lot of gunk coming out. To pull a shot, I remove the metal insert beneath the drip and place a doubled paper towel in the well and drip into a rattleware 2.5 oz shot glass, My large mug would fit under the drip if I wanted with the grate removed. As far as warming goes, I fill our mugs with hot water to pre-heat them ~ no big deal. I've only had the machine for three weeks so can't speak to long term use and will update this review when it has some age on it, but so far I am very pleased to recommend it. I'm saving $$ and love being able to have Espresso when ever I want it. Trivia.....I live 22 miles from the nearest small town (44 miles round trip to the coffee shop!) So until now, I was only able to have a latte fix once a week so I'm loving my De'Longhi!!

I LOVE this machine! !! I really do. I use it every day a couple times a day. It makes really good espresso with the crema on top and the frother makes great steamed milk and foam. I use raw sheeps milk. I make the best espresso and steamed milk because of this machine, my fresh roasted coffee beans from the local roaster in Groveland CA and my fresh raw sheeps milk. I am so flipping spoiled. All that for $99? Awesome. The tamper works perfectly fine. Not sure what the problem is for some other reviewers. I do agree however that the shortness of the steamer wand is short. Kinda makes for awkward steaming but I have learned to manage and I would still buy this machine even with the short steamer. I have learned to let the espresso pump a little longer to get the right amount of espresso. It is simply a wonderful unit and especially for the price.
reviews.review_header: so happy with my machine. my trips to Starbucks and the local coffe shop have been reduced because of this machine.

reviews.review_text: * I use this espresso maker almost every day, some days multiple times. I use La vazza Gran Crema espresso pods (delicious and subtly chocolate-like). The steam wand does fine, it heats the dairy very well but I don't quite get the thick froth that I love so much - keep in mind it's not an industrial frother so don't expect cappucino-like foam. You'll need a 12-oz pitcher as the steam wand is close to the counter-top, or elevate the machine on top of something. * The machine is very easy to use. There is one notch to pre-heat for the espresso shot, and another notch to pre-heat for the steam wand. Just turn the knob accordingly and pre-heat each setting (shot or steam wand) for 2-3 minutes. Easy enough! * It takes about two water bottles to fill up the water tank. One can get about 3 beverages (with 3 shots in each beverage) before needing to fill the water tank again. * Overall: It's been reliable, very consistent and very user friendly. My only complaints would be the steam wand length and how close it is to the counter-top. I also wish it gave thicker foam but wasn't expecting THE BEST frother when I purchased this. It takes 3-4 minutes to make a cup of espresso after preheating - but that may be because I need 3 shots! A little time consuming but SO worth a good cup of coffee in the morning, you deserve it!
reviews.review_header: I love my De'Longhi! Reliable and super easy!

reviews.review_text: I have used this around six times now and love it. I'm not an obsessive coffee drinker, but I stopped by "S.B." enough to get tired of the cost. This is working out as an inexpensive alternative and I'm already getting latte's which I like better than S.B.'s. There are a lot of variables (bean roast, pre-ground vs whole bean, syrups, etc) but with a little patient experimentation I think you'll be enjoying your favorite drinks in no time. I paired this with a hand grinder which also works great: Most Consistent Hand Coffee Grinder & Coffee Press - Ceramic Burr Grinder made with Professional Grade Stainless Steel. Manual Coffee Grinder - Perfect Coffee Grinder for French Press, Espresso or as a Spice Grinder or Herb Grinder. and the 12oz frothing pitcher: Update International EP-12 Stainless Steel Frothing Pitcher, 12-Ounce In hindsight I added the thermometer as well: Norpro 5981 Espresso Thermometer I also picked up a 3-pack of Jordan's Skinny Syrups from a local retailer and found them to be quite good for sugar free. Amazon carries a variety of these as well. I hope the list will help if you're looking for the latte/cappuccino package like I was! I had checked out the more expensive all-in-ones but didn't like the short lifespan on the units. If I'm going to pay $500+ I expect years of service, not 1.5 average. So for just over $150 after tax I'm cranking out some great drinks. *The only issue I've had so far was that when it arrived, the steam knob was VERY tightly closed, it took some effort to get it to spin, but it's working just fine.
reviews.review_header: Loving it so far! Bye Bye Starbucks!

reviews.review_text: That this is the 3rd one we bought in 7 years tells you a couple things These don't last forever, but their price point and functionality (particularly for simple espressos) are worth the few years you get out of them. On average we make 4-5 large espressos every day, and the first two units lasted over 3 years each. We may have gotten more out of them if we descaled/cleaned more regularly. They make a fine crema, and if you are primarily interested in espresso, then this does as fine a job as a $500 machine. Once again we considered better machines and will end up getting another one of these.

I love mine and I make a double latte almost daily. This said I recommend looking at all models that DeLonghi offers in this style. There are three that are close in price and worth checking out. The frother, the way the knobs set up all the little things. I am really happy with this one. It does everything promised and makes a great cup of espresso or cappuccino. The one cup and two cup size grounds holders are perfect and I find it easy to use. It a good tool and like all tools you need to make sure it is what you are looking for and does what you want.

I am very, very satisfied with my De'Longhi Espresso maker. There was a little learning curve with it. I watched a YouTube video which helped quite a bit. But also, once I just got in there and used it, reading the instructions, and using it 4 or 5 times got me over the hump and I developed my own process. I do wish the coffee filter was just slightly larger, but it's fine. And I agree with others who have said that it would be nice if the frother arm was a little higher. It's hard to get a cup with milk underneath it and back out again. But overall, and for the money, this is a really nice machine. Makes a nice cup of espresso and lattes.
reviews.review_header: I'm giving it 5 Stars with a couple caveats.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I love coffee, and a co-worker recommended this machine (along with Lavazza coffee) when I told him I was thinking about getting a espresso maker. At first I confess that I was disappointed with the machine. It's noisy, more than I expected, but then again, I think all espresso makers make noise, right? It's also kind of high-maintenance if you follow the manufacturer's directions for cleaning (which I do, because I'm borderline OCD). That said, after owning this machine for many months now with mixed feelings, I finally had a change of heart today. Turns out that I wasn't using the right kind of coffee. If you want the crema on top, make sure you buy a coffee that says so. I was using the regular Lavazza Cafe Espresso and I never really got that creamy top that I was looking for. Then I came across the Lavazza Crema & Gusto, and voila - my coffee is now perfect! So tip #1, if you want coffee with crema, buy a coffee that says "crema" because you won't get that with any coffee (at least I didn't). Then, tip #2, if you, like me, don't know how anything about tamping the coffee, learn about it. I did a google search and found really good instructions in writing and on video. They really made a difference, because you don't want to tamp it too hard to too little. Then, final tip, don't use tap water if, like me, your tap water is full of minerals. You can taste in the coffee, and it's just not worth it. Overall, it's a pretty decent machine - not too bulky and does the job, but I wish it was less noisy and a little easier to clean. Also, when this one dies, I'll buy one that will grind the coffee and that will allow me to brew several cups one after the other. When you have people over it's a bit annoying that you need to change the coffee grounds at every cup (because if you don't do that the coffee comes out a watery mess, so keep that in mind before you buy).
reviews.review_header: Not bad for the price, but you need to know a few things that I didn't...

reviews.review_text: I actually had to return this unit as it was faulty in that one valve was malfunctioning...it was a refurb unit. . However, the few espresso pulls I managed to get were excellent with superb crema. I would get this unit, but never never a refurbished unit. Great for the price. Do not expect a heavy duty machine and I have no ideal how long it will hold up, but great for the price.

Update November 2016: I've started to use it every day, and over three years later, it's still going. Don't tamp the coffee. That will let it flow faster and give you better crema. Leave a plastic cup under the steamer wand. Make sure to turn the steamer knob all the way off. That's mostly what makes it leak. In the summer, when I don't use the steamer, it stopped leaking after a while. Run the steamer until it runs "clear" in order to avoid too much water in your milk. Take out the tray when you want to use a tall cup. Put a quart container yogurt cover on the tray to keep small cups from moving. I only make one cup at a time because the drip is not even from the two spouts. No big deal. There does not seem to any point in buying another machine at this price; apparently they all have problems. And a three hundred dollar one is probably not any better. This one is still working well enough for me to enjoy espresso two or three times a day. No, it's not perfect, but it was only a hundred bucks, not fifteen hundred. Another update: June 2016. I figured out that to make it work, I couldn't tamp as tightly. I end up just knocking the basket on the counter to settle the grounds and not even tamping from the top. When it starts to drone, I turn it off, release the handle, and then tighten it back up, which helps. The coffee really isn't bad. Not that hot, but nice crema. However, It is starting to pour water out of the steamer spout while the coffee draws, and it is leaking from the bottom. So really, it is time for a new one, and I suppose three years isn't bad. I'm still not happy with the frother; only one in every four or five tries does the milk really thicken up and not just get bubbly and thin, even though I bleed it first, but I manage. The hot milk increases the temperature of the coffee. So I'll probably end up getting another one. . . . . This is an update: I see that I bought this in June 2013. I haven't used it that much, maybe 25 times. Now, in January 2015, the water won't come through the filter, even though the pump drones and drones. I have taken the filter apart and cleaned it ten times. WASTE OF MONEY. Previous review: I let the water heat for fifteen minutes; I rinse the cup with hot water. It's just not really hot enough, no matter what I do. There are other issues, like the frother is a little difficult to gauge accurately, and it's true that the cup moves around on the drain. But I don't care about those things; I don't expect perfection for the price. But I do care about having a cup of espresso that is still hot when I move it from the machine to the table.
reviews.review_header: Over Three Years Later, Still Going

reviews.review_text: Just as others remarked, this is a great little machine THAT HAS SIGNIFICANT DESIGN FLAWS! It is small, which is great for our small kitchen. The unit heats more quickly than the instructions suggest. Not just any espresso cup or shot glass will work, as they all get stuck under the drip spout causing your fresh espresso to spill. I am using a very old espresso cup and must bend down at the level of the counter top to estimate how much espresso is made. Very difficult to judge. Despite this, it does produce a very nice balanced crema if you can figure out how many seconds it takes to pull a good shot. The instructions suggest 25 seconds, which is too long & produces a weak tasking espresso. The frother is a hassle too! It does swivel, but the normal sized stainless frothing pitcher I own is too tall. I think a shorter pitcher might overflow if you're not careful or experienced with frothing milk. I even use coconut or almond milk, and it does a beautiful job. It makes lovely frothed milk, but after you manually turn off the device (which isn't a quick process either), you must lift the entire unit up off the counter by the handle or pull the unit to the edge of the counter to pull the steamed milk container from underneath the wand!! If you don't mind these hassles or cn adapt after a few spilled milks, it you can make professional tasting lattes, cappuccinos and espressos (if you don't mind the truly homemade experience of a product that is too compact for "normal" cups/shot glasses or steaming pitcher.) I do recommend strongly buying your own tamper. This machine includes a plastic tamper, which is basically a good idea, but for a properly prepared grind you must apply 25 pounds of pressure in tamping. You can't with this machine affixed tamper, or you will knock it over. Overall, I wish I had purchased the bigger unit; however, I can produce delicious and consistent drinks every morning from this small machine despite the hassle of the frothing pitcher and espresso cup not fitting AT ALL!!

Added January 24, 2013: The pump died after eleven months of use. Contacted DeLonghi, they offered a warranty replacement but I had to pay s/h costs. Took them about a month to send a new unit. Meanwhile I bought a Breville BES830XL on sale and have been using it instead of EC155. The Breville is easier to operate but also far more expensive. I see no difference in the quality of espresso. ---------------------------------------- I bought this product as a replacement of my 15-year old steam driven espresso maker. Both my wife and I are tea drinkers, we drink coffee in the morning mainly as a "caffeine delivery system" to help keep us going, but we do appreciate good flavor. According to experts, pump driven machines produce better tasting coffee than steam driven ones, so I decided to give it a try. In the under $100 price range, the EC155 had by far the best reviews, which influenced my decision to buy it. I ruled out anything with the price tag well above $100, which in my view is a ripoff of snobs who do not know what to do with their money. I tried a few of these overpriced coffee machines at a local Williams Sonoma store and I do not think that the quality of coffee they produce is commensurate with their ridiculously high price. The product is designed to make European style espresso - which is served in 50mL cups. This is about 1/4 of the US cup (240mL) - so the concept of a "cup of coffee" can be a bit deceptive here. This machine will not make a "cup of coffee" of the size of a mug - it will only make a "cup of coffee" of the size of a shot glass. This answers frequent complaints about the design of the machine, especially that the clearance between the filter holder and the base is to low. It is not - it is a perfect size for 50mL coffee cups. The machine comes with two sizes of coffee filters - for 1 and 2 cups of coffee. Since my wife and I like our coffee strong, I found the 1 cup size unusable since it produces coffee too weak to my taste, but it is a subjective opinion. Others may find coffee produced by the 1-cup filter satisfactory. However, a negative side of it is that when I make two coffees, as I usually do, I need to empty the 2-cup filter and refill it with coffee before making the second cup. It is not a big problem, however, because it does not take much time. In fact, it takes less time to make two coffees that way using the EC155 than it does using a steam driven maker (which takes about 10 minutes to produce the same amount of coffee.) Although some reviewers complained about the built-in tamper, I found it adequate and rather easy to use. This is a plus, since the tamper is always there when I need it. The pump is a bit noisy, but I found it to be the case of other pump driven machines as well. The negative side of it is that it also produces vibrations that may cause the cup placed under the filter holder to move. Again, it is not a big deal and requires the cup to be held by hand during the few seconds when the pump is in operation, but I think the design of EC155 could be improved to reduce these vibrations. The EC155 has a mechanical function selector (steam, preheat, dispense, off) which I consider a big advantage over electronic controls. The latter are notoriously unreliable and prone to failure, and when they fail, the whole appliance needs to be thrown away. This happened to me several times, and I tend to avoid electronic controls like a plague, especially that they usually add a lot of bells and whistles - and thus inflate the price - without adding much useful function over mechanical controls. The main useful add-on of electronics is a built-in timer (which the EC155 does not have - see below), but a $6 external timer will make up for the absence of a built-in one. According to the user manual, the machine needs to be preheated by at least 15 minutes, which is a drawback, especially for morning coffee drinkers. I experimented with two different methods of dealing with this drawback. One, mentioned in the user manual, entails running the hot water "empty" (i.e. without coffee grounds) several times as soon as the green indicator light goes on. The other one involves using a simple $6 kitchen timer set for about 1/2 hour before my wake-up time. I found the second method to be a time saver. I also used a side-by-side comparison of coffee made by my old steam driven machine and the EC155, using the same amounts of ground coffee (two 7-gram (0.24 oz) measures supplied with the EC155) and the same amounts of water (about 60mL or 1/4 of the US cup). The EC155 produced rich crema (foam on the surface of coffee) which the steam driven machine did not. That matters quite a bit if you like espresso, but not that much if you prefer cappuccino (as both my wife and I do). I did not detect any stark differences in flavor, but in a blind comparison I picked coffee made by the EC155 as slightly better tasting one than that made by my old steam driven maker. On the other hand, the EC155 produces much better froth than the steam driven maker. However, the EC155 has the tendency of spitting out a small amount of hot water before producing steam for frothing (which the steam driven maker does not), which may produce watered down milk. This drawback can be easily corrected by quickly opening and closing the steam valve before placing the pitcher under the frother(you may want to place a sponge under the frother to capture the water). I also noted that emptying the used coffee grounds from the EC155 filter is more difficult than from my old steam driven maker. I have to tap it really hard several times before it starts coming out in small pieces, while it takes only one or two slight taps to empty the filter of the old machine. I am not sure, however, whether this is a design flaw or merely a difference between the pump driven and the steam driven mode of operation. In sum, the EC155 is not for making larger quantities of coffee to fill the standard US cup (240mL) - or the coffee will be way too weak (at least to my taste). It is designed to produce small shots of coffee about 1/4 of the standard US cup. The coffee produced by the EC155 tends to be slightly better than that produced by a steam driven maker, but the difference appears to be small. Finally minor drawbacks (the need to preheat, vibrations, and water initially coming out of the frother) are the main reason why I give the EC only 4 stars. Otherwise, it is a good value, especially in comparison to some of the ridiculously priced products on the market.

This little machine works wonders. I wish I could get something bigger but being supper limited on my kitchen counter top space I needed a smaller version of an espresso machine. It took me some time to decide as I am extremely particular with my coffee (being European it's in my blood). The first thing I noticed was the tremendous amount of positive reviews from other buyers and although I was a little skeptical I thought 3 thousand and something people can't be wrong, and I went ahead and purchased it. OMG the espresso is so creamy and the jet frother really does it's job. Overall this espresso maker looks good and works good. Just keep in mind that the machine itself is not the only essential part of having a mouth watering espresso, latte or cappuccino; a good coffee brand makes a lot of difference!

I'd long been jealous of my friend's Nespresso, but I hated the lack of variation on the coffee, the ridiculously overdone packaging (metal cups, really?), and the steep price. I read the reviews and ordered this 5 months ago with some reservations. I probably run it 6-10 times a week (doubles, 3-5 days). I have only used ESE pods so far. (mostly Lucaffe). Overall, it's been great--but I wanted to add some information about some of the other comments. - Portion size - coffee. This is not made for American-sized portions. No 16 oz here! When I make a double, I use a single size espresso cup because that's what fits. I can fit a small mug if I take out the bottom over the reservoir. - Portion size - milk. Same with the frother - I use it with an old-style 1950s coffeecup, which is broad and shallow. If you're looking for a Sbux amount of milk, it won't be enough for you. If you're looking for espressos or americanos, it's much better. -Cleaning the frother. A lot of people complained about that in reviews. My advice: don't remove the attachment to clean it. It's spurting boiling water after all--better to take a clean cup, add a bit of hot water and soap if necessary, and run the frother again to clean it. I found that ended up cleaning it better than taking it off. About once a month I do pull it off and make sure nothing's stuck under the threads. Haven't found anything so far. -Operation. The machine does shake--and the plate the cup stands on can vibrate. I find that I have to watch it or it shakes the espresso cup out from under the machine. Sometimes I keep my finger on it. I have had very little trouble with warm-up or with readiness - I find it takes me less than five minutes to make a double. The handle often won't go all the way to 90degrees--but when I used a commercial machine when waiting tables ten years ago I had that same problem as well. Don't force it; make sure it's in the grooves and push it as far as it goes. - Water. I have hard water, and at one point my filter pitcher broke so I was using straight tap. Warm up time doubled. Once I started using filtered water again I cleaned it out and it's been fine since. I highly recommend using filtered water. Huge difference. -Selection. Overall, I find the selection of ESE pods excellent. Although this isn't really about the machine, it did factor into my decision to purchase. TL;dr: If you mainly want a decent, low-fuss cup of espresso, this is a machine for you! If you mainly want cappucinos or lattes, you may want something else. If you are Truly Serious about your espresso, this probably isn't enough for you. Also: use filtered water and small cups.
reviews.review_header: Solid Espresso Machine at this Price

reviews.review_text: I ordered this espresso maker because it got very high ratings on Consumer Reports, as high as ones that cost in the hundreds of dollars. I've had it for two years now and it's still making great espresso. The steamer has plenty of pressure to foam your milk and make it really hot. Well, I'm coming back to add to my review on July 1, 2015. I've had the espresso maker for a little over 3 years, and the seals are starting to give out. While it makes great espresso for a while, it won't last you a lifetime. I didn't use it for about 6 months, so don't know if that had any effect on it. But it recently started first to leak water from the milk steamer, and now it will barely push the water through the coffee pod. I emailed the company in Seattle that repairs espresso makers, and they said for the amount I paid, it wouldn't be worth sending it to them to have the seals replaced. So you have to weigh either investing in a much more expensive machine, which will eventually need the seals replaced, or going for this inexpensive one and expect to replace the machine every few years. So because of the low price compared to other machines and the great espresso I've enjoyed the past 3 years, I still give this one 4 stars.
reviews.review_header: Great espresso! But the seals lasted just over 3 years.

reviews.review_text: I am on my 2nd EC155. The 1st one lasted >3yr and this one is 2y4m old and still going. I use it daily for 5~8 brews, so combined, these 2 machines have provided >15,000 cups of nice espresso. The Pro-Con of all the 5-star reviews applies to me as well. So I will just put a few notes about how I use it. -- Grind of the coffee bean is very important. It makes a lot of difference even with the same bag of beans. My own experience is "as fine as possible" but not to the degree of clogging the filters. And adding a thin layer "not as finely ground" and then the "very finely ground" helps produce amazing result. ... So you should experiment what kind of grind you like best. -- if you leave water tank in the machine for too many days, the bottom will become slimy. So I take it out and rinse it everyday. I also flip the whole machine upside down to drain out the remaining water under the tank, that place gets slimy as well). Note that this kind of problem will happen even to those costing >$1k. Billionaires take showers too. -- Warming up is necessary. However this can be accelerated by pumping out a cup of warm(hot) water. You can dump it into the drain (I drink it), and that helps warm up the cup nicely as a bonus. -- Remember to wash the filter(s) once a month, if not more often. Don't forget the one that is attached to the machine which you need to flip the machine over and unscrew. -- I have a toaster-oven right next to my EC155 and I put my cup on top of that as my cup warmer -- Buy a couple small sealed boxes/jars and grind your beans for 2~ days use (I got two box, one for decaf) -- When there is a hissing sound, and getting louder, it means scale is building up. Time to descale. I add white vinegar water (1:4) mix and let it sit in the boiler for 30 minutes. -- the built-in tamper work fine for me, although I have to hold down the machine with your left hand while pushing up the cup with your right hand. 15 lb is quite a bit of pressure, so you need to press with some force. -- After my 1st EC155 died, I did a bit of research on those high (5~10x) priced machines, and found that: 1) all have 15 BAR pump, this number turned out to be "optimum", so higher BAR is not better!! 2) boiler unit may be more powerful (EC155 is 1.1kw), but typically not by much. Since my 1st EC155 died of a boiler related problem (still pumping, but water cold), I see higher power boiler as potentially counter productive; 3) expensive machines tend to be bigger or taller and I have limited space in my 50+ year house. so it turned out EC155 is the optimum for my needs. so I bought the 2nd one.
reviews.review_header: Best Espresso machine for a small kitchen

reviews.review_text: I used this twice a day. I bought this about ten months ago and it has went through hell and back. It has flown with me across the country. I bought the Squaretrade warranty so I wouldn't have to care about it dying on me. Regardless, this machine rocks. There are goofy videos on the tube about how to get the best coffee out of this. One moron insists that you should let this warm up for "20 minutes" to fully heat up the water. That is nonsense. To zap fry the water to super-boiling temperature in a jiffy, turn the dial to the LEFT to the "Steam" position and let it run its cycle (takes about a minute or two). THAT alone will heat the dihydrogen oxide to 7 trillion degrees (and compete with a particle accelerator). Then BOOM, twist it all the way to the right and you'll get superheated water. The key to good cappuccino is a good grinder. Yeah - a true coffee snob would say this machine is crap but they probably roll with a $1500 machine. ***Edit 19-Jan-2015*** The pump in the machine is no longer effective. How coincidental that it dies almost one year since purchase. Thankfully it is still under DeLonghi's warranty along with my Squaretrade. I'll update my review if they screw me over.
reviews.review_header: Excellent machine. One-third the price of a nespresso machine. Yeah, more work but its a true pressure machine.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: After trying out a friends $500 automatic espresso machine I decided to buy one of my own. Being a former Barista I was a little hesitant on buying a cheaper machine because I can't stand cheaply made espresso. BUT this machine is so great. My only complaint is it won't fit my 8 ounce cups but if you buy shot glasses or those little 4 ounce cups you're golden. ALSO I was a barista at Starbucks where we didn't use manual machines so this was a learning experience. If you're new to this I suggest watching a video tutorial on YouTube- it's not that hard. This is a great machine if you're on a budget/ trying to cut out daily Starbucks expenses.

Overall: This machine isn't going to put your local barista to shame, but you can get a decent espresso with it. I'm glad I bought it, but might not be so happy if I had paid $75-80 for it since I also had to buy a small espresso cup and tamper in order to successfully use it. Pros: 1) You can get a decent coffee with crema. 2) I got mine from Amazon Warehouse deals for under 50 bucks, which is probably cheaper than a dozen espressos from a coffee place and I don't have to leave home to get one. 3) If you enjoy badly conceived instructions, you can get some jollies reading an Italian company's Chinese produced manual. Cons: 1) The instructions give 3 different timing versions of how to make an espresso. Trust me, IGNORE THE GREEN READY LIGHT. Let the machine pre-heat for at least 15 minutes, preferably with the coffee/pod already installed. The ready light kicks on within a minute or two of turning the machine on, but if you don't wait for the machine to fully pre-heat, you'll get nasty dishwater. 2) The machine nozzles are insanely low. You can only get a small espresso cup under the nozzles. This is a pain and I had to buy a special cup to make espresso. 3) The 'built-in tamper' is worthless. You need at least 20-30 pounds of pressure on the grounds to make a decent espresso. Since the machine only weighs a few pounds, pulling the grounds up on the tamper means you also have to be pushing down while pulling up, and keeping the grounds in place with a squat machine very close to your countertop, and well, you get it. Nearly impossible to do correctly. Buy a tamper! It makes a huge difference. Caveats: 1) I don't make lattes, but the steam gizmo does shoot out steam, so I guess it works correctly. Since the machine is so squat, it may be difficult to use without buying a very small pitcher. 2) I don't use the pre-packed espresso pods, so don't know if they work well or not, but would think they do. 3) I roast and grind my own coffee, and have not tried this with grocery store grounds.

Two caveats: (1) My five-star rating is entirely relative to the price of the machine; and (2) I have not used the milk frother. This machine makes genuine espresso with a nice crema. It’s labor-intensive. It’s manual so you need to monitor the process closely. The machine has a built-in tamper, which is convenient, and the drip tray is easy to remove and clean. The filter holder is easy to clean for multiple sequential use. The metal quality of the filter is very good. Lots of plastic in this machine but that is no surprise for the price. Be aware that the machine does not come with any cups or receptacles for the espresso. My own method: I heat a shallow bowl in a microwave while the machine warms up. (The clearance requires a shallow receptacle.) I then use that bowl to make the espresso while I heat 1/3 cup of nonfat milk in the microwave. I make more than two espresso shots because my goal in the end is an Americano. (I know that the dilution of the espresso at the front end is not ideal but I am happy with the outcome. I also use a regular grinder for beans instead of a burr grinder but it works well enough for me.) Once you perfect your own method, the machine can fit your needs. One problem is that the machine shakes in the brewing process so I put a bar towel in front of the bowl to stabilize it during the brewing process. My ultimate point is that high quality espresso makers cost thousands of dollars and require significant maintenance. This machine costs under $70 and the quality is very high relative to the low price.
reviews.review_header: Quality is very high relative to low price

reviews.review_text: This was purchased as a replacement for a $400+ espresso maker made by Breville. The Breville had all the bells and whistles including a built in burr grinder, so there was a lot to fail. I will talk about this first: the Breville's burr grinder hit the dust first, and after numerous cleanings and attempts to get it to be OK, we gave up on the grinder. Even though we cleaned it regularly as recommended, there was another failure which I would assume was a seam that gave way. We had already replaced the grinder with a $9.00 rotary type which works great. After reading the reviews of this machine we decided to try it and forget all the arty things we could get. This is a solid, no-nonsense little workhorse. Makes a good cup of espresso with the requisite crema, and the steam attachment does its job to make nice foam. It also foams more quickly than the more expensive machine, thus does not add much water to the milk, contributing to the taste of a good latte. As it's built in Italy, home of great espresso, I have high hopes that it will continue to do a great job, as we will maintain it carefully. Drawbacks: first time I used the steam button on top, I had to turn it open with a pliers as it was so tight. Now it's fine. Also, the directions are not great but good enough.
reviews.review_header: Great Little Workhorse replaceing a more expensive Machine

reviews.review_text: Purchased after some research. For the price, it is a great machine. As with many purchasers of espresso machines, I did a cost/benefit analysis and found that this machine paid for itself pretty quickly. We joke at out house every time we make a latte, we are making $5. As someone expressed before, the frother is a little awkward, but I have learned to work with it. As for the espresso, there is a technique that needs to be learned, and it is some trial and error as I work toward mastery. I did some research about how to make a better latte, and it made a great deal of difference in the quality of my brew. I did buy a tamper, but now just use the back of my spoon, however, I do use a thermometer when frothing. It is an easy machine to use and maintenance is straightforward and specific --a key element to facilitate the longevity of any machine. It works like a champ every morning. This is my first espresso machine, so I have nothing to compare it to other than my numerous observations at Peet's.
reviews.review_header: From a first-time espresso machine owner

reviews.review_text: The frothing wand works well but really bulky. It doesn't stay in place and swings freely. I had to bang on the water tank like other reviewers. I thought it was broken at first but the tank really needs to get into contact with the valve. Since knocking it into place the first time, the next time it sat in without any extra effort. Same with the filter holder. Just have to break it in without...actually breaking it, lol! It's overall really great and makes a nice espresso. Especially for this price. It's an excellent choice for home espressos and lattes. Sometimes I just grind the beans a little more coarse than for an espresso and tamper lightly for a regular cup of coffee. So when either my spouse or I want different kinds of coffee we can still use the same machine.

The first one started leaking after 5 days. Amazon quickly replaced it. The new one hasn't leaked in 3 weeks, and I use it daily. It makes good coffee, but it doesn't store enough hot water to make a double shot. Then to steam one serving of milk, you will have to steam in three separate operations and wait for the water to heat in between. Takes about 3 minutes to make a latte for one person after the water first heats up for five minutes. However, the final product is very good. The coffee is well made and the milk steamer makes great froth. Overall it is good for the price.
reviews.review_header: Good basic espresso maker for the price

reviews.review_text: Okay, now I love it. But let me tell you there is definitely a learning curve. It took me a long time to get the coffee hot enough or the milk foamed enough but now that I have figured it all out I am really happy I bought this. Like others have said, it's important to turn the machine on well before you are going to use it, I aim for the 15 minute mark. The other biggie is to steam the milk long enough. I was cranking that knob on the top wide open thinking that would make the difference but nope. Now I turn it just a quarter turn and am listening for the steam sound to change from a high pitched whine to a low rumble. I have used all sorts of non-dairy milks, my favorite is hemp milk, and it works just fine. It comes with two different sized containers to put the coffee in, the thing in which to tamp the coffee down and becomes the puck at the end (?). Anyway, I use the larger one and run it twice to get two shots. I don't know if this is how you're supposed to do it, and some of you coffee aficionados may be appalled, but it works great for me. I've had it for over a month now and use it every day. Love it!
reviews.review_header: There is a learning curve, hang in there, it works great!

reviews.review_text: After 7 months (Christmas to July) , it is still running strong, and we have not had any problems. We are not espresso-philes, and we only make espresso on the weekends; therefore we have not run the machine hard. However, we have run it long enough for any vices to appear, and I see none that warrant a reduction in rating. I do not give many five star ratings (reserving five stars for the extraordinary, and no product is either the best or the worst ever), but this deserves five stars BASED ON VALUE. Highly recommended for the casual espresso fan, those on a budget, or with limited space. The unit is very compact and does an amazing job for its size and cost. Some of the knocks against it in other reviews are legitimate. The frother is annoyingly long or short - depending on how you look at it. The bottom of the tip is not high enough above the table top to allow you to slide most pitchers or cups under it without raising the unit or seriously tipping the pitcher/cup. Also, the tip is not long enough to really bury it into the milk. It is true that most cups will not fit under the unit to receive the espresso from the machine; we just press it into small, heated espresso cups and then pour into the larger cup when the milk is ready. However, these vices are ones I've learned to live with, and I am now able to froth milk to a nice paint-like consistency on a regular basis, starting with a pitcher filled halfway. The frothing tip is made of soft plastic and, as mentioned elsewhere, it is easily possible to strip the threads on it when screwing it back on after cleaning. Haven't done it yet, but probably will. I will either order a new tip or buy the metal nut that someone else mentioned in a review of the unit. But you know what? The solutions are a larger, more expensive unit; I think the DeLonghi engineers did the best that could be done given the price and size parameters. You want perfection? Go spend an additional $700 on a professional machine. The unit is kind of loud and vibrates when building up pressure for a couple of seconds, but nothing that is going to wake the house. How do you steam milk without making noise? Actually, I kind of like it; it's like the little train that could. We have not had any of the leaks that others have complained of. I have broken it down for a cleaning per instructions, and it is easy to do. Buy a three-year extended warranty for next to nothing in case you get a lemon. Overall, and for the price, this is a great machine. No problems after 7 months, so mechanically sound. It does what it purports to be able to do in a very compact unit. I mean, for the cost, how can you beat it? I'm impressed enough that I have just ordered a grinder to improve the experience. I think anyone whinging about this DeLonghi either got a lemon - and that happens - or doesn't know the rule of getting what you pay for. Again: for the price, this is a great machine. Recommend the Lavazza esspresso bricks; we've tried the single-shot pads from various companies, and the DeLonghi doesn't like them nearly as much as hand-packed double-shots.
reviews.review_header: and no product is either the best or the worst ever)

reviews.review_text: Had an old Krups pump espresso machine many years ago that I loved, it was one of the early models before it became a thing to make your own espresso at home.
