Alas machines such as those get old over time. I waited years to find a replacment espresso machine and the De'Longhi EC155 fits the bill nicely. Don't let the price fool you - At the price I purchased it, $99, in every way this is a high quality, home espresso brewer that makes perfect espresso shots every time. Without fail it produces espresso with a wonderful crema top, is quick to start up (around 15 min if you wait for it, less than 10 if you do a pre-brew to heat it up faster) and easy to use. I have over filled the filter, under filled it and everything in between testing the right measure of grounds in it and it still consistently produces perfect shots. The steam wand for frothing works great for heating up the milk and although I have yet to master the art of frothing the milk perfectly, the wand itself works wonderfully. I have managed to make great froth a couple of times, but I attribute my failures to skill not the machine. Highly recommended machine for the espresso addicts - especially if you can't afford to keep up your vice via cafe shops XD
reviews.review_header: Don't let the low price deter you - this is a very high quality machine!

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: We had a baby gaggia and a breville. The gaggia was sold at a garage sale, it was a huge heavy machine and more than we needed. The Breville died and I started looking for another espresso machine. We got this one for ourselves as a Christmas present in 2009. It has been used pretty much at least once a day since. I have espresso every morning, on the weekends my husband joins me and we have two. The espresso turns out great, the crema is nice, the machine is smaller and lighter so leaves a smaller kitchen footprint. We haven't had any issues, find it easy to clean, and I would recommend this for someone who just wants a dependable machine that delivers good espresso and doesn't want to spend 1000 dollars. For the freshest best tasting espresso I grind my own beans using the Kitchenaid grinder KitchenAid Pro Line Series Burr Coffee Mill, Onyx Black For this demonstration I used the Hues n Brews espresso cups Hues & Brews Espresso Cups/Saucers, Tangier, Set of 4 The pump failed on the Dec 2009 purchase in June 2011. We decided to buy another one based on the price of the machine and the quality of the espresso. *updated 9/9/2012 Sadly the pump failed again at the 1 1/2 year point. We do make a lot of espresso. I decided to move on and tried the Phillip's saeco, pump failed in five days. Tried the super expensive la pavoni manual lever machine, hated it. We decided at the price of this machine and the quality of espresso we get from it we'll just replace it every year and a half.
reviews.review_header: Nifty little machine, great espresso- updated

reviews.review_text: First the PROS: it's reasonably priced, does not take up much space on the kitchen counter and makes a delicious espresso! Now the CONS: The distance between the filter spout (where the actual espresso comes out of) and the base tray is way too short (exactly 2 1/4"). Therefore using a regular cup or mug with this machine is nearly impossible! - unless you're using your kid's toy china collection ;). Also, When the machine is pouring out the drink it vibrates so much that I have to hang on to the cup i'm using, otherwise it'll vibrate itself out of position and thus miss the spout. Overall it's not a bad machine for a first time buyer like myself. But, just like with most things in life, you get what you pay for.
reviews.review_header: Not too bad for the price

reviews.review_text: I've had mine for a little over 2 years now. I use 7-9 times per week and it works as good now as when it was brand new. For the money it does the job. Rotate the front knob once to the right to heat water for espresso, when green light comes on it is ready to run. Rotate the knob once more to the right and the water is released. Then for steam, rotate front knob all the way to the left, wait for green light and the steamer is ready. For steam, rotate the top dial to open up the steam. (For the best steam quality, wait 2-3 minutes after green light for steam comes on. You can run right after green light but you should bleed off water before putting steam wand into coffee, but best results occur if you can wait for 3 three minutes!) The coffee grind holders can be disassembled for cleaning, to clean the machine above/inside where the coffee grind attaches, you empty old grinds, rinse under faucet, install, turn front knob to activate water, repeat until no more grinds are visible in grind filter basket, rinsing in between. You can also use q-tips or a wash rag to detail up inside the water release area where the grind holder screws on. The cup tray is removable as well as the stainless rack for cleaning. I make chocolate latte espresso, Use the single size grind filter, fill up a 1/3 cup of espresso, add to 2/3 cup of steamed whole milk, add 1-2 tablespoons of chocolate syrup. You can add seedless raspberry jam to this for an extra treat, chocolate/raspberry. For another variation, add 1/4 teaspoon of cinnamon to the top of the pressed grind for a cinnamon flavor. Homemade chocolate syrup recipe: Mix together; 1.5 Cup Sugar, 1.0 Cup Cocoa, and a 1/8 teaspoon of salt. Boil 1 Cup Water; the add 1/3 cup to the dry to create a paste, then add 1/3 more incorporate well, then add final 1/3 hot water stirring well, until you no longer feel gritty sugar. If needed, heat in microwave 10 seconds at a time, stirring in between, repeating as needed until all is well dissolved. Then add 2 tsp. Vanilla. Keeps well in the fridge, in a tightly sealed glass container for up to two weeks. Let me also suggest this for your coffee, Cafe Bustelo, available in many local grocers in the coffee isle or in the international or Hispanic section, very low price, or here on Amazon; http://www.amazon.com/Cafe-Bustelo-Coffee-Espresso-10-Ounce/dp/B001E95KLK Update 2016: Still going strong, this is a work horse! 15 bar is 15 bar, waste your money if you want, this machine just works!

I checked out many machines before taking a chance on this one. I had a steam type espresso machine for years, and also a Delonghi coffee\cappuccino maker. The Delonghi machine finally was worn out after about ten years of steady use, so I felt the brand was reliable. The first cup I made with this new machine was excellent. In the few weeks since I purchased it I have been very pleased with the quality and taste of the espresso, and truly enjoying every cup. I grind beans finely and have used a few different coffee brands so far. I have no problem frothing milk with a small metal pitcher, andIi find I can use a low height wide coffee mug to make the brew in and it will produce a good cup of strong coffee (not quite espresso strength)that is creamy and tasteful and is equal to about 2 1/2 shots of espresso. This makes a great morning drink for me. I put in the cup a shot of half and half, and a bit of sweetener before adding the coffee and it comes out perfect to my taste. Even looks inviting. I have made espresso in demi-tasse sized cups and that too is very good, but I enjoy a larger size cup so I opt for the wide mug recipe. This is a great machine so far, especially for the price, I am glad I got it and did not spend 300 or more for a fancier and seemingly higher end model. I highly recommend it to all but the most "fanatically obsessed" espresso drinkers. You will save a lot on fancy coffee bars with this unit. Added 2017.... I have had this machine for many years now. It is getting a little worn..the seals I guess. It drips when on and not running. But it still heats great and makes a superb cup. May have to buy one again. Added 6/17: Finally gave up on the old machine. After twice a day usage for 6 years it started to leak badly. I just bought a new one, same model. It is noticeably quieter and of course does not leak.
reviews.review_header: Had this for 6 years and just bought it again.

reviews.review_text: I lived in Italy for half my adult life and went "native" upon arrival Naples. Caffe' for me is a way of life, not just a breakfast beverage. Until I bought this machine in April for $80, I was using a heavy duty Krups machine for 20 years. Had the same machine in Italy and friends still use it in Naples. When I laid it to rest, I was leary of buying an Italian machine because of the European running joke about Italian mechanical anything being job security for the fix it folks. This machine blissfully contradicts that old wisdom (hope you're listening FIAT). They must have hired German engineers to match the italian design. The caffe' is authentic, with a perfect crema everytime. Though my life changed with the introduction of cappuccino in the 1980s, I actually haven't brewed one on this machine--Latte is fine for me. The taste of the crema I'd forgotten on my old machine and the use of the stovetop caffettiera. For the first 6 weeks I had this macchina bella, I had latte 3-4 times a day. The smell was exquisite. I can't better the reviewers who detail quantitatively the benefits and cons of the EC155. I can speak to the authenticity and incredible value for $80. A proposito--Do yourself a favor and get Lavazza or Illy Caffe' to use in it. Illy is ridiculously expensive but good and is used (or was, before the recession) at all the finest bars (cafe's). Lavazza red or higher is wonderful for 40%-%50% less. The perfect grind every time and authentic. (Amazon has a subscription that beats whatever you can get locally.) Chin Chin! Contentissima nel Mojave
reviews.review_header: Italian Expat in love with her EC155

reviews.review_text: So far we love this machine! The quality is good for what you pay! I read many of the negative comments and I recommend that people read the instructions that come with it! Many of your issues would be solved by reading the instructions. The warming up process is important! It makes for a nice warm espresso! The right temperature! We decided to get it because we believe there is nothing like these manual machines! The foam on the espresso is just right! As for the steam: well, I agree that the spout is a bit short...solution? Well, I just use a smaller Frother! We have to keep in mind that this is a mini espresso maker and is under $100...so I think you need to set your expectations! Just keep that in mind. We make cappuccinos and they turned out amazing with a nice thick foam...it's also all in the milk. Let's hope this machine lasts! Because if it does, it just fits the bill for what we need.
reviews.review_header: Great buy! Good quality and worth the money

reviews.review_text: I rarely review products, well that's not true, my wife will tell you I have an opinion for everything, but rarely do I post my opinions online. I like product research and when my second Mr. Coffee espresso maker quit functioning as it should I was on the hunt for a new one. Now I've only been through 2 of those machines in ~10 years, so I'm plenty pleased with their longevity, however, I've also used some pretty expensive machines and there are amazing. So I thought I'd shop my next one a little. All the reviews are pretty good, some just whine with one star so I threw those out and 100 bucks verses $40 versus several hundred, the EC155 seemed like a reasonable deal. Well... At first, I was surprised at how small this machine was when I unboxed it. Then I thought, ah but less intrusive on the counter...that will get me points for not taking up so much space in the kitchen. I like the removable water reservoir that hides inside the machine, but at first I didn't see how I was going to know I was out of water. Look closely at the pitcher and you will see the water window gauge to the left of where the cup sits. The problem being, that's where the steamer carafe sits and out of habit, I check the water level right as I'm finishing steaming my milk. So no big deal, I'll change my habit and take a peek down there now. The big problem I have is how small it is. Seriously, I can't get my regular steaming carafe nor my espresso cup/carafe under the relevant apparatus. Yep, that's my big complaint. This machine is tiny. I'll get a new catch cup and a new steaming pitcher, but it just feels so tiny to operate with these man hands. So why 4 stars...because the end product is what I'm really after and this machine makes amazing espresso for lattes and cappuccinos. Upgrading from a steam to a pump driven system makes more of a difference than I was previously willing to admit. You can actually see the layers of crema and it tastes awesome. A note about the steaming wand, besides it being so close to the counter (in height), the arm is sort of "spring" loaded and wants to return close to the machine. I, personally, find this annoying. Also, the arm's reach down in the pitcher is really short, so during those times I use less milk, this short arm makes is more challenging to reach the milk. Now...with that said, the milk steamed up really well and the "aerator" on the tip wasn't as annoying as I thought it was going to be (I usually use it without but this one doesn't appear to be removable). The froth was nice and thick and easy to make. The biggest upgraded from my last machine was that the milk came up to temperature quite quickly. So at the end of the day, I would recommend this espresso maker. It makes great tasting espresso drinks. Upgrade your steam driven maker and you won't be sorry. Just take heed, this machine is small, so if you do find a machine similar to this, that is a little taller, buy that one.
reviews.review_header: Awesome upgrade from my last one

reviews.review_text: I purchased my 1st machine about 2 months ago and have used it to make 2-3 drinks a day. I liked it so much I purchased another one, from another vendor, for my vacation home. Unfortunately, I got 2 duds in a row-both duds expelled steam and water(up to 3 oz) in the warm-up phase. The machine should NOT lose any steam or water in that process. I was able to get another one that works properly from Amazon and I am again pleased. Starbuck's brand espresso, ground on the turkish coffee setting, is still to course to get a good cup of espresso on this machine. Medaglia D'Oro works much better. I have also had success with Fairway espresso beans ground at the espresso setting. Both are flour-like in consistency. If I had a grinder I would try a little bit coarser grind but not by much. I get very good crema with both those coffees. The frother works great. A few videos on Youtube and some practice is all you need. Better to do the milk prior to pulling the shot so that the coffee is still fresh. This machine would be better for me if there was more height for the cups so that if I made a latte/macchiato I would not lose the crema when pouring from a shot glass. Cups that are 2 1/2" slide under without tilting. You can remove the stainless steel drip tray and slide in a cup about 3 1/4" in height. Also, I would like either more space under the frother to accommodate a larger pitcher or a frother that can tilt out at an angle. You can use a 12oz pitcher but it must tilted slightly to get in and out. I have placed the machine on a piece of wood to increase the height from the bottom of the frother and the counter. Another solution is to place the machine close to the sink so that the frother swings out over the sink. All in all, it is a great machine for money.

I have had this brand new machine out of the box all afternoon. I have read the instructions through repeatedly. I fill the tank, I know it's on the valve correctly. The filter holder is in place. But when the "OK" light comes on and I turn the knob to the dispensing position, the pump runs but nothing ever comes out. This is brand new, so I can't believe the boiler output is already clogged. How long is this thing supposed to crank away before dispensing something? I know that the steam wand works, but for some reason no water passes through the filter holder. I am also appalled to read in the instructions that the thing is supposed to be on 15 minutes, and then another 30 minutes, before brewing. Are they crazy? Do they expect me to set up and wait 45 minutes to brew 2 ounces of espresso? Are they serious? I had a lot of hopes in this machine, having worked with a steam espresso maker for years. I was looking forward to making the real thing. I guess I have to wait. --- UPDATE: Amazon's excellent return service is wonderful. I filed for a return/replacement and today (Nov 3) I have the new unit. Set it up and I've had way more espresso this afternoon than any sane person should. I'm jittery, wide-eyed, my bladder is shot, but this is wonderful espresso. Really hot, which I like, nice crema, the milk wand works well especially with the 12 oz milk frothing pitcher I ordered with the first unit. Since I just make this for myself in my office and sometimes for a colleague, the capacity is nice. I also happened to have a nice set of china cups that fit perfectly under the filter holder. ____ So all's well. I give this unit 4 stars. My only CONS so far are: *the low clearance-though my nice cups fit, I wish I could put a mug or small pot under there-but see below! *I wish the frothing wand was higher and longer so I could froth more milk. What it does is okay for me now, but I wish I could do a little more. Otherwise, happy camper. _____ Another UPDATE: The only complaint I have had with this machine has been, as others have said, the narrow space underneath that restricts the size of cup you can use. Well today I realized the obvious. You can just lift out the cup tray and you immediately get another .75-1 inch of vertical clearance, more than enough for most cups suitable for a double-shot espresso or latte. Just a simple tip, but it has greatly increased my enjoyment of this machine.
reviews.review_header: I Gave Up-But tried Again-Really Happy

reviews.review_text: I worked as a barista for about a year back when we had to actually pull the shot by hand so this was not a difficult machine to figure out. I recouped my investment in less than a month since i no longer need to stop at at the corner for my morning latte. I'm throwing the cash I save into a jar for other things. Tips: - FILL THE WATER TANK BEFORE EACH USE It's a habit that will save your machine. - Get a tamper, the built in one is a joke. - Buy a couple of good shot glasses for pulling the shots. - Put the machine on a small stand. The steam wand is quite low to the counter. - Buy whole bean espresso roast and get it ground for an espresso machine, regular coffee from a can will not do. -Don't smash the grounds into the holder. A light but firm packing is best. - Don't bother with a fancy frothing pitcher for this unit. I froth the milk in the same sturdy ceramic mug that I use for drinking my latte, when the mug wall is too warm to comfortably hold, the milk is almost done. -Keep the milk level about halfway up the steam nozzle. When you're almost done, bring it down to the bottom of the nozzle to get your froth. - Pull your shots after you froth the milk, and dump them in and enjoy. - You can pull shots right after frothing but not vice versa. - If you are a syrup user, you may want a frothing pitcure. 3 pumps of syrup for 12oz, 4 for 16oz, and 5 for 20oz. Peppermint users may want to back off 1 pump depending on your tastes. This is a great starter machine. With care I would expect an everyday user to pay for their machine many times over ($5 latte / day = $35 a week, do the math). UPDATE 7/12 - I celebrated it's one year anniversary recently. I do not use distilled water, but I do clean it regularly and have had no problems with it. Blatant Plug: I use Urnex Cleancaf Coffee Maker & Espresso Machine Cleaner and Descaler to keep my machine clean. I use the Amazon subscription service for my Coffee Bean Direct beans and Torani syrups to save the most money.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: Solid machine so far. The key is having a grind that is not too fine and one that is not packed down too tightly in the head. If the coffee is too fine and/or tamped down too much, it can take 10+ minutes to fill the cup. I am still experimenting with how fine a grind to use and how much tamping pressure to exert, but clearly the machine does not have the kind of pump pressure that you would find in at coffee shop machine. Given that, it cannot easily penetrate too dense a charge of coffee in the head. But at 15 BAR, this DeLonghi makes for a perfectly enjoyable espresso if you are willing to play with the variables a bit. No regrets!

I've been using this now for several months. I have a latte addiction :-) and I've almost completely stopped going to starbucks now that I can make just as good of a latte at home. I watched a 5 minute youtube to learn how to use the machine - it's actually very, very simple and makes great espresso! I like the Illy Dark Roast Espresso, but there are a lot of different types. Pros: Much quicker than running a few miles away to Starbucks, and it's just as good Super easy to learn how to use Setup doesn't take long (once you put the water in and start heating it up, it's ready to go fairly quickly) Cons: The built in tamper is not that great - I bought another one for like $8. The frother seems to take a bit of time. I don't care about froth so I always just put milk in the microwave while I make the espresso shots. I wish there was about another 3 or 4 inches of height. Not a huge deal to work around, but I would love to get 1 4oz cup under there instead of using 2 separate shot glasses (2oz each), but I can't find a bigger 4oz cup that is short enough to fit. So for now I just use the 2 separate shot glasses. Overall, this is one of the best purchases I've made and I would buy it again in a heartbeat! (and recommend it to everyone else!)
reviews.review_header: -) and I've almost completely stopped going to starbucks now that I can make just as good of a latte at home

reviews.review_text: My review is based on the price I paid for this - a used unit for $59 in April 2016. For that price, it's a rockstar machine. My goto machine is a slightly modified Gaggia Evolution I got on eBay a few years back for $150 - I'll always prefer my Gaggia, but I wanted a simple espresso machine for my studio in the city. Here comes the EC155. I only use this machine for ESE espresso pods and frothing milk. Very quiet and powerful pump. Heats up quickly and the steam wand is surprisingly strong! I don't like the plastic auto-frother, but it does create nice froth. I use it with Intenso Aroma DI Caffe Forte Espresso E.S.E. Pods - these pods are packed pretty tightly and it still extracts nicely.
reviews.review_header: Incredible machine for the price! I use it only for ESE espresso pods and frothing milk. Quiet pump, powerful steam.

reviews.review_text: I'll give this a five star rating but I almost left four when my espresso maker arrived in a wet plastic bag. Does the company test them before shipping them or was this a return? I am thinking they test them first so I used it anyways. It is a process to make the cappuccino. But the frother works great. I still need to perfect using the frother. I have tried to make my cappuccino taste like the coffee shop's, but it isn't near there yet. I have a typical blade grinder for my beans, and yes I know to get a higher quality burr grinder but I have to use this for now. I don't know what they have or do but I find I may never duplicate the flavor of the coffee shop. It's a shame. BUT, the built in tamper works just fine, I think it does the job. The machine is small and compact so there's extra room for cups and stuff on the counter next to it. The colors are nice. Black and silver. It doesn't vibrate too hard while brewing, the cup stays in place. The water pitcher is easy to remove but it can be filled just left in too. The instructions are easy to read, and once you get the hang of it a couple times you won't need them anymore. I'm glad I bought this because I get a strong brew something I could never get with my previous machine (Keurig) and that's because I love cappuccino's! A little thing I do is make my froth BEFORE I make my cappuccino coffee, I think it gives the coffee better flavor. UPDATE: so I've used this little machine for awhile now and I needed to come back and let you know that I stopped making the froth before the espresso because it could burn the coffee by getting the water too hot, so I make it the normal way and it works perfectly. I have since perfected my cup of cappuccino by making better froth and by adding a hairs pinch of cinnamon to it. It is less than a pinch but it gives it a smoother flavor! So I am very happy with it!

I have a Jura machine and this De'Longhi. I bought the De'Longhi in Dec 2011 and it is still going strong - with no maintenance at all. I use filtered water. I moved it to my office after we received the Jura as a gift. I prefer this one for its more "authentic" experience, and the Jura for its simplicity (if you don't count all the mandatory rinsing). Pros: Simple operation and maintenance Great flavor It really creates nice crema (the tan layer on top of the espresso) Price / value Durability I bought mine in Dec 2011 and it is still going strong Heats up in about 45 seconds Cons Few cups fit in it; they have to be about 2" or shorter (see pic with standard mug) Few cups fit below the frother; 3.5" or shorter The grounds / filter cup is not attached, so you cannot tap it out like a normal espresso maker. It is a retention handle, but that will get you a smashed thumb. All-in-all, I recommend it: GREAT FLAVOR; GREAT VALUE.
reviews.review_header: Great, but with some minor issues

reviews.review_text: This is exactly what I wanted, at the price I was able to afford. I wanted a pump machine for under $100. I thoroughly read the various reviews here before I chose which machine to buy. It took a variety of methods of tamping the grounds before I came to the method which works best for me. I had lived most of my life in Miami, FL, so I was used to walking up to a window on almost every block of every street, and getting a cafe' cubano (50 cents) or a cafe' con leche (75 cents). So that is the flavor I like in my espresso; thick and rich, but I do want a nice layer of crema. I purchase either Bustelo or Pilon, already ground, in the can. (Miami Cuban coffee). Call me lazy and plebian if you wish; I love the flavor, and the grind is just perfect. I make two espresso cupsfull at the same time. First I preheat the espresso maker about 15 minutes. Turn it on, and go do something else for a bit. I use the two cup holder of the machine. Insert it, and dispense the hot hot water into the two cups I am going to use. This preheats the holder, and the cups. Dry the grounds holder - careful, is HOT! Then I fill the holder with one scoop of coffee grounds, tap tap it down to settle the grounds, then press firmly with an old tamper that I have from my last machine by someone else, I dont even remember whose machine it was. I don't use the tamper that is attached to the machine. (following what all the reviews on here said!) Then I add the second scoop of grounds, tap tap it to settle it down, and tamp that down as well. Clean off the edge so there are no grounds to interfere with the seal. It is filled just below the rim. I insert the holder tightly into the machine, and dispense the espresso into both my preheated little cups at the same time. The left nozzle seems to give a little bit more, a little faster; maybe because the water holder is on that side? YES, you have to hold the cups still, or they will dance. Actually, I fold a paper napkin on the grate under the cups, and they stay still. YES, it makes noise. So what?! This is NOT a $5,000 machine! I want it to make the coffe I like. Let it dance and moan, I dont care! I find that I am able to get two well-flavored strong cups of espresso, with a nice layer of crema. I had to play around with the firmness of tamping down until I got it right. To me, for this price, it is a great machine. If it falls apart after a year, I will have gotten my money's worth, and will get another. You just have to fool around with the pressure of tamping and amount of grounds to suit your taste.

I have been using this machine for about ~1 year now and I have been very satisfied with this product. I read up on many reviews and finally concluded to purchase this espresso machine and I am glad I did. Both the espresso maker and froth/boiler work great. It is soooo convenient that the water tank is removable, love this feature. As far as the espresso it makes goes, I can't say anything bad. I roast my own beans so it probably helps. I have given brief pro's / con's which pretty much go along with other reviews for this machine. Pros -Pretty easy to clean and the tray is removable. -This machine comes with two cups -Heats up pretty quick (~2 min)....although you probably want to let it sit for a bit longer so that the grounds basket also heats up Cons -I don't use the built in tamper, wish they provided this separately, oh well no biggie. -The only thing with the frothing is that I have to set the machine on top of a pan so that I can get under the wand to froth the milk. Pretty low machine, but this also allows me to place it under my cabinet. So I like how it is : ) -Note that you will have to use a 2 oz espresso cup as the height (grounds cup to lower tray) will not permit you to fit a 4 oz cup.
reviews.review_header: Well built machine, reasonable price, great espressos!!

reviews.review_text: It's been about a year since I bought the EC155 and I decided it's finally time to post a review. Our house makes up to 10 doubleshots per day and it's still going strong. With an average of 6 shots per day over the last year, that's 2,190 shots. I looked into buying this because my girlfriend and I were spending at LEAST $8/day on lattes. I didn't want to give up my delicious morning lattes, but I really couldn't afford to keep spending the $132/month for coffee. So I looked into making Espresso at home and haven't looked back since. If you're like I was and want to experiment with homemade lattes, this is a great machine to start with. Making Espresso at home is fun and novel for a while, but stops being worth it unless you're really making good shots comparable to the coffee shop, or its 1am and you're desperate for espresso and everything is closed. It is completely possible to make lattes comparable to a coffee shop using this machine, but there are a few requirements. This is a semi-automatic machine and you will be learning how to pull your own shot of espresso with it. This also means you can make a horrible shot. You will probably make a lot of horrible shots. And then you will (hopefully) realize what you are doing wrong, and the shots will start to become great. Don't expect to pull it out of the box and instantly make something great. In fact, the most likely thing to happen is you actually start making mediocre shots and feel the machine is only mediocre, when you could somehow improve and make great shots. You need good beans, and you need a good grind. This sounds really simple, but it isn't necessarily. The best coffee you're going to make with the EC155 is from beans you grind right before making your coffee. I paired the machine with a Rancilio Rocky, which is considerably more expensive than this guy (3-4 times more expensive in fact). My justification was, even after I upgrade the EC155, I will keep the Rocky. The Rocky is an excellent machine, but there are probably (somewhat) cheaper grinders that will get comparable results. But I can only speak to my setup and the results I've gotten. The only downside to not grinding your own beans is they will go stale much faster than grinding yourself. This just means you need to buy smaller quantities more frequently. I think it's worth the tradeoff if you aren't sure whether the grinder investment is worth it. I've praised the machine quite a bit, but there are some downsides. A traditional non-iced latte calls for steamed milk. The steam arm on this machine is really low and hard to work with sometimes. It steams and frothes milk okay, but it can be a pain to work with and clean. We usually make iced lattes because of this. The temp indicator on the front, which tells you when its ready to go, goes on briefly for steaming, and then off again, and then some time later comes back on when it's actually ready to make espresso. This can be really confusing at first and there probably should have been a better indicator. This can contribute to bad shots if you start pulling a shot thinking its ready (like I did at first). The machine's vibration actually moves the espresso glass around on the drip tray. I accidentally solved this by buying 3oz espresso shot glasses that stick up around the portafilter, so it holds itself in place. I watch the cup dance around and then get filled with espresso every morning. If your shot glasses are not this tall, you will probably have to hold them in place. This can be very dangerous because they get hot, and if you slip you can be burned. Related to the above, you cannot fit any sort of regular cup under the dispenser area. Like at all. This worked for the shot glasses I bought, but it's really frustrating tiny if you want to dispense into anything other than shot glass. Even the tiny metal steaming pitcher I have won't fit. Lastly, I specifically mentioned lattes (normal and iced) earlier because I don't usually drink straight espresso or Americanos. Putting the shot into any sort of milk removes a lot of the specific flavors of the shot, which can be good and bad. What turns out to be pretty good lattes may only be a mediocre shot of espresso. I can't really comment on that, so remember that in regards to my review. Pros: -Can make a great shot if you're willing to learn with it. -Really durable, has made over 2000 shots in the last year. -Excellent starter machine. But It's is not a $600 machine. It's great as long as you aren't expecting that. Cons: -Takes time to learn how to make great shots with, especially in learning the pull time/grind needed. -Small platform for cups/shot glasses. Can't find regular sized cups. -Vibrates a lot. Your mileage may vary and if you're experienced with espresso you might prefer a more expensive machine, but I've enjoyed it and think its a great machine for anyone looking to start making espresso at home.
reviews.review_header: Best Intro Machine I could have asked for

reviews.review_text: Pros: The machine makes good espresso. That's the main thing. At probably half the price of the next cheapest machine. Cons: 1) the machine vibrates like crazy when brewing and rattles my cup all over the plate. I have to hold the cup in place risking burns if anything goes wrong during brewing. I'll probably fashion some way to keep the cup from moving around (some day... probably after I get burned). 2) there is always water inside the machine which lhas eaked from water holder. This is my second EC155. I used to remove the reservoir after each brewing (I don't like standing water) but I finally figured out that the water in the pipes keeps leaking out (all over the place) after a brewing so I quit taking out the reservoir. I don't know why water still leaks from the reservoir even when the reservoir is in place. But judging by the drainage hole at the bottom of the reservoir holding area DeLonghi expects leakage (or at least planned for it). So if you take the reservoir out to empty it, don't leave it out... water will (in my experience) leak from the pipes out onto the counter. 3) the frothing nozzle (which I don't use) is always in the way. It rattles against the cup when the nozzle is pinned against the machine or the nozzle interferes with taking the 'handle' out after brewing.
reviews.review_header: The machine makes good espresso. That's the main thing

reviews.review_text: This machine makes excellent espresso, and looked great when I opened it. I bought it "used, like new." After using it for about a week it started leaking ever I used the other settings, so if I use the steamer the coffee continues to drip. I have to have a cup underneath. The cups also move when the machine is on, so I have to put a damp paper towel under the shot glasses to prevent it. The metal cover also moves under the cups so I actually had to tape it down. In spite of all of this I still enjoy the machine, because It makes incredible espresso and steams the heck out of some milk, I use it with regular and soy milk and get a super foamy, hot, lushes result! I also steam milk for hot cocoa for my kiddo's with it.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I purchased this from Amazon warehouse deals, paying 64 dollars with the possibility of "5 percent cosmetic damage'" and the only cosmetic issue I see is faint paint on the steamer dial. I fired this bad boy up today running through the 5 basically water coffee runs to prime it and clean it out. I ordered Lavazza crema de gusto Italian espresso as another review stated, a 12 oz stainless steel pitcher for steaming, a thermometer for milk, a tamper, and De'Longhi shots cups. Overall I think I paid 110 for all listed. Cons: Yes the steamer wand is small, but it works for a 12 oz pitcher, anything bigger probably would need some accomodations on the edge of the counter. * The metal plate under where the espresso comes up, I had to move it, in order to have enough depth for my shot glasses to fit, but that's easy, and not such a big deal. * The instructions make you feel a little bit overwhelmed, but when you get started it's second nature (I did own a coffee shop once and when I got started...it felt great!) Pros: PRICE! * Ease of steamer wand, like I said I owned a shop and am very picky about good foam, Even getting used to it, was a quick process. * I ordered the Lavazza espresso in a three pack, I am so glad I did. I noticced the first shots I pulled had a dark color, no crema, so I looked to the manual, second time I loaded the shot fuller, tamped it a little harder (not to much, with a good twist), and it was beautiful! * Ease of cleaning: Not too much to take off, dump espresso, rinse, unscrew the steamer wand plastic tip and rinse it after steaming out a bit after pulling from milk. * TASTE: WOW, I crave lattes that remind me of handmade as when I had my shop, big name places and little places often don't offer consistency, this latte today with a couple spoons of sugar made me so excited, it was so much better than any I have had in a very long time, since I owned an industrial machine myself. Tips: Order equipment to go with it, read the instructions, use distilled water to prolong the life of the machine, and clean it daily (maybe even look up espresso cleaners), keep a towel by you when steaming, if its a wet one, you can wipe the steel wand off and get the milk off immediately (think coffee shop barista :), get a good ground espresso, I highly recommend the Lavazza. Yes I have only owned this for a few days, but having a shop where I made drinks for a living, I had a high expectation, and in the comfort of my home, it is absolutely met!
reviews.review_header: From a former cafe owner, VERY PLEASED

reviews.review_text: This baby makes a great cup of espresso. However, to get a great cup of espresso, there are a few RULES you MUST follow: -- First, you MUST tighten the handle REALLY well. I mean REALLY well. The only way I can get this tight enough is to literally turn the machine around so it faces away from me, bear hug it, hold it with one and and crank it tight with the other hand. There is no other way I can get it tight enough. If I do NOT tighten it this way, I end up with a far less superior cup of espresso. If I use pods, I end up with a soggy pod and little crema. If I use ground espresso, I end up a pool of soopy grounds, and little crema. Now that I have gotten used to the process, it doesn't bother me much. However - if i had known this before i bought it, I probably would have chosen a different machine. If you want to just leave it sitting nicely on the counter and not bear hug your espresso machine every time you brew a cup, you may want to look at other options. To make a great espresso, this machine requires a "hands on" approach. -- You MUST buy a good metal tamper to go with this if you plan to use ground espresso. The plastic one attached is junk. -- Regarding soupy grounds. Other reviewers have complained about soupy grounds and not getting a hard puck after brewing. See above -- they are not tamping their grounds enough, and not cranking the handle so it's tight enough. If you tamp the heck out of the grounds and crank that handle tight, you will get a beautiful dark rich shot with a beautiful layer of crema. Every single time - but only if you follow the the rules --TAMP WELL AND GET THAT HANDLE REALLY REALLY TIGHT. -- Pods vs. ground. I have only used Lavazza pods, but both ground and pods make delicious espresso, so long as you follow the rules - tamp & tighten. -- Steamer -- you definitely need a short pitcher to accommodate the short wand. -- Other PROs = small footprint, large water capacity, quick heat up (especially if you put it on steam first) -- Other NEGs = have to hold the cup while it brews or else it will vibrate out from under the spout In summary - this is not as convenient as I would have hoped, with the turning, bearhugging, and crazy cranking of the handle every time. Honestly, I would prefer to just heat it up, turn the handle without bearhugging it, and brew a shot. But, it's not enough of an inconvenience for me to return it. And, for the price, it makes an amazing espresso. So -- weigh the pros & cons and decide if bearhugging your machine every day is enough of a turnoff to get another machine. I swear -- I cannot get a great cup without doing the bearhug.
reviews.review_header: Makes great espresso, but it has some issues that make it less conveient than it could be

reviews.review_text: I can't really complain... for the price, it does everything it says it will do and more. It's a bit slow to brew, and you have to sometimes pause in frothing/steaming to let the water heat back up again, but it produces fantastic results for the price! My only beef is in the fact that when I'm running a shot or two of Espresso, I have to actually hold the cup in place because the vibration from the pump makes the cup slowly slide off center. (thus my 4 instead of 5 star review) Other than that, you get more than you expect for the price. Great RICH brew, great creme on top. Quite the buy for a budget barista!

I wanted to express my satisfaction with this product. I spent over a month studying all the reviews and watching countless UTUBE demonstrations on how to make good espresso, nothing worked and almost sent it back. Finally, I gave up and bought some espresso coffee at the grocery store, ( $ 5.00) for a can. Filled the basket and right before my eyes, I had the most delicious espresso and thick crema! All the time I spent with a blade grinder was a waste of time and now I am about to make another great espresso. I did encounter the "wet puck" but does not concern me . I highly recommend this machine and encourage others to just go buy the right coffee unless you have the bucks to buy a burr grinder and go all out. Excellent machine for the money!
reviews.review_header: I spent over a month studying all the reviews and watching countless UTUBE demonstrations on how to make good espresso, nothing

reviews.review_text: Easy to use, makes very good espresso. Unfortunately, pump stopped working properly after two years, and no longer can produce adequate pressure for making espresso. We are buying another one of the same machine, as it seems to be the best espresso for the money, but if had the budget would probably spring for a more expensive machine that would be less likely to break so quickly. As other reviewers noted, the attached tamper that comes with the machine is completely useless, so need to buy a separate metal tamper. Not much clearance, so need to use an espresso cup or small mug to collect the coffee. Overall, we have been happy with the machine and it worked great for two years of daily use, just disappointed that it failed so quickly (thus 4 stars instead of 5).
reviews.review_header: Makes great espresso, unfortunately broke after 2 years

reviews.review_text: Purchased this machine over 5 years ago. Been very happy with it! I do believe it is starting to fail but for the $80 I paid for it we can't complain. Excellent deal, will buy DeLonghi again for sure. The key with the longevity of these machines is to use purified water. Hard water deposits are a killer for this type of stuff.

Good product & highly rated for value. I bought this as a replacement, but did my research & considered an upgrade. This hit's the mark for a good Espresso maker especially for value! it rates top 10! My previous finally petered out and it lasted 8-10 years. The customer service was quite good and quick. It arrived quickly, but was defective. I called and spoke with the representative. After trying several problem solving methods, we agreed it was a defective unit. He told me simply to cut the cord of the defective unit & upon receiving, they sent a new one! Well designed, Good product, great value, great customer service, that makes a great Espresso.
reviews.review_header: very good Espresso from a great value with great customer service

reviews.review_text: I bought this espresso maker almost 3 years ago, in April of 2012. Since then it's been used almost on a daily basis, and has had 2-6 shots pushed through each time. So it's been well used. Here we are in March of 2015, and honestly, it's just about run its life. It leaks out the bottom, the seals are going, the days of having enough pressure to produce a hockey puck (instead of soupy mess) in the basket are long over, etc. Yet it STILL makes a pretty good cup of espresso. I still get good crema and it still has enough pressure to foam milk like a boss. Really, the only downside is a bit more mess when it's in use. I have paid a LOT more in the past and received a lot less for espresso machines. I will be purchasing a new one, to replace the old one. If the cost of ownership over 3 years is $30 - well heck, that's less than a month of coffee shop lattes.
reviews.review_header: After 3 Years of Daily Use, it's Time for a Retirement Party

reviews.review_text: This was my first espresso maker, and being the research freak that I am it took me two months of constant waffling to decide which one to buy. My criteria: >Price; I couldn't spend over a hundred dollars >Convenience; If it was too difficult, I wouldn't use it in the mornings >Ease of cleanup; if it was too hard to clean, I'd let it grow moldy and crusty, and chuck it in the garbage when it became a health hazard (the fate of my previous coffee pot. I'm a pig). >Ability to make true espresso; drinking cappuccino at Starbucks has changed my palate enough that regular coffee with milk just tastes too blah now. >Milk frothing wand; I don't drink straight espresso. >Ability to make two cups; if I were to make myself a cappuccino in the morning, and didn't make one for my 12-year-old, there would be tears and eye-rolling aplenty. I've been using the De'Longhi for over a month now, on a daily basis, and am shocked by how easy it is! I really expected it to take a lot of trial and error to learn how to (a) brew espresso and (b) froth milk, but I succeeded on my first try. Granted, the first couple of cups had a slight burnt taste, but they were drinkable. Bear in mind that I chose to start with espresso pods while learning, but just received a grinder for Christmas and feel ready to start that as well. The instructions give a couple of different options for operation, and I've seen a lot of advice from users, so I'll throw my own process in to the mix. Maybe there are more refined and hoity-toity methods out there, but mine has been fool-proof (literally) so far: Step 1: Pour DISTILLED water into the chamber (tap water will cause scaling later on, and since I've already admitted I'm a pig you know that I would never clean it, and end up breaking the unit). Step 2: Place an espresso pod in the basket. Step 3: Turn on the unit and wait 15 minutes for it to warm up (do NOT pay attention to the green "ready" light; I'll explain below.) Step 4: Place an espresso glass or shotglass under the tap, with a bit of flavored syrup in it, and turn the dial to "brew". DON'T WALK AWAY! Watch, and turn it off after a couple of ounces have brewed (about the contents of a shot glass). You can go longer, but the espresso will become lighter in color, and taste weaker. Step 5: I then immediately brew a second glass for my daughter, but ONLY because she does not realize the second cup is weaker and doesn't taste as good. The "correct" way would be to use the double basket, or another pod, but I'm cheap. Step 6: Froth the milk in the mug I'm going to use (I use skim and it froths great). I tried the small frothing pitcher that was recommended by another user, but this wand is very low to the counter, and I found it clumsy. Also, it was a bit hard to get the wand down into the bottom of the pitcher. My small mug work just fine, and doing so also serves to preheat the mug and requires less dishwashing (pig, remember?) I dip the wand in just far enough to submerge the end and move it around. Once the milk looks good and frothy I dunk the wand all the way in for about 5 seconds, to heat up the rest. Step 7: I pour the espresso into the edge of the mug, so I don't displace much of the foam. Then I drink it and tell everyone on Facebook that I'm a fancy lady who has a cappuccino maker in her kitchen. Cleanup is a breeze; so much easier than a regular coffee maker, in fact. I just toss the espresso pod, rinse my cup, and screw off the plastic frothing attachment to run some water through it. Ta da! If you don't have time to wait for the unit to preheat, there's another method. Turn on the unit, wait a minute for the green "ready" light to come on, and brew some water through it. Wait another minute for the green light to come back on, and repeat a few times. Then put the espresso in and brew. It's a bit faster, but requires you to stand there and work. I have not yet tested the larger basket designed for brewing two glasses. The one drawback I've found is that the basket handle does not want to turn quite all the way, so if I were to use the double basket (which has two nozzles), I would have to set the glasses a bit diagonally from each other to make sure they lined up with the drips. If that's the only problem I can find with this machine, then I'm gonna call it a win. I still go to Starbucks regularly, but not as often. What was costing me $4 to $6 there now costs me about 75 cents. I bought an 18-pack of 18 Lucaffe' Decaf Espresso Pods and an 18-pack of Lavazza Espresso Pods Decaf/Paper, 18--Count so I could drink decaf in the evenings (see my reviews of both), For those of you wanting to buy a tamper instead of using the plastic one that's built in, the Espresso Tamper 50 & 60 Mm Sizes Cast Alloy Hand Coffee fits the basket correctly. I'm really glad I bought this; it had been awhile since I'd been able to buy myself something nice, and this has felt like a real treat after coming off of a long financial slump. I highly recommend buying yourself one; you won't regret it! I do check my account regularly, so I'm happy to answer any questions I can.
reviews.review_header: Easy to make perfect espresso, even for a novice!

reviews.review_text: If you are looking for a cup of perfectly brewed espresso that brings out the nutty, fruity, chocolatey notes of the bean - such as you've only had in smaller specialty coffee stores (i.e. NOT Charbucks) then don't buy this machine. Instead, buy a machine with PID temperature control, double boiler and E61 grouphead and spend roughly $1500+: don't forget the hours of practice and research to learn how to properly brew, too - can't just run into it willy-nilly. However, if you are like me and know you won't be able to afford your "dream machine" for some time and are putting away those pennies in the piggy bank to buy the machine (and grinder) of your dreams in a year or two, then by all means, purchase this machine, you won't regret it! There was a little learning curve, I do a small amount of temperature surfing on it and make sure to bleed all the water out of the steam wand before steaming as it can be a little wet. I used to frequent Charbucks regularly - after getting this machine hadn't been there for almost a month and then while out shopping, I bought my usual (latte or machiato). I was amazed at how poorly it tasted compared to mine at home! I hadn't realized the difference because when I started, I was making a sub-standard cup of coffee, but apparently my skill gradually increased without me realizing it: my wife wouldn't even finish hers stating it was "disgusting"! Big surprise. She loves Charbucks. Now I'm more determined then ever to continue saving for my "dream machine" and continue to hone my skills on this little guy. My only complaint is that all the technique I'm learning to properly steam my milk into a microfoam (it is possible - watch a video made by Seattle Coffee Gear) will need to be re-learned as this has the panarillo wand. But in all fairness, it probably wouldn't generate enough steam for a good microfoam without it. One last note- I love espresso too, but I don't bother making it. Good espresso is an art requiring proper grind and tamp (which are moot points with a pressurized portafilter) and brew temperature (which is admittedly inconsistent - don't read that as a real flaw though, b/c machines costing $700+ have the same temp problem - hence "temperature surfing"). So anyway, I often "test" the espresso before making my milk-based drinks and sometimes it is quite good; but for the most part I would say make the milk-based drink as it will hide many of the flaws in the espresso and will ultimately produce more consistent and satisfying results. I'm happy with my purchase.
reviews.review_header: 5 stars from a lover of coffee

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: Since I didn't know what I wanted for an espresso machine, I opted for a reconditioned. Half the price and I get to try this out. Well I really like it. It does have a vibration that moved the shot glasses but I've since figured that out. It makes a beautiful espresso. The steamer/frother works great too. I love the ease of putting the water in the back. I'm planning to upgrade to a larger one in the future, but right now, this works great! The espresso shot it manual for each one and does not turn off by itself. Once I got used to that, it was easy.
reviews.review_header: Great Espresso Machine for the price!

reviews.review_text: Great espresso maker. It's not the best of the best, but worth it for your money. Pros: -Has a steam wand -15 bars of pressure -Has an adjustable steam dial on top -Stores a lot of water, so you don't constantly have to refill -Has a drip drawer on the bottom for easy cleaning Cons: -Steam wand is really short -Cannot heat up the steam and the water for espresso at the same time, leading to pauses between steaming milk and making espresso (espresso gets colder) -Makes a fair amount of noise while making espresso, but it's tolerable. Other: -If you wish to change your steam wand and are handy, you can exchange it for the silva v1/v2 (can buy it off Ebay) and look up webpages on how to disassemble and modify it yourself. Do this at your own risk, and modifying it can void your warranty, but it has been working awesome on my machine :)

After reading many reviews of many products, I decided to purchase this model. I don't mind spending "Big Bucks" for something I really need and want, but I've got to be able to justify the purchase in my own mind first. I'm the only one in the house who drinks Espresso & Cappuccino now that we're empty nesters, so I'm not going to spend $300-$500 or more for a super deluxe unit. That being said, I'm upgrading from the $39-$49 Steam-Driven DeLonghi to this 15 bar pump model. Boy what I've been missing! I get so much more flavor out of the coffee. If you tamped the coffee on old model just slightly too much, it would take forever to brew with poor results. I tamp this holder to the max with a hand tamper ($5-$6) and the brew is excellent with crema like I've not experienced before except at the expensive coffee shop whose name starts and ends with an "S". Those folks familiar with the steam based makers know that it takes forever to foam your milk using the unit, so I have been using an "Aerolatte" milk frother available for ~ $20. I heat the milk in a coffee cup in the microwave to ~140-160 degrees F. After a little experience, you learn how long to microwave it without using a thermometer. I then froth the milk "by hand", as it were. A real time saver rather than using the built in steamer. Most reviewers of this model say it takes too long, anyway. Always remember "You get what you pay for". Expecting the features and performance of a $500 model for $79 or $89 is a pipe dream. However, keeping those couple of tips in mind, this is an exceptional unit when used in a manner similar to mine. As for longevity of the unit..... Only time will tell and I hope to update this review in a few months. Good Luck on your purchases!

Great little machine but I did have it fail on me. After several months, the machine simply stopped working - it would turn on and it would make steam, but wouldn't make espresso. This very well could have been my fault - I know there were at least one or two times that I left the machine on for several hours which may have ruined the innards, but it definitely didn't stop working after one of those sessions, just out of the blue. I'd argue that this is a design flaw to not have an automatic shutoff but I can't really fault the machine for that as I knew it didn't have that feature before I bought it. That said, I managed to pick up another machine from a "damaged packaging" auction on a website and it has worked well for me for two years of infrequent use.
reviews.review_header: Works for what I need but YMMV

reviews.review_text: I had trouble believing this machine would be high quality at such a low price, but I know De'Longi is well known for their quality, so I ordered it. I LOVE THIS!!! It is small and light weight, doesn't take up too much room. Was perfect for my needs, and you cannot beat the price!!
reviews.review_header: Excellent Quality!! Exactly as advertised! Makes GREAT Espresso!!!

reviews.review_text: I have owned two DeLonghi's and my four year old one is still working fine. It is not my "home" machine. The DeLonghi travels when we go on trips,saving many $$ on lattes. It's always a hit w. friends who otherwise wander about in the morning asking for directions to Starbucks.. Tips: 1. Always use distilled water (or else the calcium in tap water will eventually cklog something) 2. Leave the water tank installed, fill from the top. Removing and reseating the valve at the bottom will eventually cause a leak. 3. Use a Pyrex "cupcake" bowl to catch the expresso. (there's no room under the machine for a tall cup)
reviews.review_header: Good value, quality and it travels!

reviews.review_text: I purchased my first Cappuchino and Espresso maker (a Francis Francis) about 13 years ago - when I lived in the UK - and it cost about 12 times the price of the EC155 - it came from Italia and was a bit tempramental but then like all instruments, you have to be taught how to play before you can make great music. When this machine finally died (erm, due to being dropped) I looked around for a cheaper version and I found the De'Longhi EC1. It was their flagship model at the time and cost about 7 times the price of this little baby. That model was also a combined drip coffer maker too. I loved that machine and I loved De'Longhi as a company too for when my machine started to have a leak after about 18 months I contacted De'Longhi who got in touch with a local dealer who repaired it for me free of charge. The only reason I don't have that machine still is that it was one of many 240v kitchen appliances that got left in the UK. So onto this little baby (EC155)- for the price you really can't go wrong. It's small, compact and makes a fabulous espresso and cappuchino - PROVIDING you follow the same simple guidelines that great baristos have been following for generations. 1) make sure you use the right blend of coffee, 2) make sure it's ground to the right level for make espresso, 3) make sure your water has reached the right temp, 4) don't over or under 'temp' (i.e. compact) your grounds and 5) Treat your equipment well - that means cleaning it (the milk frother each time you use it and the machine about once every 90 uses). Do this and this little machine makes a fantastic crema on your espresso. This machine is perfect for making one large cup (double shot) of cappuchino or two esspressos in one go. Reason being, the volume of the coffee ground tray and the height of the machine limits the volume of coffee you can draw from one filling and the depth of the milk jug you can use. But for those occassions when you have 3 or 4 guests around and you want to impress them all with a large latte or cappuchino over dinner... there is an easy rememdy for the milk - just place something underneath the machine to raise it's height. I initially used a non-glossy hardback book. Then I could use a 16oz jug and have all the milk ready for three large cups. I bought this machine about 3 months ago, use it every day (for at least 2-3 large cups for me and my partner) and have not had a problem with it. Which is why I stick with De'Longhi (also purchased two airconditioners and fans from them over the past 10 years). I have read many of the negative comments on here and apart from mechanical faults, the issue found can all be address by the 5 golden rules above - rules that apply to any bar pressure espresso maker - which by the way, also applied to the expensive Francis Francis model I originally owned and almost gave up on until someone taught me the.. do's and don'ts. It's just a shame you can't get the same wide range of De'Longhi machines in the US.
reviews.review_header: Cracking little machine for the price

reviews.review_text: Okay so for $100 I can't really complain but I also get to use a really fancy Italian espresso machine all day at work so I do have some qualms about this machine. 1. The steamer wand needs more clearance you can barely fit a 12oz milk pitcher and the plastic either needs to come off or move for cleaning. 2. It shakes a lot, I get it I know how the machine is suppose to work but it makes me regret buying glass espresso cups. 3. There should be a tighter fit in the portafilter, I get there are more then one filter but the shouldn't be able to fall out so easily and the little clip on the handle is just not doing it for me. Like I said I get its a $100 machine but these are just little things that could be easily fixed and wish I would have looked into further and read more about

I bought this from Amazon in September 2010. It's made easily over 3000 shots of espresso. All of them great! Now it's started leaking from various places and needs replacing. I descaled it and maintained it, though probably not as often as I should have. But at today's price this machine made espresso at about 3 cents a shot over its life. This was well worth it. I've owned other machines, mostly Gaggias, but the De'Longhi gave me less trouble and makes by far the most consistently good espresso. The filter basket is small, so you really need to use the double-shot basket for a strong single shot. I don't use the milk frother much, since I admit to preferring microwaved milk when I make cafe-con-leche (aka latte). The only reason this did not get a resounding 5 stars is that there's not enough height below the filter to fit a regular coffee mug. For my next machine I've ordered the De'Longhi Bar32, since it's supposed to have a 3.5" clearance for a larger cup. If it makes espresso as well as this one I'll be very happy.
reviews.review_header: Consistently Great Espresso. Well Worth It

reviews.review_text: I am brand new to the world of espressos. I have used a cheap coffee maker for the past 14 years since I first starting drinking coffee. I fell in love with cappuccinos from local coffee shops and finally decided I HAD to start making these at home! Regular coffee just wasn't doing it for me anymore. Anyways, being brand new to espressos and being the only one in the house that drinks coffee, I opted for this lower cost maker (and the great reviews convinced me). I watched a few You Tube videos which really helped me learn how to make the espresso and foamed milk...I barely had to read the manual when it arrived. I ran 5 brews through to clean the machine and I was ready to go! The first few shots I made either came out too weak or too strong (needed to work on my tampering) but once I figured out the best way to tamper the coffee, I was all set!!! I've been using Illy espresso and steaming 2% organic milk and this is heaven!!! The machine heats up fast and the noise has not woken my children up in the morning...it is easy to use (even for a first timer like me). The ONLY CONS: I wish it was a little heavier and more solid machine...it's very light and I have to hold it down while I put the filter in place. Overall, I am extremely happy so far!!!

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I had the $1000.00 JuraCapressa from Williams Sonoma that I bought about 10 years ago. That machine quit working about 5 years ago and if I wanted one of their technicians to even look at it, I would have to ship it to them, my cost, plus send them $250.00. And, they weren't sure if it could even be repaired. That machine cost me around $50 every six months or so in maintenance. Descalers, filters, etc. I've had this machine almost a month now. So far it performs as well as the $1000 one did when it worked. I bought the ESE pods and haven't tried ground espresso yet. Makes great espresso and the frother also works great. Easy to clean. My recommendation would be to watch YouTube video to guide you through how to use it. I am considering buying this for wedding gift for someone, so that means I am very happy with this machine.

The ONLY reason I thought about giving this 4 stars, as opposed to 5 stars, is because of its pump's short longevity. Otherwise, this makes a great cup of espresso, and when the pump gives out, they replace the machine (if it stops working within the year warranty period - which, sadly, it did with my two purchases, as well as the first replacement - we'll see how long THIS replacement lasts!) And they are very forthcoming with honoring their warranty. This is the second machine of this model I have actually purchased in the past four years - each purchase has been replaced with another machine, and also the first replacement went bad (pump failed and it was not under warranty, obviously - it was a replacement), so I had to purchase a second machine, which just went bad, and which they have just replaced under warranty. So, technically, I have gotten about a year's worth of service out of each of four machines. The first purchased one stopped making enough steam for frothing - I now use a separate frother machine, so I don't care. The first one also leaked. This last purchase stopped pumping properly, strongly enough to make the coffee. You might wonder why I keep using this model, and why I purchased a second one after the first, and its replacement, failed? The price is extremely reasonable, compared to other makers. It is user friendly, easy to care for, easy to clean, and makes terrific creama, every time. The second REPLACEMENT machine also lost power in its pump, so I had to buy a new one. So I have actually bought TWO machines, but used four over the four years, because of the warranty. Maybe that is the best you can hope for the pump mechanism? The price is pretty good, even if you only get a year out of it - consider how much a Starbuck's espresso costs, and then multiply that times 30 for each day you make a great cup, and you begin to see how reasonable this is. I cannot speak highly enough about customer service - it makes the failure of the machine tolerable. I still love this little guy, despite its frailties.
reviews.review_header: Great machine, short life, wonderful customer service on warranty

reviews.review_text: What I initially didn't like about this machine: plastic parts, light weight, technique dependent, and cumbersome to clean after each use; quickly changed when it became the only thing I had available to make coffee (read on to find out why). After the initial one year of occasional use, I was pleased with the product: parts are easy to store within the unit, build it tamp, heats up quickly, cup warmer works ok (better after first press of the day), espresso came out with beautiful creme, and steam wasn't so wet. However, due to time constraints in cleanup, I literally stopped using it for 8 years and turned to my drip coffee machine for convenience. By the way, I NEED at least 1 cup of coffee every morning to function. After a fire caused by my next door neighbor that nearly killed my family, this was one of the few appliance that survived the fiasco of fire, smoke, and water damage. I was hesitant to plug this in and use it in my new place (since my drip coffee machine fried when I gave it a try), but I was desperate for coffee... and HOLY WOW! Not only did this machine work, it continued to press out rich, creamy espresso with near-waterless steam! I can't believe it! Now that I got a forced rhythm into using it, I've been making coffee every morning the past 5 months and it's still going strong! I have absolutely NO complaints about this product! It delivers such great espresso and became easy to use, I avoided purchasing a replacement drip coffee machine. They only problem is, I can't drink regular drip coffee anymore since my standards have been elevated so high by this small 15bar machine!
reviews.review_header: Lasts! Will change your palate for coffee!

reviews.review_text: I've had this espresso maker for about a week and I love it! For the price, it's a nice machine. The review that was written by someone who is actually from Italy made a big impression on me as I was able to visit there this past year and had the opportunity to drink a REAL cappuccino. Insert Homer Simpson drool here.... This works just fine for me to make cappuccinos and I didn't buy a separate tamper or a burr grinder. I use the blade grinder I've had for years and the plastic tamper dealie that is on the side of the machine. I'm sure the espresso would be even more awesome with a burr grinder, but I get good crema with what I have. I did buy the demi cups and little spoons as that's what they used in Rome and what a good idea! I hate it when you have all that foam in the bottom of the cup and you're smacking it against your lips trying to get it... If something significant happens, I will update my review, but so far SOOO good. I can't stop making cappuccinos!

My husband and I had a daily Starbucks habit we were trying to stop considering it was costing us over $2,000 a year at least. I didn't want to spend a lot, and this seemed to be the best reviewed machine in the lower price range. I am very happy with the results from this machine. There is a thick crema and the steam wand creates a creamy foam that I love. I definitely prefer this over Starbucks. The only real negative to me is that the milk steamer wand is so low that I have to use a small 12 oz pitcher. When making espressos for both me and my husband, I have to steam the milk twice to have enough for two lattes. I think that if I set the machine on a platform, I would be able to use a larger pitcher and avoid this problem. I also did a lot of research on the accessories needed for this product so will list them here if anyone is interested - all of them are available on amazon: Bodum Pavina Double-Wall Thermo Glasses (2 oz) - These espresso shot glasses fit perfectly - I know some people have complained that the machine is too low for normal coffee cups or shot glasses. They also keep the espresso warm while you are steaming your milk and don't get hot on the outside so your fingertips don't get burned. Rattleware 12-Ounce Latte Art Milk Frothing Pitcher - small enough to fit under the low steam wand. Lavazza in Blu Espresso Ground Coffee - I barely have time to make myself espresso in the morning, so grinding beans fresh daily was simply not an option. This is a great preground product. Delicous and sweet - I am not into the super bold espresso, so this is perfect for me. RSVP Terry's Tamper - The tamper on the machine is ackward to use, so you will need a separate one. The small end is the perfect size for this machine. I hope this was helpful!

Have had it for a couple of months now, and have made a bunch of coffee. I wouldn't even attempt to keep count. So far, it hasn't failed me. It has done well. Espresso is spot on and full bodied, crema and everything. Steam frother is rather awkward but also works well. A little advise is to make sure you have a sort mug on hand or an espresso cup, since there is not much space for a regular mug or cup. I dropped mine from pretty high while moving houses and it is still going strong by the way, so that's a plus. Clean the underside of the dispenser on the machine after use, since some grinds remain in it. A wet towel does well.

I researched and read a lot of reviews about this machine before I purchased it. I bought a tamper with it because quite a few people said the built in tamper was inadequate. Well I could have saved myself a few bucks because I would rather use the built in tamper than the tamper I bought! It does the job and is always there. You don't really have to put a lot of pressure to tamp the grounds firmly. I always use the double shot and fill to the top with grounds and tamp firmly. I found the Pilon brand espresso the best for my taste. Makes rich espresso with nice thick creama. This pump machine is way better than the steam operated one it replaced. Now I enjoy espresso the way I like it. I'm not into cappuccino's or latte's so I can't comment on the wand. Never used it. I have been using this machine for at least 3 years, usually I'll just drink one double espresso every morning and that's it. There is a spring loaded valve (behind the screen where the coffee comes out) that I had to adjust several times because somehow it would be in too far and no coffee would come out. I would have to loosen it about 1-1/2 rounds and it would be fine. That is the reason I didn't rate it 5 stars.
reviews.review_header: This machine makes very good espresso!

reviews.review_text: Great price for an espresso machine! I live in Seattle and regular coffee is just not doing it for us here, we love espresso. So, naturally I went on the hunt for a hearty espresso machine. I did my research, I was so impressed and equally impressed when I received the machine. It makes fantastic espresso, easy to use, fairly easy to clean. I've been using it almost everyday for months! - The only thing that I would suggest when using this machine is make sure your coffee grounds are not too super finely ground because the machine will not work they have to be fine, but not dusty.

I bought this machine after reading its excellent reviews on various sites. It's easy to use, easy to clean, and most importantly, makes a dark, rich espresso worthy of a coffee house. It took me a few tries to perfect the amount of coffee to use, how fine to grind the beans and how much pressure to apply to tamp the grounds. My advice on the tamping is to not be shy and really pack the grounds if you like strong espressos (as I do). The complaints about not having enough clearance for a "regular cup" seem to be silly, as this IS an espresso machine, and you can just dump the shots into a mug if you prefer. With respect to another common complaint, the frothing wand is short, but you can always put the machine on a counter's end and use any size frothing pitcher you want if this design doesn't suit what's in your cupboard. I cheat anyway and microwave my milk for 1.5 minutes and then use a hand frother to foam it up. That saves on having to clean the wand each time, and I'm usually rushing in the morning, but not too much to miss making a latte :-). The amazon warehouse deal was fantastic. I got 50% off because the packing box, and just the box, was dented. The machine itself was in perfect condition, and all parts and directions were included, in unopened packaging. 110% satisfied customer.
reviews.review_header: I've Died and Gone to Espresso Heaven

reviews.review_text: I had several Hamilton Beach Espresso makers and was reasonably happy with them but they were develop a leak after ~3 years with the water container. I wanted one that was a step up, worked on pressure, and water was added to top instead of side. The reviews and price of this one made me try it. I will say that I was concerned when I realized how thick the dual filter with handle was and that my teacup I used for years did not fit under it. The solution was the 2" tall "BIA Cordon Bleu Bistro Espresso Cup and Saucer, Set of 4, White". I highly recommend you buy these cups with this Espresso Maker. I was impressed that with the exact same beans and water, this machine made a much better cup of espresso. I could never go back to the $60 Hamilton Beach maker now. The only problem was clearance for cup and the cups noted above solved that problem. The pressure system works very well and espresso comes out very quickly and is consistent for about 3oz before it starts to weaken. I'm very happy with this purchase. I've been using it daily for few weeks now. note: I grind my own beans every few days.
reviews.review_header: At $4-$5 per trip to Starbucks this pays for itself in 2-4 weeks!

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: After owning two Cuisinart Espresso machines(one after the other) and having them both die after about a year's use, I decided to look for another reasonably priced machine. Consumer reports indicated that the DeLonghi EC-155 was a great espresso for the money(budget category). I purchased this earlier this month, received it from Amazon shipping within three days and got it ready to use. After having read many of the reviews of this machine on this website, I watched for potential problems and thus far, have found none. Yes, the plate that the cup rests on vibrates a bit but so did the Cuisinart. It does not affect performance, just keep your eye on the cup(as it fills the vibrating is less). I found warm-up to take only two minutes or so and it is ready to brew. It takes less time to the frothing procedure after brewing. Now to the frothing aspect.
