The wand may be shorter than the Cuisinart but I do one of these two things and it solves the problem. I have a metal frothing pitcher and I just tip it(I don't fill it to more than 1/4 to 1/3)! Or, I move the machine to the edge of the sink with the wand over the sink space which gives me even more room. Neither is a big deal to prepare a great froth. And, the adjustable steam knob at the top allows me to produce the froth quickly or slowly, but after making two cups of cappuccino, I figured it out! Much better than the Cuisinart froth. Also, I have a separate tamp that I use(I do not use pods) and I always have dry grounds when I dispose of them by just lightly tamping; but that also comes with practice. I have not had any leakage or water coming from anywhere. This is an absolutely great "little"(and it is petite!) machine for the money. Who knows how long it will produce but my past experience with Cuisinart is a year. Plus, Cuisinart's answer to customer service on a machine still under warranty is to have YOU ship a 20# machine back to them with trackable packaging and insurance(at your expense). Oh, and you need to include a personal check for $15.00 to allow them to ship another one back to you. Not high on my list of problem solving! My first Cuisinart quit pumping; the second blew the frothing wand right out of the machine(a plastic housing was cracked and broken-but not a replacement part item) into the hot milk. Fortunately, I wasn't burned. a Finally, I am stating that is a great little machine for the money. If you read consumer reports and other reviews on various machines, you'll get the picture!

Really easy to use espresso machine and very compact! If you are a beginner to espresso and want to get an affordable machine to start out, i highly recommend this. It is easy to use and easy to clean. The instruction manual makes it sound complicated, so i recommend watching a youtube video on how to use it. Once you try it the first time it is easy peasy. This machine makes fantastic espresso and is very small so it is great for small kitchens. I cant comment on whether this is a lot quieter than other models, but i find the noise level isnt bad at all. It also heats up water fairly quickly and the steamer feature makes a nice foamy milk for my espresso.
reviews.review_header: compact, great espresso, great for beginners, easy to clean

reviews.review_text: This is my first Espresso machine and I would have to say that regular coffee does not cut it anymore! I bought this after reading the reviews from http://thebestespressomachines.org/ It takes some time to get the grind/tamp/timing down just right but makes great espresso. The milk frother is a little short and difficult to work with but I don't make cappuccino often. I will use the frothing wand to dispense hot water to make my espresso an Americana and it works well for that. The water reservoir is adequate for 1-2 people for number of double or quad shots. The space saving size is a bonus though it does not come with shot cups/glasses, so think about those if purchasing. I bought a double shot glass to use with it but it was still too tall. The cup that I use now is only 2 5/8" tall and I still need to tip it just a bit to get out from under without spilling any precious espresso. Use a good quality coffee, grind using the Capresso 560.01 Infinity Burr Grinder, and enjoy your espressos at home for under $200.
reviews.review_header: Great first Espresso Machine for limited counter space.

reviews.review_text: I am happy with the quality of this machine for the price. I do notice that if the grind isn't tamped enough the grounds are watery, no big deal. Still tastes good. As far as the steamer goes, I use a metal measuring 1/2 cup to steam the milk (not that I am recommending you do this I am just stating what I do), I did purchase a 12oz metal pitcher, but there is so much waste that I don't use it. I use coconut milk, and it works fine. I also purchased some illy espresso beans, and I know this is gold standard, but I don't care for them. It doesn't taste like coffee to me. So back to the machine, the housing is plastic, as well as the water reservoir and there is a new plasticky smell, but it's not real bad. If your sensitive to plastic smells take note. This machine is easy to use and the price point is very reasonable. Overall I like being able to make cappuccino at home and not pay $5.00 at sbucks.
reviews.review_header: Happy with this machine for the price.

reviews.review_text: I have owned four of these units, two were sent back. In every single unit that I purchased, it's not long before the seal between the coffee pump and steam wand start to fail and the machine develops a prostate problem. Generally I just put a sponge down on the counter, but eventually the problem gets so bad that the machine gets replaced. I would say this is what kills most of them or the pump just weakens. These machines take a very long time to prime, and suggest you don't let them run out of water. Two of the machines had very weak pumps, and I got nothing more than a dribble instead of a steady stream of coffee. The very first machine I purchased had the best pump of all four, but none have been as good since. That first one I could really tamp the grounds hard, but my latest one I can't tamp the grounds at all or it simply won't pump. I believe this machine is capable of producing a great cup of coffee, but it's not without its problems. The biggest issue is probably quality control between machines. No two machines have been the same. The steam wand has always been outstanding, no problems whatsoever. The biggest issue is the pump and then the seal between the pump and steam wand. I finally purchased a commercial machine as the aggravation factor with these machines has just gotten too much over the years for me. They need TLC to make em' work right. For the price, I don't think a person can complain too much. It's pretty easy to spend $700 or $800 on a good quality machine. I've got these for as little as a $65. For the price, it's really a great unit, and one to get your feet wet with.

Very happy with my new Espresso maker!! I drink Illy Espresso at home, and wanted to much a "real Espresso". I previously had another Delonghi coffee maker & espresso maker Combo....the espresso maker was old, wanted a smaller and better machine that wouldn't cost me too much....so I did my research. The Difference with this machine is that it has a "special gizmo" (for lack thereof a technical word, lol) attached to the end of where you place your ground Espresso......that is where the magic happens- it produces Real Crema....what Espresso is. I Love that you can place your cup ontop to "pre-heat" your cup (you do Not want to make Espresso in a cold cup). ....give it 20 min, -or- if you can't wait: add some microwaved hot h20 to "pre-warm" your cup. It's easy to use, and has a built in side tamper. ....still have to make a Cappuccino with it.
reviews.review_header: Very happy, makes Geat Crema Espresso. Easy to operate and clean!

reviews.review_text: I started with the simple Krups steam machine many years ago. I went thru 3 and then decided to upgrade. I purchased a fairly pricy pump machine but returned it. For one it took to long to heat the water. I didn't have to wait around with the Krups and was always told my cappuccinos were better than Starbucks. I ended up with a Mr coffee that was a pump but very inexpensive. It did the job but I wasn't knocked out by it. It broke after not much time but I felt I got my money's worth. I went back to a Krups like my first but I couldn't turn the knobs on this one and I had lost the patience for steaming when the machine was ready, not when I wanted to like with the pump. After a lot of research I came around to this EC155 De longhi. Those of u who hesitate because of the "design flaws" should really give this inexpensive machine a chance. It is designed for the espresso to drip into shot cups but if you want a larger cup or carafe, that's easy to get around. I use the same glass caraf I've had for years; I just remove the silver plate and I have the extra headroom. When it comes to the "short frothing tip" ... I use a standard stainless frothing pitcher and bring the frothing wand out over the edge of the counter so I can fit it under and have control up and down. My pitcher overflows with froth. I dont see needing more that that and i could always make more. As far as the espresso strength, just use the larger filter and experiment with the grind and type of bean. In truth, most of the negative comments are directed at design preferences not actual flaws. One thing I have noticed in relationship to my previous maker is it doesn't get as hot. It's hot enough...just not as hot.

This compact pump-driven espresso maker produces excellent results for the one- or two-cup-a-day customer. If you drink more espresso than that, you should invest in a more expensive and larger machine. I've owned this machine for over a year now (as of April 2009) and it is still working great. I haven't had any problems with it at all, and some of the inconveniences described in some of these reviews can be easily overcome. 1. "the attached tamper doesn't do a good job" - it works fine if you take the time, but the pushing up motion isn't as easy as pushing down with a real tamper. Solution: an inexpensive tamper such as the RSVP Little Gem 49mm Espresso Tamper. The portafilter on this machine is 51mm wide but the 49mm size works just fine. 2. "the space under the dispenser is too small and I can't fit a coffee cup under there" - this isn't a Mr. Coffee machine, it's an Espresso machine designed for shot glasses, not coffee cups. Buy a couple of inexpensive glasses like the Bodum Pavina 2 oz thermals, they fit perfectly and keep the shots warm while you prepare the milk. 3. "the frothing wand doesn't work, is too small, is too short, etc." - the wand works perfectly if used correctly. Buy an inexpensive stainless steel cup like the Rattleware 12 oz Latte Art Pitcher. Fill it up less than half way, and be sure to hold the nozzle right at the surface to draw air into the milk. As the milk increases in volume, be sure to lower the cup to keep the tip at the surface. When the milk level is about a half inch from overflowing, raise the cup so the nozzle is deep and that will continue warming but not produce any more foam. You'll be able to feel when temperature is right (almost too hot to hold) or you can use a thermometer. You will have perfect microfoam this way. If you have trouble getting the cup out because of the counter top, either put the machine on a platform to raise it an inch, or use it on the end of the counter so the frothing wand is easily accessible. Clean the machine daily by drawing a shot of plain water without the portafilter attached before you turn it off. Always shoot some steam through the frothing wand into an empty cup after steaming the milk to clean it. Wipe it down. Rinse the drainboard, it's easily removeable. Do this and the machine will last a long time. Also clean the portafilter basket daily: the bottom screws off, leaving the basket body, plastic insert, filter disk, and rubber gasket. 5 parts to rinse and let dry, reassembles in seconds. POSTSCRIPT NOVEMBER 2010 - After 2.5 years of flawless operation, this machine has died. The heating element no longer works, when I turn the switch to "on," the green "ready" light also comes on immediately, but the water never heats up. Disappointing, but I certainly got my money's worth. I have a call into the DeLonghi service line, but if repairable, the cost is likely to be close to the cost of a new unit. The only question is whether to buy another model or an upgrade....

So I had a Starbucks habit that was getting pretty expensive. I tried using the stovetop espresso maker and heated milk, but it's just not the same. I started looking for an espresso maker, thinking I would need to shell out $300 for a decent machine. When I saw the rating and the price for this unit, I thought it was too good to be true. At one point in my life I had been gifted a cheapo machine from a big box store, and it made terrible espresso and also pooped out after a few months. I thought this would be a similar experience, but it's not. I'm by no means an expert in espresso, other than spending a lot of time in Italy and drinking espresso several times a day while there. I really don't know the mechanics that go into making good espresso, but I do know when espresso is good. Anyway, I was able to pull a shot with nice crema and a resulting hard puck of grounds on my first try with this machine. I read the instructions and some tips from these other reviews, and I used Lavazza coffee. I also steamed milk to turn my shot into a latte, and it was so good. I considered bothering my husband at work to tell him all about it. It's true that it's a little difficult to get the basket holder attached/screwed in tightly, but I figure that will change with time. And the wand is a little awkward in terms of proximity to the counter, but so what. It's not insurmountable, and I'm willing to deal with it at this price point.

I upgraded to this product after 10+ years of using Mr. Coffee Esspresso Maker ($35) that finally succumbed to hard water deposits. I love how fast the pump machine is in comparison to the steam type machine. I bought a separate tamper since the one on the machine is not very useful and in my kitchen it is up against a microwave and not very easily accessable anyway. It makes great esspresso from my cheap brand of esspresso beans. I do grind them at home and it comes out with a thick layer of crema that tastes great. The steamer arm is rather short so it can be difficult to use with a deep steamer cup. I just use an old measuring cup that I tip sideways so that the steamer tip can reach deep into the milk. The clearance between the bottom plate and the esspresso drip is also quite small so I just remove the plate on the drip tray and my coffee mug fits just fine. So far clean up is easy and I like that it has a water tank with a viewing window so you can see the water level without opening it. I only have to add water every couple of days. There are very few drawbacks to this machine and all can be overcome easily. I love this machine and would highly recommend it to anyone.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I've long been a fan of espresso and french press coffee, but over the course of the last year, I succumbed to the product of my surroundings, and found myself drinking 7-11 coffee everyday - and loving it (the horror). Spring back to the beginning of August, and my wife and I took a nice little two week getaway to Europe, specifically London, Paris, and of course, Amsterdam. While across the pond, I rekindled my love for 'fancy' coffee, where rolling around with espresso didn't make you a ponce, just a normal, upstanding person. While I was still over there, I placed an order for one of these so that upon my arrival home, I could make some decent cups of coffee. I chose this machine, like most of us, for the price - I wanted to make sure this wasn't just puppy love before ordering something more powerful, beautiful, and frankly hipster. Fast forward 3 months, and I still don't see the need to replace the machine. It heats up fast, creates good crema - especially with the Lavazza Gusto, and pulls two shots per puck with ease. It's nothing fancy. You're not going to win any barista awards with this one. It's basically featureless outside the bare minimum, but I like it. It takes up practically no space at my coffee bar, looks decent enough, and just plain works. If you're in the market for an entry level espresso machine, click buy. It's has a great value-to-satisfaction ratio.
reviews.review_header: and my wife and I took a nice little two week getaway to Europe

reviews.review_text: I bought this highly rated budget expresso machine after a trip to Italy last year. I am very much satisfied with the quality of the espresso. However, it is more accurate to call it an expresso and lotte maker instead of an expresso and cappuccino maker. The frother does not make enough form for cappuccino, especially micro form. Warning: don't listen to the online articles and videos about making modifications to the machine to improve either the quality of expresso or the form. They don't work or not worth the effort. Just keep the machine clean and tidy and enjoy your espresso and lotte. They are not perfect, but good enough.
reviews.review_header: I am very much satisfied with the quality of the espresso

reviews.review_text: We are exceptionally hard on an espresso machine and this one just keeps on standing up to the tests. Our first machine lasted 2 months through no fault of it's own. Not realizing the importance of good water, we were using our very hard well water and putting, literally, 20-25 shots per day, and sometimes more, through this machine. I decided to clean it and that was a mistake. The deposits broke loose and clogged the machine and the screws were completely cemented in so I couldn't remove them. My bad! Ordered another one, got it in two days (way to go Amazon)and have had it now for over a year and a half and still putting between 10 - 20 shots each and every day through it. I now buy distilled water for this since it's inexpensive and I've not had a single issue with the machine. I must say it rarely gets the cleaning that's recommended, either. As others have noted, the fineness of the grind is directly related to how your espresso comes out. I've used all kinds of coffee beans and have a few personal favorites, but am still using a cheap grinder. Someday I'll see how much a good burr grinder improves the espresso, but it's not a priority for me. I found several small cups at the thrift store (25cents each) that fit perfectly under the spouts, so no need to spend a lot on fancy little cups. I think some of these might be for punch and some are the older style low coffee cups, not mugs that we now commonly use for coffee. Almost all of our coffee is made with 2 or 3 shots, and once you get the hang of it you can do it rather quickly. The frother is really good! Yes, it's a bit low to the counter but it's so simple to let it sit over the edge of the cabinet top or just elevate it with a shelf or cutting board, etc. It froths exceptionally well, and as noted by others there is no need for it to reach to the bottom of your frothing cup or mug, although with most of the mugs I use (most are about 12 ounces) it still reaches nearly to the bottom with a slight tilt to the mug. I make the espresso in the small cups and pour it into the mug that I frothed the milk in. I add sugar to the mug with the milk before frothing and it melts the sugar perfectly. I'm still amazed that this machine at this price just keeps on truckin' after all we keep putting it through. I've never tried the pods as they seem a little pricey to me for such a small added convenience. I toss out my collected coffee grounds on the acid loving plants I have outside the kitchen. Don't be afraid of it. For most people it will do everything you want and for those who are expecting a coffee house commercial machine, well, expect to pay multiple times more. I can see no reason this won't last several more years at even the high level I've been using it.

For the price -- this machine is awesome! I've had it for 6 months now and use it regularly without issue. It's a very good introductory espresso machine for the occasional espresso drinker. I have a more expensive machine in my office that gives better crema, but that one costs about $400 more so for the price I am very happy with this product. Some reviewers complain about the tamp, but I only ever use ESE pods in this machine and haven't had any issues. Beware using delicate china or thin mugs as the machine does rattle a bit so daintier mugs might fall if left unattended while the espresso is pouring.
reviews.review_header: For the price -- this machine is awesome! I've had it for 6 months now and ...

reviews.review_text: We went to Europe and I discovered drinking espresso while in Italy. Wow - all the caffeine in a little tiny cup and you can drink it in seconds. This is the perfect union of speeds. The De'Longhi EC155 brews 2 tiny cups of espresso in less than 1 min. The resulting drink is a dark, hot, rich espresso full of flavor and ready for fast consumption. It comes with filters for a single espresso and a double espresso. I usually make a double espresso each morning, a double after lunch and a double at the end of the day. On busy days, a double double helps me to move fast! This is a small machine and it takes a while to heat the water. If you want lots of espresso, you need to get something larger. If you just need a double espresso a few times a day, this is the perfect machine. The frother works great but you can only use one function at a time. You might want to froth the milk before you make the espresso. When I froth milk (not often) it works very well. 2% milk works best for me. Sometimes I mix in a little half and half as well.

I've had this little machine for three years now. Make a double shot very morning M-F. Weekend I stop by Starbucks. Does it make as good an espresso as Starbucks? No. That is because I actually love the Starbucks slightly burnt espresso taste, which some people detest. I think this machine just does not have the temperature or the pressure. But does it make as good an espresso as some other coffee shops like Illy? Hack yeah. This is not a commercial grade machine, meaning if you want to make four or five espressos in a row this just won't do, as the machine starts to "overheat" and loses pressure. The milk stirrer is wonderful. It just works. If I have to be picky the one complaint I have is that the machine vibrates so much when it is dispensing espresso that the cup would not stay in place, so you have to hold the cup to keep it in place to catch the coffee. Always use freshly grind beans and tamper it right and you would get good espresso with nice crema.
reviews.review_header: Three years and it is going strong!

reviews.review_text: This is good as it gets for the price point. You have to spend another couple of hundred to do better. Trouble is, it craps out after say 9 months of regular use. Maybe you get a year out of it, at which point you can just buy a new one. A hundred bucks a year for a good espresso maker is not bad. Company stands behind their product. Replaced mine at 9 months. Good service.
reviews.review_header: This is good as it gets for the price point

reviews.review_text: From reading all of the reviews I conclude that these makers are hit or miss. If you get a good one its great but if you get a dud, it will just suck. For this reason I have to recommend that you buy one that can be returned if it does not work out. I bought a used one and it took me over a month (since i'm new to espresso) to figure out it was not performing and it was the units fault. Now I can't return it. I bought this new one, and it has worked perfectly from day one. I don't have to jump through any hoops either. Just put the grinds in, and a delicious cup comes out. I have only done the steam wand once. It works. This unit is easy to clean and does not require much maintenance. I'm happy with the purchase.

I had been using a SAECO-built unit that Starbux labeled and sold a few years ago -- a big heavy thing that made great espresso. Water reservoir was not well-designed and it some other quirks. But I wanted a more compact unit. This DeLonghi is indeed more compact and makes an espresso that is 95% as good as the bigger machine, when you use ground coffee. With the ESE pods, however, the robustness and complexity of the flavor are diminished (the price of convenience). You put a single pod in the smaller of the two supplied brew baskets and press the button and you have pretty a good single or 1-1/2 espresso in a few seconds. Even better, do all that twice, each one a ristretto, so basically a double ristretto. July 2012 UPDATE: With Illy pods, the branded side goes on top. With Lavazza pods, the dotted side goes on the bottom. Be sure the pod is pressed firmly into the bottom of the brew basket. Also, I have noticed that if you use a finer grind of espresso (I'm talking about ground coffee, not the ESE pod) this DeLonghi may jam and you will only see a slow trickle come out -- this means the espresso is ruined and you need to start over. It can also jam if you tamp it too much (but that can happen with any machine). So try a somewhat coarser grind. I tried the same fine grind in the SAECO/Starbux machine and it worked great. So the DeLonghi has less pressure (despite the bar rating) than a heavier machine -- no surprise. As for pods, I found the Lavazza ESE pods to be better than the Illy. The Illy has some nice chocolatey flavor, but it's weaker. They are both medium-roast and smooth, not like burned Starbux espresso. Both available on Amazon. No mess, no fuss with the pods. The electric control knob is poorly marked, hard to tell where it's pointing and what it's pointing at. The instruction manual is absurdly complex, and apparently written by someone who has a lot of extra time AND doesn't know how to use this model. It tells you to spend 5 minutes running a pump cycle to warm up your cup (yep). Then wait 30-45 MINUTES MORE for the boiler to warm up again (that's what it says!). Actually, you can warm your cup in hot tap water (or not at all), and the boiler warms up very quickly -- you only have to wait till the green light comes on, which takes about a minute, at the most. Run some water through into a spare cup/dish and you're ready to make espresso. The filter holder takes a lot of torque to engage into the machine, maybe that will get easier if it loosens up a bit, or maybe my unit was built incorrectly. But you only need to turn it a few degrees to make a sufficient seal, so not that big a deal. I haven't tried the milk frother -- but my suggestion would be to remove the plastic thingy (it screws down and off), and just use the metal tube end, held just below the surface of cold milk. Easier to do, and easier to clean. So in general, a very good machine, esp. for the price.

I bought one of these machines over eight years ago and it lasted right up until this past Christmas. The coffee it made was so good and it had given me such great result that I decided to buy exactly the same one. I was very happy I could find one on Amazon and at a great price to boot (less than $100.00). Nothing has changed in the machine comparing it to my older one, so I just had to clean it, plug it in and let the water run through it a couple of times before my first awesome coffee. Would recommend this machine to anybody who wants a good sturdy espresso machine at an affordable price.
reviews.review_header: DeLonghi is synomym of good espresso coffee

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: This little machine makes excellent espresso, capuchino, mocha, etc. My only complain is that the handle where the ground coffee container sits proved to be not washing machine compatible. It need to be hand washed. That's what I did until today. I thought I'd put it in the dish washer but it came out without the chrome finish! All the finish turned into a black powder. I had to clean it with white vinegar to remove. I'm sure it probably works the same, but it looks ugly now.
reviews.review_header: This little machine makes excellent espresso, capuchino

reviews.review_text: Reading a good amount of in depth reviews from people who were self proclaimed "espresso/coffee connoisseurs and watching product demonstration videos on the web, I was persuaded to purchase this item and return the Mr. Coffee espresso machine I was going to originally purchase for my father. I am by no means a connoisseur and occasionally drink cappuccino, and my dad almost exclusively drinks cappuccinos. So between the two of us, could we use this machine to create what we like that would rival that of our local coffee shops? Design The design isn't too bad. the casing is plastic but there are some features such as the boiler and portafilter is stainless steel... it's not exactly sleek like I have seen in the other product of the line, but its not unsightly. It is a small appliance that takes up very little counter space, which is good in our small kitchen. My dad still had enough space for it to be put proudly on display on the counter along with the various accessories we have purchased; it looks like a mini coffee shop in the corner of our kitchen. Prep Time: The machine is fairly to get used to but as some others said there is a bit of work involve. If you are looking for a machine where you just press a button and everything is made for you, this is not the product to buy. By the time you prepare the steamer for the milk, depressurizing and reheating for the espresso, adding the espresso to the portafilter and then pulling the shot, It's roughly 10 minutes. If you are grinding your own beans (I recommend the Mr. Coffee IDS77 Electric Coffee Grinder with Chamber Maid Cleaning System, Black review coming to that shortly as well) then add about another 3-4 minutes to the process. Functionality: The water tank was easily removable so I did not have to worry about filling the pitcher from the appliance but yet take it out to fill it. It probably doe not need to be said but make sure that you are using good water, if it is tap water then at least try to put a filter on it for better a better tasting drink. You can also see the water level when it is sitting inside of the appliance (just make sure you have good light in kitchen to see where the level is at). The steaming wand for frothing milk is low towards the counter surface, and if you are using a milk frothing pitcher that is more than 10 ounces, you are going to have to lift the machine to pull it in and out (unless you want to spill the milk). I strongly recommend that you purchase a stable block for the machine to sit on; not too high, maybe 2-3 inches off the ground if you are going to use a 8 or 12 ounce pitcher. Some have complained that the bulky steaming wand tip attempts to be dummy proof but it gets in the way, but I didn't see a problem with it. I followed careful directions on how to use it and it came out amazing. There is a metal textured surface on top and from what I saw people could put glasses on top to warm it because that is where the boiler is. If you are a klutz like me, don't do it. If you are not, then its pretty stable place. to put things. There is little room for you to put a coffee mug as is with the portafilter being nonadjustable and sitting low on the appliance. Some of said to remove the drip tray from the bottom. If you are inexperienced like we were, it is best to go with thermal espresso shot glasses like anyway that way you can closely watch how much espresso is being pulled and turn it off in time. It may be one more item to rinse out but then you wont have to be bothered with removing the drip tray each time. You can buy them online, but I went to a nationally known import store and picked up two glasses for under $5. There is a tamper on the side. some say that it sucks because you have to tamp up and recommend to purchase a tamper; others say it doesn't really matter because you technically do not have to apply 30lbs of pressure to your coffee because the filters are pressurized. I went on ahead and purchased RSVP Terry's Tamper to get used to the idea of manual tamper in case we upgraded later on down the line, and have been using that to tamp our espresso grounds. The portafilter comes with two filters a single and a double espresso baskets. You can use the pods for single serving or you can free form it with grounded espresso coffee. With this as a single boiler it will take some time going between drinks for you to go back and forth between frothing more milk and making more shots. If it is just you and another person, this appliance would be absolutely perfect for purchase. If you are one of those constant entertainers and need to have your espresso drinks ready immediately and to more than 2 people, this is not the machine to buy. The first time that you put the portafilter into the machine, you may feel as though you did not put it on securely because due to pictures and videos, you did not do a complete 90 degree twist on to the appliance and it is not pointing straight at you; from the forums I have read that is normal and it will take some wear for it to lock directly in front of you at such an angle. don't be like me and almost panic because the seal is tight you are fine; as long as you make sure that it is secure and wont move then you shouldn't worry about a leak from up top. Speaking of leaks, there will be a tad of water leakage at the bottom, but even the manual itself said that it may happen. Maintenance I haven't really had much maintenance outside of cleaning the drip trays and portafilters and that was pretty easy. According to the manual, I still have some time before I have to go through the whole descaling and cleaning process, so I will give an update in a few months when it is time. From what I have read and watched, is ts really putting the cleaning solutions through the water tank and running it a few times (so its not as much work as you would normally do during one run of making an espresso several times in a row. Is It Worth It? Its not a perfect machine, but I think it is a very good one and its affordable. You might need to make adjustments due to the steam wand, and use espresso glasses to avoid getting frustrated because none of the cups in your cabinet will fit under the nozzle :). You will also need to not mind working a little for your cup, but that in itself may be something that you enjoy like my dad and I did. During Christmas, my dad and I spent all morning using it like we were barista's; used samples from our coffee shop and enjoyed the process that we had to go through to get our "perfect cups of cappuccinos". We taste tests and made various hot drinks such as cappuccinos, lattes, hot chocolate (steamed milk). It took a pretty good beating since we used about 10 times on Christmas. Shockingly, everything came out great, but not everyone may experience that on their attempts, but its not the products fault :) that could be anywhere from the coffee bean itself to the human factor that never fails to creep up on us when we aren't paying attention to recipe instructions. So in the end did we rival the local shops by making it at home? Yes! Absolutely.
reviews.review_header: A Little Work will Yield Great Results - A.K.A. Buy with Understanding of Key Points.

reviews.review_text: This is my 3rd cappuccino machine and by far the best. The espresso comes out great and it froths really well. It's a little noisier than my others but I think it's because this is a pump machine. I'm giving it 4 stars simply because of design. It is very compact, which is good, but unless you are using a short frothing cup and espresso cups it can be hard to work with because the frother is very low to the counter and there's not much space under the dripper. For me it works out fine because I have a seperate coffee counter in my kitchen. I keep it on the end of the counter top so the frother hangs over the side and I froth the milk in my large 'to go' coffee cup and just spill the espresso in once it's done. It turns out to be a plus for me but I can see why others have complained about it. Really all they had to do was place the frother higher up on the machine and it would be practically perfect. I also place a paper towel under the espresso cups for traction. The pump action makes it vibrate a little and the cup slides to the side...not a big deal plus it keeps the drip pan clean. For $83 you can't go wrong. My cappuccino comes out better than Dunkin Donuts and Starbucks and with the amount of cappuccino we drink this machine paid for itself in 2 weeks.
reviews.review_header: Can't go wrong for the price

reviews.review_text: I've had the machine for almost a year. Not one single problem up to now. Buy it. This is not a percolator machine so do not expect the same features or behavior. It' wonderful, it vibrates and makes a little bit of noise. Otherwise, if you follow the instructions in the videos in the web you shall end with a nice cup of expresso. Any ground coffee that comes from Puerto Rico is perfect for the machine. Today you can find that type of coffee in many state markets. To know how your end product should taste, when you travel savor an expresso in Spain, Italy, Miami, Cuba or Puerto Rico... Do not use the tamper attached to the machine, its worthless; buy one made of aluminum. If you have issues with your hands or arm you will not be able to apply the necessary pressure upon the coffee grounds. It consistently takes me less than seven minutes to make a cup of expresso from scratch. Have had no problems with the water tank. The clearance between the spigots and the tray to put the cup is small, so you have to use a low and wide cup and be a little careful. It is a basic and small machine so you must cultivate a bond with it so that you get the best result every time. Will buy it again without any reserve.

I received this a christmas gift for my boyfriend and I love it! For the price it is an awesome deal, He got this for $80 and since we had prime we were able to overnight this for $8, which was worth it. I didn't give it five stars because it will take some time for you to figure out how to get the espresso perfect. After a few days of practice I figured out the machine. With higher end espresso machines, you want the grind to be powder fine. With this machine you want the grind be just a little finer than you would use for coffee. You don't want to tamp too hard either. The grind is the most important part to make good espresso, and I have made some awesome espresso with this inexpensive machine. Yes it is more time consuming than coffee, but you will find that with espresso machines in general. If you're espresso is dripping out too slow (like a drop at a time) then your grind is too fine, or you may be tamping too hard. If you are having trouble, don't give up, just play around with it a little bit and you will be able to get it right. Highly recommend

I received this as a gift a couple of months ago. I absolutely love it. Coupled with Illy Medium Roast Beans, this is quite frankly the best espresso I have ever had, and I can enjoy it any time I want in the comfort of my own home. The machine is very affordable to boot and will pay for itself vs any of the Pod based espresso machines or buying at local coffee shops. Pros: -Incredible tasting espresso from an overall simple machine -Warm up and brew times are relatively fast. While it says to wait 20min to brew, I haven't noticed a difference in temperature from when the green light turns on a few min after powering on vs waiting 20min later. In all transparency, I don't need my espresso to be scalding hot either, but like I mentioned, I haven't seen any difference in the brew quality or temperature -Machine is very affordable -Built in steam want makes very good froth when used properly -Water reservoir is a good size and doesn't need to be filled too often Cons: -Shape and location of steam wand are a little awkward, but still very usable. Just not ideal. -Unless you really tighten the knob for the steam want, it can drip water. -Steam wand has some parts that are tough to clean -Machine is fully manual. So you need to be ready to tamp the espresso yourself, and I recommend a hand held tamper vs the built in plastic tamp. This means you'll need to spend a couple of min every moment making your espresso vs a much more expensive, fully automatic machine that makes your expresso at the push of a button -Tightening the espresso cup requires holding the machine in place -Your cup may move due to vibrations int eh machine. I use a rubber pad to ensure it doesn't move -It's best to keep the the grounds cup and filter clean daily. Total time from machine on to clean up can be 5-8min depending on how fast you are.
reviews.review_header: When paired with quality beans (like Illy Medium Roast) this machine makes the best espresso I've ever had

reviews.review_text: As good as the last model which finally gave out after seven years! The milk steamer is even better than the previous model, even though it is not designed as well; it is spring-loaded so that when you swing it out to heat the milk, it springs back under the machine. The water and steam both heat up quickly. The only disadvantage of this machine, as others have noted, is that it has a low slung spout under which nothing fits, but see my review for a 3-once metal pitcher (BC-3 stainless steel from Update International on Amazon). It's perfect. BTW, I found out the hard way that you should not use fine china espresso cups underneath the spout; eventually, they will crack, even though this one vibrates less than the previous model. This model is great for New York City kitchens where there is virtually no space for appliances.
reviews.review_header: Terrific Espresso Maker for the Money

reviews.review_text: I've had this for over 6 months and it still makes great coffee. My only real issue from the start is with the milk steamer. While it does its job of steaming milk, it's a bit cumbersome to use and clean and because of the shape and small length it's difficult to find a pot that fits perfectly so I end up having to hold the milk jug or risk spillage. After six months of heavy use the water pump at the top appears to have a leak after making coffee and it drips for a few minutes after brewing. It still functions but it makes a bit of a mess. I'll have to find the manual and see if I just need to replace a washer or something. All in all - it's saved me a ton of money in Starbucks and it still makes great espresso and latte. This was my first espresso maker and it was a great introductory machine. Next time I'm probably going for one that is more expensive now I know what features are important to me.

We waited to review- we have owned this for at least half a year and ARE IN LOVE! Seriously, this cheap little tool has been giving us the best coffee drinks! I don't use the milk/steamer attachment, so I can't speak to that, but the espresso is great! So happy with it! I can't believe it was under $100. We have literally stopped getting coffee at a stand or cafe, there is no need to. I have even considered bringing it with us on road trips. The espresso isn't quite as strong as a coffee stands', but its better than our aero press and french press. I have to say, in the beginning I wasn't sure if I would like this due to the loud noise it makes and the shaking of the machine. Over time I have gotten use to it and understand that is just part of its charm... or at least I have overlooked it based on the coffee it has made me!
reviews.review_header: ... for at least half a year and ARE IN LOVE! Seriously

reviews.review_text: I have had no problems with this, works well. I've tested every aspect of it, no problems. A little noisy, you can look at youtube for more information. There exists a great review on there by "ureviews." I recommend cleaning the parts touching coffee while they're freshly used, wait for cool down. As long as you take care of this, thus far it has taken care of me.
reviews.review_header: There exists a great review on there by "ureviews

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: This espresso machine replaced my previous Hamilton Beach one after five years of service. I love espresso, but I cannot spend more than this prace range — And I am absolutely happy with my De Longhi's quality! The only down side is a bit of ergonomics in the coffee filter: In most other espresso machines, the filter fits tightly in the holder, so disposing of the used coffee is as easy as a couple of whacks. With the DeLonghi, the filter is completely loose, and I have to hold it in quite an uncomfortable fashion so it does not fall off. But besides that detail, I would surely buy again this same model.
reviews.review_header: I love espresso, but I cannot spend more than this ...

reviews.review_text: Simple to use, easy to clean up. Good crema on the espresso, although I'd like to get a stronger shot. I may have to experiment with the grind or the tamping a bit more. One important lesson learned: when using milk steaming function, always purge the steam tubes into an empty container after heating the machine to the steam setting and before steaming milk. The first thing out of the steamer will be a bunch of hot water that you don't want to inject into your milk. I also wish this had a little more space for a taller cup under the filter so I could brew directly into a larger cup for latte/cappuccino. As it is, I make the espresso into a small measuring cup and then pour it into a larger mug.

This is my second espresso machine. My first was a Krups purchased 12 years ago, and it had issues. Leakage, for instance, if you did not attach the portafilters just so. There is zero leakage with this machine. Notice that I used the plural regarding portafilters. Most machines come with two portafilters (the black ice cream scoop-like thing) and this comes with one, and it has two spouts for the espresso to come out of. Well, in my house it's one pod per person unless they really need to be amped. The two outflow holes are obviously for two containers to catch the brewed espresso. If you do espresso shots, this can be a problem, so you'll need a wider espresso cup than the standard shot cup to accommodate it. There are instead two inserts for the portafilter, one for ground espresso, one for pods. The Krups was better made than this machine, but cost three times as much. I've not tried ground espresso, but if you like pods, this is a great machine. You get 15 atmospheres of pressure, and you don't have to wait long for your fix. Sweet! It is easy to clean.

I was an occasional coffee drinker, mostly mochas, looking for something rich I guess. Then I discovered the exceptional coffee served in European cafes on a recent trip and looked for a way to recreate it. I believe the fundamental difference is drip vs. espresso so I was looking for a good but inexpensive espresso machine. Read up a bit, read a few reviews of various machines, and eventually settled on this one. I'm not an experienced espresso maker, I hardly know what I'm doing, but I find this pretty easy to use and I'm able to make a coffee that is like what I got in Europe, so I'm happy. No complaints so far, but a word of note to others like me, it took me 4 or 5 tries to become comfortable with making espresso. It's not difficult to use but being new to me, I wasn't sure in the beginning of even the basic steps. Do be sure to read up on the other plentiful reviews of this product. One general thing to note is that this machine is small. And for guidance on using it, there are several Youtube videos of this product. Pros: > perfect size for me and my kitchen space > makes a good cup of espresso Cons: > small size makes it difficult to get the arm on tight > small size can be a problem if all you have are big cups

I just ordered this as a replacement for the same exact machine, which unfortunately broke after 5 years of regular use. These machines are easy to use and make very good coffee. I buy my espresso beans from starbucks and this tastes very similar to what i buy at an actual starbucks. I took off one star because the one one I had did break after 5 years of use, but I imagine that is not bad for a product that I used daily. Pros: -Compact & stylish design -Consistent coffee -Simple operation with the dial -Large reservoir to hold water so don't need to refill daily -Steams milk faster than other brand espresso machines I've owned (Krups) -Produces great tasting espresso Cons: -A lot of parts to clean which can be tedious, but something that has to be dealt with on all espresso machines. On occasion the steamer wand gets clogged with milk and I have to use a needle to unclog it. -I use little shot glasses to measure out 1 oz of coffee. When pulling two shots, the glasses need to be position just right so the coffee ends up in the cup. -No option to make quantities of more than 1 or 2 shots.

I love it! It makes great espresso with crema and it doesn't cost a fortune. Some people complained that they had difficulties with hot water delivery from the start. So, when my machine didn't spit out any hot water, I immediately called Delonghi customer service. The rep I talked to was fantastic, VERY nice and helpful. Here is what happens: at first, it might be an air lock inside machine. I did as advised - heat up the machine and turn the knob on espresso/hot water. If no hot water comes, turn it back on just heat, wait several minutes and turn on espresso. Repeat several times. On the fourth or fifth time, the air lock was broken and hot water started coming. No more problems. One note on shortcomings - it is a little noisy as it makes espresso, so I had to put it on a foam pad. Also, it vibrates a little as it dispenses espresso and a cup 'walks' around, I put a folded paper towel or a paper napkin under the cup to prevent it. These are my reasons for 4 stars instead of 5.

While I'm sure some people here may have received faulty units, from the negative reviews I've read, I believe many people just need to practice using a pump espresso/cappuccino machine. Once you get the routine down, the machine works great and makes a delicious espresso, cappuccino, or latte. The directions don't teach techniques well, so I recommend searching You Tube for a video with a similar machine (like the Saeco/Starbucks Barista machine). Most importantly, for those folks, steam your milk FIRST, then make the espresso. AND clean the steam wand after EVERY use making sure to blow out some steam to get any milk residue out of the wand! Milk is VERY sugary and gets sticky and crusty very quickly. I bought this machine to replace my DeLonghi Rialto Super Automatic that stopped working after 6 years. I have been very pleased with this machine so far -- and I've already put it thru it's paces. LOVE: - How fast it heats up - That it's so light and portable and takes little counter space - Has great steam pressure for efficient frothing - Easy to use & clean DON'T LOVE - The base is so light that it moves and can tip when attaching/removing the espresso basket. - The espresso basket on my unit doesn't seem to swivel all the way for brewing, but this does NOT affect the machine at all - just different from my past machines. As you can see, neither of these are deal breakers. For the money, I think this is a great little appliance!

Received this wonderful machine today. Have made 5 espressos and 3 cappuccino. They turned out perfect. There is a bit of a learning curve, but if you know the basics this machine will work fine. My first two pucks were a little wet, however I adjusted the quantity and pressure and subsequent pucks were nice and firm with a scant amount of moisture, as they should be. The 12oz pitcher works fine. I will add more as I use it. Hopefully the longevity of the machine will match the performance. This is a really good entry espresso machine. Follow the instructions and you will be good to go.

I bought this about 10 months ago, and used it daily. It has now failed, unable to deliver water, the same problem as many others have reported. I have maintained it as instructed, cleaning out with vinegar every 2 months or so. This is an unacceptable life for any kind of commercial product. I liked the great espresso, with good crema. It easily makes frothed milk, and the steamer is very easy to clean (just wipe it and let steam for half a second). It has height limitations for cups but espresso cups and shorter cups all fit fine. If you can accept that this thing will last about year, go ahead. If not take my advice, don't buy one. Build quality has to be suspect (cheap materials in the pump construction?). -- Update 6 months later -- It's working again. I didn't throw it out. I paid more attention to the coffee grind. If the coffee is too fine, the filter blocks up. Maybe a more powerful pump would handle it. Use the grinder at the store and set it it at espresso grade, or pay careful attention to how long you zap it in your grinder. I still love the coffee it makes, its adaptability to pods and ground coffee and its good milk frothing. I do now use highly purified water (reverse osmosis) and haven't need to descale it yet. I hope it lasts longer!
reviews.review_header: Great - but watch the coffee grind you use

reviews.review_text: I used a DeLonghi Cafe Parme steam-driven espresso maker for about 8 years. My budget was under $100, and I feel this purchase was money well spent. After trying the boiler system, I'll never go back to a steam system. I understand that more expensive machines are probably nicer and deliver even better espresso, but I'm perfectly satisfied with this machine. I don't think the warm-up time is excessive. Honestly, I just turn it on when I come downstairs in the morning. I have two dogs, so I send them out and feed them. By the time I'm done with that, at least 10 minutes has past and I go ahead and make my espresso. I do wish there was more clearance so that you could pull the shots directly into a mug. I did as someone else suggested and removed the metal tray and put a small mug down into the base. I don't have any issues with the amount of clearance for the steam wand. My experience has been that the machine does an excellent job pulling shots, and does an awesome job frothing/steaming milk. Here's my routine. Turn the machine on to warm up for about 10 minutes. During this time I get the ground espresso and filter ready, and put milk in my metal container and put it in the fridge. I put a small mug under the filter and pull my shots. I have another, larger mug ready so that I immediately pour out my shots and put the small mug back under the filter--it continues to drip a bit and I don't want the espresso to be watered down. Then I switch over to the steam function and take the metal container with milk out of the fridge. When the indicator lights goes back on I froth and steam my milk. Easy-peasy. I'm perfectly happy with my purchase and highly recommend the machine. Like I said, more expensive machines may be better, but for the <$100 price, this is excellent! UPDATE (1/27/13): Still using this machine. Still works great! Just needs occasional cleaning. UPDATE (11/15/14): Yep. Still using the same machine! I just use filtered water and clean it when it starts to slow down. Wow, have I gotten my money's worth out of this purchase! UPDATE (4/23/15): I FINALLY had to replace this machine. It finally conked out on me. I ended up buying the same make/model, because the first one was so good to me! :)
reviews.review_header: Great espresso maker for the money

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I wasnt sure what to expect as I thought this would be just a little bit better quality than the typical smaller inexpensive espresso units,But I was so pleased with this De'Longhi 15 BAR Pump!! It heats up very quickly and the pressure of the pump makes me the perfect double shot with nice crema... I also feel the unit is very easy to use and clean. The frothing wand is great quality, it does exactly what it is supposed to do, I think probally just as well as the professional units do in Batista cafes. I havent had any issues with it at all and I use it at least 3 - 4 times a day (some days 2 of the uses is just for kids steamers) I figured that when I saved up more money I would get a bigger nicer De'Longhi and this was just a temp unit. But I am so pleased with it I will be keeping it and there is no need to upgrade. This is a GREAT PRODUCT ESP FOR THE PRICE!! At first I thought that the Porta Filter handle was very hard to slid in and out, But over several uses it got much easier, not looser but it just needed "breaking in"... Some complaints were it was too short & some had to put this unit on a book or something, I haven't found that to be a problem, I have a 20 oz frothing pitcher(just a lil over 1/4 full of milk) and I am able to tilt it under the unit just fine with out having to lift the machine. I am a AVID espresso drinker,and I feel I know a good shot of espresso, and with the proper beans and ground size and texture and tamp, You will feel like your at a real barista stand when your making and tasting your espresso! Im so pleased!!
reviews.review_header: Great Home Espresso for the price!

reviews.review_text: This is my savior. When we got back from Italy we immediately sold our coffee maker and searched for an espresso machine. I was looking for something efficient, yet not overly expensive, and that didn’t take up the whole countertop space. This is beyond perfect! It makes a perfect espresso every time with perfect crema. I cut a little piece of grip shelf liner for the place that holds the cups to keep them from moving and that was all I had to do to make this a perfect machine.

My wife and I had been using a Mr. Coffee Walmart special and it didn't make the best espresso, but for capuccino, it was a cheap solution. It died. I did a LOT of research on a replacement machine. I noticed that there were negative reviews on everything from $30 on up to $3,000. I'm thinking "There's no way I'm spending $3,000 on a machine I may not be happy with!" Actually, there's no way I'm spending $3,000 on a coffee machine, PERIOD. My wife's a coffee snob though and has friends that have and so she was more willing than I. I found this one and noticed the high ratio of satisfied to unsatisfied customers and pled my case that if we didn't like it, at least we hadn't committed a whole lot of $$$ and then we could try the "you-get-what-you-pay-for route". I must admit I read all the reviews and tips on how to make the best cup of coffee using this machine and it paid off - my wife says I made her the best cup of coffee she had ever had using this, the Hario mini mill, Terry's tamper, and some African beans another connoisseur friend of hers gave her for Christmas. We've been using it for 8 months and the only negative is that the steamer sometimes drips a bit - but we haven't cleaned it once since we got it, so maybe it time for a bit of maintenance!

I purchased this in September 2014 for slightly less than $100. At the time I was looking for the highest rated, cheapest pump espresso machine I could find and haven't been disappointed. That said, it is definitely an entry level machine and I'm planning on upgrading sometime soon. Pros: + good value + makes good foam and heats quickly + simple to setup and use (it was my first machine ever and was incredibly easy to get started using) Cons: - loud (especially at startup) and rattles - low quality finished -- the metal scratches easily and the labels quickly rubbed off - "ready" light doesn't accurately reflect heating - the built in tamper is located in an awkward location and is difficult to clean - espresso production / dripping has worsened over time (much slower and more watery, even after several cleaning attempts)
reviews.review_header: Excellent value for the price, but not the most durable

reviews.review_text: I like this machine very much. It is eay to use and makes good espresso. The included scoop fills the strainer basket with just the right amount of grounds. Then, when I place the strainer into the machine and turn it to seal for the brewing, the coffee in the strainer seems to be automatically compressed. I get good tasting coffee and good crema. This is a good bargain.
reviews.review_header: I like this machine very much

reviews.review_text: I love this machine. So I give it five stars even though there are some minor (in my mind) problems with the attachments. First, it makes awesome espresso and cappuccino. I only use 100% arabica coffee, that is important in my opinion. Some people who do not like the machine appear to need the usual giant coffee cups for their espresso, but that really has nothing to do with espresso. A 20oz mug full of filter coffee will definitely have more caffeine than an espresso, but I cannot drink that **))$#% bitter stuff. You have to wait some times, until the machine is properly hot. A hissing sound will tell you when. I always fill in espresso roast directly. There is a size limit on the cups that you can use. My spiffy espresso cups are a little over 2 inches tall, my cappuccino cup measures 2.5 inches in height. But in worst case the bottom can be removed, I guess, to fit a bigger cup, I just don't see the point in that. I use the smaller coffee holder for espresso and the bigger one for cappuccino. The cappuccino will therefore obviously contain more caffeine then the espresso, although the cup also holds much more liquid. Everyone will probably have to test him/herself how much coffee to use. Even with the holder full of coffee, it will eventually only let a water-like substance through, after the coffee has been used up, so bigger cups do not make much sense anyway. Espresso/cappuccino are incredibly good imho and plenty strong for me with lots of crema. I recommend not to use the tamping attachment. It attracts coffee grinds on the top surface and is impossible to clean as is cannot be swiveled or moved away otherwise from its position. The plastic measuring cup will do just fine. The frothing wand is too close to the ground and too short to be of much use. I bought a 7$ electric frothing wand that works wonders for my cappuccinos, and I use very little milk with it. The steam-driven wand adds some water to the milk, hence producing a slightly different froth consistency and warms up the milk. It can be combined with the cheap frothing device, but I would not recommend it. The much-ciritcized watery consistency of the leftover coffee comes from filling the holder to the top with coffee grinds. If you use less coffee and tamp it down nicely, it is not watery at all, but that all depends on the extent of your caffeine addiction, I guess. Anyway, it has some slight issues, but is is the right machine for me. All visitors love the espressos/cappuccinos they get from it.
reviews.review_header: Great machine with some slight imperfections

reviews.review_text: Is quite decent expresso at a bargain price. You don't really have to let it heat up as long as they say. It's not top of the line but it is also not top price either. Good value. Easy to use.

Seriously! This unit exceeded my wildest expectations! Just read the instructions and you're ready to dump the expensive coffee shops! The only thing you'll miss is the free wi-fi and the cranberry-lemon-poppy-granola bars! To make a PERFECT cappuccino also consider getting the " Stainless Steel 10oz. Steaming & Frothing Pitcher ", the " RSVP Terry's Tamper " and the " Bodum Pavina 2-1/2-Ounce Double-Wall Espresso/Shot Thermo Glasses, Set of 2 " right here on Amazon. For around $100 this combo makes a cappuccino that is JUST as good as any coffee shop I've patronized! Lastly, be sure to get coffee especially fine-ground for espressos... don't just get an "espresso blend" for drip coffee makers! You can get " Cafe Bustelo Coffee Espresso, 10-Ounce Cans (Pack of 4) " brand here on Amazon (look at its great reviews) or just about any big discount store and it makes a perfect crema and is delicious. Look for a yellow can. Set aside an empty 11-12 oz coffee cup and pull an espresso that just fills the 2.5 oz Bodum Pavina glass (the crema should drag across the bottom of the spouts on the espresso maker. Set the glass of espresso aside and fill the frothing pitcher with COLD milk. We successfully use plain almond milk or 2% cow milk. >>Be sure to only fill to just under the indentation in the middle of the pitcher.<< Use the steamer wand to froth the milk following the instructions that come with the EC155. The milk *should* froth up to just nearly overflowing, making just the right amount of froth. If you use coffee flavorings (like Torani Brand syrups) put them in the coffee cup first (2-3 teaspoons is what we like)... then pour on the froth... then pour your coffee on top. (Be careful... the wide and thick Bodum Pavina cup is a little hard to pour from without espresso dribbling down the side.) Give a very slight stir with a spoon and serve. If you like a very hot cappuccino just microwave for 20-30 seconds and then serve. Anyway, this machine seems to be very high quality for the price and if handled and cleaned carefully after each use, should make great drinks for a long time! There are only a couple of things I would state as "cons" concerning this machine. The first is about using the TWO CUP FILTER. In my use, it seemed to produce an inferior cup of espresso compared to the ONE CUP FILTER. The second "con" would the tip on the steamer/frother wand. The steam sputters out around the threads and splatters around a bit. And the plastic tip is pretty hard to clean because it has deep areas that are hard to get to. We use a toothpick while running under hot water. I read a blog somewhere that tells how to replace the tip with a simple hardware store domed nut. (Google it.) I'll probably do this mod soon. Lastly, with espresso, be sure to replace the coffee for EACH PULL! Being cheap to the point of re-using used coffee will REALLY disappoint you! Pull one shot, dump the grounds, refill, and repeat! As stated the items above are a PERFECT Espresso/Cappuccino-making combo that we put together after much research. I hope you enjoy it as much as we do!
reviews.review_header: Whoa! This little star makes a cappuccino that really bucks for less than 50 cents!

reviews.review_text: I could give this thing 1 or 2 stars for length of life but I could give it 5 stars for quality of espresso. At this price it is a disposable coffee maker. Expect to get a couple years out of it and then the motor won't have enough power to keep pulling the shots. Learn it's flaws early and you can work around them. Don't expect to get anything out of the first pull or if you do, expect 1/8th to 1/4th shot, don't change out the grains and when the light comes back on, then pull your shot, i find this makes it work just fine and fast. I sometimes use it to make an americano by pulling a couple shots through the same grains. I almost never use my regular coffee maker unless I have guests over. Look at the complaints on the $1,000 makers and above! why spend a ton of money on something that has an equal chance of being a lemon when you can have this for under $100 and buy 10 of them over 20 years and always have a new one you don't feel trapped with that makes a great cup of espresso.

I bought this machine in 2008 to save money on daily lattes from Dunkin' Donuts. Ten years later, I still use it 5 or more times a week and with regular cleanings, I have never had a problem. I'm not a coffee aficionado, so I'm not sure that I can comment on the quality of the espresso this machine produces. I just know that I like the espresso that comes out of this machine when I have the beans I love. If you are a coffee lover, but not a coffee snob, this is your machine.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I purchased this after researching as many machines as I could, reading many of the reviews/comments/complaints, and decided this would be a best purchase of my first espresso machine. I like espresso, it's just gone to soon after you make it, even if you savor the flavor and stretch it out as long as you can. So I also make mugs of strong coffee so I can sit and enjoy. This machine makes both great. The flavor and strength of my first espresso was far better then any I ever had at a *bucks. I had to experiment with the grind and tamping because I too was getting watery pucks at first. Like another reviewer, I found it's all in the grind and the tamp pressure. I have a capresso burr grinder with 8 settings in the fine to extra fine range. I tried all of them. To fine and it would not make coffee, less fine and would have great coffee but a watery puck. less fine yet and the proper tamp pressure, and it was perfect. Of my fine settings it was about in the middle. BUT, it was also in the tamp...Until I got the Terry's tamper, I couldn't get it tamped firm enough to use the fineest grind that I wanted. Now I have the proper grind marked on my grinder, fill the double filter with two scoops, tap it to settle it, tamp it, refill to the rim, tamp etc. until full. Put it on the machine, brew for 15-25 seconds and its done. Rich, strong espresso, wonderful aromatic crema, dry solid puck. Now if I want coffee, I just brew a double and a single, put it in a mug, add hot water to the top, and enjoy a creamy, flavorful, aromatic coffee with no bitterness or acidity, almost as thick as chocolate milk. To speed things up if I have guests, or if I want several cups, I ordered three more filters from partstore.com for 12 bucks each. I pre fill them and can make four double shots in a row. Also, the frother makes works great. Just learn how to do it on line first. Just under the surface and raise it up as the volume increases. And I use whole milk, which is harder to froth but tastes great.
reviews.review_header: Great espresso is Not That Complicated

reviews.review_text: I am loving this machine. In my college days I worked in a coffee shop so I have experience with a professional grade machine. I was worried a small version like this couldn't create enough steam for good foam or brew a nice cup of espresso. After a month, this machine has exceeded my expectations. It is a great machine for the price. I have a stainless steel carafe for foaming milk. If you hold the wand just below the surface of the milk, you get perfect foam. My only complaint is that after foaming the milk, I have to tip the machine slightly to pull out the carafe, otherwise I will spill the foam. But this is a minor complaint and could probably be avoided by not creating so much foam but I like my cappuccino foamy. Definitely recommend this machine.

I received this yesterday - after spending about a week looking at specs and reading reviews on several different espresso makers that were in my budget. I kept coming back to the De'Longhi, read and re-read many reviews. There were a few repetitive complaints I will list & subsequently add my feedback to the end: 1) can't fit a big enough cup under it - well, it IS an expresso machine and true to typical size of an espresso cup, i don't see the problem. I have coffee shop style (read: small) cups from Williams Sonoma that I use - there is a tad of a clearance problem, maybe a millimeter - but what I did was brew a double shot, making the cup full, then dump it into a larger cup and add my frothed milk, etc. maybe an extra step but no bother to me personally. 2) the machine rattles so much the cup almost jumped off the rack - i did not experience this problem at all! I think that was a bit of a stretch, but whatever. 3) the steamer wand isn't long enough/not right size - again, no problems here. and i didn't buy a specific metal pitcher - a pyrex glass 1 cup measure did the job for me perfectly. 4) preheating the machine - it says 15 minutes - my "ok" light comes on prior to that, but either way, 15 minutes is gone a flash in my mornings, so this too, was not a big deal. 5) the filter has sloppy/soggy grounds after a cup of espresso is brewed - maybe these people are popping it off right way or something... i finished my java and when I took my off, had no problems here either. All in all, for the price, the compact size, the quality of the name, the ease of use and the fabulous espresso that it brews - with a very rich, dark carmel colored crema - I totally give this little gem a thumbs up all the way. I even found a $20 rebate coupon online running now thru early December - so for a total cost of under $60 in the end - it's a deal! More of the 5 stars are accurate than the 1's by a long shot - take a chance on it - Amazons return policy is amazing anyway, so what do you have to lose?

So far, I'm very impressed with this little machine, especially considering the cost. It takes a few (3-4) tries before you figure out how much pressure it takes to tamp it down. I also recommend purchasing a separate tamper, since the one attached to the machine is difficult to use. It's plastic, the machine is lightweight and it's hard to put enough upward pressure on the grounds. I'm reliably getting a decent crema on my espresso. The machine is short, so it easily fits on my countertop with room to spare and refill the water without moving it, however that means there is not much clearance for the cup or the frothing container of milk. It won't take a cup much taller than a demitasse cup. The frothing arm spits out a lot of hot water before a good blast of steam, which waters down the milk. When I first turn it on, I use an empty cup to catch the hot water, turn off the steam, then switch to the milk. Heating up the cappuccino cup first is a good idea anyway. For under $100, I'm really happy with machine so far.

This is a nice machine - as long as you get one that works/lasts for a reasonable amount of time; unfortunately I've had to go through several to get one that finally lasts longer than 3 months. My current machine is going on 9 months and has made close to 300 double shots of espresso at this point (saving me quite a bit of money in the long run as opposed to buying my drinks at a coffee shop). The design of the steam wand leaves alot to be desired, but I knew that when I bought it (I use another machine for steaming). The construction is ok - lots of plastic, but it doesn't seem overly brittle. No, it's not fancy but it does have a real pressure pump and can make some pretty darn good shots. For the price it isn't bad - but I wouldn't be happy if it didn't last at least 150-200 shots (and pay for itself in the process by saving money over coffee shops).
reviews.review_header: Good machine - watch for quality control

reviews.review_text: This espresso maker cannot be beat for price. Using Lavazza coffee, we get excellent espresso shots that start dark transitioning to beautiful rust color and ending in a nice crema on top. The mill frother is ok. I instead pour warm milk at 150 degrees F into a French press, pump rapidly 10-12 times and get great dense froth!y milk.
reviews.review_header: Great espresso maker for the price

reviews.review_text: Love the coffee/espresso this makes. Taking into consideration other's comments, I put this on top of a butcher block to make it possible to put vessel with milk under wand. I also cut a square from a silicone potholder to put on the metal tray and this has kept my cup from vibrating off the tray! I use an old style coffee cup that fits perfectly under the two spouts.

Pump espresso makes americano more flavorful as the water temperature is lower. Great machine, easy to use, easy to clean. It would be great to have more clearance for a bigger cup and we made a little adjustment: removed the metal cover and now bigger cup fits. We use aerolatte for frothing milk -- I never liked the ones that came with espresso machines since they were hard to clean and didn't last. UPDATE: After 2.5 years it stopped running. After reading the reviews, I was supposed to run a cleaner through the system every few month which I didn't. I ordered some and we'll see if this will fix the issue. Other than this, it lasted 2.5 years with daily use of 4-5 cups a day without any problems and it was refurbished to begin with. If cleaner will not fix it, than I'm buying the same one with 4-years warranty. They came down in price a lot.
reviews.review_header: The best coffee I made at home!!!

reviews.review_text: So I have not used it to make froth as yet as i have been making ice drinks - summer here in Florida. You have to wait for the green light to come on which takes about 10 minutes the first time. The light wil almost always go out during the process. I usually stop it and re-start it when it comes back on - which is always less than a minute. You really should not fill a small espresso cup more than 1/3 full to get full bodied coffee(not the really small ones). I need 3 shots to make my 16 oz iced mocha. Takes time but it does a decent job making espresso. I recommend it unless you can afford to spend $300 or more which will definitely do a better job. The water container is easy to use and keep clean. It has to filter baskets that you can pre-fill with espresso. It does what is expected of it. Nothing more nothing less. I have had expensive ones in the past but for now this works great. I would buy it again. Easy to clean as well. I use only ILLY espresso fine ground. I love Italian espresso.

So far I have been using this expresso/cappucino maker for past 2 weeks and I must say that I am impressed and have not been to Starbucks (5Bucks) since then. Buy yourself a nice expresso or ground roast ... and save $4.00 everytime you make a cup ... after 20 some cups this machine will pay for itself. The money you will be saving everyday going to Starbucks will compensate for high gas prices at the pump ;) Absolutely love this unit here ... perfect cup every single time. I have added a photo collage on how to make a cappucino Caio ! ======= So its been over 10 months since I purchased this expresso maker ===== With over 550 cups made including for my friends, guest and family I must say this is one heck of a machine, I was not expecting this machine to last me this long. In my mind I had that as long as I get 200 cups out of it I got my money's worth. So far I have cleaned this unit throughly with vinegar 3 times and there are no complaints. For most part I am using Lavazza Crema Gusto coffee ($3.49 on sale), filtered water and I use Deans Half and Half for cream. Excellent froth and crema every single time. I ususally steam clean the stainless steel pod after using .. helps maintain the equipment. Once you purchase this unit you will notice that your social life will improve, friends will stop often for a cup of coffee :) and for less than $0.35 cents a cup its the cheapest way to entertain your friends. ============ Over 3 years Now and still cranking cup after cup ========== I must say I am impressed ... with over 2400+ cups of cappuccinos made and served to many family and friends I must say that I have gotten every single penny worth from this unit and then some. My recipe for perfect cup: Raw sugar - to your liking (1 teaspoon) Deans Half & Half Lavazza Crema e Gusto Expresso

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I purchased this product along with other coffee making items in April 2012, and now its Jan 2013. Still going strong, and my lattes like or better than what I can order at Starbucks.
