Here's my poor man's espresso set up, I paid a total of $120 $20 Coffee grinder: KRUPS 203-42 Electric Spice and Coffee Grinder with Stainless Steel?blades,?Black $80 Espresso maker: THIS De'Longhi EC155 $15 12oz Milk frothing cup: KRUPS XS5012 12 Ounce Stainless Steel Milk Frothing Pitcher,?Silver $5 5oz Espresso cup: Update International BC-5 Stainless Steel Bell Creamer, 5-Ounce, 2-3/8-Inch This month I was concerned with the espresso maker. It was only dripping (or sometimes not at all) and a 2.5oz shot would take 60 seconds! I tried to clean and unclog the porta-filters. I removed and cleaned the filter by the boiler. I even twice tried to descale the machine using a 1:1 distilled vinegar and water solution, making sure I give it 15 minutes before flushing out the solution. Even after spending a couple of hours doing this, the machine refused to cooperate. Finally, I sucked it up and went to bed-bath-beyond and bought a brand-name descaler Durgol Swiss Espresso Special Decalcifier, 2-Pack 4.2 fluid ounce Bottles . The instructions were to dump the 4.2oz with 4.2oz water in the tank and run that through the machine. I was quite pessimistic initially! However, this actually worked! I had to flush 4-5 tanks of water through the machine to completely flush the solution out. I'm now writing this review after pulling a perfectly timed 25-second shot on my newly restored EC155. I remember when I initially bought the machine that it was quite loud, and I was happy that with use the thing quieted down a bit with use. However, I noticed that after descaling the machine is now as loud as it was new! Bummer! So... I guarantee this machine will stop working if not maintained properly. I'm amazed that the thing kept working for 8 months without any maintenance. I wholeheartedly recommend the durgol descaler to restore your EC155 to full working order!

I have been using this for over a year now. It works pretty well. I can make a decent espresso in just a few minutes. The only thing I don't like is the steaming wand. There's not much space for it, so you can't steam very much milk at a time. It also tends to drip milk down the side of the machine if you don't make a conscious effort to keep that from happening.
reviews.review_header: It works pretty well. I can make a decent espresso in ...

reviews.review_text: This is a great introductory espresso machine. I’ve had it for many years and still enjoy it. I have had issues with the pump failing, generally after one year. The customer support is great. They will give you a new replacement if you mail in the electrical cord of the broken unit. I’ve noticed that the machine struggles a lot if you use very oily beans- the pump seems to have a very hard time forcing enough pressure through and one pull would take up to a minute. If you use nonoily beans, there is no problem. Also, the espresso machine should work while using a very fine grind and tamping with 30 lbs of pressure. If you try doing that with this machine, the espresso won’t come out or it will take 1-1:30 minutes for a double shot. To sum up, I think it is a great introductory machine, but I will probably upgrade to something better once my current machine dies again.
reviews.review_header: Some issues with the pump, but excellent customer service. DON'T USE VERY OILY BEANS!

reviews.review_text: I bought this machine in September of 2012. As of today, 3/21/2013, it's still running just fine. I have deep cleaned it maybe 3 times and use it at least 3-6 times a week. I always use filtered water. I am very anal about the cleanliness of my espresso and coffee products in general. I'm the guy who spends more time cleaning the machine after use then actually enjoying my coffee :) I'm only going to touch on the negative aspects of the machine since you can read MANY other reviews that highlight the positive. My biggest complaint is with the portafilter. It's mostly plastic and the metal piece is a cheap quality metal. Mine use to be a shiny chrome finish and now it is a dull grayish color and doesn't slide into the locking mechanism as fluidly as it use to. The piece that pops out of the portafilter I will call the basket. There is a single shot size and double shot size. Who actually uses single shot basket? lol. The basket consists of 4 parts that unscrew for cleaning. Only problem is, you don't know how tight to tighten the piece when putting it back together. If you torque it down to much it will slow down the flow of espresso leading you to think your grind is too fine or your tamp pressure is too much, when the problem is the basket gasket screw tightness. If you leave it too loose, it may let the espresso flow out too fast. I usually just tighten this a little bit past the "numb" once it starts to give some resistance. Last thing about the portafilter is after a few washings, you will start to notice water creeps in between the two piece, plastic handle. It's held together by three screws, so every now and then you might want to take it apart and clean out all the coffee grime that has accumulated in there. From day one I didn't like how the portafilter felt, but it will pull a decent shot of espresso is everything is right. (grind, tamp, ect.) The only other negative aspect of the machine is the small space between the portafilter drip nozzles and the base where you lay your espresso cup. It's very small and it's hard to find proper size shot glass to fit underneath. I, 95% of the time take the metal base piece off to give me that extra inch or so of clearance. This defeats the purpose of the drip catcher altogether but it's not too bad if you lay down a piece of folded paper towel or rag and place your shot glass on top. This keeps your glass from rattling too...tricky tricky. Everything else works great. It heats up well and gets hotter as you use it. The steam wand works good at this price point. I usually steam up at the most, 4-6 ounces of milk or cream when making a latte or cappuccino. I use an insta-thermometer and it takes less then 1 minute to get to 160-185 degrees. I like to steam it on the hotter side because I always make a quad shot and it takes a little time to clean out the portafilter and shot glass between shots. I use to use the Hario Mini Mill Slim hand grinder and just recently acquired the Breville Smart Grinder. The Hario slim works well with this machine on the 4th click out from full tight. I'm still getting use to the Smart Grinder but it works well somewhere in the middle of the espresso grind settings with this machine. Make sure you buy your own 50 mm tamper as the one on the machine isn't ideal. Keep it clean and use fresh, filtered water and I'm sure this machine will last you until you feel you are ready to upgrade to a better machine. That's what I'm about to do, but I will keep this machine in the pantry for a back up or maybe give it to a friend who wants to learn to make good espresso. If anyone has a recommendation of my next espresso machine I would love to hear it. Please write a comment. Thanks and happy coffee drinking.
reviews.review_header: Great entry level machine...for the price.

reviews.review_text: Makes decent espresso and is very easy to use. Quick points on how I've gotten this mini maker to do what I'd like: Steaming milk: - For the steam wand, you can produce microfoamed milk for latte art by cutting off the skirt portion of the frother. If you know how to steam milk, you can still make the extra foam for cappuccinos. - You can also get into the machine and replace the wand, but you also void your warranty. - You can get a smaller/shorter frothing pitcher, or move the whole machine to the edge of the counter, so your pitcher doesn't run into the counter. Espresso: - My espresso was hit-or-miss with crema, until I fine tuned my grinder to something more powdery. The "espresso-grind" setting at the local store is NOT fine enough! - You can also experiment with different espresso baskets. The only real downside is that the water doesn't stay constant enough sometimes, and the "Red light" will turn on while in mid-espresso extraction, as well as steaming. Temperature fluctuation are not good, but unless you're particular about your espresso, it still tastes great.

I gave this machine 5 stars because it really is a wonderful espresso machine. It's easy to use and the perfect "Beginner" espresso maker. But 16 months later, I am sad to report it has died. If I had paid $400 and it lasted only 16 months I would NOT be giving it 5 stars. But the machine did not cost much and I have used it daily, which is around 500 cups of delicious cappuccino for less than $.20 each. So I did get my moneys worth. It's been acting strange for a few days. I always warm it up for 15 minutes but beginning yesterday, the espresso is weak and cool. I think maybe the heating element has gone out. Steaming has been acting up for a couple months, but today it got worse. When it's switched over to steam, it just sits there. After maybe 40 seconds of silence, it starts sputtering out a stream of water which slowly turns to steam. Once it does start steaming it does a great job! But the cool weak espresso is the end of it. I'll be ordering a new espresso machine in the next day or two and it won't be this one. Cuisinart has a 3 year warranty....maybe I'll try that one. Edit: one week later.....my brand new Delonghi EC155 is sitting on my counter and I am happy. Last week after my old one broke, I went on the hunt for a new espresso machine. I didn't want to order one....I have gotten quite used to a fresh cappuccino every morning so I wanted one I could get locally. The Cuisinart that I wanted would need to be ordered. I got a Krups espresso machine that was sitting on the shelf at my local Bed Bath and Beyond. What a piece of junk! I was unable to make that machine produce a decent foam and the water tank had a strong chemical smell. So I returned it and ordered another Delonghi (2-day shipping) only this time , I spent $13 on an extended 3 year warranty. So that will solve the problem. Edit: 12/2011. As expected, my replacement Delonghi EC155 lasted 20 months and failed. This time it was the espresso part that would not work. The steam part works just fine. Thank goodness I got the extended warranty. I ordered yet another Delonghi EC155 today.....my 3rd one. I use this machine every single day (for less money....only $79 plus it has a $20 rebate) so even if 18 to 20 months is the expected lifespan of this machine, it's still only pennies a day for delicious cappuccino. When this newest one fails, I will probably buy a 4th one.
reviews.review_header: Wonderful machine, but lasted only 16 months. Get this machine with extended warranty

reviews.review_text: Waited for a few weeks to give me time to test this unit. Overall it seems to be a good unit for the price. Makes good expresso. Has a small footprint. Frothing process works fine but a little cumbersome as the steam arm is short. Water reservoir is small but it makes 3 or 4 cups without refill and its easy to get at. Controls are simple and straight forward. The tamp is attached to the machine and is not very handy but that is not a big deal. How long it will last is of course yet to be determined. Overall given what I know about it now I would recommend it.

works great and makes great espresso, but there are design flaws. My number one complaint is the shortness of the area to receive cups. You can barely fit a shot gloss under the espresso spout. Not able to fit any kind of coffee cup underneath it. Really needs to be taller. Other than that I have very few complaints and like it. The frother works, the water reservoir is great.
reviews.review_header: needs to be taller but is overall a great little espresso maker

reviews.review_text: We bought this espresso machine to replace our Mr. coffee espresso machine that had bit the dust, my only complaint with this machine is that there isn’t enough room to fit any kind of cup to catch the espresso. With our old machine I would use a small mason jar to measure the amount of espresso I brewed, but with this one my only option is to use a very small Pyrex bowl. The coffee still tastes amazing, and I love the milk frother, I just really wish they would have made the machine a little taller so that we could at least put a cup underneath it.
reviews.review_header: Coffee tastes great, design a little flawed.

reviews.review_text: Ten years ago I worked as a barista, and I think that previous knowledge has helped me get the best cappuccino possible out of this machine. Here are my tips: First, read the manual. It's important to know about the settings that allow the machine to heat properly. Secondly, you need to buy some extra stuff: 12 oz stainless steel steam pot, clip-on thermometer, tamper and 5 oz stainless steel pots to catch the espresso. Anything larger than a tiny little pot will not fit under the extractor. You might also want espresso mugs, too. I recommend that you tamp your espresso grounds to 30 lbs. of pressure and twist as you push downward (press downward on a scale until you get a feel for it). Steam your milk between 140-160 degrees for optimal flavor and frothing. Together, the espresso shots I pulled from the machine and the milk I steamed made a nice cappuccino. I can't wait to buy mocha and vanilla syrups to try even more kinds of drinks!
reviews.review_header: Cheaper than Starbucks any day; however, use it properly!

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: Originally 5 star .. se reason for dropping to 4 star .. last paragraphs. Often, I have a big lunch at La Teresita, a small Cuban cafe and restaurant in Tampa, with my good friend Westgate. Afterward, we order big "tazas" of Cuban espresso, loaded with sugar. Delicious/Sabrosisima ... but how to make it at home has always been frustrating. I had a little Salton espresso machine, bought from Amazon long ago. It worked fine, but, somehow, did not come up to the standards of La Teresita espresso. The Salton was just a "steamer." So, a search of Amazon's store revealed the DeLonghi EC155 espresso/cappuccino maker. I got it for an Xmas present to myself. This morning I used it for the first time. the instructions were a bit befuddling, however I surmounted that and gave it the required five rinsings with water passing through the system. Then came time to make the espresso. I didn't have a fancy espresso cup, so I used a short coffee cup. Soon the coffee came out, with a nice foam on the top, something that the Salton would not do. Adding the sugar that I like ... I was suddenly in La Teresita Cuban Cafe. The primary secret was the internal pump in the DeLonghi ... it's not just a steamer. I liked it a lot ... so I ordered a replacement when it died after 3 years. Next one sounded like an airplane going overhead ... and the thing jiggled so much that coffee cups would bounce off. Amazon sent another one .. much quieter ... however, I am lowering my rating to 4 stars because of the noisy pump

Okay, so there are some issues with this one. The main one being the size. You will have to be careful of what size milk steamer container you purchase- the big ones will NOT fit in this little guy. BUT I just put mine up on a pedastool (lucking coffee maker- LOL) and it works very well. I use shot glasses when making my espresso and it works perfectly. It does not have an automatic shut-off, so you will have to keep an eye on your espresso and make sure it isn't geting too watery. I LOVE mine!!! I have had it for over a year and a half and have NEVER had an issue with it. Easy to clean, easy to use and GREAT results! If you have never had an espresso machine before (this is my first) this is a GREAT place to start! Cheap- compared to most other machines, works AWESOME and makes super yummy espresso drinks! Thank you!

I love my machine. This is the first espresso machine I had bought and did a lot of research to make this decsion. Great machine and saves me so much money since I no longer need Starbucks in my life. I did buy a tamper because I did not like that it was attached to the machine so that would be my only negative. Also if you use syrups look at [...], they have so many flavors to choose from, great prices, and will turn any of your espresso drinks into pure heaven. My personal favorite is Banana Mocha Iced Latte! Use to buy them at a local coffee shop on special occasions and now I can make them everyday :)

This little machine works great for me. I was a barista for .. too many years. I have always used semi auto and automatic, fancy espresso machines. This one does a fine job for the price. I have not had success getting the machine to produce crema, yet, though, but i remain hopeful as I'm still adjusting to it. I have also never had to tamp my espresso myself- the machines I have used in the past have always taken care of that for me. I know, I know, what kind of barista AM I? So, this has presented me with a learning opportunity.. I have had times where the espresso drips very slowly, and I believe that to be a fault of mine own poor tamping skills. Otherwise, this machine is great for the price, and I'm a happy customer.

Liking this espresso. Gave it 4 stars instead of 5 because the swinging steamer arm is annoying. Wish I could swing it away and it would stay away at times. It keeps swinging back. Otherwise very nice machine. It's small and perfect for someone with limited counter space.

I used to get a latte EVERY morning at Starbucks. Now I don't even crave "the" Starbucks latte anymore. I make my own shots, steam my own fully organic milk and have a heavenly cup each morning. I use the espresso roast from Starbucks so I am not completely cutting my trips to Starbucks, however I found that using my organic milk my latte tastes better. It comes with the side coffee tamper that flattens where you put ground espresso coffee to begin doing the shots (so no need to purchase it). It is very simple to use. Add water, turn it on to heat up, once green light comes on turn it own to begin making the espresso, once done, turn all the way to the other end for the steamer to begin steaming water so you can steam milk. after a couple of minutes just open a nob that begins the steam and that's it. Its also easy clean up. make sure to run it without coffee before your first time. I bough a stainless steel pitcher for the steaming of milk, a portable coffee cup (Starbucks, ~$22) that is stainless in and out since milk stinks if it sits in there after you are finished and by the time you get home from work, it smells bad and stays bad (if its plastic). Coffee/milk drinkers, always gets stainless steel in and out on the coffee portable cups. Plus they are also much better at keeping coffee warm for HOURS! and the outside remains cool and comfortable for easy handling.
reviews.review_header: My beloved morning best friend! The reason I get out of bed!

reviews.review_text: Can't tell you if it is better than another machine or not. I can tell you it makes a nicer cup of coffee than a typical brewer. It does take a few moments of time to prepare a cup but I think it is worth it. That said, I am looking forward to it breaking in the future. I have quirks with it that I would like to not have when making coffee. Mostly that my favorite mug does not fit under it. In fact it misses only my a few millimeters. Oh well. I also think the steamer is a bit weak. Though I have not had much experience steaming milk prior I think this one is probably not as good as others. This machine was a great intro into making espresso. I am glad I bought it and I do use it everyday. I will be able to buy my next machine with better knowledge of what I am looking for. I suggest this as a good first machine. It will teach you what you need to know and it will prepare you to know what you need in a future machine. This is an excellent starter system and the coffee is REALLY good.

The short and nasty: as a graduate of the school of Starbucks back when pulling a perfect shot was a skill and an art, I have high expectations for espresso. Obviously, I need a thick crema and I want to see a dark heart. This machine has consistently given me perfect pulls from the first shot. I often marvel at the beautiful separation of the espresso while it's pouring and savor the final shot... whether I'm making a straight espresso or a homemade iced caramel macchiato. Seriously. If you're going to get this machine, get clear shot glasses. You're going to love watching this thing work. Now, the only draw back is its squat design. I literally have to tip my 1oz shot glasses to get them under the portafilter. Yeah, I could remove the stainless steel bottom for an extra inch... so, that's a possible solution to that problem. With regards to the wand issue that others have mentioned, that it is too short and too close to the counter, I just put the machine on a little stand that gives me extra space. Again, I don't know how they expect anyone to use the steam wand on a flat counter, but there are options. Final verdict, the price and quality of shot are worth negotiating the short design. You won't be upset.

I like coffee a lot, but I am not a coffee snob. I was willing to buy a burr grinder and a few other appliances, but I mostly made my own coffee at home with standard drop coffee maker. When I am out, I always enjoyed fancier coffees, and I had messed around with steam-driven espresso makers over the years. I kept wanting to get a pump-driven espresso machine, but there are so many choices, and the costs are sometimes a bit overwhelming. Anyway, when this went on sale, I snapped one up. I have been using it for a few weeks now. It has been exactly what I was hoping for. The coffee, after some trial and error, tastes great. I am still developing my skills on the foamer side, but it works like a charm. This is the best entry level espresso maker that I have played with. I have used others at friend's and family's houses. All of that praise stated, you need a small and wide foam pitcher to work with the steamer. It is a little awkward, but that is my only criticism. If you are looking to spend around $100 to enter into the pump espresso maker market, I think this is a great choice.

I used to be a barista at a coffee shop, so coming from that, this machine has a lot of problems. I'll list them here: - Grabbing the top is the only sensible way to get enough force to either tamp the grounds using the built-in top or lock the cup in place, but the top is ridiculously hot, so I occasionally get minor burns trying to avoid it and get the right amount of pressure - The steam wand leaves a lot to be desired. I have to put two cappuccinos-worth of milk in my regular-sized frothing pitcher so that the wand reaches the top of the milk - Steam wand is hard to clean. Getting anything up inside the black cover on the tip is difficult. Once, it even clogged and the next time I turned on the wand, nothing came out, then, all of a sudden, there was an explosion of steam. Dangerous! - Not a lot of pressure through the ground. It takes forever to get a double-shot. All that being said, I'm quite happy with my purchase. I bought, as recommended by other reviews, RSVP Terry's Tamper so I don't have to use the built-in. I don't use the machine as often as I thought due to how time-consuming it can be, but it's still a nice treat on weekends. Knowing everything I dislike about this machine, I still would have bought it because you can't beat the price.
reviews.review_header: You get what you pay for

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I prefer this machine to the $400 Saeco one I purchased a few years ago, as it froths better. The water that comes from it is also hotter. Here are a couple of tips for using this machine. 1. If you are grinding coffee at the store, use the Turkish grind, which is finer than the espresso setting. If you are new to espresso machines, start by using Illy coffee. 2. The built in tamper presses the coffee down enough. 3. When frothing, let the water heat up in frothing mode for a few minutes after the green ok light turns on. This way you end up with practically no extra water added to your steamed milk. I learned this by accident. 4. For the first use of the day, run though some heated water, before adding coffee.

Really great value little espresso machine that served me well when I lived in America. Quite easy to clean and makes good coffee. I bought my own tamp, milk frothing jug and espresso shot glasses to go with it. The milk frother was pretty decent for a cheap machine - can't exactly get some microfoam going on but it got some decent froth happening at least. Pros: - Good for making coffee for one person at a time - Good value for the price - Easy to clean - Makes decent espresso - Steams milk ok enough for a cheapo cappuccino Cons: - Hard to fit a cup underneath, so I had to buy espresso shot glasses - Hard to froth a lot of milk because the frother doesn't reach down very far, but it's enough for one person - You probably won't like it if you value your microfoam - The tamp is a bit useless - just buy your own Overall, I thought for the price it was a great machine and fixed my espresso cravings when I moved from Australia to the US.

This espresso machine is the best in its price range. I did some research before finalizing on this model but I am very pleased. A few things to note, be sure you place the portafilter in the machine and then push the handle to the right otherwise it will not seal and the water will run down the handle and make a mess. Coffee creamer does not frother very well with this machines arm, 2% milk does and do not be afraid to crank up the steam nob. Lastly, do not get discouraged if your first espresso tastes terrible. It takes a lot of trial and error to get it to your preference. I have saved $25 by avoiding Starbucks with this machine in my first week.
reviews.review_header: This espresso machine is the best in its price range

reviews.review_text: Tell you what, I ran this machine daily for a year, an entire year, and I love it. Sure, it'll vibrate enough to rattle the cup right out from under the stream of surprisingly decent espresso being extracted (seriously, keep an eye out for that), and the little frother nozzle is near impossible to clean, but here's why you need one- it's cheap, it makes reliably good espresso, and you can steam up a mug of milk in next to no time. It's easy to use, heats up quick, and has a certain wallet-friendly look to it that says "sure, all of these matte black plastic surfaces could be stainless steel, but we'd also like you to be able to afford this machine." I appreciate that.
reviews.review_header: A no-frills dynamo for those who enjoy a simple espresso experience

reviews.review_text: AMAZING espresso machine. After reading up on hundreds of reviews I am so happy we went with this espresso machine. Super easy to operate and clean. You get perfect delicious shots with plenty of crema (even without any modifications). After a few tries to figure out just how to make it work, it is absolutely easy to get perfect microfoam (again, without any modifications). The frothing wand is a little bit short but for a 12oz frothing pitcher and if you just angle it in there just right, you CAN get the wand to the bottom and get amazing foam without any problems. We've had this for about half a year and now my parents bought one too. Anyone who has used this machine in my family has loved it. And for the price, you seriously can NOT go wrong.

I did a good deal of research before purchasing this machine. I saw a lot of pros and cons for it, but more pros, so I though this would be a great one for the price. So far I have not been disappointed. We had several guests in town yesterday and I ended up having to make about 10-12 cups of espresso for everyone and each one came out with a wonderful flavor and lovely crema on top. As I was reading through the reviews prior to purchase, there were a few other reviewers who gave good tips on a frothing pitcher, a tamp (because I did not realize this one came with a built in one) and some helpful hints. So this is a consolidation of those hints and my experience. My biggest concern with this machine was soupy grinds instead of a hard puck. But since I knew many people had given helpful reviews, I came back to do some research and found my answer. Which was simple, the espresso basket needs to have more espresso in it. Fill the basket until you have a "cone" of coffee that rises above the edge, then use the built in or if you prefer external tamp. Don't press too hard or the grinds will be too packed for the water to penetrate. Make sure to wipe excess from the edges. However, even with the soupy grinds that were left over, I still got a great flavor and beautifully colored crema in each pull. Several people pointed out that there were water pitcher leaks, I haven't had an issue with that, because when I put it in after filling it, I just make sure to press it down well, you can feel when it is pushed all the way down in place. It recommends 15 minutes of heating, but it doesn't take that long, I turn it on to heat while I'm getting down cups and preparing everything, then do the water run, to make sure it's good and hot. Yesterday, when I had so many guests, I just did one water run, because it was in constant use, and everything was piping hot, even with a few minutes in between uses. I saw some comments that the machine does not cut itself off, so the pull would just keep running making things watery. There's a green "OK" light that should be on when you start your pull, and the moment it turns off, just flip the switch back to the warming position or off (if you aren't pulling anymore shots). Many complained that the steam wand made their milk watery. Even professional machines that baristas use in shops will build up water in the steam wand. Years and years ago I was a barista (so when I was getting soupy grinds I was concerned since I did use to do it for a living), and if you express the steam wand before using it, you won't have this issue. I just stick a paper towel under the area the wand is pointed at and turn it on low until all water comes out. Then I already have the paper towel just in case I spill anything from the pitcher or let it over flow. The frothing pitcher http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000MR6I9I/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 is a good size, I believe this one is the 12 ounce, someone else also recommended a 10 ounce, I think either is fine. It fits under the nozzle well, and the only issue I would have is if I build the froth up to the edge of the pitcher, but that's more to do with me than the machine. Either tamp works, I personally like having an external one, but that's just personal preference and it's not expensive. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0001XRNEM/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i01?ie=UTF8&psc=1 You do need a smaller cup to fit under the machine, I have had some demi cups for years that fit wonderfully, so that hasn't been an issue. I do not have these, but based on the measurements they are probably a great option. http://www.amazon.com/BIA-Cordon-Bleu-Bistro-Espresso/dp/B000Q935OI/ref=sr_1_7?s=home-garden&ie=UTF8&qid=1398088082&sr=1-7&keywords=demi+cups Overall, for the price and the ease of making espresso, this is a great machine. All of the parts of the filter come apart easily for cleaning, it's easy to unscrew and wash the steam wand guard, then screw it back on and the storage for the extra single shot filter is great. It doesn't take up much space and is easy to operate.

I owned one of these years ago but moved on to a higher end model, which my wife never got the handle of. After two years of me being the only one who could pull a decent shot, we went user friendly a Nespresso unit that, while dead simple to use, is expensive due to pod costs and, frankly, makes barely passable espresso. (The Nespresso caps contain 5 grams of coffee, but a decent shot needs 7 grams.) We rocked Nespresso for three years, but I got tired of weak shots and high-cost pods, so we looked at all our options (and our budget) and realized that the De'Longhi model we started on was the right solution for us. The story on this machine is simple- with the right ESE pod, anybody can pull a very drinkable shot. With the right ground coffee and a little skill, you can make a very good shot. And you get all of this at a very friendly price. On the down side, the machine relies on pressurized portafilters and lacks a 3-way solenoid valve, so you will never pull the perfect shot with mountains of tiger-stripped cream, and you will always have to clean a soggy puck. However, that is true for most machines under $500 anyway, so unless you've got big bucks to invest on a Miss Silvia, this cheapie will most likely serve your purpose and save you money. The other feature I'm not in love with is the steam wand, but you can whisk cold milk and microwave it pretty easy and get froth for days. Just make sure you do the "Mr. Miagi" with the whisk to get the fine foam you crave. Bottom line, this is a fantastic entry-level espresso machine that will serve the needs of all but the most picky coffee geeks. UPDATE- after use, this machine doesn't seem to brew at a consistent temp. Occasionally, my shots taste a bit scorched. Also, the steam wand leaks. I stand by my original claim that you cannot get a better machine for the money, or even double the money. That said, I am contemplating saving up for one of those better machine all the same.
reviews.review_header: Not perfect, but amazing bang for the buck.

reviews.review_text: Review UPDATE!! Below is my original review...I have had this machine now for several months, I've used it every day at least once a day and it still works as good as new. I love it and am so incredibly happy with it! So I have to say I was kinda scared to buy this. There are so many reviews out there with it some good some bad. Some of them were saying it vibrates so hard it shakes the cup off. Others the steamer was poor, ect; Well here is a little background about 10 years ago I worked at a coffee shop for around 3 years and I have to say I know how to make a good cup of coffee. So I decided for the price Id give it a go and I LOVE IT! The espresso shots come out perfect with just the right amount of cream. The steamer works wonderfully...Yes its a little short not much room to work with but we have it at the edge of our counter so just hold the steamer to the side so we can easily remove the frothing pitcher. If you don't have this option I can see why it would be frustrating. My husband who is not a coffee drinker at all has actually gotten up and started making himself white mocha's in the Morning. The fact that this machine offers two different size filters is perfect: he can use the small one that gives a very small shot and Me who likes around 2-4 shots of espresso in a drink can use the big filter. I will say if you aren't sure what an espresso shot is suppose to be then it will take some practice getting the grind/water ratio correct for you. All in all I say this is a perfect buy and for a wonderful price. I do plan on getting on here again in about 6 months to let you know if it's still going wonderfully*A lot of people said the problem with theirs is that it stopped working after a while** As to the cups vibrating off I use the little European tea mug one is short enough to fit under but allows both nozzles to empty into the same glass securing it from vibrating off. All in all I would say this is a wonderful buy and look forward to my morning Espresso.

Great little machine for specialty coffees at home. I got it as a starter machine for my husband, as he got fed up with our local famous coffee shop. The quality of their mochas had gone downhill, so now he makes them at home and they are better than the $5 kind. FYI, if you are making mochas, I recommend Ghirardelli chocolate Barista mini-chips, dark chocolate.
reviews.review_header: Great little machine for specialty coffees at home

reviews.review_text: I bought this and initially had an awful time making espresso shots with crema. I found out later that it's due to a bad grind. I am not a coffee snob, but if you don't use the right grind, you'll get the equivalent of bad bad drop coffee. I bought a Capresso burr grinder and now the thing pumps out great shots with excellent creama. Don't skimp and buy a blade grinder, you'll get awful shots. While the machine is not fully automatic, it's fine for me. It's not too terribly loud and does it's job efficiently. While some of the pieces feel a bit cheap, overall it's well put together and performs up-to-snuff. What I liked: -Simple to use -Quick espresso -Inexpensive -A great $20 rebate! -The frothing wand works great (but see below) What I do not like: -The space between the filter and the grating is really short. Use tiny shot glasses. -The frothing wand is really short. I had to place the machine at the end of my table to get a cup underneath it. -The customer service of Delonghi is awful. Their phone service is only open during my workday and I am waiting over a week after emailing them and still haven't received anything back. I recommend this machine for the casual espresso lover.
reviews.review_header: Great buy for the money...just use the right grind

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I had a Krupps for years that finally died. This is a much better choice, especially at the price. I love the crema that this machine makes. I drink espresso straight, but I love the creaminess of a well made one. This machine consistently produces the perfect cup. My wife likes a cappuccino, the milk steamer on this does a great job as well. I am extremely happy with this purchase and I would recommend this unit to anyone.
reviews.review_header: This is a much better choice, especially at the price

reviews.review_text: Bought this as a Christmas gift for my boyfriend. He loves making his daily "tiny coffee" from this machine! It is easy to set up and use. So far we have not had any issues with the machine! Only advice is to ground the beans to an espresso granularity as it does slightly affect the taste and texture of the espresso output. It was the right price point for this type of machine. Would gift again!
reviews.review_header: Great Gift at an Affordable Price!

reviews.review_text: Bought this two years ago, not expecting it to last. It has; but, after learning the idiosyncrasies of the machine to give a predictable pull, we want something more. Others have said the cons; true, but each can be "overcome". Heat for at least 15 minutees in advance and then purge slightly into the cup -- only emptying after the basket has been filled with burr ground coffee and tamped with a accessory purchased tamper. Obey the green light. Consume immediately. This machine lasts and is a great intro model. It now goes to my son as we migrate up.
reviews.review_header: Good Starter -- trial and error taste learning curve

reviews.review_text: Here's what I gather to be the essentials (all purchased on Amazon after piecing together some reviews, Subscribe n'Save where applicable): De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker Espresso Tamper 50 & 60 Mm Sizes Cast Alloy Hand Coffee Taylor Classic Cappuccino Frothing Dial Thermometer DaVinci Gourmet Classic Sugar Free Syrup, Vanilla, 25.4-Ounce Torani 750 ML Syrup Pump Lavazza Crema e Gusto Ground Coffee, Italian Espresso, 8.8-Ounce Brick I ended up buying the machine with a 20% off coupon, so yay for me. To be brief, I like this purchase, a lot. Sure, its a bit of a process to make a latte, but it's a labor of love, and I kind of enjoy doing it. I would say it probably takes me about 15 minutes to make two of them, so if you're dreaming of having your latte good to go in Starbucks time, it ain't happenin. But it does make a great substitute latte, and I'll admit I can't even do drip coffee anymore. I'm a snob now, that's what this machine will do to you. Here's my morning process: 0) Turn on the machine, wait I dunno, a minute? While heating, go to #'s 1/2/3. 1) Empty the grounds from the day before 2) Put two scoops of the Lavazza grounds in the double-shot filter (I never used the single) and tamper down, secure the filter to the machine 3) Put two pumps (1Tbsp) of syrup into a coffee mug (Thermos Sipp 16-Ounce Vacuum-Insulated Travel Tumbler, Stainless Steel or Contigo 16-Ounce Double Wall Stainless Steel Vacuum Insulated Tumbler) 4) Brew the espresso (I usually fill a 3 oz. espresso cup to the brim) 5) Switch to steam mode, wait maybe 30 sec. Steam 4oz milk (to 150F-160F) 6) Pour espresso and steamed milk into coffee mug and repeat 1-6 for myself So again, labor of love, but for the price you really can't beat it. I wasn't willing to drop several hundred dollars on a commercial machine just to get my milk hotter, faster. You can if you'd like. Good to know: -The Lavazza grounds are the way to go. You avoid the process of having to further grind your favorite blend down to make the most of the espresso brew, plus they're super cheap via subscription. I'm all about avoiding pain when possible. -The longest part of the process, by a mile, is waiting for the milk to steam to your desired temperature. This pain can't be avoided, sorry. It's relative pain, 2-3 minutes maybe. -The next longest part of the process is simply emptying the spent grounds and putting in/tampering the new stuff. You could avoid some of this by purchasing the pods I suppose. Seemed pretty extreme to me, and not really cost efficient. -DON'T REMOVE/DETACH THE FILTER/HANDLE (TO EMPTY IT) IN STEAM MODE. Seriously, I learned this the hard way. There must be a ton of pressure built up or whatever, but if you do remove the filter (i.e. to empty the coffee grounds) in steam mode, coffee grounds will splatter all over your counter in a thunderous boom. Don't do it, you've been warned.
reviews.review_header: Great for the price ... for a latte guy.

reviews.review_text: Absolutely wonderful espresso machine. It is the perfect little machine for home use. Pros: Pretty small, not taking up too much counterspace. Not ugly Very easy operation Has steam wand Has single and double serving tray for espresso Overall, easy to clean Cons: The steam wand has a plastic piece that needs to be taken off after steaming milk in order to clean it properly. The steam wand is so short, you can really only fit a small cup to steam milk in. I don't know why they bother with the built in tamper, it just makes a mess everywhere, buy a separate tamper. One thing to keep in mind is the unit needs to be warmed up at least 20 minutes prior to espresso making. I sometimes go longer just to make sure. This ensures a consistent extraction and makes it much more tastey. Make sure you are consistent in your preparation of your espresso, any change in your preparation and you will notice a difference in the taste. Also, for me, the turkish grind of coffee produces the best flavor. Anything coarser and there is insufficient crema. Do your research on how to extract the perfect shot and you will be fine. This is a great product and really elevates your daily caffeine intake experience.
reviews.review_header: Great little espresso maker, I'll never drink coffee again.

reviews.review_text: LOVE the de'longhi. What most reviews don't tell you is this little baby is a sexy beast. Time after time she makes a consistent espresso but shes just got curves and a swagger most espresso makers will make you pay thousands for. Since most people check reviews (meself included yar) for the "grievances" I will say this. NONE of them are worth not buying this puppy. REMEMBER YOU ARE BUYING A 80 DOLLAR *#*#*#**# MACHINE! some people over analyze this like they are paying millions of dollars and it drives me nuts. Best 80 ive spent maybe ever. BUY THE DELONGHI. Id also rec the tamper and lavazza coffee that are in the "suggested items" they make a mean cup. The built in tamp: works fine i have used it before the actually tamper came. Sure if you have 8 extra bucks, (some reviewers may not, as it seems the way they review it) The steam valve: works great everytime. Seriously. Not sure why people were griping about it. Small space underneath: so what. Do you want your entire counter to be taken up? I remove the plate and just place my cup there. Its fine. again, 80$ machine dont expect a ferrari at the cost of a Kia. Crema and taste: seriously, machines that produce this CONSISTENTLY time after time just dont exist at the 80$ mark i am absolutely impressed. Just bought this machine have been using for one month. WIll see if it lasts time after time but honestly, i already got my moneys worth with this machine in the first month. People you cant expecti it to last forever dont be naive.
reviews.review_header: Perfect Perfect Espresso everytime....just dont expect a ferrari at 80$ !

reviews.review_text: This is the best and least expensive pump type expresso maker I have found. Produces consistently good expresso -- two cups at a time -- with lots of foam. Good size water container. I found that if one heats it up with the switch on steam and then quickly switch to expresso, one does not have to wait to heat it up or run an initial water run. Steam function is excellent. I have had it for six months and there have been no signs of mechanical problems. But we will have to see -- at this low price I would be pleasantly surprized if the pump lasted more than a few years. I buy distilled water to minimize possible corrosion - it is worth it at .89 a gallon. For price and quality, you cannot go wrong with this machine. I used to own a Krups pressure-type (no pump) expresso maker which really made sucky expresso and cost $30 more. Update January 15 2011. I have had this now for about six months and there have been no problems at all. I would suggest using distilled water (cost about one cent per cup) and you should not have to use chemical cleaners very often. Update August 20,2012. So far, it still works as well as before. Very occasionally, the espresso function seems to get some sort of "vapor lock" which slows down the feed. No problem, just let all the pressure out with the steam function, and start over.
reviews.review_header: Best for Price - Excellent foam and taste

reviews.review_text: This low cost machine works very well for a while. It makes good espresso. I have owned two with similar results each time. I was not careful with the first. I left it on for hours between uses, and did not clean it. It started running weak after 8 months or so, at 2-4 shots per day, and gave out soon after. That was about 800 shots, so the machine cost me about 10 cents per shot. The second one I turned off right after each shot, and cleaned regularly using Durgol 0291 Swiss Espresso Special Decalcifier . It still started running weak after 8 months or so, at 2-4 shots per day. Cleaning it each time made it run better for a little while so it has lasted 9 months. It is pretty much giving out right now as I write. So, maybe 900 shots. Not much difference -- plus I have spent nearly as much on cleaner as I did on the machine. I thought of getting another, especially with the rebate, but instead got a DeLonghi BAR32 Retro Pump-Driven 35 ounce Espresso Maker . I cannot say how long it will last, since I just got it, but other reviewers said they got 2-3 shots for two years. It works well with the same grinds of coffee as my EC155s did, or maybe even a step finer (using a Rancilio Rocky Doserless Burr Grinder ). But it costs rather more than the EC155. And it takes a bit more space since it is a couple of inches wider and a couple of inches deeper.
reviews.review_header: I have owned two, just got a DeLonghi BAR32 Retro

reviews.review_text: I bought the De'Longhi EC155 from Amazon for several reasons. First, I was curious about my ability to make "barista" quality espresso at home. Second, my 23 year old son, who is currently studying art at the University in Florence, Italy, has indicated that he would like to be able to make it when he returns home in 2 months. Third, I really like the convenience of getting a two gulp eye opener in the morning (a double shot of Italian blend has that effect!), and forth, after researching the espresso maker alternatives, The De'Longhi EC155 at a final cost of $59.95 (including tax, shipping, and $20.00 mail in rebate) offered the best value considering the several espresso maker reviews I read. I was not disappointed, even though I'm a novice when it comes to brewing espresso. It is extremely easy to use, and when dispensed into an espresso sized cup is quick and delicious. Clean up is a snap, and cost is less than 25 cents a cup. I would recommend using a fine or powder grind, and the built in plastic tamper works great if used properly (the brew cup, it comes with both a single and a double shot size, must be filled all the way). In short, it works great, we're happy, what's not to love?

I love this little espresso machine. I have had it for about 4 years and have used it on an almost daily basis. It has never given me problems. With 15 bars, it's a powerful little machine for its size. I have limited counter space, and this thing takes up hardly any room at all. It's completely worth the price, and an awesome machine! Having said this, here are a couple of pointers I've figured out along the way: -Not just any steaming/frothing pitcher will work. I have never seen one small enough at a store. Many are too tall to fit under the steam wand and make for a very awkward time steaming your milk. Buy the Stainless Steel 10oz. Steaming and Frothing Pitcher here on Amazon. -DON'T clean it out with vinegar. I can't remember if the directions stated to clean it by running it with vinegar in the water for a few shots, or if I read this online somewhere, but in any case don't do it. I did it twice, and both times my coffee tasted and smelled like vinegar for weeks afterwards. I mean, I like vinegar, the smell and taste, but not in my coffee. Not cool. I suggest just running plain ol' water through it w/o coffee to clean it. If the water you're using isn't too hard, the inside workings of the machine shouldn't get too 'dirty' or clogged anyway.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: You may think I'm crazy, but this is actually our third repurchase of this machine! We loved it the first time and it lasted 1.5 years for only $99 It made great espresso! We were distraught when it broke (the pump failed). We wanted something pricier but couldn't pass up the cost on this little deal of a machine, so we bought it again, at $99! The second time around we were very happy and the machine lasted another 1.5 years until it broke, this time it was the heating element. Now these machines have been reduced even further because there is a newer version on the market, and although we were still thinking we will eventually buy something more elaborate and expensive, we bit again, this time at $79, figuring we will have another 1.5 years. For two weeks now I have exhaustively ran water through the machine, wiping, cleaning, pulling shots, and frothing and frothing. I still cannot get rid of the nasty machine oil flavor. I can't use the frother at all yet, because it keeps leaving the disgusting taste in my milk. We have actually been drinking the espresso with microwaved milk. Hubby seems to think it's getting a little better, but my taste buds aren't buying it yet. Ok, I suppose it is improving, but please be aware that you need to follow the manufacturer's instructions and THEN SOME before you will see results...it could be weeks! The plus side is the crema is beautiful. ;) Amazon only allows returns if the package is unopened and unused, so we are out $79 this time if taste doesn't improve. It's hard to write a bad review on something that was not a problem in the past, but I think in this case (and probably because messing with my caffeine makes me angry) you needed to know. My advice is to buy it somewhere you can return it, just in case this problem doesn't go away. and, purge on! 9/2013 Update. This machine is still working great and we love the coffee. So now, 5 years later, we still love our morning coffee. Incidentally, this machine that I complained about purging the machine oil taste has lasted longer than the first two and is still running great. We use is at least twice every day. Two thumbs up!
reviews.review_header: Machine oil flavor takes time to purge!

reviews.review_text: I carefully read all the reviews as I was looking to be able to make the perfect latte at home. I hit the jack pot. I had a Nespresso machine with a frother, but the mail-order-only pods were becoming very expensive. This model is well priced, easy to use and my lattes are absolutely delicious; better than the much more expensive DeLonghi version. As I am lactose intolerant I use almond milk and it froths the milk fabulously. I could not be happier. I am still struggling to find a latte mug that will slip in place under the filter holder.

A good cup of home brewed coffee has been my personal quest for decades. I have failed miserably. Having gone to school at Berkeley, my standard became Peet's coffee, brewed at one of their stores there (I'll add that the ones in Sacramento aren't as good. Must be the water...). I've got French Presses, gold filters, paper filters, two steam espresso gizmos. Etc. All left me whimpering in defeat. A recent several week trip through Italy & France got me addicted to just the pure espresso drink -- no milk, no frou-frou. No nothin'. Tiny little cup of espresso after great meal. Got home and started looking at espresso machines knowing, with my record, I was doomed to failure. But, shazzam! this DeLonghi actually works. I got a set of 'chat noir' demitasse cups and am, once more sipping something darned close to what I had in Italy. I'm currently using Peet's (who proudly kept their apostrophe, vs. that other coffee place) Major Dickenson, but will try the pods at some point. I run a few shots of hot water through it before brewing. Haven't used the steamer or anything else nor am I bothered by the low clearance for cups. Got to use the demitasse cup so the little finger is properly extended when sipping... . Anyway, worked great the first time. Used for 3 solid weeks now. Highly recommended. Update: February 2012. I don't know what the market is now for low-priced espresso makers -- maybe there's others now at a low price -- but this puppy is still going! I still think it's great.

We love it! You do need to get little espresso cups or take out the drip tray and you can fit a small coffee cup under it. We grind our espresso and have it in a little container ready to go. It heats up in about 1 minute (not 15 like it says). The steam wand is a little hard to use unless you have a really shallow cup. It does a good job steaming though. I worked at Starbucks for more than 2 years, and this is a great, affordable way to make your own gourmet espresso drinks at home!

Works well as a entry level espresso machine. It has a nice sized reservoir and simple design. It is pretty easy to clean as well. There is even a small form factor to this machine, so it does not encroach on your counter real estate. One little issue I feel should be addressed is that when when the machine is making steam or even espresso, it cannot hold to the proper temperature for the required time to complete the job. I find myself waiting for the machine to heat up again before proceeding, which can be slightly annoying, however the end product is still great. If you are learning how to make espresso or just want to indulge on occasion, then this is a really great machine to learn on. It is not by far the best option, but seeing as espresso machines typically run into the hundreds to thousands of dollars, this is a safe bet and is well worth it. This is definitely where you will find the best bang for your buck.

Long time espresso drinker, brand new to preparing a cup for myself. I wanted a simple, inexpensive machine to help me "learn the trade" and this unit didn't disappoint. It works exactly as advertised and I had the preparation and brewing process down to a science by my third cup of espresso. This unit is NOT for the experienced brew-master. It's a great unit to start you off if you're interested in learning how to brew your espresso from the ground up. For the price, I'm very, very pleased and I look forward to not only drinking my cup (or 2) of espresso every morning, but also going through the process of preparing and brewing. When you're ready to brew and you turn the knob to pressurize the chamber and force the water through the coffee puck, the unit is a bit noisy and it vibrates a little more than you would like, but they are small deficiencies given the very low price and the high quality cup of espresso you are able to produce.
reviews.review_header: Great espresso maker for the price

reviews.review_text: Bought this for my wife for Christmas. didn't know it, but I have had to make her the chocolate Mocha thing she liked so much at Starbucks. Evidentially she likes it better at home then bought from Starbucks now. We just buy the Starbucks espresso blend and have them grind it for the Espresso machine. Get a free cup of coffee with each $8 bag. The bag lasts forever. Saving money out the wazzu on this machine. I am an efficiency machine, so start to finish it takes about 10 minutes to get everything out make it and clean it up. Clean up is not horrible, but I would recommend that it be done immediately, not 5 or 10 minutes later. the grinds will get stuck in the strainer cup and the frothed milk with evaporate from the steamer arm. Then you got to scrub it rather than wipe it. We had one problem once, and it wasn't the machine, but the grinds. We bought some other brand espresso beans and ground them in the Kroger store grinder on the espresso setting. It was so fine the machine couldn't get water through the grinds. It was giving a drop every 5 seconds. I had to mix the grinds with another bag and that helped a bit. Just make sure you don't get grinds to fine. You should have a shot of espresso in about 20 sec. If too fast or slow you did something wrong.

We'll start by saying that we really do like this product and are enjoying using it. We make mochas and they come out great. But there are a number of design elements that are a little problematic and instructions are not clear. So here we go with the areas that need improvement: 1. The picture shown makes the machine look taller and thinner than it actually is. It is quite low and there is not a lot of room to work with either the espresso making part or the frother. 2. We bought the suggested frothing pitcher only to learn that the pitcher is recommended by Amazon, not by DeLonghi. That little pitcher is too small. We contacted DeLonghi and they said, "Oh, you don't use a frothing pitcher with that unit, you just use your cup." Okay,good to know, would have been nice to know up front! 3. Whatever you use for frothing - pitcher or cup - you have to hold it - you can't put it down because the frother doesn't reach down far enough. 4. Be careful what size espresso shot glasses you buy! A 3 inch glass will be too tall and won't fit. DeLonghi doesn't give you any instructions or dimensions for this - you have to figure it out on your own. You want the 1.5 oz glasses that are 2.38 inches tall and 1.88 inches wide. 5. Instructions are poor, especially with regard to things like the appropriate accessories. As we said, despite all this, we have figured out how to make good mochas. We make the espresso first, mix in Ghiardelli chocolate (we recommend the squeeze bottles - you can buy them on Amazon) then froth 4 oz. milk in the mug and then add the espresso to that. Yum. Oh yeah - and a dollop of whipped cream.
reviews.review_header: We Love It, But Here's Some Things You Should Know!

reviews.review_text: I'm pretty happy with this product. It works well, but there's an area that I fee could be modified to make it better. The steaming wand will only reach the top of a 10oz pitcher, good enough for frothing creme, but not for properly heating the milk. In this case, the wand should reach down, close to the bottom of the pitcher. I find it easier to just heat the mild in the microwave, while frothing the creme with the De'Longhi.

This machine must be judged for what it is and for whom it's designed: it is an inexpensive, entry-level espresso/cappuccino maker made for beginners. If you want to control water temperature and pressure, and if you care about how long ago your beans were roasted and how the husk was removed, this is not your new machine. If you are like me--someone who enjoys the taste of cappuccino and likes making it for yourself and your spouse--then this machine is a darling. In my estimation, with this machine, and as a beginner, I make better cappuccino than any that I've had at an American coffee chain (that is not a grand claim if you include Starbucks, which in my estimation makes truly awful coffee), and on par with what I can get at my favorite mid-range restaurant. My wife and daughter agree, at least to my face. To see how to use it and some good (if somewhat goofy) explanations, see the "Crew Review: DeLonghi EC155" YouTube video. I have now owned the machine for four months or so, and this is what I have learned: 1. Keep the machine clean. 2. Before steaming your milk, run some steam through the steam arm to drive out the water that has condensed. If you do not, you will dilute your milk with water. 3. Contrary to other reviewers, I have found that the built-in tamper works just fine, since with this kind of machine you do not need to tamp with much pressure (see the video). 4. Twice I have ground my coffee too finely and the machine has "over-extracted" (I believe that is the correct term): the water spends too much time in contact with the grounds and the espresso drips out slowly, it is black with very little crema, and it tastes extremely strong and bitter. Both times I thought something was wrong with the machine, but it worked well when I changed how I ground. With my new burr grinder I find that I have to grind one or two notches coarser than the finest grind. 5. I make my espresso with Eight O'Clock Bean, whole bean, Colombian roast coffee, and I find it to be delicious. I have tried more expensive beans and others that are especially roasted for making espresso and cannot really tell the difference. If I were not adding the frothed milk, I probably could. 6. If you wish to use a tall mug or cup, you will need to remove the drip tray, which is easily done. 7. The steam arm is a bit low as well, but it works just fine if you have a low pitcher. Amazon sells one. 8. It may very well be that after some time will will begin desiring a more expensive and versatile machine as my taste begins to become more discerning. That will take some research, because DeLonghi makes more expensive machines than this one, but I have watched some YouTube videos about them, and as far as I can tell, they cost more because they are larger. Otherwise they operate nearly identically to the EC 155: they can brew one single or double shot at a time, and they brew in the same way, so I anticipate that the coffee would taste no differently. 9. I have nothing negative to say (that could change the longer I own the machine); I believe that many who have reviewed the machine negatively have not researched how to make espresso with this kind of machine and they have not followed directions (it is also possible that DeLonghi ships some lemons). Many who give the machine some cons are probably rating it in a classification in which it does not belong. I give the machine the highest recommendation, considering what you get for the money. Addendum 4/28/2013, five months after purchase. I still rate this machine with five stars. I add the following tips: 1. Allow the machine to heat for the full 15 minutes stated in the instructions. The green light will come on after just a minute or so, but the machine will produce much better steam when it is fully heated. I presume this also has an effect on the flavor of the coffee. 2. From some Youtube videos I have learned that high-end cappuccino makers produce what people call "dry" steam. This one does not. To get the steam as dry as possible, before frothing the milk I run the steam for awhile into a plastic cup, which I sometimes cover with a cloth, until the steam arm stops sputtering. 3. Different coffees behave differently in the machine. I noted earlier that I do not grind on the finest setting. That was because I was trying out a new coffee. I don't know what it is about that particular coffee, but I could not grind it as fine as I can others. 4. Skim milk froths just fine, but whole milk tastes much better. I have also learned that frothed milk should have the consistency of wet paint. To achieve this, I immerse the steam head about 1/4 inch into the milk and try to hold the milk pitcher at the same level as the volume of the milk increases, without allowing the plastic head to become completely immersed in the milk. It's possible to treble the volume of the milk, but you'll get better consistency if you double it or a little more. What you don't want is foam: large bubbles that you can make out with the naked eye. If you get them, swirl the milk around some and tap the pitcher on the counter top until they subside. You want milk with the same, thick consistency throughout 5. Froth the milk before you make the espresso. If it needs swirling, I swirl the milk while the espresso is brewing. If you allow the milk to sit, it will begin to separate with milk-consistency milk on the bottom and foam on the top. 6. I "pull" a double shot for about 20 seconds (I have yet to use the single shot filter that comes with the machine). A little more and the espresso is too weak to my taste, a little less and it's too strong. 7. The time you need for a good shot will also depend on the type of coffee you're using, how finely you grind it, and how firmly you tamp it. So you'll spend some time figuring out which variables you'll play with to get the coffee you like. 8. I'm about to purchase a coffee tamper that fits the filter. I believe it requires a 53 millimeter tamper. The tamper on the machine continues to work just fine, and I believe because of how the machine brews it does not require 30 pounds of pressure as some machines do.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I just bought this particular espresso machine, its my first De'Longhi product. Have only made a few lattes so far so will not speak to long term points. The machine was very easy to set up, had it up and heating water in less than two minutes. The twist knob on top has a solid feel and turns easily so hopefully will hold up well over time. The turn dial on front has a nice solid feel to it as you turn it so again I'm hopeful there will be long term appeal. The steam wand is different on this machine than my old espresso maker, this one has a black 'nozzle' that screws on the end which turns out is pretty handy, makes it easier to manage tip depths and the foam I've gotten so far had a nice fluffy consistency. One downside I did find, the machine is rather light and so when you connect the filter basket holder and turn it to tighten the machine turns with it, kind of annoying but I am thinking about getting a small rubber matt or something like that and put it under it to prevent that. Another feature this machine has that I didnt know about until after I set it up is there is a tamper actually built onto the machine which is really awesome because I lost mine! My last latte machine was over 500 dollars and this one I paid 75 dollars for; overall with the performance this is delivering I just dont see any reason to spend as much as I did in the past on a machine.

Surprisingly---this is a terrific item! I thought it would be a little bit cheesy and not make the very best espresso, given the price and size of the coffee maker. But I am delighted to be wrong. It makes professional grade espresso drinks!!! The only thing is that it rumbles a lot when it makes shots--especially at first, before it gets going. Other than that--we could not be more delighted with this purchase. $100! Normal coffee makers cost that amount! This is fantastic. I worked in coffee shops pulling coffee for ten years. What a great home device. Couldn't be happier.
reviews.review_header: Surprisingly---this is a terrific item! I thought it would be a little ...

reviews.review_text: This one is for my office. Needs little space, was easy to set up and get going. After priming the machine for a few hours, it produced an astoundingly adequate espresso with good crema, aroma and taste. Of course, one ought to use the best espresso coffee grounds (fine) available. Machine is easy to clean. I am not using a tamper, just a spoon to tug the coffee in and down. So far no soggy aftermath in the filter - which some reviewers reported and I was afraid of - so messy. Had a bigger DeLonghi expresso machine a while ago. It did not last long. Clogged up and never recovered, despite strong efforts to descale and de-clog revive. Hope this one will not disappoint. For now, I am looking forward to many aromatic espresso cups with this little machine.

I have had this machine for a number of months now and can say that it is still an excellent machine. Excellent crema with a smooth taste and not too bitter like the previous versions I've used. Yes, the grounds basket is too low so improvisation is needed but, once you have that figured out, no problem. The grounds basket also tends to be a little soupy after the espresso it made, but I can't say that I mind at all. I would definitely recommend this machine to people and will buy again. The one major con I have is the directions are awful. They are inconsistent with what they tell you to do when it comes to the time period required for the machine to heat up. One paragraph said to wait 15 minutes for the machine to warm up while another said to wait 30 minutes. Then it contradicted itself by stating to wait for the green light to appear before making the espresso. Well, the green light tends to appear after 1 minute or less. This discrepancy is important due to the increased possibility of burning out the heater more quickly. So, we began making the espresso after the light turned green and didn't wait the 15 or 30 minutes it stated. It was still hot (most of the time) though I can see the need to wait a few minutes (max) after the light turns green. After months of use, it does take a little longer for the machine to heat up (another minute or so) but I would contribute this more to user error than machine error. Given we run the thing a couple times each day, ever day, I'd say it's done an excellent job. 5/5 for me. Will definitely buy again.

for some reason this makes better tasting coffee than the krups machine ( XP 3200 ) i'm replacing. i don't know why that should be, but there's more and deeper coffee flavor. the Krups machine has an auto-after-one-year-breakable mode which allows it to not brew anything at all. I got this De'Longhi mostly because it's not a Krups. this one, you should know, takes a half hour to reach full ready to brew, though there's a short cut allowed after 15 minutes. i'm adjusting my habits to allow the extra time, but i could also put a timer on the circuit to start up before i wake up. note too, that the drop between the spigot and the tray is very shallow -- an espresso cup shallow, and you'll need something short and wide to catch a fuller cup in one, as i do. i got a small ceramic dish from Target, one thick enough to be insulate my fingers from heat. i'd recommend this to anyone needing an under- $800 espresso machine, for decent espresso. over $800 dollars, i'm just guessing they're better from what i see at stumptown coffee places.
reviews.review_header: for some reason this makes better tasting coffee than the krups machine i'm replacing.

reviews.review_text: This was the first real espresso machine I bought for myself, when I was spending $5 a day and wasting a 1/2 hour out of my day getting my coffee fix I figured it was a better idea to do it at home. I am an admitted espresso snob so I researched the heck out of machines. After my research I settled on the De'Longhi EC155 and was fairly happy with it from the start. It made a pretty decent espresso shot when using a good dark roast, the correct fine grind and made sure it was correctly packed down. and for the price I thought it was well worth it, I saved quiet a bit of money, controlling the ingredients and calories in my lattes and having fun making drinks for myself and my friends. But after about 10 months the steam wand quit working, then about a month after that the pump for making espresso stopped working altogether. I did use it almost everyday, sometimes 2 times a day but I always cleaned it and used distilled water so I felt like it should have lasted longer than it did. My coffee maker cost less and my husband never cleans it and it lasted 3 years so I was little disappointed by that. But in the long run it paid for itself 10 times over (Uh, $5 a day or more for a lattes x 10 months is around $1500!!) and for me was worth it since I don't have $700 to drop on an espresso machine. Here are some things I wanted to note: I did have a hard time at first getting the steam knob to work because the factory had over tightened it so hard that the knob was stuck and it was twisted in the wrong direction (not the normal righty tighty) so after a lot of fussing my husband FINALLY got it unstuck. But the knob was always a bit lose after that. The Espresso from my machine always tastes burnt if you brew it after steaming your milk, my assumption is the machine is just getting too hot to create the steam that its not cooling down enough before I would pull the espresso shot, and burns the coffee, but according to the product description its not supposed to. (it did for me anyways) The machine would rattle and shake when making a shot if the water was even remotely below 30% water (probably because its a mostly plastic not very heavy duty machine) The size is nice and small, I was worried because my husband drinks only coffee so we have a coffee maker and a espresso machine on the counter but it was the perfect counter top size. about 1/t the size of our coffee maker. Overall for the money I think its a pretty good deal for someone who wants to make lattes at home and is on a budget. I'm even looking into buying a replacement De'Longhi I'm just hoping it lasts longer.
reviews.review_header: Liked it but it didn't last long...

reviews.review_text: After FOUR YEARS - UPDATED - this machine is a little workhorse. It has never failed me and continues to make beautiful espressos every morning. I descale it about once or twice a year. Lovely, dependable little machine. I buy whole bean, light roast, and grind myself in a burr grinder. The whole process smells heavenly and starts the day with joy. I would buy again in a heartbeat! AFTER TWO YEARS --UPDATED - this little machine is my morning buddy, 2-3 espressos every day, going strong. It works like a charm. Wipe it clean every day, take the little filters apart about once a week and wash, and descale maybe twice a year. The espresso is delicious. I travel regularly to Italy and am picky about my coffee. This will froth milk beautifully but remember that this machine has a single boiler and will need time to build pressure back up between the two functions. Translated, leave five minutes between milk drinks. I could not be more satisfied with this purchase. I love this little machine and I enjoy taking care of it. It has been used daily for almost two years, very reliable. Like a car it will thrive with proper maintenance. ------------------- PREVIOUS UPDATE ---I've had this little machine for almost three months now and continue to be pleased with it. I wanted to share a maintenance tip - descaling is necessary! As I had read in numerous places, the EC155 requires descaling after about 200 coffees in order to remove mineral deposits on the boiler. Sure enough, as mentioned elsewhere, the EC155 began running slowly after about two months of use, barely dripping coffee into the cup, and I have been very regular about cleaning the filters and the group head screen. So as mentioned in the manual, I bought a commercial descaling powder, poured it into the full water container in the machine, ran it through, followed by a full clean container (this took about an hour, all told) - and voila! It runs as it did when it was brand new! Just like changing the oil in the car - take care of your machines and they will pay you back. This machine makes lovely espresso. Some tips: Let the machine warm up 20 minutes prior to use and then run it only when the green light is on, for pressurized water that is hot. When the espresso is done, leave the filter in place for about a minute to let the pressure dissipate. This will avoid removing it too soon and the residual pressure spewing the coffee out. When frothing milk, make your shot first, wait a minute, remove the portafiler, flush and wipe the grouphead, and then switch the dial over to steam. Wait a couple of minutes so the pressure between the two sides settles down. Then froth your milk. Yes, the espresso has cooled down, but your milk is nice and hot and everything will be lovely. This is probably my only little complaint with this machine - the boiler serves both the coffee side and the milk side, and you have to be patient with the pressure requirements between the two. If you are enjoying several espressos every day, plan on descaling the machine once a month. It makes the machine run like new. Once a week, take apart your filters and unscrew the grouphead. Clean the screens. Makes a difference in taste if you get all the old coffee out. YOu wouldn't want to eat old pieces of pie in with new, would you? Of course not. For maximum happiness, buy a better tamper. The one on the machine works, but to me the diameter is a bit too small and also it is slightly angled. This makes it hard to get your coffee flat, and you get a ridge all the way around. A good tamper makes you feel all warm inside and the coffee pours out more evenly. Remember: descale once a month! You will be glad! Enjoy. This machine is great value for the money if you clean it properly. Wonderful espresso. ORIGINAL REVIEW -- I have never made anything but drip coffee all my life, but now I am totally hooked on this little machine. I've had it for about two weeks and the result is delicious! I learned from YouTube videos and it was pretty easy to start out. I use Illy Dark Roast grounds and I enjoy the whole process of measuring, tamping (and I like the built-in tamper because it is convenient and consistent), pulling the shot, and using the grounds for compost. I even like cleaning everything and leaving it all ready for the next time. The machine is quiet and makes the house smell heavenly.
