The crema is a lovely light brown and soft so I think that is correct! My husband is thrilled with this addition to our life. I just started trying cappuccino and I haven't got the frothing right yet, but that is my problem and not the machine's. I found true little espresso cups and they fit nicely, also little plastic shot glasses work fine. I love this machine.
reviews.review_header: Still my best friend after two years

reviews.review_text: My husband purchased this as an early Christmas present for me. I got this in the middle of November of 2012. I use this every day and make about 1 to 2 espresso drinks per day. I have not had any problems with this unit. I am finally able to make quality espresso drinks at home! I used to go to Starbucks daily. Since receiving this machine, I have only been their three time. And that was just to use up the money on my gold card. I have had other espresso machines in the past and none of them seamed to do a very good job, This little machine not only produces an excellent espresso shot but also does a great job at frothing milk! The wand is a little low but I have this at the end of the counter so I don't have any problems. I have not had any problems with leaking either! Very good quality! Would definitely suggest this to anyone that wanted a good at home machine!

We have had this model for at least 6 years. Haven't cleaned it as often as I should and this is a work horse. Use it at least twice a day. No issues and the coffee and steamer are just as good as what you get at a coffee shop but the savings has been huge. Crema (foam) is perfect. The only thing I wish is that it would be taller to make it easier to get a taller coffee cup or under either of the steamer or espresso spigots. I just use a shallow measuring cup for the espresso and to steam the milk.
reviews.review_header: No issues and the coffee and steamer are just as good as what you get at a coffee shop but ...

reviews.review_text: Sold by Casa.com (Quidsi Retail) via Amazon $99-: Received item in 2 days from Amazon seller w/ free ship!! I made sure to read and follow all instructions first: After a few try's I'm pulling some nice shots with crema head and dry pucks! The steamer / frothier has plenty of pressure. This is a great little machine so far. My advice to folks having trouble with it, read the instructions and quit your whining and nit-picking!! I plan on keeping this one clean and cared for. I'll leave up-dates if any problems over the next 6 months... And did I mention to, follow the instructions, and get some instruction from online sources, then you won't experience most of the problems that the three star and below reviewers are having.
reviews.review_header: Read & followed all instructions & it works great!!!

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: During the holiday break, we switch from coffee to espresso. Been using this every day just about, I just leave it on and make a cup every few hours. It is designed for espresso cups, so when I want to fill a full coffee cup, I just use a small bowl under the double dispenser. Pretty easy to use, no complaints, makes a good espresso and a nice full cup using a single fill of the double cup size dispenser. Had it about a month, been on daily duty for the last week or so. Lots of heavy duty metal where it needs to be, seems like a well built budget priced appliance.

I've been using this machine for several months now at least once daily. I am enjoying the great tasting espresso that it makes. Easy to froth the milk if you want to make cappuccino. The four star rating is because the cheap design of the frother. You supposed to unscrew and clean the plastic frothing head every time after it is used. It is too easy to cross thread it when putting it back, since the the soft plastic piece will not guide well. They should had put a metal, threaded insert in the plastic since it is to be removed frequently. Because of this I mostly avoid making cappuccino. Another minor frustration is the tamper to compact the coffee grind, where it is placed. Very awkward to to use it. Giving it as a separate attachment would had been much more useful.

Close to a month ..still enjoying my daily coffee(s)...update on the review below : set the knob to steam at the start of any coffee making..it seems to prime the machine faster...this is especially true for cappuccino...steam your milk and then get your shot out..the light should be green if you have just gotten steam out...and if necessary steam / froth milk again after pulling the shot... at *bucks a tall cappuccino is about $3.80...at that price I have already recovered my total investment..so all good ! Lived in Firenze for nearly 2 years...had good coffee there and all over the rest of Italy...but never a cappuccino as hot as I wanted...even after learning the word 'bolente' from a local....this machine changed that...I now have my cappuccino exactly as hot as I like it. The only down side so far is that I am addicted....at least 2 cups per day since the machine was delivered. Ordered the tamper (50 & 60 mm size), EP 12 ss frothing pitcher and Lavazza crema e gusto ground coffee along with the EC155 purchase and have not regretted any purchase. Some of the users suggested removing the black end to the steamer and that was the first thing I did. Yes, it makes sense to get cups that will fit below the spouts...bought those as well...Konitz cappuccino cups and Norpro demitasse cups..these too were worth it. No operating issues so far....great 'crema'..so far. Will be interesting to see what is the effort needed to clean it when the need arises.... other than that, if this even lasts 6 months it will have paid for itself many times over...fingers crossed.

Right out of the box, the De'Longhi EC155 produced perfect crema. I have made of two dozen shots and it only appears to get better. I only wish it was a little more sturdy, more metal in the design would have been nice. For those complaining about it leaking, well, duh, make sure the reservoir is seated properly. It is also quite easy to spill out of the reservoir by just moving it.Practice common sense. If your shots are not coming out right, go on youtube and learn how to make espresso or read the documentation provided. This machine works perfectly so I couldn't imagine someone not being able to make great shots unless they either do not know what they are doing or have a faulty machine, which is possible. Despite some minor engineering and design complaints, this is a fantastic machine. At the price, it is unbeatable.

I bought this from Amazon 3 years ago after reading reviews for many machines sold on this and other sites. From what I could discover, the pump design of this little machine is unusual at this price point. I took a chance and ordered it and it has not disappointed. An espresso comes out with a beautiful, sweet coffee foam, and the milk steamer is nice, too -- perhaps not the frothiest but for my taste it suits just fine. The only problem I had with the maker was as a result of my carelessness: I forgot to turn it off now and then, leaving it on for a day at a time, and the thermostat burned out. Fortunately, this happened within the warranty period and I was able to get it repaired. Now I diligently turn the machine off when removing my coffee and it has worked like a champ ever since. Also, like any other item that heats water, periodic cleaning with vinegar will be needed to keep the nozzles from clogging. Highly recommend this espresso maker if you want a budget machine that delivers.
reviews.review_header: Love this machine, have used it for 3 years now

reviews.review_text: Bought this in 2012. It is working wonderfully. I make 2 double lattes in the morning before work, and it is still working well. The seals are still in place, and the pump is working wonderfully. I haven't descaled it as of yet. It has become the best part of the start of my day. Tip: I use Crystal Geyser water in it. It is the best tasting out of all of the bottled water for espresso. I'd love to use my own well water, but we have too many minerals. If you take care of this machine and clean it well after each use, it will take care of you. I'm even considering buying another for backup if it finally decides to die. I like to hedge my bets.
reviews.review_header: Works better than any machine I've owned.

reviews.review_text: I purchased this espresso maker after a prolonged comparison search on the internet and I am very happy with it. I wasn't interested (or capable) in spending a couple grand for a top of the line machine, my price range was up to around $400. I searched & searched the internet for reviews and found this machine brought up numerous times. The price was less than 1/4 of what I had planned to spend, which was good from a financial point, but a bit concerning from a quality point. Upon arrival, I cleaned everything up as directed in the instructions. Initially, I was using preground espresso beans, and they worked very well with this machine. I had recently been given a low end burr grinder for Christmas and I did find some issues when I started to grind the beans myself. I ground the beans to, what appeared to me anyway, the same size as the preground beans I had initially used. Things did not work well! The espresso came out very watery and with no crema. I ground the beans down to a smaller size (which appeared much smaller than the preground espresso beans I purchased) and they still didn't work. I was about to give up, but I decided to turn the grinder to its finest setting and give it 1 more try. When I put the finest ground beans into the machine, it brewed up a very nice espresso with a thick layer of crema. I prefer lattes over straight espressos or cappuccinos and I was very happy with the first cafe mocha that came out. I've tried a few other lattes and they've all turned out very well. The frothing wand works great. The first frothing I did ended up being more of a cappuccino form than a latte form, but I learned my lesson and I haven't made the mistake again. I've only been using it for about a week, but I am very happy with it so far! UPDATE: I've continued using this machine most every day and things are just getting better. The low end grinder is still working great too. The first lattes I made using this machine tasted fine, but I couldn't get the froth to the level I wanted it. Since the flavor was okay, I wasn't too concerned about the froth, in fact, I had accepted it the way it was. Then one day, I was frothing up my milk and I noticed it was very evenly aired. It had a very nice shine to it. I pounded it on the table a few times to ensure a nice mixture of the air and liquid and started the shot brewing. I made the mistake of letting the frothed milk sit without movement for a few minutes and I noticed the air appeared to have bubbled back up to the top of the milk. The next day, I made sure I kept the frothed milk spinning around while the espresso brewed and when I poured it into the espresso, it looked different than I had seen before in my lattes. It looked like the lattes I see on the internet where I have been attempting to learn proper technique. The air bubbles were nicely mixed into the entire liquid of the milk and it appeared even and thick. After pouring it into the espresso, there was a nice large spot of milk in the middle of the espresso. I took a picture of it immediately and I have posted a short video of the first latte I made & then the most recent latte I made. I really thought it would take a more expensive machine to get a proper froth, but it wasn't the machine, it was my technique that was causing the problem. This machine makes a fairly good espresso and does a great job frothing. I don't particularly like straight espresso, so I don't need a perfect espresso to come out of the machine. I absolutely love the lattes this machine produces. I personally use Torani dark chocolate sauce & even add an occasional additional Torani flavor to my lattes & they taste great! I'm a very satisfied customer of this machine, especially for the price!

We recently received this after quite a bit of anticipation. I recently have become addicted to cappuccino and toured coffee shops all over the Pacific Northwest refining my tastes. I take my cappuccino dry, sans sweetener, so the taste of the espresso is very important to me. My office bought a cheap steam driven espresso maker, which is nice for an occasional cup but it produces very bitter tasting espresso. I think that is because there is not enough pressure, so you are essentially getting very strong drip coffee instead of a true espresso. Anyway, after drinking espresso for the last few months, I can no longer stand the taste of drip coffee and I knew I needed an espresso maker for home in order to reduce the amount of money I would spend at coffee shops throughout the day. I turned to Amazon for some research and decided on this unit. The size is compact. A lot of reviewers have complained about it. I simply use a ceramic sake cup when pulling shots and then pour into my travel mug. I use a 1 cup Pyrex glass measuring cup to steam my milk. Problem solved. The built in tamp works fine. I know some people have purchased a separate tamp but I do not find that to be necessary. Pre-heat time generally does not take 15 minutes. I usually turn it on to heat, grind my coffee beans, load and tamp and when I am done its ready to go! The milk frother works okay. Its not amazing. Sometimes I get a really good froth and sometimes not so much. It doesn't bother me, I just use a hand whisk to froth up my milk if its not frothy enough. I only do this on the weekends when I have more time in the morning. When I am on my way to work, I just use the frother on the machine and its fine. I guess in that case, I get a latte instead of a cappuccino, but the point to be caffeinated, not be picky about milk froth. I am not and have never been a barista, so if there are better techniques to making a cappuccino, I don't know them. But I have spent a lot of money on cappuccinos at coffee shops and this tastes just as good as anything I can get where I live. It isn't quite as good some of the coffee shops in Portland, but since I only travel there occasionally, I'm very pleased with the quality I can achieve at home. If you buy espresso based drinks at a coffee shops once a day, this is worth it. I calculated that we will have to make 24-30 drinks with it to justify the price. I drink about 2 cappucinos a day and my hubs drinks an americano in the morning, so it won't take long for us to recoup the cost. UPDATE: My machine started to drip very slow and the last two shots I pulled tasted burnt. It was producing very strong espresso but with no crema, just black, burnt, high octane espresso. It gave me a stomach ache. I was slightly annoyed. I started by running just plain water through the system, didn't help. I then ran water through the grounds basket. Helped a little. Then I took the entire grounds basket apart, including unscrewing the gasket on the bottom. I washed and rinsed it all. Now its back to new! I just pulled another shot and it was wonderfully creamy, smooth taste and fast. It was a little annoying that it already got clogged so quickly but if you just rinse it all once in a while, it will probably be fine. I also think it might have been because my DH was not grinding the coffee fine enough.

pros: pumps water through the grounds no sweat, much less money than sumutha silly pricing for the fancy ones easy to operate and (mostly) clean and takes up very little room on the counter; frother does the job. Cons: won't do 4 shots at once without a WHOLE lotta fiddling and gaming of the settings; frother works well but is too low to the ground, frother end is a cheap plastic part, woulda paid $5 more for a metal end on it; not enough room for any but the most shallow coffee cups; their filter inserts are a "take this apart and clean it" pain. Took a while to learn how to get it to produce what I like, but that is mostly because I didn't want to just make 1 or 2 shots at once . . I like it, the wife likes it, the dogs aren't afraid of the sounds it makes . . good deal all around.
reviews.review_header: Does what it says it will do for a reasonable amount of money, won't make a BIG cuppa cappuccino

reviews.review_text: This machine performs as described, and produces a nice espresso. I have some observations related to some other reviews. The first is that it is true the steam arm is too short. This is workable, you just have to think about your pitcher size and depth or just the level of milk. Also, several people have complained about the lack of a hard puck after drawing the shot(s). I think this is a misconception about the way the espresso basket assembly is designed to work. This assembly is more complex at the outlet to regulate the flow without complete dependence on the pressure used in tamping. After experimenting with this, it seems that there is a good range of coffee compression that works just fine. I would call this a plus for the average user. It also means that suggestions to buy a separate tamper are unnecessary. The built in tamper works just fine for this machine. One other thing to note, is that for the first several uses, a bit more water comes through before you activate the pump than you might expect. This stopped after something like 10 uses on my machine. Summary: Just use it according to the included directions. You will have great product with ease of use and cleaning. This is a great value! This is one gadget that hardly takes up any space, so it is easy to keep out or store as you wish. Best kitchen gadget I have ever purchased.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I've had this machine for 4 months. I've learned a fair amount about making espresso during this time in part, due to trouble shooting this machine. It's akin to techies or car mechanics who like to tinker versus someone who wants something because it just works. I've read the comments about design flaws i.e. short wand, no room for cup to fit under boiler and porta filter, vibrating pump... all this is true but there are work arounds. I bought a frother and the pump vibration seemed worse at first and it varies...just rest a hand on it wall you pull the shot. The problem with this machine is that sometimes especially after it's thoroughly heated, it just simply is unable to push water through the portafilter even without coffee. I've descaled yes and I've had it working only to fail me again. I've learned a lot from this machine but this machine is just a 100 dollar education. Get a real machine and don't look back. ========UPDATE======== I cannot speak to the De'longhi manual. I'm not sure backflushing is addressed at all. The machine can become clogged easily. I almost tossed the machine but discovered instead to run clear water through an empty porta filter allowing it to pressurize. Placing a basin or or microfiber cloth around the edges of the base to catch water, I found that rotating the portafilter to the left while machine is running allow the machine to spit out an occlusion. Use caution, the water coming out is hot but this seems to have restored my machine to being able to produce a decent espresso.
reviews.review_header: I'm ready for something that "just works"

reviews.review_text: We purchased this based upon several website reviews as a "best buy". The item was shipped quickly and arrived in unopened original packaging housed inside a larger shipping box. We cleaned the "internal circuits" as instructed at the top of page 9, IMPORTANT : "the first time the appliance is used, all accessories and the internal circuits must be washed through by making at least five coffees without using ground coffee." During these 5 cleaning cycles the unit vibrated excessively and produced very little steam. At the beginning of each process the unit would drip/dribble constantly until the "steam" cycle but still it appeared to produce little steam. The whole time the unit was extremely loud and nearly danced off the counter top. We had used a less expensive Mr. Coffee brand unit for several years but the heating element appeared to finally burn out. We made espresso daily and never had issues. It appears the Delonghi unit was bad right out of the box. We will try a different brand or go back to Mr. Coffee.
reviews.review_header: Excessive vibration right out of the box, dribbled like a baby but no steam. Will try another brand.

reviews.review_text: It caught on fire internaly somewhere can see damage from outside but it did smoke. Happen when turned the nob to preheat.
reviews.review_header: Enjoy a cuppa burning plastic this thing is a hazard

reviews.review_text: We've had this machine for 6mos now and it's sadly stopped working. Constantly leaks water, struggles to get enough power to produce a decent shot, struggles to froth milk, just plain struggles. We've tried everything in the trouble shooting section of the manual with little to no avail. We've tried contacting Amazon for an exchange/replacement with little to no avail... because evidently, 6mos is a perfectly reasonable life expectancy for an espresso machine?! ((They recommended calling De'Longhi... maybe it's their problem)) We've contacted De'Longhi and are still waiting for a response... will update this review after we get some sort of resolution but based solely on the performance of the machine that we received - F. I would NOT recommend this product to anyone AND if Amazon is at all concerned with selling products that aren't complete s**t... I'd recommend that they stop selling this model.

It's 2017, but this was from Christmas 2016 and it appears to be defective. The product packaging looks okay, but I cannot determine why water isn't pumping and the machine vibrates so much that it moves the cup around. This is definitely the worst appliance I've bought online. I'm reading how some people have waited 10 minutes for the water to move, and that sounds defective. It's been over 30 minutes since I unplugged it, and the boiler plate underneath is too hot to pack this crap back in the box. I don't even have the Amazon box it came in, so this is pretty inconvenient and I'm not touching this brand again.

From the minute we turned it on, the milk frother leaked. It leaks the entire time the machine is on, to the point we need a towel down beneath it. We contacted the company, and they agreed to send a replacement, but AFTER we cut the power cord and mailed it in, because "that's their policy". Which would leave me with no machine for 1-2 weeks, despite the fact it was defective upon arrival. They don't want the machine back, just the end of the cord. I suggested mailing it in AFTER I receive my new unit, but without success. So now I will just hope for quick shipping times. I very disappointed with their senseless policy, and will never purchase another DeLonghi product again.

At first, I really liked this unit. Compact, simple to use. The tamper leaves a lot to be desired, but the frother was reasonably easy to clean as was the rest of the unit. A little on the loud side, however. Fast forward a couple months, and I will be replacing the unit. It works just fine, but IT IS TOO LOUD. I purchased an EspressoWorks system for my office, and it's wonderfully quiet, even when frothing. The De'Longhi unit has gotten louder with use, and shakes so much during the espresso pulls that you are forced to hold the cup down while the espresso is pouring or it shakes right off the stand. And the steamer.....! It started out being simply loud, and recently has decided to get even louder, to the point where it's almost painful. It's simply not possible to make a latte in the morning without waking EVERYONE up with this unit. I'll be replacing this with the EspressoWorks system instead.

I researched espresso makers for a long time before choosing this one. I never saw anything (probably missed it) about the horrendous smell and taste of plastic. The odor and taste seems to be coming from the water reservoir. I've tried a few of the online hacks to get rid of the taste and odor, but no luck. You can't wash it out, vinegar it out, or baking soda it out. If you like your coffee to taste like an inflatable baby pool that's been baking in a hot garage for a few years, you might love this.
reviews.review_header: I'll take a latte with a shot of plastic

reviews.review_text: I moved from drip coffee to steam machine, then started grinding whole beans for freshness, then moved to a burr grinder for an even, consistent grind. Each step improved my coffee, and I really wanted to move up to a pump machine, but couldn't justify the cost. I started saving money and reading reviews, and this machine had by far the best reviews for the money. Things I learned after I bought it: There are more variables, so it does take a little more experimentation than a steam machine to make a good shot. But I enjoyed the process, and found even a mediocre shot from this machine is better than a good shot from my steam machine. Once I got the result I wanted, I found this machine more consistent. When adjusting your grind, time each test shot, and go finer or courser until your brewing time (from pump start to full shot) is 30 seconds. Buy the "Frequently bought together" tamper. The built-in tamper is permanently attached to the machine. It might be fine for leveling your grounds, but it would be difficult to tamp them with it without tipping the machine over. I ordered this tamper along with my machine, and I'm glad I did. I was concerned about a few negative reviews claiming it didn't fit, or its metal plating flaked off, but I've been using it every day for five months with no problems. For more details, read my review. The review pointing out that the machine needs to be cleaned out periodically is correct. The manual recommends cleaning it every 200 shots or when it becomes slow. There are clear cleaning instructions in the manual. It's not difficult, but I needed a very fine needle to clear out all the tiny holes. I can't comment on the steam wand, because I never use it. I didn't know how hard it would be to find a single espresso cup at a reasonable price. I drink mostly Americano. I just wanted something that would fit under the group (spout) and catch the espresso for transfer to a larger mug. The manual contradicts itself, saying you need to preheat the machine 15 minutes, or thirty minutes, or by brewing a blank shot (no coffee) before use. That's nonsense. Turn the knob to preheat, and the machine is ready as soon as the green light comes on. Even when starting cold, this takes less time than grinding the beans. You can brew a blank shot to preheat your cup, but if you are in a hurry, even this step is optional. The pump makes some noise. Not a whooshing noise like a steam machine, but a mechanical hum about as loud as an electric mixer. It only makes this noise during the actual brewing—which should last about 30 seconds if you have your grind right. It is silent while heating the water. This noise is accompanied by a vibration that may cause your cup to slide off-center. I haven't had the espresso miss the cup, but I keep a close eye on it. The drip tray is removable for easy cleaning, and can go in the dishwasher. If you leave the drippings in the tray too long, they contain enough water to grow mold. Solution: Wash the drip tray frequently. I started sprinkling a little boric acid in the tray (the tray is plastic, no worry about corrosion) and when it all dissolves, (one to two months at my usage rate) I put the tray in the dishwasher. I haven't seen any mold since. Update 11 June 2016: After 2 years, water started to leak over the top of the basket instead of going through the grounds. Shops that do repairs on this machine wanted almost the price I paid on Amazon for a new machine. I tracked the problem to the gasket that seals the basket to the machine. I found a replacement online, but when I tried to remove the old gasket, I found I had to completely disassemble the machine, including several parts that were not designed to go back together. In short, this is a disposable machine, not intended to be repairable.

I had this machine for over 5 years and was pretty happy with it. It died on me one day because honestly I never ever deacaled it or cleaned boiler unit, which I should have done as per instructions. Long story short, I decided to buy another one because I already new this machine, it was the right size for me and I liked that frother was on the different side than all other machines since this was perfect for my kitchen setup. But when the new machine came in it was an utter disappointment. 1. I could visually see that some parts were made of cheaper, flimsier plastic and metal. 2. The old machine was loud but this one was just impossibly loud and rattled like crazy. 3. What killed it for me though was the frother. It just could do its job and make a goof froth because the pressure would be gone in no time. I had to return it and would not recommend it to anyone. Seems that the manufacturing side of it went down the hill since the time I got my first machine and yet the new one was $20 more expensive.
reviews.review_header: Used to be a good machine

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: This is my 6th machine. I've owned both high end and cheap machines. I have a big problem with this one. It allows an unacceptable amount of water into the milk during frothing. I've experimented with a number of wait times and line purging, but even at its best, it's not good enough. I also do not like the spring loaded frothing wand. I like to blow the line out into a towel after frothing, but this thing snaps back into the brewing area. If you drink straight espresso, you'll like this machine. It brews nicely, and I love the water tank design. Unfortunately, I'm all about the steamed milk. It's so cheap, I'll probably keep it as a backup.
reviews.review_header: Great For Espressso / Cappuccino Not So Much

reviews.review_text: I'm on the fence. I used to have a fancy Breville, but couldn't justify the cost now that I have kids. I NEED my espresso drinks though. This machine makes the coffee, but it's not good. I can't quite figure out what's wrong. It doesn't pull fine ground espresso (a courser grind does ok). It does pull a three part shot but something doesn't taste right. The first month I had this the coffee was to die for. Something has shifted and I can't figure it out. I time my shots, so it just makes me feel like it's the machine. I will say the frother makes the milk so thick and frothy with no effort though!! Good for the price. I still drink it, but it doesn't always stop me from driving through!!
reviews.review_header: Decent for the cost, not outstanding.

reviews.review_text: Bought in August liked it untill it started leaking everywhere. Tried everything to fix it but couldn't. I suppose it will be in the next trash pickup? Too bad. I have been trying to contact the US office and the Italian corporate office for the last 3 months . They don't even have the decency to acknowledge my correspondence. In the mean time it has been sitting on my counter for 3 months without me being able to use it! I really think this is a bad reflection on Amazon? No one seems to be interested in fixing the problem. Too bad up until this point I was having a good experience with Amazon ,even promoting them to family and friends. I don't think I will do that anymore. Too bad.

3 to 3.5 stars - - - Many other reviews have pointed out concerns or problems with their machine that I have not faced. There has been no leaking water (as long as the water reservoir is pushed in fully, it is well sealed). The espresso "puck" (used coffee grounds expelled from the filter basket) comes out whole and dry. No wet mess here. All I can figure is those having problems either do not tamp the grounds down firmly, or are using coffee that has not been ground fine enough. (An espresso grind should appear almost as a powder). The tip of the frothing arm, while small, is ample enough for the job). The machine makes a good cup of espresso, and is easy enough to use and maintain. I do have a couple of complaints, though. The biggest problem is the small size of the machine — more specifically the distance from the warming tray to the bottom of the filter basket holder. Most espresso demitasse cups and espresso glasses are too big to place in the 2.5 inch space that is given. A one ounce shot glass is about all I have found that can fit. Placing the bottom of the filter holder even 1 to 1.5 inches higher would have solved this problem. The other problem, for me anyway, is the espresso does not come out hot enough. Even if the warming tray, shot glass and esspress mug are all warmed before hand with extremely hot water, the espresso that comes out is just hot enough to be considered good for drinking (there is barely any steam). If it sits even five minutes, though, or if you add any steamed milk (also comes out only warm) for a latte, it is already cool enough to guzzle the entire cup in one swig without any fear of discomfort - forget burns. Coffee, and this includes espresso and lattes, should be hot — not just warm.
reviews.review_header: I reccomend, but with a few reservations...

reviews.review_text: I originally wrote a 3 star review of this machine. I thought it worked okay until it broke. I emailed De'Longhi customer support and they told me I could get a replacement since it was less than a year old. My rating now goes to 1-star because of their very poor service. After getting the initial good news that I would get a new machine if I was to send in a copy of the purchase receipt and the machine's serial number (both of which I did immediately), I have heard nothing. I've emailed many times back to their customer service, referencing the original conversation that requested the machine info, but since that first positive message, nothing. Not only will I not be interested in this specific machine, but I'm done ever considering any product from De'Longhi.
reviews.review_header: Not very good espresso maker and really poor customer service

reviews.review_text: The DeLonghi EC155 is the very most basic espresso machine that one can experiement with. Yes it's pump driven but it's also extremely light and frustrating to operate. It feels more like a toy than a kitchen appliance. I can easily see many homes purchasing this, using it for a couple weeks, and forgetting about it. I'd recommend going with something a bit more user friendly like the nespresso systems or saving up a bit to get a better machine that they'll enjoy using. If going with the nespresso make sure to go over the pros and cons. A great starter machine that I'd recommend over this is the Starbucks Barista. Do a little google search and watch some videos. They are no longer made but can be found on craigslist for about $100. That machine is well build and although it also has it's limits, it's a usable machine that won't be forgotten about as easily as this machine.
reviews.review_header: Look in to other alternatives-cheap plastic toy you'll stop using after a couple weeks

reviews.review_text: I would give this all five stars, if the machine lasted more than a year. We've made coffee only over the weekends with it. We've used it gently, did not use the milk frother attachment for the most part of our usage. The machine drips water very slowly, as if there isn't enough pressure build-up. Most online recommendations suggest descaling the machine. We've tried that, but that didn't fix things either. There is no build-up, and I don't think that is our problem in any case. I don't wish to spend more money buying descaling products and invest more money into an already broken machine. It may be worth pointing out that the previous version of this machine lasted us two years and stopped working in exactly the same way. With that machine we assumed we had a defective model, or had hit some kind of a weakness or limitation in the machine. We used the previous one more often and for longer before it died. It could just be a gradual degradation in quality of materials used in these machines. I sometimes hear people saying their espresso machine lasted them ten years. I just don't see how that could be possible anymore. I am just disappointed that I need to shell out another $100 for a machine that will last us another year, or two if we are lucky. I am looking around for other options. This machine is supposedly a best seller in semi-automatic espresso machines, so it's a bit difficult to look beyond that and weigh out the reviews of the other machines in comparison with this one. Somebody in the Questions and Answers section suggested that this problem may be a result of a pump diaphragm weakness. (glimmer of hope) He also said it was unrepairable in this model, and he just had to toss it away (glimmer of hope fades away).

I've bought this machine a couple of times, because it does produce good espresso, cappuccinos, etc.--when it works. And it works fine for about the first year. Then it starts leaking. Yes, I've cleaned it regularly and carefully, and this makes no difference. Neither does replacing gaskets. It still leaks. I chalked this up to a faulty machine the first time. But given that precisely the same thing has now happened twice, it seems to be a design flaw. If you're willing to buy one every year, or you feel lucky, or don't use it very often, or are willing to station a tray underneath at all times, by all means give this product a shot. But just know you're getting what you pay for--a disposable machine that needs to be replaced way too often. UPDATED: I have further reduced the stars to one because this time, the machine only last a few months before leaking. I cleaned it religiously, and only when I disassembled it a bit did I see that there the culprits were multiple faulty parts such as washers and hoses that go bad far too quickly. I tried to replace them with parts that are available various places online, only to find that the design makes it all but impossible to repair. (Actually, it is impossible thanks to poor plastic material, mostly.) It's really a poorly designed machine unless you decide that it's disposable. But it's pretty damn expensive for that purpose. Word to the wise: Just spend a few hundred dollars on a machine that isn't a piece of crap.
reviews.review_header: Do Not Buy: Develops leaks all too quickly--can't recommend anymore

reviews.review_text: Almost a year after purchasing- it still works great and really has a small footprint. We use it a few times a week. Read many reviews before settling on this one. This is my first espresso machine and it is easy to use and clean. Agree with other reviewers that the steam wand is a pain to deal with- not enough clearance between it and the counter for a standard size steaming mug. All in all, pleased with it and would purchase again.

I bought this machine to replace a similarly-priced Lavazza EP850 machine that I'd had for 6 years. I really loved that one, but given that it was no longer being made (I could get a new one at a few sellers) and that I wanted to be able to not use capsules, I decided to look around. I invested a good deal of time researching machines on Amazon, top-ten lists, etc. This machine seemed to be the favorite in this price range, even if some people noted its short life (I purchased the 4-year protection plan for that reason). But, for the reasons below, I returned it after 5 days. As someone who has a good deal of experiences with this type of machine, I didn't feel it was a learning curve--it is not made well for a cup of latte/cappuccino given the wand and generally a number of design flaws that are too much to overcome. I noticed immediately when I took the machine out of the box that my 3 oz tiny Le Creuset espresso mug barely fit under the handle, but since this was the only cup I planned to use I thought it OK for now, even if I couldn't figure why the design was like this. I was really surprised to read about how long the machine should warm up (15 minutes at least), given that my Lavazza one required 8-10 minutes, but perhaps this shorter duration was an exception. After letting some water drip through before putting coffee in, I found it easy to make a good-tasting shot of espresso. This is why I give the machine 2 stars. However, I noticed that after I stopped the machine it took ~10 seconds for water to stop running through - my Lavazza machine hadn't been like this. The result was lots of mess. Also contributing to the mess was that my very short espresso cup could barely fit under the holes of handle, so I couldn't get it out without tipping it a little. I really don't know how I could have a shorter cup than 3 oz. I didn't find it difficult to put the handle in its place like other reviewers have noted. One thing I didn't like with the handle and that I would have changed if I'd kept it is is that there's a big plastic part under the where the coffee drips - scalding hot coffee drips onto this plastic and then dribbles through 2 holes into the cup. Why isn't this stainless? One thing I saw on youtube videos was that people had unscrewed the plastic part and cut off the top where the coffee would run through so it's not dripping through plastic--odd. I'm not the most handy person and wouldn't know how to cut it. Nonetheless, the cup of espresso was very hot and the crema was very good. Now the steam wand. It is awful. Beyond awful. I've used my old Lavazza machine and others to froth milk. In fact, right before that machine died with the same type of milk in the same stainless container, I made froth that you could have cut with a knife it was so dense. But with this one the mechanism is very flawed. I tried 6 different times, some after watching videos and reading articles for this specific machine. I know that there are different sounds milk frothing makes and you want to be in the quiet zone--I could never find it. And the steam got so furious and hot (this isn't a good thing) after a little that I had to shut the valve quickly and milk had already spilled all over. I looked at my old Lavazza wand and I was able to take part of it off and put it onto this machine when I unscrewed the plastic part from the DeLonghi wand. This didn't work because the wand is so short (because it's so oddly close to the counter) that it doesn't extend down far enough to allow the over piece from the Lavazza machine to work. I could see the construction was so much better on the Lavazza machine and this one simply cannot work as is. And this brings me to my decision. Option A: Buy a $40 milk frothing pitcher and just abandon the one that came with the machine. This seems silly - it's defective inherently, part of what I paid for, so why should I spend more? Option B: do what every single youtube video showed: get a modification for the wand or replace it completely. Less silly because you're actually using the machine and I like machine froth (don't mind doing the work) BUT it voids your warranty. Based on reading numerous reviews, I specifically bought a 4-year protection plan, so now this would be useless if anything else on the machine broke. Option C (the winner): return it and find another machine--likely going a step or two up since it seems that lower-end machines require modifications, acceptance that parts don't work well to begin with, lots of plastic and cheap parts that break and render the machines useless, etc. After really liking my Lavazza machine for 6 years, although I wish it could have used my own coffee and the espresso temperature wasn't quite as hot as that from the DeLonghi, I can say that the DeLonghi wasn't nearly as nice in the same price bracket ($150 vs $100). The wand doesn't function well, the foam is watery and non-existent -- never could I make it double in size, unless you are willing to pay to replace it (knowing how to do so), thereby voiding your warranty, you can't overcome this. The design is really flawed in other ways. I didn't fully understand what other people wrote in their reviews, I though my espresso cup is really short, maybe they're trying with mugs, etc, but the space between the bottom of the handle and the base is far too little - I may have gotten use to it if this were the only problem. Finally, it's plain messy - the water that comes down after the espresso is done pulling, the frother gurgling like crazy. In all, despite the low price point, the cup of coffee and the aggravation are not worth it. I suggest moving up in price to get something that will really work. After my Lavazza machine working so well for 6 years, having paid just $150, I know it's possible to have a lower end machine work well. But, given what I've read and having tried this one, which gets top honors on several lists, I'm not sure what that is in 2017. Certainly not the DeLonghi EC155.
reviews.review_header: Don't buy if you want to froth milk + poor design

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I agree with most of the negative reviews surrounding the durability of this machine. While I was hesitant on purchasing a machine at such a low price (for what it "is"), it seemed like a nice, little "apt- /or condo-sized" machine..... but shortly after owning it a year, I regretted my decision. I found the problem, once I took the machine apart to inspect it (knowing I'd had it too long to return or even request a replacement part for). It turned out to be a little brass fitting that is primarily responsible for handling the water pressure. I couldn't tell if the threads around it had corroded & began leaking, or if the fitting itself had been damaged (& I've long since trashed my unit, so I can't provide a picture), but in either case, I don't think that a brass fitting is ideal for this machine as brass is an alloy that is commonly made from lead (i.e. something you don't want in drinking water), & even though brass has many of the same properties as copper (in that it is corrosive "resistant" & handles heat to some degree, & can be made "lead free"), it doesn't appear to have the durability needed to give this machine more than 6-12 months of use; mine lasted right at about a yr (or just after the warranty expired). Given that my problem seems to commonly arise in other buyer's experiences, I don't think I'll be getting another DeLonghi product, & regrettably cannot / will not be recommending this machine (or any DeLonghi products), to others; mainly due to that this problem has existed since I bought it (nearly 4 yrs ago now), & people are CONTINUING to have the same problem (I suspect from that fitting)..... thus.... DeLonghi knows about the problem but has yet to address it... still to this day. The price point is nice, but I'd HIGHLY recommend looking elsewhere for your coffee / espresso machine. **** As previously mentioned, my machine lasted a "whole year" (lol), but as an addendum, I used it perhaps once or twice per week (tops), & made sure to run a certified cleaner through it, periodically, to make sure there were no deposits building up on its internal parts. Despite all of the care (& limited use) I provided, the machine still began leaking (from that brass fitting I mentioned) GOBS of water during the brewing process; & even some after the brewing, as the machine cooled down. This machine only has a 1 yr warranty on it, & with a track record of lasting about 1 yr (or less), you'd really be better off searching elsewhere for a machine......... unless, of course...... you don't mind dishing out $100 annually on an espresso machine (I paid $100 for mine, anyway... I don't know how long it'll run at the $70 price it has now, but I honestly wouldn't even pay that -- I'd place this machine in the $30-40 tier, max., given its consistent durability issues, & other various issues I discovered with its use). Cheers, & GL to any who gamble with this machine!!
reviews.review_header: Aesthetically pleasing (both outwardly & its initial performance), but has ZERO durability...

reviews.review_text: Update: July 2013: After a few months of frustration this unit is getting put away in a dark corner; Cannot believe how bad this is.....I have tried switching brands, grinds, different packing pressures and nothing works as the old model did. Coffee is watery and lacks real body or even a decent crema. The unit is cleaned before each use so no one can say that it is "blocked". In fact - a lot of times a blob of coffee grounds is clogged up in the exit screen that the filter sits in. If I have a lemon then I am stuck with it...but I will not buy a a De'Longhi again. ____________________________________________________________________________________________________________ I had the previous model for 6 years without a glitch until the boiler finally burned out. This new model does not have the same performance and the grounds are sticking to the top portion of the water injector along with a watery mess in the filter. Pressure seems inadequate and not 15 bars judging from the results. I am using the same coffee brand and packing it the same as the previous unit. No matter how it is packed ..the watery soup is a problem.

I bought this with the thought of having a few shots of espresso in the morning, and it has worked ok for that. The espresso and cappuccino is decent, but the mechanics of the machine itself is mostly why I gave it a low rating. When you turn it to the brew setting, the machine vibrates and has a rattle to it. It vibrates so much that you will need to move the cup under the brew stream a few times before it's done. It is also nesecary to remove the metal plate where the cup sits to put in a normal size espresso cup. The cups we have are about 2-2.5" high and they only fit if you remove the metal plate that sits over the overflow area. I think the cups they picture will work fine (although not included...) but the cups we bought did not. Not a huge deal, but worth noting. The other issue is that the milk steamer/frother doesn't work that great and It is also a pain to clean. If you want a good espresso maker that is quiet and feels solidly built, keep looking. For the price it's not terrible, but it didn't meet my expectations.

Let me start with this - for the price this machine is good but you won't get even close to what real espresso should be. For cappuccinos it's not bad at all. It steams milk well, even though the foam is not as fine as it should be. Espresso capability aside, I had several annoyances with it. 1. The silicone isolation of the water tank broke about 10 months after I got it so it would leak everywhere. My suggestion is when it's still new don't take the tank out all the time and fill with with a cup instead. 2. The dirty water pan grill doesn't fit well in the pan so it would often move around. 3. The machine is really light so every time you twist the portafilter, the whole thing will move around. Also because of the light weight, the pump will make it vibrate a lot, making our cups move about during pulls. I would only recommend this if all you want is "an espresso/a cappuccino" made with pre-ground coffee. If you're happy with what you get at Starbucks, you're probably going to be happy with this. I spent over a year experimenting with various coffees, grinds, and modifications but eventually ended up buying a much more expensive machine. There's just no other way if you want good home-made espresso.
reviews.review_header: Good for it's price but not for real good espresso.

reviews.review_text: I actually purchase this machine twice-- once in January 2012, and again in August 2013. I was relatively happy with the first machine I purchased, despite its shortcomings. However, that machine stopped in just over 18 months. I felt that I had gotten pretty good use out of it for the time I owned it, so I (stupidly) opted to buy the same machine again. The second machine had issues almost straight out of the box, and whatever quality there was had noticeably dropped off in the time since I bought the first unit. The second one barely lasted 6 months before it was completely unusable. The milk frother went first, after about 4 or 5 months. It continued to make espresso for another month or so before the machine gave up altogether. Since that time, I have lived without an espresso machine and am now looking to buy another. There is a part of me that really loved the first machine I got-- while it lasted-- and is tempted to get another of the same model, but I won't because the quality simply isn't there. The PROS from the first machine I purchased-- If counter space is an issue, the small size is great. It made a decent cup of espresso. Good price for a pump machine-- IF it holds up more than a few months. The frother worked well, once I figured out how to use it. The CONS-- Almost too small-- it's hard to find a cup to fit under the spout. Vibrates horribly when in use. Perhaps this is due to the small/lightweight nature of the machine? Horrible ergonomics. Extremely poor quality. Yes, it's an inexpensive machine, but it breaks FAST. (I made one cup or less a day with both of my machines.)

I got about 8 months use out of this before the pump died. During that time, it was trouble-free and I was satisfied with the espresso it produced, even though the espresso could not really compare with that produced by more expensive machines or even a Nespresso machine. On the plus side, it was cheap, although I did splurge for an after-market tamper. The two stars I subtracted were really because even a cheap machine should last at least a year, especially considering that I made, on average, only one cup per day.

I bought this espresso maker with such fabulous reviews and price point i couldn't refuse. It worked great for the first year and was easy to use after that I started noticing the pump was degrading and began to just drip. I went thru several cleaning cycles over the course of the year but sadly is just a drip coffee maker now. I would recommend getting the warranty if you want this to last over a year. Also the base only fits small cups around 3 inch height it would be nice to be able to fit taller size cups.
reviews.review_header: Worked great for the first year!

reviews.review_text: UPDATE: Was a good machine until it stopped working about 15 months in. One morning, it simply had no heat - a heating element must have given out. I give it 2 stars still because I got quite a bit of espresso out of it for $90. But I'm very hesitant to buy another one now. Then again, the next level up is the $500+ machines, so maybe I'll just buy one of these every year or two. Still, it really should last longer than it did. I'm on to iced coffee for the summer anyway, so I'll keep shopping and see if anything better pops up when I'm ready for espresso again this fall. I was very skeptical when I opened this, because it seemed very complex to use. Once I figured it out, it's a piece of cake, and it makes a really tasty cappuccino. I use it daily, and I love it. (Also, it says it takes 15 minutes to be ready, but that's wrong. It's really just a couple minutes.) If you don't already have a tamper, frothing pitcher and espresso shot glasses, invest a few more bucks and buy them. They will be much easier to use than trying to improvise with stuff from around the kitchen.
reviews.review_header: UPDATED: quit working after about 15 months

reviews.review_text: We bought this unit Feb 27 and by June 24 it doesn't work very well. The only problem is it won't push enough water thru the grounds very well. It takes a lot longer than before. All of the stainless steel filters are clean, plenty of water... It's as if the pump has gotten weaker!? Buying online makes it VERY hard to contact the seller to find out what's going on. Actually, I can't find out how to contact anyone. I think I may go to Costco, at least I have a year to return things. No hassles, no problems. If you buy this unit, get the 2 year plan, maybe then you have some contact. Other than that, we have been happy with it, it's just wore out in 4 months making 2/3 cups a day on average.
reviews.review_header: we have been happy with it

reviews.review_text: After a week of enjoying many excellent espressos in Lisbon I came back wanting to buy an espresso maker, especially after the vile sample of overpriced watery crud Starbucks served me on the trip back from the airport. I am a coffee tyro on a budget, more so because I know that these days spending 5 times over the odds guarantees you nothing. (Those $300 plasticky dress shoes are made in the same sweatshop as the $60 plasticky dress shoes and fit just as poorly.) It didn't take much research to land on this de Longhi model. It helped that our regular coffee maker that has been faultless for many years is also a de Longhi. As someone who appreciates good industrial design (i.e., Italian) and robust construction, I didn't hesitate to order it and at under $80 there was not much risk. It has exceeded my expectations for quality and features (and probably I don't want all those extra bell$ and whistle$ anyway). It looks good on my kitchen counter and cleaning it is easy. The only quibble is the slightly awkward tamper placement, which makes it difficult to apply much force (left handers need not apply!). But any serious home barista will probably get a standalone gadget for that task anyway. I just use a wide flat bottle cap (from a Starbucks bottle hahaha) – simple. After about 60 cups so far (in the clear double-walled glass types also sold by de Longhi) and a little experimenting with coffee types and brewing variables, I can make a passable espresso. Any substandard brews are down to me and the choice of grind, not the machine. It's probably already paid for itself in 3 months, and I don't anticipate needing to 'upgrade' in future. I still have to learn cappuccinos, and I'll update this report when I have. Meantime, anyone know of an Alfa Romeo 2000 GT Veloce for sale in good condition? UPDATE, July 2015 After many more brews I have learned a lot more about espresso in general, and I've come to the conclusion that what this machine produces is strong coffee with foam on top, not espresso. Despite its claims, it does NOT produce the 9 bar pressure required at the business end of the machine where the hot water is forced through the ground coffee. However, it still a very solid and well designed machine for the price, and what it produces is still better than standard coffee shop brew, or what I can get out of a regular home coffee maker. I've tried with enough different beans to know it can't be just that. It is what it is, but it's not a machine for a serious coffee lover. UPDATE, July 2016 Well the machine is shot after about 18 months. There is obviously no pressure, and I don't have 5+ minutes of chinese water torture. I'm sure I didn't help matters by forgetting the maching for about an hour a couple of times, but I think it would have failed anyway. I guess it more than it paid for itself in coffee runs I didn't make during that time, but I expect substantially longer life than this. Any suggestions for repair are welcome. I assume there are seals that are bad, although I don't notice any leaks.
reviews.review_header: Value for money and a pretty good brew! Well, I was half right!!

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: This is the second DeLongi product we have owned that has died in a year or less! It worked fine since April '16 when we bought it, then last week it started not having the force to make the coffee fast, but was still doing it if you gave it some time. Now it is dead.

Makes a very good cup of espresso or americano or what-have-you. Easy to use. Nice crema. The only problem (as can be seen in various other reviews) is durability. With semi-daily use and proper care, mine lasted two years and two months and then just quit. I think the little pump just has to work too hard to make it work. I felt bad throwing out so much plastic and metal after only 2 years, so I'll probably go for a higher-end machine next time.

I had a Mr Coffee cheaper unit for many years but it wore out as we're daily users. We wanted something a little better and this was so well rated on multiple sites and in articles that we bought it. I've had it for a few weeks now and I am just not happy. For those unaccustomed to the Mr Coffee machine: You add your coffee, tamp it, and then dump the appropriate water in the top, turn a knob and walk away. The result is a strong, tasty brew. For this one, you're supposed to wait like 15 minutes after your turn it on to brew. Had I known that prior to buying it, I wouldn't have bought it. I don't have time for that. Once you are able to turn the knob for it to brew, you have to sit there and babysit it and stop it once it's brewed the shot(s) or it will just keep running until it runs out of water. It's loud as others have said and the cup has to be held or it vibrates off the machine. I typically like 4 shots so it takes a while to do all of this once you load it (only takes 2 at a time unlike the Mr Coffee that takes 4). I could live with that except the result isn't particularly flavorful. I'm using the same coffee I've always used. I'm really disappointed.
reviews.review_header: We wanted something a little better and this was so well rated on multiple sites ...

reviews.review_text: I have been using this model of espresso maker for a few years now. It makes good coffee, consistently. It is easy to clean. They last 13-15 months at 1-3 cups (ie: load grounds into the strainer and pull shots) a day and then fail, //regardless// of cleaning protocols. Accept this, and you will enjoy the product of this machine; if you do not, you will simply come back here and write angry things.

I gave this expresso machine 3 stars because the quality isn't what it should be. This is my second of this brand machine. I bought it because of the stainless steel water reservoir. The first one of these I bought worked about 18 months before the pump on the coffee side would no longer function. My prior Krups machine had lasted for 4 years before I switched to the De'Longhi. I bought another DeLonghi in December and it came broken, making a metal scraping sound and putting out mostly water. Amazon did a nice job replacing it for me quickly. The new machine I received two weeks ago works as it's supposed to. My concern is that it only produces enough expresso for one cup of about 4 ounces. After 4 ounces, the machine produces almost clear water. My Krups machine made more with the same amount of coffee. I have to wonder if the De'Longhi manufacturing process has fallen below expected like so many things made in China. Big Italian name, poor quality. Update - the machine is not working properly, and cleaning for calcification has not helped. I think these machines are not meant to last more than 12 - 18 months. I am looking for a new machine again.

We bought one of these back in 2009, and it lasted seven years, did a fine job. When it started dying (struggling with pressure) we got another, and what a piece of junk.the second one was, both for steaming milk and making espresso. Even brand new it was working worse than the dying one. Maybe they switched to cheaper parts? The new one had been on the shelf as a backup, so it was too late to return. I went with the Mr. Coffee machine instead, and it's been way better. This DeLonghi machine is junk.
reviews.review_header: Used to be good, now it's junk

reviews.review_text: Do not buy this used. I have had two used and inspected machines. The first one looked great and worked for about a month and a half. The second one showed up wet, with old milk in the frother and not working. When I contacted Amazon to return the first one, they gave me the number to De'Longhi. De'longhi said this machine in not fixable, it is replaceable. There is no point in buying used, because De'longhi will replace any that are bought new, but not the machines that are purchased used. It's much more worth the time and money to buy it new. We plan to purchase a new one, if it works I will update.

I will say that I now own three of these machines, but not by choice, and here is why. I had wanted to replace my older Krups machine, but that exists no longer, so after some research, I purchased one of these models. This was several years ago, and when something went wrong with it, while still under warranty, they told me to send in the whole machine, at my expense, and THEY would decide if it deserves replacement. It, did, so they sent a replacement to me. This machine is now about two years old, and the only problem I have is with the gasket inside the head, so the machine will drip water (or coffee, if you have the filter on) while the machine is heating. I called the company, but they do not sell parts, but offered me a second machine at a lower price, about $ 70. This THIRD machine lasted about 2 months before a fusible link in one of the thermostats went bad. This meant that the green light is automatically on, immediately when turning on the machine, because the machine thinks it is already hot. When I called the company THIS time, all I had to do was cut the cord at the base, send that in, again at my expense, and they sent a new machine to me. This FOURTH machine leaked as soon as I tried to fill the reservoir. I knew there was just a loose hose or something else similar, but the company said if I unscrew the bottom to look, I void all warranty. "Just cut the cord at the base..." This time I told them, I did not want a replacement EC155, and asked for the next model up, and they sent the BAR 32 as a replacement. I then unscrewed the bottom of the fourth machine and the problem was indeed only a cut in the water line. I spent 50 cents to replace that from the local hardware store, a couple of dollars for the fusible link on the third machine, and about 5 dollars for extra cord and plugs to replace the original cords I had to mail in. I now have 3 of these machines, and all three work. HOWEVER! These two newer EC 155's have not seen much use. The filter holder does not fit into the head well, because it is an extremely tight fit, and I don't wish to break the machine. (I believe it is another gasket issue, because the filter holder fits into the older machine easily.) Also, the frothing wand does not stay in one place,but swings back, as if spring-loaded, under the base. This makes it harder to operate, because you either do not move the frothing pitcher (which is unreasonable, because it will not heat the milk in a consistent manner) or you have to have a non-heat sensitive utensile to hold the wand in place while you froth the milk. My issue is that these machines are now made in China, and the workmanship (rather, lack thereof) shows. The company is well aware of this, because they now only ask for a cut cord instead of the whole machine for them to decide if it warrants sending out a new one. They sent a new machine to me instead of allowing me to replace a 50 cent, 6-inch piece of tubing. Also, their own website lists these machines at about $ 80 now, so they did come down in price as well, because my first one was well over $ 100. As a pump machine, they are worth $ 80, but not any more than that. Their customer service is good, but you should not have to wait 3 - 4 weeks for mail turn-around, and you shouldn't have to use warranty in the first place, as any good machine should last longer than 6 months. Anthony
reviews.review_header: Okay machine, worth $ 80, but no more. Shoddy parts and labor, but company stands behind product.

reviews.review_text: It does produce good quality espresso but only after much effort. The machine is loud, vibrates a lot, takes a long time to heat up, and the odd shape inside the espresso basket makes it very tough to remove the grounds after using. I much preferred my prior cheapo machines ($35 or so at target) but after burning out two of them in 5 years decided to spend more on quality. After just two months this machine completely stopped heating. Since it was too late for the Amazon return window I had to go through delonghi for the replacement. It's sort of a tedious process and after waiting two weeks already I emailed to follow up and found out there is another thing I need to mail them, which I was never told. Their service reps are very nice on the phone but I'm looking at nearly a month without a machine before I can expect the replacement. At five bucks a day for coffee shop coffees this will quickly add up to the cost of a whole new machine. I don't recommend this machine.

I purchased this used and it was in perfect condition. Just a learning curve to figure it out. If the coffee grounds piece seats where it is suppose to, coffee only drips out, if it is ascew just a bit off center, it leaks around the center and down the handle. It only gets hot enough for a double espresso and not more for another long bit. I would not recommend this, it does not poor out the way it is suppose it. tired of watching video of this product and doing it the way it says and it only trickles out.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I am really disappointed with this little machine. I have had it for only 2 weeks and it is already having problems. The espresso is coming out in a slow drip and not producing any crema. As well, the green light goes on and off throughout making the espresso, even when I have preheated it for 30 mins. I think I will have to return this

My current De'Longhi worked fine for about five years, but since a few weeks the pump no longer works. A regular (3.5"=89 mm) coffee cups just fits and could be used to catch a double espresso. The coffee extract can either be used pure or diluted to desired strength. These machines do not have a volume measurement, so the extract volume must be determined by stopping the pump after the desired amount of coffee extract is produced. I normally use a glass coffee carafe with level indication to catch the desired amount. This carafe is lower than a coffee cup (85 mm) and comfortably fits below the drip mozzles of the older De'Longhi. Unfortunately this new model has only 65 mm clearance below the drip nozzles and almost nothing fits below the nozzles. Very poor design!

We use an espresso maker every morning for cappuccino - have a separate milk frother since none of these home machines have sufficient steam capability to adequately froth milk. Now the issue: We just received our 4th DeLongi EC155 in the last 5 years. We just got this one March 3, 2018. The one before (bought July 17, 2017) only lasted 7 months before the pump failed to force water through the coffee. With the one before that, bought on Dec 10, 2016, and the pump failed again resulting in the July 2017 purchase. The one before that, was bought in Sept 2013 and lasted 3 years. We have very high quality water with very few minerals and then filtered again through the refrigerator. My assumption is that DeLonghi is using a different pump over the last couple of years with limited life. Unfortunately, when looking at all the other reviews for other machines, none get good reviews for reliability and often cost $100 - $500 for anything reasonably affordable for home use. It's more cost effective to buy a DeLonghi every 7 or so months than spend lots more money and just get more of the same poor performance.
reviews.review_header: Good enough for home use, makes solid espresso, just be ready to replace it at lease yearly.

reviews.review_text: Makes an amazing espresso drink, although buy a real tamper, the one attached is useless. Wish there was a higher clearance to fit a taller cup but that's a small complaint. Overall, a great little espresso maker. Terrribe customer service drops this to 2 stars. Machine was clogging up after 6 months and I couldn't budge the screw to take it apart to clean it. Delonghi customer service said not to worry about and just descale the unit so it stays clean. I said it's defective because I can't take it apart as shown on the manual, they offered no solutions. Cheap company with poor customer service bad warranty policy. Buy at your own risk.
reviews.review_header: Makes an amazing espresso drink/ bad customer service

reviews.review_text: I've had this coffee machine for roughly three months and it worked well (shots were a bit on the weaker side as I would have expected). The last week before it died, the machine became extremely slow. I performed the recommended maintenance with no difference in performance afterwards. Eventually, espresso ceased from coming out. Now it's just a loud-vibrating brick :-( Before you purchase this machine consider the following: - The machine is loud (even when it was new) - It vibrates so much the cups underneath move from underneath the espresso dispenser so you must watch them at all times. - It's hard to fit any cups underneath it. My shot glasses barely fit. - The built-in tamp is nice - The water level view is nice - The steamer is in an inconvenient place for use. You must move the machine around to use it with bigger cups. - The shots aren't as strong (I like really strong shots, I needed at least 4 from this machine). - It's slow when dispensing espresso. In short: I was disappointed that this machine didn't live up to my expectations. The price was right, but I felt the quality was below average. If you do buy this machine, I hope you don't have a similar experience that I did.

Purchased on May 2016. Died on April 2018. I keep this machine clean, regularly run a cleaning cycle and for about half a year it was not even used. First the water wouldn't run through the coffee no matter what the grind size was or how loose it was packed. The pump seemed to loose force. Then after it started working again I barely got 4 cups out of this machine before the heating element broke and now all I can get is cold coffee. The machine doesn't even get hot to or warm to the touch.

This smaller model De'Longhi replaces my long-used one when the heating element quit. It makes a nice espresso and cappuccino with good crema, but several important issues should be noted: The twin dispensing points are so very low to the base plate that only a cup no taller than 21/2" will fit under them. This forced me to buy special cups [HIC 9-piece cup & saucer set, with stand, model NT314]. The unit vibrates enough that you have to carefully hold the two cups in place while they fill. The instructions say to preheat the unit 10 minutes before us, but even then, the green "ready" light goes out almost immediately, meaning it is quickly cooling off. HIC 9-Piece Stackable Cappuccino Coffee Tea Set, Fine White Porcelain, Set Includes 4 (7-Ounce) Cups with Matching Saucers and Metal Stand, Gift Boxed

Wasn't in my door more than 10 minutes before I realized what a seriously design flawed machine I bought. I read the frothier was LOW....but to be only 3 5/16" off the counter top leaves me with very few container options. If you want espresso you have to wait 15 minutes to pre-heat THEN you can start the espresso making process. Basically, it should have come with container necessary to froth and it should have clearly stated- "always have a spare 15 minutes to make your coffee. The coffee dispenser clearance is also on the low side but not as bad as the espresso and frothier.

This machine was a good intro machine. Something cheap to get you into espresso. There is a number of downsides, but at $300 less than the next step up, it was the clear choice. The pressurized portafilter does a pretty good job at getting good espresso out of a not-so-perfect grind. There are a few downsides, but you cant really complain for the price. 1. Small boiler. I would have to pause 3-4 times when steaming a few ounces of milk to prevent the frother from spraying water. The steam wand is pretty bad.. I could never get real microfoam with it. It heats the milk.. but not much else. (but hey its $100). 2. Heats slowly, making more than two shots at a time without a pause can get tricky. You have to time it right. Like any machine, you kinda have to adjust your technique to match the speed of the boiler and the way everything works. THE BIGGEST DOWNSIDE OF ALL: Mine died after 6 months. Probably because of a calcification issue, but still. I expected better. If you get this machine (which you probably should if you only have $100 and want decent espresso), GET THE WARRANTY. And decalcify it regularly. If you can afford it, save up for a $400-$600 machine. The investment will probably be worth it, especially if this one dies on you.

I purchased this espresso machine for my husband who is a new devotee to the world of coffee and espresso. We have never owned an espresso machine before, but this looked like a good option based on the price and mostly-positive reviews. Unfortunately, just after the 30 day return period ended, the machine gave up on him. It stopped producing the necessary pressure to put water through the grounds. He tried cleaning with Citric Acid, even though we don't have particularly hard water and it was well before the recommended cleaning schedule. Very little improvement. He called the company and was walked through some procedures to try to get it working again with no luck. Finally was told to cut the cord and mail that (not the whole machine) back to them for a replacement. They wanted to charge $15 to mail a new machine to him, but he when he objected they put him on hold for a few minutes, then came back and said they'd waive that fee. Seems sort of ridiculous to even suggest that a product replacement should have to be paid for when the product is still under warranty! He was happy with the performance of the machine until it gave out, but I just can't give it more than 1 star, even with the replacement on the way, if it's going to fail after one month of 2-3 times daily use. Guess we should have paid more attention to the previous negative reviews. Wonder how long the replacement will last. Once we run out of free replacement options, we'll upgrade to a better product. Edit: 12/13/13 Just wanted to come back and note that the replacement machine that was shipped to us has worked just fine and held up ever since. Hubby is still enjoying his cup of espresso daily. I'm not updating the star rating since I don't want to give the false impression that this machine can be trusted by all, but when it's functional he's happy with it.
reviews.review_header: Stopped Working After 1 Month of Use!

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: This is not an automatic machine. You need to think of it as an experience. This machine is the polar opposite of the kind where you set a timer the night before and wake up to coffee. You need to be ok having a relationship with it. Otherwise you will find your morning pretty stressful. This review includes the collective wisdom I've culled from reading hundreds of reviews (seriously, who has time?) as well as my own discoveries. 1.
