As several reviewers have noted when I posed the question, there is no automatic turn-off. Coffee will keep on coming out until you stop it. Know this and you will avoid the "I Love Lucy" effect, I.e., coffee pouring all over your kitchen counter. Either measure into demitasse cups and stop it, or get to know your cappuccino cup size and stop it. The key point is: stop it. 2. The milk frother is, as everyone has noted, very low. To solve this, Amazon is pairing the machine with a tiny frother, described by one reviewer as "Alice in Wonderland" size. Here's the nice big but squat one I bought: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000Y8UCCY/ref=oh_details_o05_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1. That is the Krups Sx5020, 20 ounces. Works like a charm. In a tiny apartment works great for me to store it in the freezer, a move that apparently helps with creating froth. 3. If you are making cappuccino in one of those lovely, comforting soup-bowl-size cups, you haven't a prayer of getting that baby out from under the machine without spilling coffee all over the place. One reviewer suggested removing the metal tray and putting a paper towel in the base instead. Works great! Thank you. Ok so those are the things that were driving me crazy after making the switch to the Delonghi from a French press plus Aerolatte. Do these things and your morning will be sane. Honestly I had no complaints about the French press and if I am making coffee for more than 2 people I will definitely return to it, since we each have a doppio in our cappuccino and turning them out individually for a crowd sounds like becoming a professional barista. (I already have a job.). When the price comes down on the semiautomatics I will be first in line.
reviews.review_header: Everything you need to know to solve all the problems, especially if you are making cappuccino

reviews.review_text: The machine produces good crema and has a large water tank. The people who say water isn't coming out either need to wait for the pump to charge the lines which takes a minute or so when it is new/dry, or seat the tank and portafilter properly. My beef is that the boiler is too small and can't maintain temperature consistently. Sometimes you can pull a whole shot, but most of the time it's slightly more than lukewarm. This happens even when the machine is preheated. The OK light turns out whenever it feels like it while you're pulling the shot. In my opinion, proper water temperature is a big deal so I'm not too pleased with that, thus 3 stars.
reviews.review_header: Would be awesome if boiler was more efficient.

reviews.review_text: There are a number of things that I do not like about this espresso machine, and before I continue, I should let you know that I have returned it. The espresso machine that I'm purchasing is replacing one that I've had for about 25 years, so sadly, this is very emotional time for me. :-) But seriously, there are some things about this machine that are very frustrating so here they are. Someone has taken a simple process and made it complicated. You shouldn't have to take 15 minutes to simply start the machine in order to prepare for an espresso. Despite the instructions telling you so, this was not necessary. After all, who wants to wait 15 minutes for the machine to warm up after waking up for their cup of coffee. The filter comes in two sizes, so unfortunately, you have to make coffee to the strength that these filters will allow. Even their larger filter size was unsatisfactory for a very strong cup of espresso or cappuccino or latte. For some strange reason or another, the filter has to be aligned perfectly within the filter holder. You can't just drop it in. This design seems pointless and only takes more time. I did not like the frothing plastic piece because it required you to take it off each time to clean the milk out that got trapped inside. You could not just simply wipe it off. After removing the filter you're guaranteed to get additional coffee dripping down onto the pan. Yes it's removable but who want to take another step out to clean this as well? There is very little space under the area where the coffee is dispensed and if you do not have a very short container or demi tase cup, forget it. My wife got tired of hearing me complaining and insisted that I return it. After exchanging this product for a basic model that cost $45 less , I am back to making my coffee shots in less than 4 minutes with very little cleaning (I love Amazon, so thanks for making this such an easy return process). If someone is fine with taking 10 - 20 minutes for a shot of coffee go for it. You may love this machine as a number of reviews clearly state.

Received item with scratches. Took pics before using just in case. Tried, but wasn't satisfied with neither the product and neither with the coffee it made. Returned and received only partial credit. I Do not recommend doing business with this seller. ....and for you coffee espresso lovers......forget this machine altogether..... There's little control regarding amount of water being used per serving. Must compact coffee grinds to get any satisfactorily results....but it is a waste of time.....you will not like the results.....not with this machine. I know what an espresso tastes like or should taste like.....and this machine is impossible to accomplish the task. But it is cheaper than most....once again.....don't recommend buying from this seller.

A previous reviewer made the comment that the coffee that comes out isn't true espresso and I have to agree. It's stronger than normally prepared coffee, but if you're looking for that "puts hair on your chest" kind of jolt, this isn't the machine for you. Also, when the "pour" function is on, the machine vibrates strongly enough to make the cups move out of place, spilling coffee. I found that by putting a paper towel underneath the cups, they stay put. The distance between the bottom of the spouts and the base is pretty short, so a normal 6 oz cup doesn't fit. I had to buy espresso cups, since none of the many types of cups in my kitchen fit, which a bit annoying. I've had it for a few months and so far, no signs of blowing up like other reviewers experienced. The instructions say to let the water "perk" for 15 mins before moving the dial to pour, but the green light comes on after only a few and it doesn't seem to make any difference with the quality of the coffee.
reviews.review_header: Took a while to figure out ways to deal with quirks.

reviews.review_text: Makes decent espresso, but has started to leak water from the head after just a few weeks.

I just got my machine in the mail, and after reading the instructions and assembled it, I tried to brew my 5 cups to "clean" the parts. The problem I'm having is that the machine is rumbly (it's knocking my glass around and it's not staying centered under the drip). But the more glaring problem I'm having is that no water is being dispensed. Looking through the book, it advised me of a few things: 1 - There was no water in the filter. (There is) 2 - The filter is installed incorrectly. (I poured the water out, put the tank back in to make sure the filter was open, it was. I refilled the tank and put it back, the filter was still open) 3 - There was a blockage. (I haven't used it yet? I'm not quite sure what could be blocking the water from even trying to come out?) If anyone has any pointers, I would really appreciate it. I'm a newbie to this, which is why I went with this model and brand, but I'm debating about returning it if I can't get any water out. It could 10000% be operator error, but I'm really lost as to what is wrong with this thing.

So far...it's just okay. We bought based on reviews after having a "steamer toy" for close to 15 years. My Krups worked fine and I think I just got used to it. Plus I don't expect to make hipster perfect coffee at home anyhow. But it finally bit the dust so we bought this. Firstly, I didn't realize how tiny it was so no coffee carafe will fit under the coffee spout and only very tiny traditional espresso cups will fit. Not awesome as I'm not about to go out and buy espresso cups. The steam arm is rather short so for steaming a large amount of milk it's kind of a pain. It's doing the job okay. I can only compare it to a product that most coffee afficionados cringe at hearing about so I'm not sure if this review would be useful to any coffee snobs. For those of you just looking for an easy to make espresso and steaming milk, maybe stick to the "steam toys." It's annoying to have to preheat this unit just for a cup of coffee as I'm making a latte rushing out the door in the a.m. but it does an okay job.
reviews.review_header: Okay, not overly practical - Probably best for those who don't like to rush their lattes, and espressos

reviews.review_text: Ok for 89 bucks. I'm not a coffee connoisseur, but I think this makes a tasty espresso. My only complaint is that the steam function doesn't work well. It runs out of steam quickly and takes a long time to reheat. I bought this to test the waters. I'll upgrade to something nicer when this inevitably craps out, if I see myself using this often enough to justify spending the money for a nicer one. Update: pump isn't strong enough to push water through finer espresso grounds. Steamer attachment is pretty worthless because you can only steam milk for about 10 seconds at a time. I'll spring for a nicer more expensive one next time. Still, this is good for a first machine.

I bought this espresso machine after a trip to Italy, where I fell in love with espressos. I bought this machine to have the convenience of espresso-making at home, and overall, it does what it has to do: makes great-tasting espressos at a reasonable price. However, this machine does have some pretty annoying aspects to it, so beware. First, when it is making espresso, it vibrates rather hard and loud, making it hard for me to make espressos while my people in my apartment are sleeping, as well as causing the small espresso cup to move out of place. So you have to hold the little espresso cup in place or you'll have the espresso drip miss its mark. Second, the machine drips on well after it's been turned off, which gets a bit messy. All in all, the annoyances are not such a big deal, but I would have spent some extra money to get a machine that doesn't drip past the shut off point and doesn't vibrate so darn much and so loud. UPDATE @ 10 months: This machine is a dud. I didn't even make 25 cups of espresso through it over a 10 month period and it has simply stopped pumping, even after I cleaned different parts out. The buyer shouldn't have to take this to maintenance after such modest use and so soon. Set your sights elsewhere, even if you have to pay more.
reviews.review_header: Not worth the money, machine died after very little use

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: It is OK machine for about 1 year, but I guess for the 80$ price this is what you can expect. Right now after an year of usage a few critical parts are failing. #1 The pump(right now it barely makes any pressure). #2 Froth Dispenser - there are some plastic parts in the handle which cannot be cleaned and also there has some spring that is stuck. Still I guess it is OK, because it made about 300-400 espressos (for about an year). Doing the math ... 80$(for the machine) + 100$ (12 months coffee) = 180$. So it is about 0.50$ per day for espresso.
reviews.review_header: It worked fine only for about 1 year

reviews.review_text: Bought this pump in February 2012. Liked what the reviewers had to say about it. It seemed to have only one real drawback - the frothing element was too low - difficulty in removing foamed milk container - this is true, but I can live with that. I still like the machine, but I had problems with the frother leaking water during the brewing cycle. It got so bad, I had to put a cup under the frother to catch the water - I would get a full cup od water by the time I got a cup of esspresso. I contacted amazon.com (very helpful) and they asked that I contact the company - so I did. The company gave me the run around - had me do all this stuff with descalling, etc. After 4 weeks of e-mails back and forth and a threat that I would contact amazon.com, I asked that they replace the pump - it was on warranty. I followed their instructions, sent them $15.00 (why? I do not know) and they sent me a new pump. After about 3 weeks of operation with the replacement pump, I have the same problem - a leaky frother. The leak is not nealy as bad as the first pump - just a few drops, maybe a teaspoon. I will continue to use the pump, because it does produce a great espresso and cappuccino - I simply put a espresso cup under the frother during brewing. However, 2 things that truly rub me the wrong way 1) the time it took to replace the malfunctioning machine and 2) the run around I got from the company - plus sending an additional $15.00 for a warrantied product - I guess that's 3 things. Would I buy another De'Longhi EC155 Bar Pump Espresso & Cappuccino Maker? - No.
reviews.review_header: 2 Stars to 4 Stars: Don't Like-It's OK-I like it

reviews.review_text: I would give this a 5 star but the difficulty in setting the filter onto the machine is insane. It's almost impossible to line up the arrows without another person to hold the machine tightly. My wife is a barista and loves how the machine froths Almond Milk, she loves the ability to pull long/short shots but it's SO FREAKING HARD to just hook the handle/filter/shot piece we almost want to return it for something else. She literally has to put the machine in a choke hold to set it by herself. Good thing she practices Ju Jitsu. Edit: We just returned our first machine and got another one. SAME exact issue. The Filter Holder is incredibly difficult to set onto the machine. It's not set crooked and there is no obstruction. Edit #2: The second machine we just got has a bad Steam Wand. The first ones Steam Wand worked great, this one can barely put out any steam. What the heck is going on at Delonghi!? Changed to 1 star.

Design (6/10): It's ok. Overall the machine looks cheap, but the machine is cheap, so no high expectations there. The space for the cup is too small, so if you don't have a special cups for expresso you'll not be able to put your cup in there. Coffee (7.5/10): Good coffee. Not super, but very good. Very comparable with Nespresso. Quality( 3/10): Died after 6-7 month. If you consider buying - please add extra $100-150 and buy a decent espresso-maker not this compromise between quality and price.

Based on the reviews, I ordered this machine from Amazon. The machine was wet and the plastic wrapping it was in was also wet. This was supposed to be a new machine. I couldn't figure out where the water came from. The outside of the box wasn't wet. Then I read the instructions. It is normal for water to stay in the bottom of the machine. Since when can this be normal, I wondered. I followed the directions about cleaning the machine by running it without coffee. When I did make coffee, the coffee was awful. The plastic water tank may be a factor in the terrible taste of the water. Although I had washed the water tank a few times with soap and water, it still smelled of plastic. In addition, the steamer nozzle dripped water. The steam was also not sufficient and strong enough to froth milk. I had a Krups that produced a wonderful froth. Unfortunately, I couldn't get a replacement part for that Krups so I had to buy a new machine. Fortunately, I was able to return this machine to Amazon.

The issues I have with the appliance are #1. it seems to make weak espresso, watery, so I have to add about three or four shots to make a decent cup of cappuccino. #2. hot water squirts out of the frother for a really long time before it becomes steamy so don't put your milk under it until you know it's actually shooting steam or your milk is also watery. #3 you have to carefully watch while the coffee is coming out because it just keeps running until you stop it and if you get distracted it runs over and gets everywhere. #4. you have to make sure the cup or cups are centered on a very small area or the stream of coffee will not go into the cup and since the vibration of the machine makes the cup move you have to stand there and watch it and keep moving it back into place. #5. It doesn't come with the cups and the area is shallow so I had to buy three different sets to find one that actually fits underneath. #6. The thing that holds the coffee grounds really holds them! You have to bang and bang it against the trash can to get them to come out or dig them out with a spoon and it makes a big mess. #7 all of this takes about 5-10 minutes just to get one cappuccino....so if you are buying it because it has two spouts, it doesn't much matter. You will need both shots and probably a couple more to make one good cup. If you want two you better set aside a big block of time for that. #8 It is expensive by the time you buy all the other things you need to actually use it, the frothing cup, the espresso cups and a lot of beans just to make one cappuccino. The good things are that it has a swivel arm for the frother so you can hold it over the sink while it shoots water out of it and that prevents the counter from flooding. The reservoir where all your coffee goes if you don't stand there watching it is removable so easy to clean. It looks nice.
reviews.review_header: You will need both shots and probably a couple more to make one good cup. If you want two you better set ...

reviews.review_text: This was my first entry into making espresso at home. This machine is cheap, but has too many drawbacks in its design, which negate it being inexpensive. Several that De'Longhi could have avoided due to its size. On top of these, my unit leaked water so I had to return it. I really wanted to like this and the price point was great, but it just wasn't worth the struggle. I'm not sure what a suitable alternative in a similar price range would be. 1. The steam wand: let's out too much water. It takes like 10 seconds to purge and it never completely purges, it constantly spurts out bits of water instead of pure steam. I suspect it's not getting hot enough. 2. The wand is too short and sits too low. You can either lift the machine on a stand to make up for sitting too low, but there's nothing you can do to extend the length of the wand. You would either need to use a tiny frothing pitcher (and risk making a mess each time) or put too much milk in the pitcher to reach the wand. Combine that with the steam problem on the wand and you're going to end up with too much milk and not enough control. 3. The tamper is just a little plastic piece off to the side. It's works, but a handheld tamper would be much better, but the real problem is that it's slightly too small for the grounds basket. Why couldn't De'Longhi make this large enough to be a perfect fit for their own unit? 4. The portafilter sits very low in the machine as well, so you are limited to using very tiny cups or first pulling into shot glasses. I didn't have tiny cups that fit, so I used shot glasses. But the unit rattles so much as you're pulling a shot that you have to closely monitor, else the unit will rattle so much that it causes the shot glass to move off to the side and completely miss the espresso pouring down.

My Mr Coffee espresso machine died after 10 years, and I thought this would be a nice upgrade. I've been disappointed in a number of ways. 1) I typically make 2 lattes at a time, and the espresso pot I used with our old machine is too tall (there was plenty of room with the old machine). So I use 2 espresso cups, but it's a tight fit and I have to hold the cups in place as the machine vibrates 2) the coffee basket designed for 2 cups is too small 3) my frothing pitcher is too tall (again, plenty of room with the old machine). So I'm bummed. Maybe I'll give this one away and go back to Mr. Coffee.

This is my first Espresso/Cappuccino machine and I'm writing this literally after making my first cup of Cappuccino. Let's start with the most important thing and that is the taste. My first cup came out really good. I'm very happy with the overall look and taste of the cup. The point was to replace my regular Starbucks habit and this cup would indicate I'm well on my way. That said there are a few quirks with this machine that I didn't seem to read in other reviews. 1. The space to put your espresso glasses to collect the espresso is extremely small. You'll definitely need to buy some small "shot" style espresso glasses to fit in here. 2. When you turn the machine on to operate it, it vibrates EXCESSIVELY. So much so it has me wondering if my machine is defective. I literally have to hold my Espresso glasses in place to prevent them from moving out from under the filter when it's running. And it's VERY noisy. 3. The manual recommends that you "warm up" the machine for 15-30 minutes before making your Espresso. So if you plan to use this every morning before work, you're going to have to plan accordingly. 4. The milk frother is quite short. You're going to need a relatively small and shallow frother. Even with one that is pretty small, getting it on and off the frothing utensil is a challenge, especially when it's hot. All this said, I'm still happy with my purchase because the cup of Cappuccino tasted great and I think the price of the machine is pretty good, especially if you're a prime member. Good luck!
reviews.review_header: Good price and my first Cappuccino tasted great, but here are some things I wish knew before purchasing

reviews.review_text: My machine lasted a little over a year before the pump failed. If you read the other customer reviews, you might think this model was designed to fail right after the warranty expires. It is cheap and it does make a passable cup of espresso, but be forewarned, this machine does not last long. If you're trying to save money by skipping the coffee shop and making espresso at home (like me), keep in mind that this will basically cost you $70 a year just to have an EC155 that works. That's just not good enough, so I will not repurchase this model.
reviews.review_header: That's just not good enough, so I will not repurchase this model

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: to be fair its dirt cheap & was decent at first. but 7 months later for me - water leaking out of the bottom, pressure not much to speak of. also, i don't know where they came up with "15 bars" of pressure this machine supposedly has, maybe in theory, but in real world this thing has never been anywhere near 15 bars. obviously theres no way for me to measure it without ripping it apart, but i know my bars.
reviews.review_header: you get what you pay for

reviews.review_text: I bought this espresso machine as a gift for 2 people and they absolutely loved it, so when my coffee pot broke, I thought I'd give it a try. The box arrived and the packaging was subpar. Basically it was a box inside of a box, no added fluff. And the outside box was ripped and torn. Once I got the machine out of the box, I noticed water droplets everywhere. I took the clear plastic off and noticed water all over the side and dripping on the floor. I gently shook the machine and could hear water swooshing around. When I looked in the reservoir there was no water in there -- just the packaged accessories as though it was new. I could not for the life of me figure out where the water was coming from. I opened up the bag that was sealed which had the manual and warranty info in it to see if it mentioned anything about a pre-filled machine, but couldn't find anything. So, I packed it back up and sent in a request for a replacement. I don't know how I'm supposed to send it back since the box that Amazon sent it in is not reusable. I thought Amazon improved their packaging, but now I'm thinking not so much. Who knows if it was a return that should of not went back on the "shelf", or if it was in fact a lemon direct from the manufacturer? I'm willing to give it another try, but my gosh what a hassle. Hoping Amazon handles this situation promptly and appropriately. Once I get the machine up and running and use it a few times, I will update my review. Updating 10/26/12: I've been using this machine daily for a few months now. About a week ago it started going out on me. It would do a few shots fine, but then the pump would not give the pressure needed. I called the manufacturer today and it still under warranty. They want me to try descaling it first though. So, off to go buy descaler (a good thing to have w/ any coffee maker probably), and if that doesn't work, then I will be sending it in for repair. I make about 2-3 drinks a day with it. When it worked, it worked fabulous. Paid for itself w/in a couple weeks. For this reason, I've upped it to 3 stars. Only 3 because I truly believe the pump to be broken (rather than a descaling issue), and at just a few months of use, that is not acceptable. I will update again after I descale.
reviews.review_header: I got a lemon, or something

reviews.review_text: I love De'Longhi products and this was my second coffee maker from them. It made fine coffee, frothed good milk and did all the things a coffee maker should do. I got good crema when using good espresso coffee and had no problem with tamping or any of the other things I saw commented on in the reviews. My happiness lasted only three months and then the other issue I saw repeated again and again in the reviews occurred. The pressure stopped and I got my coffee one drip at time. First noticeable problem was that it kept hissing if left on - a seal problem I assume - then it blew coffee grounds all over the place as I released the handle one day and then, nothing. And before anyone asks, yes I cleaned it, pumped it out and all other recommended fixes to no avail. The milk still steamed but the coffee trickled. All that said, Amazon refunded my money and I have enough faith in the brand that I bought another De'Longhi which is again producing good coffee.

For the most part, this is a good machine for the price. It produces a gorgeous and delicious crema, which was high on my priority list. What I didn't like about the machine is that it is excessively noisy, a bit awkward and clumsy and the whole unit vibrates to the point that you have to watch that your cup does not move from directly beneath the espresso port, speaking of which, sits too low to be able to put a standard size cup or café receptacle (with a wider opening than an espresso cup) beneath it. The milk frother also sits too low to be able to froth a coffee mug of milk directly. I had to use a wide mouth frothing pitcher tilted sideways and the wand still didn't reach to the milk as far as I wanted. I also had to go back and make a second espresso after using the "two shot" screen, as the two shots were really only equal to one for me and my cappo was weak, although I use a good, imported Italian coffee (Lavazza). I will comment that my personal preference and standards for espresso and cappos are high because I drink them daily after living in Italy for three years. I have since been using an inexpensive Krups steam driven machine which we bought back in the 1990s (which says a lot for that machine as long as you get one with a separate setting for steam and coffee and you know how to manipulate the machine beyond the standard instructions). We have used it off and on throughout the years as we have spent much time living overseas, so it was put up during that time and we had to use a local machine for local electricity. However, as much as we have used the heck out the Krups, my husband and I have long wanted to upgrade to a pump driven machine. The DeLonghi is a good machine for the price if you are basically a weekend or occasional espresso/cappuccino drinker, or want to be the barista for friends while entertaining. I think if I got used to the machine on my daily basis it might be ok, but I prefer to eliminate the design and functional issues by finding a better machine.
reviews.review_header: Decent machine for the price if you don't need it every day

reviews.review_text: I have an older of these units that developed a leak( from pump to steamer), which I was able to fix with epoxy. In all fairness I often left the boiler turned on all day which would have weakened the plastic tube prematurely so I was happy that a little jb weld epoxy could fix the machine. , This old machine makes a very reliable cup of expresso, which is much better than a steam toy's result. However I bought another of these machine. That unit had a pump which at first vibrated toomuch,but then after 4 months of limited use(at most 2 cups a day) it got very quiet and wouldn't put out enough pressure to make a coffee(let alone espresso). It looks like DeLonghi is pretty good about providing a replacement: you pay 15$ more and send the cord in. Within a few days of my mailing them what they asked they sent a replacement. But the replacement machine, simply doesn't work anywhere as as well as the three year old machine, its just got a wimpy pump. ( i'd give the old machine 4 star, but the new one only 1.) So i end up using the old machine with a leak I expoxied and I have two unusable machines with bad pumps sitting around (one with a cord and one without)
reviews.review_header: given me good coffee but bad vibrations

reviews.review_text: I bought it to replace a Krups I have been using for 10+ years that they have stopped manufacturing. The EC155 is poorly designed and made with lightweight plastic and thin pot-metal components. There is barely 2” between the dispenser and the tray which means you have to use expresso cups as regular sized cups won’t fit, the foaming spout is spring loaded and gets in the way of inserting the filter assembly . The water container handle broke the first time I pulled it out to clean and the whole mess racks to the side when tightening the filter handle. Another irritation was the measuring spoon was missing, it does make good expresso, however the method the use to regulate the flow is once again a thin plastic valve clearly susceptible to failure. I can’t stand using this first thing in the morning so I’m’ going to treat this as a loss on the craps table and buy a better made machine.
reviews.review_header: This was the worst purchase I have made in a long time

reviews.review_text: This machine failed twice in less than a year. First, it developed a leak, and I fixed it by replacing an "O" ring inside. (I am an engineer and can fix about anything.) Later it started leaking again, and I gave up on it, replacing it with an old model Le'Longhi that my son used for several years. The first "O" ring failure was probably caused by our leaving the heater on all day. We did that to have a faster cup of coffee, but the bad "O" ring probably failed because of heat - it was near the heater. Although the part was easy to find and buy on the internet, the machine was down several days, and was about a two hour repair for me. If you already have one of these, don't leave the heater on unless you are about to make coffee.

This coffee machine is by far amazing for the money. It delivers an excellent coffee rich and bold BUT NOT bitter - tops off with a perfect crema and though you wont get a very thick froth with the steamer it's thick enough and I truly can't imagine you can get a better coffee from any other machine in this price range. WHY THE THREE STARS? The first machine broke after 3 days so i got a replacement machine and it did not work as well as the first when the first was working. I am now ordering a THIRD machine because as I said it makes EPIC coffee so fingers crossed three times the charm. I will say that amazon has made this so easy for me, it's the first time I have ever had to return anything and amazon sent me the new machine in two days and sent UPS to pick up the broken one the next day. I AM AN AMAZON FAN :-) Waiting now for my third De'Longhi and will write back.
reviews.review_header: THERE IS NO QUESTION THIS MAKES EPIC COFFEE- BUT...

reviews.review_text: OK. So there are a few things that I find rather annoying with this machine. 1: This thing vibrates like crazy. If you don't hold the cup, it will vibrate right off the machine when you are trying to make the espresso. ( This could be something wrong with the unit ) 2: The tamper ( the press you use on the coffee or espresso grinds ) is attached to the unit, it can't be removed from what I can see. This is just stupid and creates a huge mess if you try to use it because of its placement. It just makes it difficult to clean and get grinds everywhere if you use it. I have my old one from my last machine and am just using that. 3: The steamer is very low to the counter. You would almost have to put this machine up on something to get a coffee cup under it. The arm is also very very short and it's difficult to really get a good froth out of it. I had to get a small tea cup to froth the milk and I pour that into my coffee cup and then the espresso I made. So it takes 3 cups to make one drink. Silly. 4: I have had some issues with this leaking a little espresso. I made sure there was nothing blocking the rim, there grinds where not too high to get a good seal and it was in nice and tight. What I like: 1: The water pitcher is inside the unit and pulls out easily with a handle. Easy refill! Great. 2: This unit seems to heat up rather quickly. Thats all I got on the likes. ____ So Frustrated with this unit. Was really missing my espressos when my last unit broke. I'm thinking I will have to continue my hunt and end up spending a lot more money on a unit to get something better. I hoping this would be a good machine. I don't need a lot of bells and whistles. I just want a cup of espresso without a big production.

I used a very similar De'Longhi machine in Italy and loved it. This one is a bit of a let down though. It does make excellent expresso and steams milk just fine. However, the unit is shorter and doesn't have much room for cups. The height below the steamer wand will not fit a coffee mug without tipping it a lot to get under the wand. That's a problem once the milk is steamed (if you use a cup rather than a pitcher) A large steaming pitcher will not fit. Even a medium sized one is tight. Even worse, the distance between the filter holder and cup stand is minimal. You'll have to use a small (3 oz or less) mini-pitcher, a short teacup or demitasse cups to catch the expresso.
reviews.review_header: ... used a very similar De'Longhi machine in Italy and loved it. This one is a bit of a ...

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: had no cups small enough to fit under. Purchased two glass cups made for these type of machines and they were to tall and useless with this machine. Had to use a small fruit bowl and it is not worth getting burnt almost every time. I did like the ADJUSTABLE steam output which the two I have now does not offer. I Get splashed every time I go to use steam because first few seconds spit water and NOT steam so run steam and they put cup under and get splashed with how coffee everytime with the units I have NOW!
reviews.review_header: TINY TINY CUPS REQUIRED TO FIT UNDER SPOUT-EXCELLENT OPTION FOR STEAM CONTROL

reviews.review_text: This machine started out great, but after just 6 months of light use (2-3 times per week) and regular cleaning and descaling, it broke. Hot water now pours out everywhere every time, making it unusable. There's clearly a reason this thing is so cheap: it's not built to last even a year. Spend a little more and get something that is higher quality.
reviews.review_header: Broke after 6 months of light use

reviews.review_text: I'd used a Krups steam model for many years, but it finally gave up the ghost. I read multiple reviews on the De'Longhi, and decided to purchase it, primarily because it seemed to be the best "budget" model available. That said, I have been underwhelmed, though not totally surprised. Per other reviewers commentary, it is somewhat cumbersome to use if you want to make multiple shots of coffee. I like my coffee very strong and dark, and use french roast beans (the same that were used in my Krups machine). Unfortunately, I'm not able to replicate the strength and taste with this machine. It seems weaker, even when I take the time to change out the coffee for multiple shots. In addition, though not a deal breaker, it is very noisy, and has a significant vibration when the pump is engaged. There is probably another machine that would meet my needs, albeit for a much greater cash expenditure. Therefore, I'll likely try a french press next, and continue to use the De'Longhi, but rarely.
reviews.review_header: primarily because it seemed to be the best "budget" model available

reviews.review_text: It makes very good coffee. It's a simple machine & not much will go wrong, I should think. I drink up to 20 cups of espresso daily (yes, I do), so this is no small thing. My last Saeco ended up making crummy coffee with wonderful beans. But this machine does not fit right on my counter, in my limited space, which all other espresso makers have done. The steamer is on the left, the basket fits from the left, rather than the center. I usually heat milk in the microwave, so I don't actually need to use that space or remove the steam wand for cleaning. But, it is hard to place on the counter & hard to place my grinder on the counter, too: it is in the way, on either side, or behind. This is also as light as a toy & skips toward me when expressing coffee. I must keep pushing the cup back under the spigot. The booklet shows little cups warming on the top & I shudder to think how many would end in shards. I do not expect it to last a long time. I'm betting on a year at the outside. But it's easy to use & makes nice coffee. The problem is all in the design.

Had to return it after it began pulling very weak shots just after 2 weeks of use. The water came out very slowly and the coffee tasted very burnt/watery like. Thankfully Amazon allowed me to return it and I got a second one thinking that it was just bad luck, but I was wrooong!!! After 6 months of working ok it began to do the same thing!! I am not going to even try to repair it. It has fooled me twice and I am not going to fall for it a third. I am thinking buying a little more expensive espresso so I do not have to deal with this anymore. Its very frustrating...

I no longer recommend buying this machine. I've recorded my experience with this model in the paragraphs below in reverse chronology. If you read the 1-star reviews on this machine you will see that many of them are rated so due to pump failure. Of the total reviews a full 30% are rated 1-star. Update 2-13-2015: The machine purchased on 5-30-14 has failed in less than one year. I have complained to Amazon about the consistent poor quality of the pumps in this model and suggested they stop selling it. DeLonghi has offered to honor the 1-year warranty, but I would rather have a refund so that I can move on and purchase a different brand. Out of 5 machines purchased in the past 4 years, 4 have had failed pumps. Even though all but one of them essentially paid for itself before crashing,I will not purchase another one because it's become a hassle to have to return it each and every time. Despite having one machine tha t was operational for 4 years, the other 4 died of the same cause...failed pump. I'm changing my rating to 1 star because DeLonghi continues to offer this machine in light of the known fact that the pump is not reliable. They need to up their manufacturing standards. Update 5-30-2014: The machine purchased last March 2013 has failed. Again, it was the pump which has given out. I had purchased a Fair Trade Warranty, so will get refunded for the purchase price. With the money I'm buying another DeLonghi, same model. Doing the math, I figure that if I purchased a latte every day (I do drink at least one a day, sometimes two) my grande latte would cost me a minimum of $3.50 a day at my local coffee shack or $4.35 a day at Starbucks. Making my own at home costs $1.36 a day and that's with organic milk and a K-cup pod of pre-measured coffee. At the least, I am saving $781 a year by making my own with this machine. Even if I have to replace it annually at a cost of $99, plus tax, I am still money ahead. Again, this machine makes delicious lattes when it's working properly! Still 5 stars! Others have written extensive reviews on this espresso maker that I relied on to make my initial purchase. I made my original purchase in 2010. I took that machine to my office so I could make lattes there, and 3 years later it's still working. I bought a second one to use at home which stopped pumping after 18 months. As the warranty had expired, I threw it away and bought a replacement. That machine was a lemon and I sent it back to Amazon and got a replacement (same machine). The replacement works perfectly and this time I bought Square Trade warranty (about $20 for a 3-year warranty on small kitchen appliances). This machine is not perfect, but it makes delicious lattes and has paid for itself many times over again. I'll keep buying the for as long as De'Longhi makes it!
reviews.review_header: Poorly Made Machine That Won't Last

reviews.review_text: This is a great product. The steamer works very well and it makes really good espresso. I use it almost every day and haven't had any problems with it. My main complaint is the noise. It is pretty loud when brewing. Also, you have to let it heat up for a long time before using it. Overall, I really like it and would recommend it. As an update.....I've now had this product almost a year. The steamer has quit working well and the unit drips. It rattles VERY badly when brewing. I have contacted customer service and, after a lot of run around, they are sending me a new one (as soon as I cut the power cord off this one and send it in). Their customer service is friendly enough but they take FOREVER to resolve issues. I had to send my personal info several times because different people were working on the complaint and they don't lof the emails into a file for all agents to review.

Pretty disappointed with this product especially w/the rave reviews: As stated previously, there's no room to put a cup under the spout. The directions state to dry the bottom of the unit out to get rid of the standing water occasionally - No way to do that w/o turning the unit upside down for a while and letting the water drain out of the quarter size hole that opens into the heating chamber. The big thing is the quality of the espresso - I found it weak - This is after running 5 batches of water sans espresso through it as required by the directions to get it clean enough to make espresso. The directions admonish the user to use just the right amount of tamping for the perfect brew so I made the 1st cup w/light tamping and it came out pretty weak - This is using the recommended Lavazza espresso - Rechecked directions to make sure I wasn't missing a step - Good to go - So batch # 2 I tamped pretty hard - The unit had no problem pushing the steam through but the result was about the same. I pressed my old Krups steam espresso maker back into service using the same espresso, tamp pressure and water amount and the difference was massive - The espresso was much more full bodied and vibrant tasting - I'm sending the unit back. Thanks Amazon - You're Amazin', Just a word about Amazon - Me thinks most of you weren't around when back in the day Amazon was some wacko "on line" (What the heck is "on line" ??) book retailer and the creditors were knockin' at the door. They really are a company that's earned their status in the world of on line retailing - they ARE the reason we have on line retailing today and I just want to give them a shout out and say thanks for world class customer service.
1st try and it is broken. Read a lot of reviews that said this, but I was optimistic and ordered anyways.

UPDATE: This machine, which I adored, started leaking heavily in June, I've followed all the cleaning protocols and tried to fix it, but can't use it anymore. I'm saving up for a better machine. It worked well when it worked. My darling husband purchased this machine for my birthday in November. He did a ton of research and this was the best machine for the price. I love this machine. I've been spending too much money in coffee shops for espresso and now, we use it every day. It is easy to use (especially with ESE pods), easy to clean and makes delicious. I would suggest buying a tamper (the delonghi plastic tamper is stuck onto the machine) Espresso Tamper 50 & 60 Mm Sizes Cast Alloy Hand Coffee . Also, I was able to find a small milk frothing pitcher Stainless Steel 10oz. Steaming & Frothing Pitcher on Amazon which made a big difference for me with being able to froth milk etc. We also got a ESE pod sampler Espressotiamo Grand Sampler 72 ESE espresso pods which allowed us to try 30 different espresso pods. Now we just order our favorites. I don't know if I'll ever become the sort of espresso drinker who has a $400 burr grinder and a $400 machine but I love having fresh, amazing espresso every morning. I am able to make a better espresso drink than 75% of the cafes out there, and I live in Portland, Oregon, the american home of good coffee.
reviews.review_header: I love this machine! Quick and Easy! BUT STARTED LEAKING

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: Machine has worked fairly well for us, but upon deep cleaning the device today, we discover one of the electrical connectors has melted. Not sure when this happened, but it's the last time we will use the machine because it's clearly a safety issue now.

I own a DeLonghi EC140B that I purchased from Newegg a few years back for 50. I love it and thought I would take the old one to work and buy the EC155 for home. The EC155 arrived and the first irritating thing was standing water in the inlet under the tank. Testing purpose? Refurbished? Doesn't matter, I do not like water in a brand new machine. Then I spent an hour to figure out why in the world the machine would not deliver water through the boiler outlet. Yep, I let it sit with full tank for an hour and more, green light indicated it's ready. The boiler outlet is bone dry. The steamer works fine and delivers steam. There is sufficient heat and pressure. Apparently the pump is clogged or one of the two temp sensors is not working. I assume this machine uses separate valves that are controlled by two separate temp sensors (2 temp sensors according to manual). I really hoped I'd love this one too, but DOA with water in the machine? Extremely disappointed. I actually go so far and think that this was returned (standing water at inlet) and they never bothered to check why, and just repackaged it. Returning is the only option. Reading other negative reviews I rather try to get something similar at the local store next time. Update: well, after not being able to find anything decent at a similar price I decided to change refund to replacement. Replacement shipped within two days, thanks Amazon. The machine works great just like my older EC140B. Giving it 4stars and hope it lasts as long as the old one. Great espresso, cappuccino or cafe au lait - can't beat the price. Update Oct-23 2012, 1.5 years later the pump is finally giving up. On the other hand the cheaper model I purchased from Newegg is still making great Espressos at work. Now it's really time for another brand. At $80 giving good Espressos for 18 months isn't too bad I guess. I therefore have to give it a mediocre rating.
reviews.review_header: DOA - got replacement - all is good

reviews.review_text: I just updated my review, 12/6/2011. ORIGINAL REVIEW =============== I just got this 2 days ago. I drink two lattes a day, so I get regular use of it. Previously I used a Mr Coffee steam espresso maker. I didn't like the metal-alloy boiler in the Mr Coffee machine. The metal visibly deteriorates over time (2+ yr), so I am consuming whatever it is made of and I don't like the idea of that. For the price, this machine is a GREAT value. It makes real espresso, something the steam type makers don't seem capable of. Pros: -Price -Great Espresso -Great frother -Pumped, not steamed -Stainless steel boiler The only significant negative on this machine is that the space where the coffee comes out is RIDICULOUSLY! short. I have little espesso cups and they won't fit under it. I bought two shot glasses at Kroger that looked pretty standard to me. They are about 1/4 inch too tall. I am still looking for the right cups. Don't hesitate to buy this machine, but if you do you will want a couple of shot glasses that are about 2 1/2" tall, maybe even slightly less. UPDATE 11/14/2011 ================= I have experienced quality issues with the machine. Water started coming through the coffee basket whenever the heat was turned on, preheat and steam modes. It is not enough to make it unusable, but is a significant amount. I contacted Delonghi support and they are replacing it, but what a hassle. I have to cut the cord off and mail the cord to them, with a $15 check. The worse part is, I can no longer use the old machine, so... Not sure I'd buy again if I knew it would be this poor quality. As a result, I changed my rating from 4 stars to 3. UPDATE 12/6/2011 ================ I got the new macine via mail on 12/3. After a couple weeks of waiting for the replacement, I checked to see if my check had cleared. It had cleared about a week earlier, so I sent an e-mail to DeLonghi asking when I was going to receive the replacement, noting that I knew my check had cleared. I don't know if it is coincidence or not, but the replacement shipped the same day I sent the e-mail. Hmmm. So, if you have warranty issues with this machine, it will cost you about $20 to get it replaced under warranty (their $15 fee, and postage to return the cord to them). You will be without your machine for three weeks (per my experience). Maybe it is not worth the hassle. I do still enjoy the espresso it makes.

This is a lemon: it produces weak coffee and watered down cappuccinos. I am using Illy caffe', i tried to switch to lavazza. I tried to pack on a lot of coffee... not effective. i am hoping to be able to return it because it is a waste of money and time. Not recommended.

Was very excited to upgrade to something that received so many positive reviews. Sadly, I did not have the same experience as others. My main issue is that I cant get a decent espresso out of it. I have tried grinding the coffee from fine, to coarse... no luck there. I tied using filtered water, that didn't help. I even have giving it time, as some of the reviews mentioned it would get better, no dice. At the end of the day, I get a week espresso. The milk frothier is the only thing that really works great, but even that is weird. I do clean the wand everyday, but the recommended is much more infrequent than that. I wouldn't recommend this product to anyone. In fact, I'm not sure I will even goodwill the one I have as I don't want to pass along the issue to someone else.

I purchased this machine in June of 2015. It was replaced early this year under warranty - the wand started leaking steam and water every time it was used. I had long since purchased a frother and had been using that instead. The replacement machine has developed the same problem despite never having used the steam wand. I will try to cap it with duct tape or some similar measure. On the other hand, the machine makes great espresso. I use it every day.
reviews.review_header: the machine makes great espresso. I use it every day

reviews.review_text: Fine for espresso. The frothing attachment works "OK" but could be much better. For a cheap machine, does the job, no frills, nothing to rave about. This machine only made it 6 months and 25 days, then the pump died. Attempting to get warranty repair. Will post updates.
reviews.review_header: Does the job... until it doesn't. Short life span.

reviews.review_text: Don't buy this. I spent good money on this and not long after the return time was up it started leaking. I contacted customer support at DeLonghi after I did all of the trouble shooting in the owners manual and they just wanted me to call them and do more. I changed the gasket out and everything, still leaking. I learned my lesson the hard way.
reviews.review_header: Do Not Buy, Will Leak, Terrible Customer Service

reviews.review_text: NOT enough wattage to pump sufficiently, espresso is so-so. The tamper is a joke, you don't tamp up, you tamp down to make a puck. The frothing wand is almost useless unless you use a very short vessel for the milk. The machine is noisy and vibrates terribly. Water tank is too small if making multiple cappuccinos. It went back by day three. I replaced with a Melitta model: 40791, which Amazon also sells, you can see my review of it I just finished. The Mellita is FAR FAR superior to the De'Longhi for a variety of reasons: higher wattage, long frothing wand, quiet, heavier, LARGE exterior water tank - a better quality machine all around. The only thing I didn't care for on the Melitta was the tamper, it was plastic but most machines don't come with a good tamper so I wasn't surprised. I purchased a $15 stainless steel tamp from Amazon as well.

I loved this machine the first month I had it. I especially loved making hot chocolates with it. I was in the process of learning how to pull a perfect espresso, and hadn't quite perfected it yet, when the pump just stopped working. This was only after about 15 espressos, less than a month old. The steamer works still, but I can no longer make espressos. I did all the suggestions the manual stated, and my husband actually took it apart to see if he could fix it, only to determine the pump was broken. Unfortunately, I can't recommend this to anyone.
reviews.review_header: I loved this machine the first month I had it

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I should hav spent a little bit extra to get better quality. I work at starbucks so I hav experience with these machines.The machine itself serves its purpose ....BUT the steam wand is horrible.the worst.the machine is so short tht u hav to essentially lift the whole thing to use a steam pitcher at all. The wand keeps moving toward the center of the machine while u r steaming so if u try to move it back, u burn urself a lot.dangerous.this machine will not even fit standard shot glasses underneath without having to move the drip plate.dnt waste ur money.I hav used this for months now and already want to upgrade.for the price, its ok.but not worth the aggravation.

If you're looking for an entry-level/inexpensive way to make espressos, keep looking. We've been through two of these now, and will never buy a De'Longhi branded product again. The first one made it a year before developing a leak on the bottom whenever you'd run it. By then we were out of warranty, so it would've cost more than it was worth to repair it. The second one(exact same model) we bought at a local Target, and it only made it 6 months! The problem with the second one is that boiler seems unable to maintain enough pressure to push water through the coffee grounds. We ONLY ever used distilled water, and cleaned all parts and reservoir with espresso machine cleaner! I was able to get another week of use out of the second one after spending over 2 hours running cleaning and then rinsing cycles through the boiler, but now it's stopped working again. Don't say I didn't warn you! Do not buy!
reviews.review_header: Avoid! Will break in less then a year!

reviews.review_text: Unsafe, overly complex unusable. I just tried it for the first time and it's construction is totally flawed. Takes forever to make espresso when all you want to do in the morning is get it done now. You can't get your cup under the coffee filter and it overflows every time.

I've had mine less than 6 months and it constantly spews water constantly using over 10 oz of water for one shot of espresso. I've cleaned it numerous times per manufacturing process and it still takes about ten minutes to make a double shot. it worked great for about three months and then went down hill fast. I should have gone with a different one.
reviews.review_header: it worked great for about three months and then went down hill ...

reviews.review_text: The filter holder leaks water into the espresso, no matter how many times I adjust it, tighten it, etc. and I have only had this machine a couple weeks. It has leaked from the get go, making the espresso quite watery. I was looking for a simple lil machine, which it is, but the leaking water makes it a bust. I tossed the box so cannot send it back - I'm out $70 - I would NOT recommend purchasing this machine whatsoever.
reviews.review_header: I tossed the box so cannot send it back - I'm out $70 - I would NOT recommend purchasing this machine whatsoever

reviews.review_text: It's okay. I like that it's small and doesn't take up much space. However, your container that the espresso drips into better be tiny. We have to remove the silver tray and jump through some hoops to fit our old one in there. I considered returning it because of this but didn't want the hassle. It does make tasty espresso.
reviews.review_header: Needs TINY mug/espresso container to fit under spout.

reviews.review_text: Buyer beware, I have only had this espresso maker for less than 4 months and the milk steamer no longer works. I am now out of the return window. I am out of hundred bucks and not happy. I cannot recommend this espresso maker. I bought this for the milk frother / steamer as I already have the moka espresso maker, which I love for it's simplicity. I should have listen to my better judgement, paid less and purchased just an actual milk steamer, which I am off to do now. argh.
reviews.review_header: Steamer / Frother stopped working after only FOUR MONTHS of very minimal use....Buyer beware

reviews.review_text: I've been quite pleased with this little machine for the 3.5 years I've owned it, especially considering its very moderate price. Other reviewers have covered its strengths and weaknesses very well. Over the last several months, however, it started leaking more and more severely. Water began pooling on the counter under the machine, at first intermittently, later after every use. Eventually water began to drip from the plastic case around the group head (not through the group head). I figured I would need to replace the machine, but I thought I'd try to open it up and see if it could be repaired easily. I'm sharing my experience here in case it might help anyone else, but should you follow these instructions you do so AT YOUR OWN RISK and please BE CAREFUL! To open the machine, I removed the four screws holding the top panel, two from under the cover and two from under the front edge; I also loosened the steam control knob and used a knife to pry it up and off the machine. The top panel and rear cover can then be removed. Turning on the pump, I immediately noticed water dripping and squirting out of the connection between the boiler unit and the hose coming from the pump unit. The hose is held on with a small clip, easily removed with needle-nose pliers. Removing the hose revealed a small o-ring on the end. (The o-ring might not come out with the hose, in which case you'll need to use tweezers (or something similar) to remove it from the boiler connection point.) On closer examination I could see that the o-ring had split and failed. Some searching online showed that I needed DeLonghi replacement part number 5313217701, which I ordered at minimal expense. Upon receiving the replacement o-ring, I slipped it over the end of the hose and used needle-nose pliers to push the hose + o-ring fully into the connection point; the new o-ring was larger than the old one so it took quite a bit of pressure to seat the hose + o-ring all the way into the connection point, inserting the tip of the pliers into the connection opening to push the hose deeper. Once it was in all the way, I could reattach the clip to hold the hose in place. Turning on the pump, I saw no more leaking and reassembled the machine. It's back to working as well as it ever did! I'm glad I was able to make a cheap repair to the machine, nonetheless the leaks I experienced, and reading similar reports by others, does make me question DeLonghi's reliability. Accordingly, I'm reducing my rating to 3 stars from the 4 star rating I would have given otherwise. I've posted some customer images showing the interior of the machine and the hose with failed o-ring, so please have a look for them.
reviews.review_header: Started leaking after 3 years, repaired it myself

reviews.review_text: I bought this machine for my mom, but should have sent it back.. All and all, if you are looking to but an express machine, spend a few more dollars and get a better one, this one is nothing but a pain, to brew one shot of expresso you have to stop the brewing at least 3 times and wait for the light to turn green again. The frothing arm is always in the way and stays directly under the brewer unless you hold it. The frothing feature is also very difficult to use, I never could figure it out, my mom did, so it does work but is defiantly not user friendly.. I ended up with De'Longhi ECP3420 and would recommend spending a few dollars more for it.
reviews.review_header: spend a few more dollars and get a better one, this one is nothing but a pain

reviews.review_text: I read the reviews, looked at the number of people who bought this, and took the plunge. (Actually just stepped into the puddle given the cost). Not disappointed at all. Was considering spending three times this amount to assure quality but now I am glad I didn't. Works great every time, 4 shots every morning for two months or more. Great coffee, no problem with the finest grind on my burr grinder. Lovely crema every time. It's already paid for itself. PS: Well,,.. A year is up and the pump has gone out. Okay, I got 2 - 4 shots a day for most of a year at roughly the cost of 2 lattes per month. So, I really don't have room for complaint, but I wish it had lasted longer. Made great espresso while it worked. I just think it should last longer than a year.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: It offers the 15 Bar Pump technology at an extremely low price. However, it feels cheap and not particularly solid. I got it today, it felt plastic and cheap. It vibrated loudly and the steamer function did not work properly. I packed it up and got a return authorization. Look, if you don't want to spend a lot of money and just want a "starter" machine to see if you will use it enough to later buy a solidly made "Metal" model, I'd recommend this because let's face it, it's less than the cost of a dinner date. But I have 2 friends with "Metal" and solid expresso machines and this one felt and looked cheap compared to theirs. For instance, the handle that you put the expresso into, did not fit smoothly or properly twist into place (as my friends models do). Now the "solid" machines will run you $300 - $500 (minimum), so it is not a bad idea to buy a machine like this to see it you would use it enough to justify a larger investment (kind of like buying a Kindle Fire before buying an iPad). So although my initial experience was not good, I do see this machine as being the right choice for a large number of people. Let's face it, we all have received or purchased small appliances (Juicer anyone? Bread Maker? Rice Cooker? Pasta Maker? Slow Cooker?) that we end up never using!
reviews.review_header: It is inexpensive for the Technology - But Feels Cheap

reviews.review_text: I really enjoyed this little machine while it worked. I've had it for about a year and a half and tend to use it almost every day, with no problems for the first year. But in the last couple of months it started leaking very badly, and then today it just screamed and started spewing steam. How unfortunate. I will miss it.
reviews.review_header: I really enjoyed this little machine while it worked

reviews.review_text: This is not my first experience with a De'Longhi espresso/cappuccino maker. A few years ago we purchased a two-in-one (coffee maker/cappuccino maker). At around two years the coffee maker stopped working but the cappuccino maker side of the machine kept going strong. We replaced the coffee maker a long time ago but had this giant machine with only one component working on our counter. We decided to go with another De'Longhi for the espresso maker. The components are all similar to the previous one we had, all except the frother that is. The wand on our other machine was long and slender and came off very easily, whereas the one on this system is short and wide and needs to be unscrewed. We have tried daily for two weeks to get the frother to work thinking it may be operator error. We have called the mfg. and checked youtube to see if there is something we should or shouldn't be doing. The closest I have come is a little bit of foam but mostly it's a latte. Also this machine gets way too hot when frothing the milk, the milk starts to boil which the mfg. said they never hear of, the always hear that the milk stays cold. Since we've seen people produce foam on youtube our consensus is that we got a lemon and just got a faulty one. I had no issues at all with the espresso portion of the machine. The tamper really isn't the best, but I've used the same tamper on my old system so I've figured out how to use this over the years and get great espresso w/creama. As other reviewers have said, the espresso you buy really is essential. I have no issues with that aspect of the system, but I do not want to buy a separate frother for cappuccinos.

This is an update to my original review below. After running about 30 singles through the machine, the noise has been dramaticaly reduced. Apparently there was some air trapped in the system that caused it to run loudly. That worked itself out after about 15 shots and now the sound is a simple buzz as it should be. Also I can now fully move the handle to the correct position where I get the optimum pressure. I'm guessing it took a while for this part to get broken in to where the gasket could be fully compressed. I'm still not 100% happy with the short steam tube, but I've gotten a larger 20 oz frothing cup and this allows me to tilt it 45 degrees and not worry about spilling any milk. If I could, I would rate this at 4 stars, with one star off for the unit arriving with a broken lid hinge. Original review: I received what appeared to be a new unit, although it had residual water inside of it. Perhaps the boiler was tested before leaving the factory. The top cover was broken at the hinge, so it can't be flipped back, but it comes off completely. There is no way to fix this. I suspect that every unit will have a broken lid in a matter of weeks. The hinge is poorly designed with two 1 mm long nibs holding the heavy lid on. Once one of the nibs breaks off, the lid won't stay on at the hinge. The filter holder does not fit tightly enough unless you put on so much force that you think you are going to break the machine. If you don't force it, water will leak down the handle. You need to grasp the coffeemaker tightly with one arm like a football and use your other hand to force on the filter, otherwise the unit will leak. Even with extreme force on the handle, I can't get it to line up the 2 filter outlet holes with the drip basin on the bottom. It also means that if I use 2 cups, I have to align them very carefully at an unusual angle. I am thinking that something was not assembled correctly on this unit, but I didn't bother to look at it carefully to see if it can be fixed/realigned. The machine is very loud. I'm not sure why it is as loud as it is, but you have to yell to talk to someone standing next to you. The frother is poorly designed and will not take a standard sized frothing cup unless you tilt it at an angle so that you can only froth to half the depth of the cup. I also wish the frother was on the opposite side since it gets in the way when trying to lock on the filter cup. In all, I'm disappointed, but then this is a low end machine so you can't expect perfection. The fact that it was broken from out of the box is annoying, but I doubt there is very good quality control at the factory in China and no one wants to pull a unit off the line for a broken hinge. However, I will not buy another DeLonghi product because this is not a good sign of quality. Yes, it does do what it is supposed to do, just with more complications, noise, and mess than one would expect.
reviews.review_header: Less than perfect (better after first week)

reviews.review_text: I was so excited to get my very first espresso machine. Because of the price, I wasn't expecting it to work as well as some of the more expensive models, but it didn't work at all! I got a defective unit, and when it came out of box, I noticed a peculiar condensation coating the inside of the plastic. My first thought was that maybe it was actually a used/refurbished model, and they'd tried to pawn it off as new. It was a LOT of water. The box it had come in wasn't damp either, so I doubted that it accumulated during shipping. Basically, the steam wand worked, but no water would come out when I switched the knob to the "espresso/coffee" setting to pull the espresso shots. The pump ran and ran, but no water would come out. I am really disappointed. Delonghi was professional about servicing my complaint and offered to send me a new unit as long as I cut the electrical cord from the old one and send it to them as proof, although I must confess I am somewhat skeptical about the quality of the manufacturing. I may try and return it with Amazon and select a different machine.
reviews.review_header: I am really disappointed. Delonghi was professional about servicing my complaint and ...

reviews.review_text: I think this maker makes a good espresso. It provides a lot of "crema" on the top without any difficulty. I do not use the press on the side as it seems awkward, instead I use a hand presser. I do not use the steamer often. Does not seem you can get a frother mug underneath easily. Several drawbacks, one mentioned in other reviews is the low height (~2 1/2") of the cup which can be used underneath. I know it's not a coffee maker and is probably designed for a demitasse only. A second drawback is the vibration of the machine when the pump is on. When I first used the machine I could not figure out what all the noise was. Some silverware about 2 feet away on the counter were clanking and the cup on the maker vibrated off the stand. The vibration is most significant before the espresso starts coming from the maker. Need to cushion under the cup. A third drawback was the temperature of the espresso. After thinking the espresso did not seem very hot, I took an instant read digital kitchen thermometer to take temp. With the water coming out directly from the machine without using grounds, the temp barely reached 160F. This does not seem hot enough. Difficult to rate. While espresso was fine, other issues are of an annoyance. Issues, I think, should not be part of a properly designed product.

This little guy lasted about two years before breaking (it won't push water out of the basket)... I'm not sure how much of that is to blame on me or on the actual espresso maker, as this is the first one I've owned. It was great when it worked, but I wish it would've lasted longer.
reviews.review_header: It was great when it worked

reviews.review_text: I have had three of these and they work well until they don't. After about one year of use, the pump dies and you are no longer making espresso. Oh it will make a cup of thin, weak drip coffee with no crema but not espresso. The replacement pump does not seem to be available and if it were it would be more than half the price of a new machine. Now I have one working machine and two seriously sad hulks taking up closet space.
reviews.review_header: Machine OK but Pump is Junk!

reviews.review_text: I was really excited about the reviews on this espresso machine, but unfortunately the real thing has been a bit underwhelming. First, it does make espresso, it can froth milk. The rattling, noise, and awkward spacing of this machine make that process pretty unenchanting though; I don't really enjoy making my lattes, and to me that's an important part of the process. I wanted to step up from a Mr Coffee to have real espresso, but the cup rattling, fact that I have to remove the bottom plate to awkwardly fit my espresso cup, and shoddy milk frother that is too short, too noisy, and too unreliable make making a latte a fairly unpleasant process. IMO, you're better off going with the cheaper Mr Coffee that doesn't make true espresso or going up for a better espresso maker if you want a real experience. The downsides of this machine don't really make creating a morning latte that enchanting of a ritual. HOWEVER, if all you want is a nice cup of true espresso this is for you.
reviews.review_header: Can get the job done, but downsides make it fairly unenchanting

reviews.review_text: Here's the problem...I buy one of these (or the retro version, which looks better) every 6 to 8 months. The retro version has never lasted more than 6 months, but this version lasted 8 months. Why do I keep buying them? I do not know what else to do. While they work, they make GREAT espresso and cappuccino. The price still beats Starbucks or other possibilities. But, make no mistake, the pumps just seem to wear out. I have done all the correct cleaning and care stuff. I do not believe ANY of the reviews stating that their units have lasted for years. The DeLonghi machines do not last. But, I have tried several other brands, and their definition of espresso or cappuccino is not mine. I just ordered another DeLonghi. I guess I could buy the warranty, but it takes WEEKS to send it to their prescribed repair locations...then more WEEKS to get it back, only to find that it still does not work. I have done that. In spite of the Italian name, I think these are made in China. Who cares. Built-in obsolescence. We have taught them too well.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I am familiar with this type of machines, and De Longhi makes good quality appliances. I like that I can use either ground coffee of my choice, or Ese pods and it makes a very good creamy espresso. However the milk frothier doesn't work properly. The plastic nozzle doesn't seal when screwed back into the steaming pipe, causing steam to leak from the upper part of the nozzle. The milk warmed up but didn't double up in size or make foam as it is supposed to do. The purpose of owning this machine is to make a good cappuccino for breakfast, but that is not possible. I think that it is a design flaw that has been corrected in newer machines.
reviews.review_header: and De Longhi makes good quality appliances

reviews.review_text: Have had this for a few days now and it makes a good cup of espresso but my biggest gripes with it are 1) it vibrates badly so much so that it ruins the joy of making the espresso. I had another "mini" espresso maker years ago that was all stainless steel and much heavier base -- that did not have this problem. I will probably mess around with finding a base that I can put this on that will dampen the vibrations.

I am returning this item for multiple issues. (1st item I have ever returned). 1. Instructions indicate you need to wait 1/2 hour for the water to come to temperature before brewing, a long time to wait. There is a method for a quicker cup that involves cycling the unit from the dispense and heat modes multiple times. However, even with the 1/2 wait time, it does not produce enough coffee without reheating for two cafe' cups without going to reheat cycle. (My Keurig can heat a 16 oz cup at a time with no problem.) 2. The unit vibrates when dispensing to the point you must hold the cups in place in order to keep them centered under the dispensing spouts. 3. As noted in other reviews, the foamer is too low for a standard foaming cup. A minor item, but "just another brick in the wall". Could not get the milk hot resulting in a luke-warm cappuccino. Disappointed considering the reviews the unit has received.
reviews.review_header: Disappointed considering the reviews the unit has received

reviews.review_text: When I purchased this espresso machine it was great except for it's relatively moderate/high vibration. After approximately 8 months of use; it began having moderate to major problems. The machine has been leaking water for several months from multiple areas and just recently the water began leaking & spilling out everywhere throughout the entire machine. I'm hoping De'Longhi will fix or replace this defective Item. I've owned a De"Longhi espresso machine in the past, prior to this purchase and never experienced any problems. However, I'm unhappy with this purchase and defective item.
reviews.review_header: When I purchased this espresso machine it was great except for it's relatively moderate/high vibration

reviews.review_text: I have used this machine for almost 3 years of near-daily use. Landed back on this page because now my espresso comes out ridiculously slow (drips to a full shot over 4 minutes) and comes out looking more like drip coffee. Considering buying this unit again since i am familiar and its one of the only units within this price range.
reviews.review_header: Lasted ~3 years, not bad i guess

reviews.review_text: I got this a couple of months ago and am very unhappy about the unit. The pumps vibration can make your cup to shift away from the dripping coffee and you can start over. I fixed the problem by sticking two furniture felts to the bottom on the front, so the cup will slide to the back. I don't know if the pump is getting weaker or what the problem is, but the coffee is now just dripping and it takes for ever to make me an espresso, I don't even wanna talking about a whole cup of coffee. This is good for you, if you are NOT a coffee drinker, but want one in case you have 1 guest that wants a cup. I had to leave my 4 dinner guest all by themselves for over 5 minutes to make them espresso. then every minute or so, I walked out there with one cup to the amusement of the group.... I thought De'Longhi was a good brand, how wrong can one be.

Bought this unit May-2015, I use it a lot , like 5 of 7 days. It just died 2 days ago. Is that good usage for a $85 machine? The expresso it made was perfect until 2-3 weeks ago, then I noticed it lack of froth.
reviews.review_header: I’d give it 4 stars but lasted just 2 years and 4 months.

reviews.review_text: This product was defective upon arrival. I had some similar issues to others: when I opened the product, the inside of the bag was wet, which didn't make sense. When I turned the heater on, steam and hot water would spew out of the filter holder if the filter was not attached.
