reviews.review_text: Bought this espresso machine about 10 months ago. When all of a sudden it stopped working. I called Delonghi to figure out what to do with it, and all the did was give me steps to descale the machine, even though it was still under warranty. They would not exchange it or fix it or anything. I gave up and simply threw it away. Machine makes good coffee but we surprisingly had a bad experience with the brand

Machine is very small and doesn't turn itself off when a shots worth (or two shots) of espresso has finished brewing. Have to constantly keep an eye on it, which isn't easy because the spout is so close to the platform where the cup (which has to be very small) sits. Can only use a 12oz. frothing pitcher because anything larger won't fit under the steam wand. If you want to make a larger beverage (anything larger than a small) you'll have to brew/steam twice. I highly recommend investing more money in a better machine that isn't going to be such a headache.
reviews.review_header: which isn't easy because the spout is so close to the platform ...

reviews.review_text: I was excited to get my new De'Longhi Espresso machine as the pump on the DeLonghi we had been using finally went out after several years of solid use. I chose the De'Longhi EC155 as in appearance it was the closest to our older discontinued model. It had been rated 4 stars and I thought it would be fine. I wish I had read the 1 & 2 star reviews and not just looked at how many stars. When I first opened the box I was shocked to find water inside the bag that the espresso maker was in. I should have sent it back then but I decided to try it out anyway. I started out by going through the manual and cleaning it (making espresso drinks with no coffee as the manual puts it). Lots of steam poured out from somewhere near the filter basket. There was enough steam to obscure most of the front of the unit from my sight. The steam was not coming from the steaming wand. The Espresso never got any crema on any of the shots I pulled. Finally I looked at all the reviews (on other sites too) of the product and found people saying that if you followed some convoluted procedures that you could get some crema on your shots. I was never able to duplicate their apparent results so back in the box it went.

Our old steam pressure espresso maker was giving out at 20 years old and I thought this highly rated model would replace it. It does produce better creama and the milk foamer is certainly an improvement. But the twist valve that sends steam to the foamer doesn't close tight enough and it drips hot water all the time the unit is on. Warning, the coffee wasn't as hot as with our older, cheaper maker. The instructions ask that the unit be turned on 45 minutes before you make espresso and that is a big ask when you are getting ready for work. Also with the dripping foamer you lose a lot of water while waiting. We generally let it warm up about 10 to 15 minutes. I wish our old Salton model was available - I'd buy it in a heart beat.

I purchased this machine and the first one that shipped to me was defective. The steam wand was pushed way over into the middle and would not stay off to the side. The filter holder was constructed incorrectly and rather than pointing straight out when in position was at a 45 degree angle to the left. I watched some videos on how to use it and noticed others' didn't look like that. I called the manufacturer and they told me to cut the cord and send it back based on defects. I returned to Amazon and was shipped a new one within two days. While this one has similar defects, they are not as pronounced so I decided to try it. Everything seemed to be working - I put the water in, warmed up the machine, put the coffee in and tamped it down, secured the filter holder, turned the knob to coffee and NO COFFEE - just the sound. I am so frustrated. Even the frother stopped working when I tested it before milk was actually frothed.
Too noisy--This machine makes too much noise!!! Not only that but you need to pre-heat for 15 mins--Do they now the meaning of espresso?? Going back

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I bought the DeLonghi EC 155 15 and had it for 5 days only before I returned it. Out of the box the product is well finished and has a sturdy appearance. Instructions are somewhat long but overall use of the machine is not very difficult, except for the confusing Steam valve on top, which you would expect only works when the device is set to steam, but it actually can work virtually on any setting as long as the machine is on, and one must keep it in the closed position. I bought the espresso maker to make my own coffee at home with quality flavor and finesse. The machine delivers quality espresso, nice crema, at the right temperature and with a few tries, anyone should be able to make coffee with consistent great taste. The disappointment came only after using it a couple of times: 1. the height between the espresso pump and the cup holding area is too short. I couldn't possibly place any of my china's cups, and it a standard corelle, so all the cups are fairly small. I had to get a espresso set that would fit those narrow limits. Then, as soon as you switch the machine to pump water, the vibration and noise that hard that the cups move out of place, and the coffee would be lost! I had to manually hold the cups until full so the vibration would not move them. I got burned by a the hot spurt while learning this feat. Then I tried making cappuccino: The steam nozzle is fast and effective, it will heat up your milk and create good foam. However, it is quite short for which you can't use a deep jug, and whatever you use, will have to be fairly full before you start. Since it is so short it is hard to keep control over it and the foam overflowed every time leaving me with the mess. I have learned my lesson. My next coffee maker will have to accomodate most of my cups, not vibrate so much and have a longer steam nozzle!

We read the reviews about how great this espresso machine is and the price was in our range, so we made the purchase. We really liked this machine, except it only lasted one year. BUMMER! Would probably pay more for something that would endure the multi-day use.
reviews.review_header: Liked it - but only lasted a year.

reviews.review_text: The unit is so unreliable. I'm convinced that you simply get what you pay for. This is my 3rd try with this machine. The first put out a beautiful cup of espresso about 2/3 of the time, but I'd not used distilled water and ours is very hard, so I blamed its early demise on that (8 months). The second delivered a good cup/thick crema only about 1/3 of the time, in spite of my very careful attention to warming, tamping, cleaning, grind, and water (distilled this time, only.) I finally returned it (the cut cord is what was required, and plenty of correspondence) and received a new one in the mail a couple of days ago. It appears that this one will be able to deliver a good cup with good crema about 1/3 of the time, also, although I'm certainly willing to persevere, as a really good cup is to die for. Maybe the technology is just not there yet. I am so consistent with the way in which I prepare the machine, coffee, etc., I can't imagine why there is such a variation in the final product.
reviews.review_header: About every 7th cup has a good crema.

reviews.review_text: If you are looking to make really espressos, I would not recommend. You really have to get into the more expensive machines. I ended up taking the plunge and buying a Breville. As a cheaper alternative I recommend the Wacaco portable maker. It does a much better job than cheap electric pumps:http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00VTA9F6U?ref_=cm_rdp_product
reviews.review_header: I would not recommend. You really have to get into the more ...

reviews.review_text: This espresso maker made exactly 6 cups of espresso before it stopped heating sufficiently. The water comes out luke warm. I was out of town for awhile due to a death in the family and did not get to try it out during the return period. I am now stuck with a piece of junk. It foams well, but is not nearly strong enough due to a lack of temperature. If I use it, I then Have to microwave the espresso to get it hot. I WOULD DEFINITELY NOT RECOMMEND THIS PRODUCT!
reviews.review_header: DOES NOT HEAT WELL. WILL NOT RECOMMEND

reviews.review_text: Works reasonably well, and quickly. Cream is nominal or barely produced. Steaming wand doesn't seal completely when not in use, so you get some hissing and dripping, but that's a pretty standard complaint with less expensive models. Bottom line is that, at this price point, there's not a lot to gripe about. Does the job and is probably comparable to many offered at twice the price.

The DeLonghi works well for small amounts of coffee. It does not come with cups and finding ones small enough was difficult. Update:- purchased February 2017 pump broke and machine unusable August 2017.
reviews.review_header: The DeLonghi works well for small amounts of coffee. ...

reviews.review_text: Used this for 8 months of weekend usage (maybe 50 times) before the pump and basket gasket both went out. This thing is a total piece of crap. The body is cheap plastic that contorts when you lock the basket in place. This unit replaced a 3yo Cusinart EM100 which produced far better crema than this and could actually brew a double shot. There is no way that this thing hits 15 bar; the cheap vibratory motor can perhaps get 7 bar. This machine can barely pour a single shot before having to stop and heat up again. Many folks put price as a pro, but my money would have been better spent with a better machine. I will never buy from this manufacturer again; I had to put one star because there is no zero.

I purchased this machine several years ago and was very impressed with it. That first machine was excellent - the second one is horrible. It has been nothing but trouble from the beginning and completely stopped working at the one year mark. My advise - try a different machine. March - 2018. I received the third machine as a gift. It worked for almost a year. Buy a different brand- or at least a different machine. This one is crap
reviews.review_header: That first machine was excellent - the second one is horrible

reviews.review_text: I've been using a larger heavier metal cuisinart one for the last month that I got free, had a broken steam wand. I like the feel of that unit better than this, I'd estimate it was somewhere between 200-300 for that one new. This delonghi unit is mostly plastic as the picture shows, has a slight cheap feel to it (well it is $80) but it's functional and makes a fine esspresso the same or maybe better than the more expensive older unit I was using. PROS: -Makes good espressos fast -Steam wand works fine -It just works, make delicous capacinos! -inexpensive CONS: -Drip unit is low, doesnt' fit normal size coffee cups underneath, must use shot glass cups or very low profile ones -Machine is lightweight with a lot of plastic, therefore it vibrates the whole unit and shot glass cup will vibrate out of place, just need to hold it in place for 3-4 seconds while it fills up... -would be nice if water reservoir was at least 50% larger, no big deal though! -seems like it will probably last a long time -Steam wand is short, must angle a cup to submerge wand for froth, but it still gets the job done easily I think it's growing on me the more I use it though. I've only used it a couple times so far. All in all if I could easily return or start over I'd probably get the $160 unit with similar reviews, just for the solid feeling, with less vibrating/moving cups. It's cheap enough where I can replace in a year and sell on CL for 20-25 next year anyways! Good for a starter unit until you start to crave the extra bells and whistles as usually happens over time. 3 1/2 stars, close to 4

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: This is my third De'Longhi EC155 (if you count the warranty replacement on my first purchase). My first machine started developing "leaks" from the steam wand within the first year of purchase. In addition, I found that the machine had problems developing enough pressure to push water through some of the more finely ground coffees such as Illy. With a little extra effort on my side, De'Longhi eventually responded to my inquiries and replaced my machine with a new one. I had some of the same issues with the second machine, but learned to work around the short comings and only use the more coarsely ground espresso brands such as Cafe Bustello. After about a year or so of regular high volume use (at least two double shots a day) the pump finally gave out and was unable to create enough pressure for even the more coarse grinds. I shopped around for awhile, and eventually ended up buying another EC155 since I knew it made good coffee and was relatively inexpensive. I will summarize the Pros and Cons and a few observations: Pros: - This machine is easy to use and makes good espresso with a nice crema layer - The steam mechanism works well enough and with some practice makes a decent latte or cappuccino - You can get this machine for between $70 & $80 if you wait for a sale - The footprint of this machine is pretty small - does not consume much counter top space - The machine is easy to clean and maintain. - Once contacted, De'Longhi was good about replacing the machine. Cons: - As noted above, and in other reviews, the pumps on these machines seem to have a fairly limited life cycle - Although I don't have any leak issues with the current machine, it still seems to struggle if the grind is too fine, limiting me to using Bustello or LaLave - The machine seems to have a fairly limited life cycle. Putting all of these issues aside, I decided for now that this was still the best machine for me to purchase. From reading reviews on other more expensive machines it sounded like many of them had issues as well, especially with pump life (and were sometimes difficult or expensive to repair). I am also willing to admit that I may not have cleaned my machines as routinely as necessary to avoid the issue with the pump. With that said, I still recommend this machine but with some reservations. I would also recommend the Krups XS5020 SST Frothing Pitcher due to it's low profile in order to fit under the wand. You can also purchase inexpensive tampers and thermometers on Amazon that definitely do the job. Just be careful not to under tamp (too much crema) or over tamp (to much pressure required). I will update this review once I have more history with my current machine.
reviews.review_header: Some Issues But Makes Good Espresso

reviews.review_text: I purchased this machine about a year ago based on the many positive reviews and reasonable price. Had I written a review anytime in the first 10 months of owning it I would be giving it 5 stars as it produced an excellent cup of espresso and seemed like a complete bargain. But then after around 11 months of regular use it wasn't making great espresso anymore. The unit had been cleaned and descaled regularly according to the directions but took much longer to pump out a cup and wasn't producing much crema anymore. This progressed quickly to it taking a very long time to make a poor cup with no cream whatsoever. At that point I read through all the reviews in more depth than I had originally and found out that this is a very common problem. If you actually use the machine a lot you will be lucky to get a year out of it before the pump fails. At that point I was happy to still be under warranty and contacted De'Longhi customer service. After a couple of emails back and forth with them to confirm I had serviced the machine properly they agreed to replace it. As instructed I sent them the power cord, my receipt and $15 (almost 20% of what I paid for the unit in the first place). They told me a replacement unit would be released for shipping when they received my power cord and check. They did cash the check promptly, but after a month I had still not received the replacement machine. Since I had received no communication from them at this point I sent a query as to the status of my replacement. After about a week I received a reply stating that they were sorry but the unit is on backorder and they will ship me one as soon as possible. Another 10 days have since gone by with no replacement or further communication. So there is a reason this machine is so much cheaper than anything else out there that makes decent espresso - it's not built to last. It still might be a bargain if you only use it on weekends or consider $80 a year cheap compared to Starbucks, but if you use it frequently expect to replace it every year. And then there is the customer service. It's unacceptable to me for a company to advertise a 1 year warranty, then take months (if ever) to actually make good on it. I see these are available for immediate shipping on Amazon, if De'Longhi cared to keep me happy they could order one of these or offer to refund my purchase price so that I can. When I replace this unit with a pricier one that has a longer lifespan I will be hard pressed to buy a De'Longhi.
reviews.review_header: Short life span and poor customer service

reviews.review_text: Pros: -Dual temperature (no burnt shots. Can pull as many shots as necessary without burning the espresso) -Great foam -The removable parts come apart to clean easily -Overall: Makes a great latte Cons: -It takes a long time to heat the water to make espresso -low clearances for both the espresso (I have to remove the metal tray to fit a 2.5 in cup under the filter holder) and the steam wand (I have to line up the machine sideways along the edge of my counter in order to have enough clearance for my 2 cup measuring cup to fit under it.) -It vigorously vibrates to the point that I have to readjust the expresso cup to keep it in place and make sure the whole machine doesn't walk itself of the counter. Overall: I like it, it does the job decently; but if I had the money for a nicer one like a Breville, I'd buy the nicer one. It's a vast improvement over my old one that has just one thermostat that would burn the coffee as it warmed up past the ideal temp for expresso on it's way to "steam" temperature. Update (8/9/13): it's still trucking along after 9 months of daily use.
Only enough clearance for small espresso cups. The steam wand doesn't stay pivoted out of the way, it always pulls back towards your cup.
reviews.review_header: Only enough clearance for small espresso cups. The steam ...

reviews.review_text: Not a fan of this unit at all. Took 15 minutes to an hour (as per instructions) to bring the water to temp. The heat was then quickly dissipated as it passed through the grounds leaving tepid expresso. The unit vibrated so much that I had to hold the espresso cups in place; otherwise they would vibrate out from underneath the spouts. I seriously doubt that the unit generated 15 bars of pressure but to be fair, I had no way of measuring that. My 5 bar unit at home clearly makes a better espresso. Needless to say, I returned the unit for not being as advertised. Very disappointing.

I purchased this espresso maker in April 2013 through an Amazon.com seller. The machine worked perfectly until late June 2013. Then the coffee started dripping very, very slowly. The basket filter was not clogged. I tried pumping water only without the basket - still only a few slow drops. I checked the round metal filter screwed into the water outlet on the machine, which sits above the basket and coffee. That filter was also not clogged, but I removed it and tried to pump water anyway. Still only a few drops dripping very slowly. The plastic water bin was full as usual, and seated properly in the machine as usual. I could not return the machine to the seller because they limit returns to 4 weeks after purchase, and the machine died about 11 weeks after purchase (pump failure). I have sent an e-mail to DeLonghi with a copy of the purchase order, and requested a refund. I give this machine 1 star for the 11 weeks that it worked without any problem. I hope other purchasers have had better luck. UPDATE: July 26, 2013 I contacted DeLonghi about the pump failure. Their first offer was for a product exchange. They told me to cut the cord off at the base of the machine, and mail it with a copy of the invoice. I wrote back and said I did not want another machine with a defective pump. The second offer was for a refund, and I needed to e-mail them a copy of the purchase invoice with the claim number. I did so. They sent a reply stating that they wanted the invoice in .pdf or .jpg format. I sent a reply telling them that nowhere in the purchase information, nor in the e-mail from the previous customer service rep, did they require a .pdf or .jpg invoice for a refund. I do not have Adobe software and cannot produce either .pdf or .jpg documents, and Amazon.com does not enable customers to download copies of the invoice in these formats. I sent the same invoice in an attached Word document and asked if that would suffice for a refund. If not, I will give them the info to view my Amazon.com account to verify the refund. Stay tuned if you want to know their reply.
reviews.review_header: Pump Died after 2.5 months;DeLonghi Conditions on Refund!

reviews.review_text: There is barely room under the dispenser for an espresso cup. The pump vibrates so badly the cup will fall off the platform if you don't stand there holding it. The pump doesn't have enough power to push through a finely ground shot. You can't see if there is any water left without opening the lid. The frother gets filthy dirty with dried foam very quickly.

I purchased this machine after reviewing many comments and I thought it was a good deal but after couple of months it didn't work properly and now water is leaking. it's really a bad product and a waist of my money. I'm very disappointed.this is the worst purchased I've made.

I got this machine and the De'Longhi BAR32 Retro, one for the office and one for at home. Both were working great for one year, and then the pump lost the ability to generate sufficient pressure, so that now the coffee drips quite slowly, rather than flows from the dispenser. Lime residue (calcium carbonate) is not an issue, as we live in an area with soft water, and as I descaled the machines regularly. I also use the same ground coffee in these machines as when I bought them, so a coffee that is ground too fine is not an issue either. If you want something that lasts, don't buy these.
reviews.review_header: Good for one year and then pump pressure falls low

reviews.review_text: Product was returned after one use. It took several minutes for the water to come through the machine after turning it on. The machine started to vibrate when it was running, and the espresso was watery and did not have "crema" on it. The seal was already leaking water where the water comes through the espresso. Overall disappointing. I will repair my old Krups espresso machine and hang on to it for as long as I can.
reviews.review_header: Product was returned after one use. It took several ...

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I have been using the De'Longhi EC155 for about 3 months! It was back ordered and I had to wait 2 months to receive it after placing the Amazon order. For the price, it was worth the wait. I had a steam machine to make my Latte's previous to this one. I was actually happier with that machine and my Latte's, but as it died after 3 years(I so got my money's worth), I decided to get a pump version, but did not want to spend $$$$$$ on my next machine. I agree with all the reviews about the short froth arm, and the small espresso cups. I work at a Espresso bar and normally have 3 shots in my Latte's, so trying to drink them at home, with one small shot is a pain! I could empty, reload and make more shots, but that seems more of a pain then settling for my 8 oz. Latte. As I have to steam more milk for a latte and want the temp. at 150 degree, I do not understand why the green light keeps going off. It takes me about 4 times of turning the steam off, waiting for the green light, back on, then off. I have reread the manual, and it says this will happen. This is another pain I just deal with. I like the water reservoir, so you aren't filling with water every time. The espresso comes out very tasty! If you like Cappuccino, it does a great job of making foam. It does not cost a ton of money! So for the $79 I paid, I decided to keep it and put up with the flaws! Next purchase, I will pay more and get a more professional Espresso machine.
reviews.review_header: Still using it, but frustrated by design flaws!!!!

reviews.review_text: I was so excited to finally purchase a home espresso machine, something I have wanted for a long time. I did a lot of research and found that this machine seemed to be a good deal for a quality machine. After I got it all set up on the kitchen counter, I found that when I poured water into the unit it would flood out of the machine. I wanted to keep the machine so I tried and tried and tried to reach someone through the Delonghi customer service line. The machine comes with a year warranty, which is nice, but let me tell you it is IMPOSSIBLE reaching someone through their 1-800 number. Cumulatively, I spent 5 hours on hold. One morning I even woke up at 5 am to call right when their lines opened (at 8am eastern time, I am on PST) and was still immediately put on hold. What is the point of offering a warranty if they have some dummy number that seems like it isn't even staffed? I am incredibly frustrated and disappointed. I will never purchase from Delonghi again.
reviews.review_header: Arrived defective, spent hours trying to reach a customer service representative

reviews.review_text: I'm accustomed to an espresso machine that shuts off after the one shot measure. Also the directions for cleaning are more involved that I care to perform. The handled espresso holder is VERY difficult to turn into place...I must hold the machine down to accomplish this. (Not easy for one with arthritis.)The espresso is good. Guess I'm just spoiled. I'd rather have simplicity.

It doesn't really make true espresso. The machine makes a replica of my favorite coffee beverage, but hey, for the price... If you're looking for a dorm room or cubicle machine, this would be fine provided you use good coffee. I'm far too fussy to have stayed with this one, and I've already replaced it.
reviews.review_header: You get what you pay for

reviews.review_text: I just got mine today. I read the entire instruction manual and did as it asked. It steams milk fine enough but after a half hour of letting it heat up the water is still ice cold. It makes a lot of noise like it is doing something but nothing happens. Customer service hours are not convenient, will have to email and hope for the best. Edit: Knock on wood! As soon as I wrote my bad review it decided to start working! It made a pretty good shot of espresso. It took almost 40 minutes to heat up though, so set your alarm clock earlier, you will need the time. Also would recommend getting espresso shot glasses as the clearance from the head to the bottom of the unit is minimal. Steamed the milk well too.

I drink espresso several time a day - every day. As new this espresso is fabulous, a nice froth on top like a commercial machine would produce. This is my 2nd machine which leaks after about 1-1/2 to 2 years. The leak starts (i believe) inside the pump area where the water tubes connect. I was thinking of replacing the guts with parts available for sell through ([...]) to my first machine but decided for the cost... to replace it with the new machine. Now having paid over $200.00 for two of these espresso machines, I'm saving to put that kind of money in a different brand.

This machine is good for someone who wants to be able to make strong espresso-style coffee and steam milk and does not care about making high quality espresso. I had this machine for a year and it served its purpose well, but I was blown away by the difference when I upgraded to a more powerful machine. This machine will extract espresso better than a stovetop pot or a steam-driven machine. But the extraction will be fast and therefore more bitter than a true espresso. This is perfectly fine if you are planning on making lattes or adding sugar/flavor syrups. This machine will also steam milk, but will not allow you to get microfoam (no latte art) If you want to have room to increase your barista skills and get some really great espresso, I would recommend saving up a little more and getting the Breville Duo Temp Pro (what I upgraded to)
I'm so bummed by this machine. It worked once for espresso and not at all for frothing. I know wouldn't turn either. I returned it.

Earlier used a stove top espresso maker until I got this as a gift. Although it is easier to make espresso with this, the following are the issues: 1) The espresso strength is not consistent. 2) Set up time is long. Need to turn it on for a long time, before the machine gets ready. So, if you are making 1 or 2 shots of espresso, takes about 30 minutes to make it. 3) Milk warmer and froth not great. 4) Difficult to clean. I continue to use it because it is easier than the alternative of a stove top espresso and much cheaper than a high-end espresso and cappucino maker.
reviews.review_header: Not the right one if you are particular about your Espresso and Cappucino

reviews.review_text: We wanted an inexpensive espresso machine for my wife and I to use instead of going out to Starbucks everyday for our daily cup o' joe. When we started using this machine, it worked great...but only after 2 full months of use, it broke on us. The light turns on but when we turn the dial to start the espresso drip, nothing happens. The foam/milk heater doesn't work either. It's just broken. We are really sad. We used the machine almost every morning but didn't expect it to break so soon. And since the return time frame expired for Amazon, I am going to have to see how we can return/replace this item from the company...if that is even possible. What a hassle. Don't bother purchasing if you're looking for a product that will last.

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: I bought this for my hubby for fathers day as an upgrade to our old Krups cappuccino maker. We are not new to making espresso at home, we have done it for years, but this machine did not deliver what it touted. Every cup we made, regardless of bean, tasted and smelled like hot plastic. It was noisy and vibrated the cups off the metal plate so you had to hold the cups while the espresso dripped. A total disappointment, I was so disgusted with it I got rid of it at a garage sale for $10.00. I am glad that I did not get rid of our Krups, we continue to use it today, which still makes a great cappuccino.
reviews.review_header: UGHHH!! HOT CUP OF BURNING PLASTIC!

reviews.review_text: I am not new to the espresso machine world, we have owned three different models to date. This was my first time purchasing a less expensive model, but after reading the reviews and knowing the reputation of De'Longhi I figured it was worth the gamble. This machine at a glance is great, it is easy to fill the reservoir, it warms up quickly, when you properly press the coffee it empties with ease as a nice hard puck. Why do I hate this machine then you ask? Well it is because since the day we received it there was a strange taste that gets infused in the brewing/steaming process. At first I thought it was simply whatever they used to clean the machine with, and so I filled the reservoir with water and ran the whole thing through the machine - but it makes no difference. I have now owned this machine for 6 months (long past its return point) and it continues to add in this horrible taste.
Great espresso... lasted about a year before the pump went haywire and one of the internal hoses burst. Fun cleanup!

I had a De'longhi combination espresso and drip coffee machine, but after 12 months and a few days, the espresso heater died. One draw back was that the tank was pressurized so it took quite a while if you wanted to make a few coffees in a row - not good for dinner parties. Since we had other drip coffee makers, I replaced it with this espresso machine but it has been quite disappointing. You can only fit espresso or small cappuccino cups under the filter and it only takes a tiny amount of coffee so it is fairly weak for my tastes. I estimate the basket it takes less than half the amount of coffee in the the combo machine took. For a decent latte, it takes 3-4 double brews to get the same good taste that a single double brew on the combo gave. If all you want is a 2oz Espresso, this will probably work for you, else look elsewhere.

It worked great at first and then after a few months quit pumping under pressure. I doubt I used if 50 times. Cleaned both filters and descaled as per the instructions, with no luck. Called Delongi and was told it is not reparable. Going out in the garbage.
reviews.review_header: Quit pumping after less than 50 uses.

reviews.review_text: Lasted for about 1 year before cleaning it wouldn't bring it back to new. Tamper is useless. Get a separate one and put the correct pressure on your grounds. You'll need to use espresso cups as most other cups are a tight squeeze. The frothed is a little low so I have to put it next to the sink to get a frothing pitcher underneath. Regardless of all its shortcomings, its a great little machine to get you started.

I owned the older version of this 85.00 unit for 2 years without incident.(EC 140B) I un-boxed and got ready to use this new model,and the first thing I noticed was my 2.5 in demmitasse would no longer fit. It can only accommodate two-inch shot glasses. Whatever cup I managed to get under the filter holder, the new model would vibrate right off the platform if left unattended, which is a new design too. I boxed and shipped back. This is no loner an 85.00 bargain.
reviews.review_header: New model, not like older version

reviews.review_text: I've had this machine for 1.5 months now, and have so far only gone through one 8 oz. can of LavAzza Caffe Espresso. You might call me an occasional coffee drinker. I liked it at first -- easy to use and it made great crema. I use only distilled water. Then one by one things started failing: 1. The filter basket got twisted and stuck in the arm. (I called De'Longhi and they sent a free replacement, which is nice). 2. The arm blasted while I was pulling a shot once. I figured it was a fluke and that I hadn't put it on tightly enough. You can be sure I was especially careful on the next use. 3. It happened again! Hot hot water under pressure again forcefully ejected the arm from the machine. Yes -- the espresso was ruined, coffee grinds everywhere. Luckily I wasn't scalded. I hadn't tapered excessively... so what gives? At this point, I don't want to take another chance with this.
reviews.review_header: I liked it at first -- easy to use and it ...

reviews.review_text: It is an ok espresso machine for what you paid for. Steamer is fine but not very consistent. The pump feels like less than 15 par of pressure. I grind my coffee bean to the same medium fine and temper the same way every time but it sometimes flows quickly and other times it turns into a dripping machine. In the end i guess you get what you pay for.

This unit produced an excellent espresso either from ESE pods or from tamped grounds. It had a nice body a well formed crema as other reviewers have noted. However, after about 6 months this unit gradually lost pressure until it completely failed. I followed the cleaning procedure and regularly cleaned this machine, yet it failed in less than a year! I guess I will either upgrade or have low expecations of these units in the future. Wouldn't it be great if I could purchase a 3 year warranty for this dud?
reviews.review_header: This unit produced an excellent espresso either from ESE pods or from tamped grounds

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: As a professional chef I know that this machine isn't really a good choice up front. But it was inexpensive and I was lured by the nice aesthetic of the product. Well, not a month after I purchased this machine it began to malfunction. I went back to read previous reviews and read that there is some user manipulation that can restore the functionality of the machine. To no avail. Priming the pump, cleaning filters, running descaler did nothing. Leaking relentlessly. Steam pouring from water port. I think this product is or can become dangerous. Do not buy this product...unless of course you need an ornamental coffee machine on your kitchen counter.
reviews.review_header: Nope to dope and this POS!

reviews.review_text: Updating this review after using it for over a year... I'm finally giving up on this machine and finding a new one. At first the machine worked pretty well, but very soon the frothing wand started to leak water whenever the machine was turned on - even to just make an espresso. Now there are spurts of water coming out when I try to froth milk and the milk never actually froths. I've been told I needed to clean the machine - but this started before I'd made my first 20 lattes. Cleaning the machine resolves nothing. I liked the price and I got what I paid for... junk. I'd never recommend this machine and from what I've read online, many many people have regretted this purchase. There are all sorts of mods to improve it, but I'm thinking De'Longhi should have just created a product that works properly out of the box. I'm not rebuilding this machine to get a simple espresso or latte.
reviews.review_header: Owned for a year. Can't wait to dump this junk in the trash.

reviews.review_text: I read lots of reviews before settling on this espresso machine, so I was ready for the design "challenges," which I didn't find challenging at all. (If you use a short bowl/cup for the espresso, and position the machine near the edge of the counter so the steam wand hangs off, it's not a problem.) I was so ready to love this machine but I encountered a couple problems that were NOT in the reviews: 1) The espresso is strangely weak-tasting, despite its dark color, and made an even weaker latte, even though I greatly reduced the milk proportion. I like a strong, almost "burned" flavored espressos/lattes and the lattes from this machine taste like a watery Starbucks. I tried several grinds and roasts but nothing really helped. I also tried making doubles (and triples) but the espresso flavor could not stand up to the milk. 2) The instructions suggest "warming up" the machine for 30 minutes before making your first cup! So, if you're like me and have limited time in the morning to enjoy your black gold, plan on setting your alarm 30 min early. The instructions also said that to speed up the warming process, you could run the machine several times with no coffee.... I don't know if that made a difference or not. I tried everything and kept waiting to taste strong espresso, but it never happened :( For these reasons, I must give a thumbs-down to the DeLonghi EC155, though it feels like I'm somehow betraying my Italian ancestry! Perhaps a "steam" style machine will suit my tastes better. UPDATE: I sort of figured out why my lattes were weak with this machine: it's because the milk frother "sputters" water before getting to pure steam. So I was watering down the coffee. The sputtering didn't stop and it was too labor-intensive to let it do that for a couple minutes into a cup or towel before it got around to steaming. Returned!!
Broken in 13 months of sporadic use , dispute good care and water softeners. Steam works , but no pressure no make espresso. Very disappointed
reviews.review_header: dispute good care and water softeners

reviews.review_text: I purchased this as the replacement for another De'Longhi espresso machine that began to leak after one month of use. This was a more expensive model, so I had hoped it would be better quality. When I opened it, a piece of plastic was broken off of the top of the back water reservoir. I looked past it because I was excited to have an espresso machine again. It leaked all over the counter the very first time I used it. I tried again, making sure to follow the directions and tighten up the handle. Still leaked everywhere. I am so disappointed to have received two defective items from the same company, however, Amazon was lovely about it and allowed me to send both back and they issued full refunds (I did have to call and debate the restocking fee they charged for one, but they reversed that as well.) I won't be buying another pressure machine -- Bialetti, here I come!

Espresso taste good, but it is very noisy, and vibrates a lot where I have to hold the glasses or they will fall off the tray. The small steamer stick is not that great for frothing. But you get what you pay for, and it was my first Espresso machine. Lets just say, it is not what I expected.
reviews.review_header: Vibrates, Noisy, but makes descent espresso.

reviews.review_text: I think I'm being too critical and I may change my rating to more stars in the future, however this is an average espresso machine in my opinion. It replaces my old Cusinart espresso machine that was sooo much easier to use. And the coffee was just as good. With this one, just reading the manual is a 4 credit course! Aside from the complexity, I also can't fully tighten the handle. It will only close about 3/4 of the way, so there's not enough space for 2 cups.

I did a lot of research before settling on this one and I'm disappointed. The coffee comes out great (enough for me), but the space under the filter is so small that I can barely fit my smallest cup under there. It also vibrates so much that I have to hold the cups in place lest they dance away.

It's an old model, and for example, it makes you waste too much time for cleaning the milk foamer after you make cappuccino... it makes a good and warm coffee but the foam for cappuccino is not that good. There's not even enough space for a big cup for cappuccino. It's quite noisy and it vibrates so much that you HAVE to hold the coffee cups.
reviews.review_header: it makes you waste too much time for cleaning the milk foamer after ...

reviews.review_text: I recommend against buying. Mine worked fine for about a year, then it started leaking boiling water all over the counter rather than going to the cup. The design is not serviceable so basically it is a disposable machine. The company was very nice to deal with by telephone, but after the one year warranty is up, I was left with junk for the landfill.
reviews.review_header: Disposable Only, Use for a Year and Throw Away

name: De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker

reviews.review_text: How disappointing it was to receive this highly rated and researched machine only to find that the plug, spring, and other vital parts for the water reservoir were missing! There wasn't even a parts list so we didn't know what we were missing until we went online to look it up. Rather than try another we chose to return this for a refund. I have no faith that another would be shipped to us with all necessary pieces or, that it would stand up to daily use seeing what kind of sloppy work they seem to do.

Just about a year and a half old and it has basically stopped working. It started by not pushing the water through the espresso, which I thought was because the grounds were to fine. Nope. I descaled it to see if that was the issue. Nope. Now, the steam wand won't produce steam. I suggest spending a bit more money for a better machine. This on I thought had good ratings, but it sucks!

It's OK. I guess for the price the negatives are minor. You have to wait a little longer after the light says it's ready if you want really hot milk or coffee. Does NOT include a pitcher for the coffee, and if you intend to use it for anything but espresso shots it is a paid because of the lack of clearance between the spout and whatever cup you will use, say if you want to make a double shot cappucino. But did I say it is an inexpensive machine?
reviews.review_header: Get what you pay for...and little else.

reviews.review_text: Three major design flaws kind of ruin this machine for me. 1) As others have mentioned, the frothing wand is miserable. Worse for me since I don't want the foam so much as heating milk without the microwave; 2) There is no shot size preset, so you cant just select single-, double-, short-, or long-shots, you have to stand there and turn it off when you have your desired size; 3) The brew head is kind of goofy with the rubber seal inside and the way you have to fill the whole filter basket instead of there being a little extra space. I can only compare this to either cheap-o machines or commercial machines. It is way, way better than the krupps and mr coffee cheap-o "espresso" makers that don't make enough pressure for true espresso. but the design is also far off from the commercial versions. I give it two stars because with freshly ground beans and a close eye, it does make great espresso.
reviews.review_header: not the best, not the worst

reviews.review_text: The machine vibrates while Brewing espresso so much to the point where you have to hold the cup in place so espresso won’t pour everywhere. Also, we have tried many different types of coffee and none are quite as dark as a typical espresso should be.
reviews.review_header: Not good for an espresso drinker. More like small cup of dark roast coffee.

reviews.review_text: Only worked for 5 months. I cleaned and descaled per the instructions. I owned high end makers' espresso machines, and this not as good taste as them but understandable because of the price. Still this only 5 months life is not acceptable! I wont buy Italian espresso machine anymore.

The coffee maker doesn't seem to have any pressure and the coffee just slowly drips out and it takes 10 minutes to get the expresso for a latte. We contacted De"Longhi and we have to cut off the cord and send it to them and they will send a replacement. While we wait, we have no coffee. Hopefully the wait won't be too long but based on what we found by way of google, we are not getting our hopes up. Will probably have to go out and buy another machine and it will not be this brand! This is the second of these machines that we have purchased. The first machine we had worked great for a short period of time. Then whatever forces the steam through the grounds stopped working efficiently and we had to wait for the expresso to drip, drip, drip into the cup (the machine has a very low clearance so only an expresso cup will fit underneath the nozzle). It also lost that thick expresso characteristic. The coffee grounds cup is small so you can only make one expresso shot at a time. So to make a double shot latte you have to fill the coffee grounds cup twice and wait while it drip, drip, drips. In the end, this machine is just a fancy, very slow way of making drip coffee.
reviews.review_header: no pressure to force steam through grounds.

reviews.review_text: Excellent for about the first year. I would give it 5 Stars initially, however in year 2 the performance went way down even after cleaning it. Since it was about 2.5 years old, it has been almost unusable. I spent a little over $100 for it in 2013. It is still cheaper than buying espresso, but I would have expected it to last longer.
reviews.review_header: Doesn’t last much more than 2 years with regular use.

reviews.review_text: Horrible. Didn't open till after return date is my fault. However this unit vibrates so bad that nothing stays on the tray. Steam arm is worthless as it only goes back and forth I could go on and on but, I already feel like an idiot for ordering it and missing the deadline to return it.
reviews.review_header: Horrible. Didn't open till after return date is my ...

reviews.review_text: Not impressed. Steam wand hardly works, doesn't heat milk well at all. Waste of money
